comment: I ordered 8 of these computers and they all have had the keyboard/mouse removed and a random 3rd party's mousepad placed inside. The computers all have a custom Windows 11 Pro image on them. None of the Dell tools are there. This made me uncomfortable so I booted to a Windows USB, deleted all the current partitions, and installed my own copy of Windows Pro. Thankfully, the OS activated just fine on it's own, from the hardware, and the computers are legit looking aside from a Polycom support sticker that says call for service. The mousepad says pconline365.com. So definitely some strangeness here, but after the fresh Windows install everything is probably OK. Also, Dell OEM sticker removed from the cardboard packaging when we got them.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Optiplex 9020 å°å‹æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦,æ­è¼‰ Intel Core i7-4770 é«˜é” 3.9GHz,HD Graphics 4600 4K æ”¯æ´,32GB RAM,1TB SSD,DisplayPort,HDMI,Wi-Fi,è—ç‰™ - Windows 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
I bought this Amazon Renewed PC in 2023 with Windows 10 Pro, 32G of RAM and a 1T SSD for $187.99 with free shipping.
I found a 2015 PCMag review of a Dell Optiplex 9020 with a MSRP of $989.00 8G or RAM and a 128G SSD drive.
The Dell Optiplex 9020 was originally sold with Windows 8.1 Pro installed but included the option to downgrade to Windows 7 Pro.
The BIOS has a 2019 date but I believe this was replaced along with the OS, RAM and SSD drive.
The Intel Core i7-4770 CPU was first released in 2014. It's a 4th. gen Intel chip and in 2023 we are up to the 13th gen. The Intel Core i7-4770 CPU is not on the list of acceptable CPUs for Windows 11 so the OS cannot be upgraded to Windows 11 and will loose Microsoft support in October of 2025 in only a couple of years.
I believe this PC was originally sold 5 to 9 years ago before substantial upgrades that were part of making it an Amazon Renewed PC in 2023.

I shrunk the Windows 10 partition and made the PC a Dual Boot Machine that will primarily run the latest version of Linux Mint which I believe will support this older CPU for years.

It came with a VGA port two DisplayPort connectors and a DiplayPort to HDMI adapter and can drive three displays at once.

I did not use the keyboard and mouse that came with the computer as I was replacing a computer connected to a KVM (Keyboard, Video, Mouse) switch.

I have found no defect so far and the case looked new when I opened the box. Although I know the case and CPU are old and windows tells me it can't be upgraded to Windows 11 I am really happy with this purchase.

Couple it with a Norcent 24 Inch Computer Frameless Monitor, 75Hz Full HD 1920 x 1080P IPS LED Display, HDMI VGA Port, and it is a very good package.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Optiplex 9020 å°å‹æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦,æ­è¼‰ Intel Core i7-4770 é«˜é” 3.9GHz,HD Graphics 4600 4K æ”¯æ´,32GB RAM,1TB SSD,DisplayPort,HDMI,Wi-Fi,è—ç‰™ - Windows 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
The computer is refurbished with 1TB SSD and 32GB RAM. It came with USB keyboard, USB mouse, USB WiFi adapter and port display to HDMI adapter. It seems to run great even if it's very old. Dell website shows it was shipped in 2016 and probably manufactured earlier because it also says the originally installed OS was Windows 7. I hope it may work for a couple years more.
The setting wasn't easy as windows was locked and asking for Walmart email or security key. I have a laptop running on dual OS (Linux and Windows 11). I erased Windows with the Walmart credentials nonsense from the refurbished Dell drive by installing Linux using a bootable USB. Downloaded Windows 10 Pro and created a bootable USB using my laptop's Windows 11 (it's hard to create Windows 10 or 11 bootable USB using Linux. I get files larger than 4GB error).
I reinstalled Windows 10 Pro using the bootable USB and removed Linux. Trying to install Windows from USB while the desktop still has the Walmart locked Windows wasn't working. That's why I used linux to override that mess and go back to remove Linux. An option suggested on Dell website to do a clean reinstall or recovery (Support Assist OS Recovery) doesn't show up in the BIOS. The refurbished computer is now working fine but I think USTechno should have made sure Windows setting is straightforward.

comment: This is the 3rd unit the first one was delivered to wrong address by Fed exğŸ˜¡. The second one developed a bad power button issue would not turn on no matter how many hopeful pushes of the button. The 3rd one so far has performed flawlessly so far. For some reason on the 2nd one I had to change tv input before turning it on or there would be no video displayed. This third one is normal you can power it up then change the tv input and video is there. I am using the video output to HDMI cable I purchased from Amazon works great. comment:
Right out of the box I couldn't find any defects. The computer looks brand new inside and out. No chips, no scratches and no dust or smugs inside or out. Setting it up was quick and easy. I ordered a DisplayPort to DVI adapter at the same time and the video feed to my old Acer DVI monitor is awesome. The HD audio output by-amped to my full sized Altec Lansing speakers is excellent also. I've spent a few days checking it out and everything functions correctly, and the system is very quick.
I bought this because my old computer finally up and died on me and like a bad boy it wasn't backed up. I pulled the hard drive from my old computer and set it up so I could access it through a USB port and I commenced chasing down pictures and saved files. Needless to say I spent a lot of time digging. I was able to find most of the stuff I really wanted. Through it all the little Dell just whizzed a long with no complaints. For the price it is simply awesome, and you just can't beat it. As far as I'm concerned, it's a real mega steal.
Bye the way, this computer has feet on both the long side and the end so you can use it either way. I find the DVD drive much easier to access with it on its side.

comment: This little guy was impressive. They definitely put a few extra features in there to make sure that as a refab, it is definitely quality. Runs fast. Small case models have airflow issues - you have to know that. They also have power supply issues: if the power you're plugging into is not solid, has too low amperage, etc. - it won't turn on, at all. So, in an older building, this pc won't light up. In an office building - no problem. And, it is a little powerhouse. I haven't "taxed" it, but I didn't buy it to be taxed and was pleased with all the add-ons for the cost. Have already recommended it to multiple clients.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Optiplex 9020 å°å‹æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦,æ­è¼‰ Intel Core i7-4770 é«˜é” 3.9GHz,HD Graphics 4600 4K æ”¯æ´,32GB RAM,1TB SSD,DisplayPort,HDMI,Wi-Fi,è—ç‰™ - Windows 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
I received an email a day before the delivery date from the company explaining how to download wifi drivers if there was a problem at boot up. It had a link that took me to the drivers. I ended up not needing to use them, but it was a nice gesture.

The computer comes with:
- Wifi USB dongle
- Bluetooth USB dongle
- AC power cord
- Display Port to HDMI adaptor (computer only has Display Port slots)
- Corded Mouse (low quality but useable)
- Corded Keyboard (low quality, but better than the mouse)
- Paperwork that explains that Windows 10 is a OEM volume install so it comes pre-activated.

The outer housing of the computer was in almost new condition. The only flaws noticeable were a couple small scratches on the silver Dell logo area.
It started right up and booted into Windows without a problem. It took me moving the Wifi dongle to another USB port to get a connection, but that was the only problem I ran into. Since then, the computer and connection are stable and strong.
The graphics are good for business and video/internet duty. You can play older games, but the GPU isn't made for gaming so don't buy this computer for a kid who wants to game unless they like vintage gaming.
I like the computer and knew the limitations before I purchased it. It's a big step up from my old laptop and the only real downside (which I knew before buying it) was that it's not Windows 11 upgradable.

comment:
This is a nice desktop a a reasonable price. When I first conneced everything and powered up the system, I could not get WIFI access. I contacted the seller and they responded that WIFI access was via a USB plug in that was in the keyboard box. I hadn't opened the keyboard box because I was using my own wireless keyboard and mouse. I plugged in the USB dongle and I now have WIFI on my 4G home network, but not on my 5G which I would have preferred.
Also, I found the wired mouse and keyboard inconvenient because I have the desktop located just far enough away that I need a wireless mouse and keyboard. Overall, this is a good buy, and the seller was very responsive when I had questions.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Optiplex 9020 å°å‹æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦,æ­è¼‰ Intel Core i7-4770 é«˜é” 3.9GHz,HD Graphics 4600 4K æ”¯æ´,32GB RAM,1TB SSD,DisplayPort,HDMI,Wi-Fi,è—ç‰™ - Windows 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
Dell should have been MUCH MORE UPFRONT about what this machines does NOT have:

TPM - the description said this so no big deal

Incompatible network controller - the drivers have been retired by dell. The machine did not pick up my late model comcast wifi router. Simply did not show up in a list of available routers. You will need an external high gain USB A or C antenna. Not expensive but a fundamental feature of modern computers does not work.

NO HDMI port - with copyright protection 4K will not work for streaming and you will be relegated to SD for TV or movies - I'm shocked there is no HDMI port. Just DisplayPort which is not digital from my understanding. AND THERE IS NO DP TO DP. I had to go out and buy one.

Not a deal breaker because of the hardware installed but dell and amazon could have been more upfront about its limitations. Buyer beware.

comment: when I first turned on the computer it was like I bought a brand new one, setting up windows, putting your Microsoft account, ect, but then when I installed my anti-virus software in it automatically detected a trojan virus that was in the system files. And right away i started to lose data from certain programs. So, Luckly I'm sort of a geek when it comes to computers and right away i started to run chkdsk & other commands that lets me know what's wrong with my OS, and then "BSOD" for those who knows what that means, it means corrupted system files or faulty hardware. Anyways i had to get a new ssd for it and get the original OS it came with when it was first sold, and i was surprised at all the upgrades that was done to it. Anyways to make a long story short it now is running with windows 10 and a brand-new Samsung ssd which is a faster ssd then it came with. So now I'm a happy camper because this is one of the fastest computers i have ever owned or even seen..

comment:
So this is the first time I bought a " refurbished" computer and I was somewhat suspicious . I think im a good shopper so I wanted to know what one of these cost brand new, so I googled it,,Imaging my surprise when 3 pages of this computer come up,, all refurbished ..and what's more, I cant find one new..
Now I'm wondering how many are there.. And what's the story,, did the guy in Indonesia fall asleep on the production line,, a chip or processer got put in wrong,, did dell have to recall hundreds of these and stop making them..
But aside form all that I opened the box and it was brand new, not a scratch on it. Ive had it running for 3 weeks now and not a problem, rocket fast
one note , it does not have a HDMI port,, it has 2 " Media Ports" but they give you an adapter, the resolution is better than what i get off my cable box .
So worth the money

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Optiplex 9020 å°å‹æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦,æ­è¼‰ Intel Core i7-4770 é«˜é” 3.9GHz,HD Graphics 4600 4K æ”¯æ´,32GB RAM,1TB SSD,DisplayPort,HDMI,Wi-Fi,è—ç‰™ - Windows 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
Very pleased with the purchase. The computer looks new inside and out.
The pros are dual monitor support (critical for my use), it's fast, it has plenty of ram and the 1tb SSD rocks. The cons are no bluetooth dongle included (no biggie), not upgradable to win11 (win10 EOL is 2025), and the WIFI dongle.. while it works, isn't the best.

I spent another 25$ on a decent WIFI card and bluetooth dongle and everything works like it should and WIFI signal is great. I already had a nice wireless mouse and keyboard. The included units are very basic and wired.

Oh and not that it matters anymore but the DVD is read only, no burner.

Oh, and for what ever original reason they had, mine had both serial and parallel cards added.

I chunked one of them to make room for the WIFI card.

I would definitely recommend to anyone wanting an inexpensive work station.

Edit to add, this is the wifi card I used (sourced from Amazon)

TP-Link AC1200 PCIe WiFi Card(Archer T4E)- 2.4G/5G Dual Band Wireless PCI Express Adapter

OEM driver from TP-Link was much faster in my application than the default win10 driver. Other than that, no brainer install and configuration

comment:
I had a house power disruption that shut down the computer. I attempted to reboot and the processor didn't find the HD and would not reboot. I directed the system to run diagnostics via the blue screen option. After 15 minutes of system evaluation the HD was discovered and the system allowed reboot. I am concerned that this may be a symptom of potential HD problems. I have not yet seen this happen again, yet.
I am happy with the computer otherwise.

comment: Computer gave message that the computer had no hard drive upon the first boot. I ran through the boot sequence diagnostic and every thing was ok with the exception of no hard drive. I contacted tech support and they responded that I should watch a you tube video on how to partition a hard drive. This would have been ok, however the computer did not recognize a hard drive being in the computer. Finally I took out the CD Rom Drive and there was actually a hard drive installed under the CD Rom Drive. The Power Cable had came unplugged during shipping. I reinstalled the cable, reinstalled the CD Rom Drive, and the computer booted as it should. No you tube hard drive partition required as Tech support suggested.

comment:
I ordered this refurbished computer November 28th and it was delivered December 12th. This is a holiday present. Today, December 27th, I began the set up. There was no real documentation in hand, just follow the instructions as they appeared on screen. I attempted to install a software program using a CD. However, the CD/DVD/R drive does not work. It would come on momentarily then shut down. I had to use a bent paper clip to open the drive to retrieve my installation disc. I called the company's tech hotline for help in the morning, and they called back in the afternoon the same day. They said the drive is defective and gave me a choice of either sending me a replacement drive that I would install, or they would exchange the computer for a different one. The fastest way is to have them send me a replacement drive, but this still will take approximately two weeks because, as I was informed, it is the holidays. Could be also that the company is located in Ontario, and I am in the US. He said he had no way to expedite. So back to the old computer for now. This is my first refurbished product from Amazon, and I am not impressed or satisfied at this point. I'll try the replacement drive because it is the quickest but still a two week wait. It could be that I may ultimately sent back for a refund. One other point, both the mouse and the keyboard have short cords so these will need to be replaced as they will not reach the back of the computer when placed on the desk. Will update review later.

Update 12/30/22: I decided to return the unit for a refund. This was described as fully functional and in excellent condition, but the DVD/R drive did not work. I should not be expected to install the replacement. It could be that the computer's bios did not recognize the drive. Who knows? Also, as mentioned earlier, the keyboard and mouse cords were too short and did not reach the back of the computer on my desk. Now I have to replace them? I lost confidence in the product; if the drive did not work out of the box, then what else will fail? Amazon was true to their word and is processing the return that I sent back via their UPS return label. I did have to pack it up though (I saved the original shipping carton that it came in).

Machine runs ok. Upgraded integrated video card. It ran fine with the integrated video I just was looking for that little extra speed . Editing video much faster than my I5 with 8 gb of ram. This machine is actually older than the one I was using. Probably wouldnâ€™t have bought it if I knew how old it was . I just assumed it being a I7 with 32 gb of ram it was
newer . USB Wi-Fi fell apart very flimsy. It only has TPM 1.2 canâ€™t turn on Memory integrity . I think it has to do with upgrading the video. It says thereâ€™s a incompatible driver igdkmd64.sys . I donâ€™t think itâ€™s specific to this machine. I was able to get windows 11 to run but switched back to windows 10 . Overall Iâ€™m happy with the performance just hope it lasts.

comment:
Later Update 1-22-2023:
The computer has been perfect until 1-21-2023, since Feb 2022. I think the mother board has failed. I didn't purchase SERVICE PLAN. I have sent a request for a mother board per my own Troubleshooting. We will see how that goes. So far so good, EXCEPT the failure. Price was VERY GOOD for all this machine does. I need it for work. Hoping a mother board or replacement chassis can be sourced quickly for a reasonable price.

I purchased this system to try and get reasonable response times to my few demanding requests. No games.
But, I did get a Samsung dual port 4K curved monitor. I run an Fire-stick in the HDMI port using a DP to HDMI cable and this computer in the Display Port using a DP to DP cable. Both 4K. All of it works good. on the computer using streaming apps, I can watch 4 or 4 streams at once. Using the spoit screen, I can see a movie, show, or youtube. If i choose the split screen, i can watch all simultaneously. Kinda weird but it works. I just have to select which to LISTEN to!!
â€˜I can have open unlimited tabs on 3 or 4 browsers with no impact except getting lost in a cloud of tabs and browsers.
This machine does everything I wanted and more as the DVD works fine and it wanâ€™t even referenced in the add.
I can close out or sign off all of them in less than 20 seconds. I can sign off and restart including sign on to user again all within 1 min and 4 seconds.
Actually a bit unbelievable to tell you the truth.

I only wish I could have had the OPTION to add a multiple port low profile PCIe USB 3 and C card within the order.
Zero complaints.
Kirk Klitzke

I received my new Dell Optiplex 9020 today 4/5/2023. It arrived in a nice box, well wrapped. It came with a standard keyboard and mouse, also a wifi dongle and a HDMI to display port adapter.

I went through the initial Microsoft setup which was fairly easy.

The Wifi dongle seems to be working really well, no dropping in connection so far.
The HDMI to display port adapter seems to be working fine too.

The PC is SUPER quiet and it boots very fast, I am very happy with the purchase.

I already setup my network share with my other computers and everything is awesome.

If I have to say anything negative, it would be with the delivery, it took about two weeks to receive it. There was some kind of delay with the shipment. Otherwise, very happy and would recommend.

comment:
I downgraded this review. See below.

I didn't read the specs carefully enough. This does not have an Ethernet jack to plug into the internet. I was able to order an adapter to plug the Ethernet cable into a USB port. I could have ordered the dock, but that would have added an extra $250 and at that price I should have just bought the upgraded version.

The cheaper models of Dell have a known issue where the hinge on the monitor breaks. The screws come loose and if you are not watching, it will damage the plastic around the monitor. I leave my computer on a desk. When I do travel with it, I carry it in a padded laptop case. After 5 months of gentle use, this should not be a problem. I'm shipping it off to Dell for a repair. Technically I'm still under Basic warranty but we know they will still charge me for it. There is a long list of these complaints on the Dell support site about this and the company is not doing anything about it.

comment:
I was excited to get this new laptop. Not that I wanted one, but Microsoft makes one buy one with Windows 11: I began having issues with my Windows 10 laptop since Windows 11 was announced. 1st, thanks to a local delivery company, delivery was very late on this laptop. Very late and when calling them, they had no idea what was going on. When we contacted Off--- --x, they had no idea what was going on either and didnâ€™t even care. In fact, if we didnâ€™t phone the delivery company, it would never have been delivered. O----- --x was no help in tracking or getting this laptop to us. Shame on O---- --x. A helpful supervisor did take the time to give us a credit but couldnâ€™t do anything else.
I do love the speed of the laptop. It is quite fast. The speakers are lousy. Even on highest level, it is low and tinny. Horrible for a laptop like this. I have two older laptops that have better speakers. However, the biggest con with this laptop is its lack of durability and reliability. Within just 3-1/2 months of use, the touchpad and mouse failed. Can't use it. Through remote testing Dell made the diagnosis that it failed and informed me that they would send me a replacement per the warranty. I am to send the broken one back or have to pay for it. After waiting a week, I checked on Dell.com to find out the status. No status showed and all I could find was, "Resolution Pending". What does that mean? I have no idea. Just how long am I supposed to wait to get a replacement part? I canâ€™t use the laptop without it. I donâ€™t like the touchscreen. I would think under warranty the replacement part would have been shipped out directly. No need to say how very disappointed I am in this purchase. The price at the time I purchased in in late February 2022 seemed reasonable. After this, all I can say that it was and is now still overpriced. Save your money and purchase another brand. And I miss having a CD/DVD recorder/player. As with everything else, size shrinks and prices go up. Overall, this purchase was a big nightmare: from the lousy shipping company; Do----- shipping of Jackson, MS to the failed touchpad/mouse, and lack of efficient warranty service and response. I'm not pleased at all. Sorry, but I canâ€™t recommend this pc at all. I guess I should have listed to the rest of the negative reviews at Off----ax.

comment:
tldr, expect to make some small changes, but a solid investment
I had to return the initial computer. The screen was broken and it came badly packaged (loose in bubble wrap). The return was easy. Second PC came in a smaller box with specialized and well made packaging. It ran well out of the box, but there are two almost necessary upgrades you'll need to make this usable for use.
1. SSD. this comes with an HHD but adding an SSD was easy. I'd never even seen the inside of a computer before and did it in 5 mins. you'll need an SSD, SATA data cable, and SATA power splitter. This cost me $30 on Amazon and made many games playable and the computer much faster.
2. better wifi USB. a $10 on Amazon boosted my speed x10+ up to ~200mbps (which is good considering how far my office is from the router)

Speakers are tinny and bad, but everything else operates well.

comment:
Package arrived quick but screen was damaged upon arrival, contacted assurion to advise but no response or It could be me not answering suspicious numbers, but no message concerning my issue was left.

Besides the big beautiful cracked screen I received the Hard drive which surprisingly came with a DVD slot, where a lot of people in the review advise they didn't have.

Setup was easy, the speakers lights up but unable to produce sound and I wasn't able to get keyboard to light up, the keyboard is cheap and undesirable but I have no problem buying a upgrade.

At this time computer is being utilized with the Crack screen it's an eyesore but I'm still capable of getting projects done and playing games.

This is an excellent purchase for the price I would definitely recommend, just pray you have a good delivery.

comment:
The goodish: At first I really liked this computer, I got it for some at home work and gaming (Minecraft & Valorant). It was great for work. Minecraft lagged badly in Java but once I switched to the windows/bedrock version it played smoother. Valorant seemed to play good but I donâ€™t have great internet so itâ€™s hard to tell & the PC would occasionally crash mid game leading to afk offenses. One thing to note is that the monitor it came with was a wall monitor, I knew there was variations to what monitor you could get but there was no info about it possibly being a wall monitor. It was actually kind of nice for me but if you live in a place that canâ€™t have a wall monitor keep in mind itâ€™s possible for it to come with one that only works on the wall.
The very bad:
As mentioned before it would occasionally crash completely powering down but it would always boot back up and work fine after. About 6 months after I got it the pc crashed mid use, I went to turn it back on and it popped up with a screen saying the PC needed to be recovered with a special disk. I looked up the error code and saw that sometimes that is caused by a usb or power cord not being properly connected and to unplug all cords and check their connection. I did this and In doing this found that the power cord (sent with the computer originally) had melted. For background I only use the computer 4-6 hours at max in a day and had only had the computer on for about an hour when this happened so if I was using this full time for work instead of just occasional projects I donâ€™t know how this pc would have held up. I reached out to the pc seller and after about a week of trying to get in contact (calling and them never picking up or calling me back, them insisting on calling me and then not) they told me to simply pick up a new standard 3 prong power cord. I was obviously worried that there was a bigger issue that would lead to the pc melting a cord but did what they said. They didnâ€™t tell me any other details like what voltage requirements it needed so I looked around and got one that matched the voltage that most on the market are, that didnâ€™t work. I looked at the original cord and it had a different requirement and after scouring the web found one that matched it and tried it however that didnâ€™t work either with the computer only having a flashing orange power light/nothing on screen/and the fan running loud. I then reached out to the seller again and told them this and they said to take it to a local computer repair person because my warranty had ended. Luckily I had gotten the extra asurion protection plan. I called their tech support and they told me that this usually means that the power supply unit has failed and I would need to file a claim to get a refund. Iâ€™m glad I got the protection plan but this means packing up a pc, monitor, keyboard, and mouse and shipping it to asurion in order to get an Amazon gift card refund.
Bottom line Iâ€™m in shock that in only 6 months of owning this pc the power supply unit failed and on top of that the customer support was incredibly lacking once I did experience issues.

comment: You get what you pay for! Everyone has different thoughts on reviews until you buy it. I never do reviews but I have to. I bought three of these computers for my kids for Christmas. I got them early December so I was able to see what they were about. Clearly they are refurbished and if not then they are not taken care of in their wear-house. The first one I opened the PC tower was dented and rusted and looked like garbage. It was kinda depressing. The best part is their customer service they do replace the item really quick but while you are doing your return on the phone they will ask you to do a 5 star review so they can look good. I give their customer service 5 stars they are great but I will not do a review before I get my items next time. That was the first computer return. A week before Christmas I set them up for a surprise for the kids. As I turned them on one of the monitor was messed up and had lines running through the monitor. I had to submit a photo of the monitor to prove the monitor was messed up. The bad part was, one of my kids had to wait til the new monitor came to use it. I now just received the new monitor tonight, 12/26/2022. I connected the monitor and guess what there are the lines again running through the screen. Second screen same issues. Like I said I give it a 2 star rating because it was a great price, bad product, great customer service, bad gift for Christmas surprise because you donâ€™t know if it will work for the kids. Butâ€¦â€¦ I do have to say, the kids do love them, great for a first computer and for the issue with my one sonâ€™s monitor, Iâ€™m not even going to waste my time with it anymore. Itâ€™s more frustrating then anything. He is using my Samsung monitor for now and itâ€™s working wonderful for him. So for anyone who buys it leave a review and I want to see if Iâ€™m the only one with issues.

comment:
For the price and everything thing i got this was great. I only had the computer for a month EXACTLY before it started running slow and stuff so thankfully I'm computer savvy more than the average person and i ran a diagnostic test on mine and i needed an updated graphics card and guess what. A NEW HARD DRIVE!!! This was a super easy task but this was irritating. As soon as you get this computer make a recovery USB asap. You will need likely need it. (You should make one anyways). My hard drive went to trash within the month and a quick replace (got one from Amazon) and I uploaded my recovery USB and i fixed it myself. No problems since, I run heavy programs from time to time like Steam, adobe, i have multiple windows open etc. Once i fixed the hard drive I was good but I'll probably update it some more with new fans and such. If you want a skeleton to build on this is a cool computer. If you need a working computer this is fine for simple stuff too(until it gives you issues).

Tech support was a little irritating because all the tests I ran they asked me to do again and they woulda sent me a new hard drive but they're 50 bucks and i upgraded my space to 2Tb soooooooo yeah.

Overall it's okay. Knocked off two stars because my hard drive and my graphics card needed to be replaced within the month.
The computer itself is 8 years old, as long as the motherboard works you can fix it and upgrade as much as you like.

comment: I needed to replace my aging 10-yr. Old computer & bought a much better rebuilt computer from Amazon which included keyboard, screen, mouse & speakers. The cost was only about $200 & included shipping & 90-day guarantee. New, this unit would likely cost $1,000 or more. Anyhow, when setting up the new computer, I ran into a fan problem. I immediately called customer service & after some discussion & sending of photos, they confirmed the fan had likely failed. I had already spent hours on transferring my old computer programs, files & contents to the new computer, so I didnâ€™t want to send the whole thing back. So, customer service technicians suggested I consider installing new fan myself if I felt comfortable. They said it was fairly easy & sent video to help me out. They also reiterated that if I couldnâ€™t handle putting in the new fan, I could still exercise 90-day guarantee. Well, since Iâ€™m not too handy, I damaged the fan trying to put it in. No problem says customer service. Weâ€™ll ship you what you need to replace it. And they did & I did. Very proud of myself, but couldnâ€™t have done it without customer service support & follow-through. Thanks, guys. Maybe my next job should be computer technician!

comment: computer works great. I do woodworking projects and it is slow on the load up but once it is working it keeps up with no lag time. Had to issues with the connection of the speakers and the number on the screen in both upper right hand and left hand. They helped with the speakers and I got them connected right away. The number on the screen was not so helpful. Was not a big deal at first until they wanted to call me 2 minutes before they closed. They emailed me and told me they tried several times to call. I do have caller Id and a voice mail that they chose not to use. They just hung up. I found there was a thin plastic sheet on the screen with the numbers. Would have been nice if they would have asked me to check that since they shipped it that way to me. All in all though it works great and I am satisfied with it.

comment: I am enjoying my new computer. Sure it may be a refurbished one, but, to me, it's new...and I love it! It's so easy to use. Whether I want to play a game on it, or send emails, or whatever. Being this is a 3rd generation intel cpu, it works how it should and just fine. Being it is a business type of computer, it probably has logged many hours but it seems to be built more robust for business use.

It's a good computer and the seller ships it fast and packed good in the box. I am happy with this purchase.

comment:
Well let me first say, FedEx can kiss my A$$.. I waited ALL day for them to deliver and then they never came, said they attempted to deliver with no luck.. I have cameras, they never came by!!!

Anyway, rant over... The only complaints I have about the product I received thus far is;
The case is a little beat up..
Also the ports do not match the picture.. It's suppose to have 2 display ports, it only has one.

Lastly, the peripherals are a joke.. The display is very under par, the mouse and keyboard are wired (I can't stand) and the speakers are a complete joke..

If you need a computer and are like me and can't believe the prices of "New" this is a computer for you. It will do everything you need and more.. Just get a better monitor and wireless peripherals..

The desktop tower itself seems fine and is working rather quickly. Just wish I'd have bought only the tower instead of this whole kit where most of it is basically useless for us. comment:
5 stars because it met my expectations and hopes. The monitor is actually really nice and wide and probably would cost at least $100 on its own.
Keyboard and mouse are ridiculously cheap pieces of plastic that don't function very well and would recommend replacing them with 8-10$ ones from Walmart (or amazon probably.)
As far as using this for gaming, it caps out at 60 frames per second so as long as you don't mind that, I am able to play League of Legends with 40-60 frames. Didn't expect much more from such a cheap computer, but it does the job. It also came with little USB speakers that are kinda cool, but again, you can find much better ones for a decent price on amazon if that is important to you. A month later and the computer is still running with no issues, other than the fact that if I touch any metal part of it I get shocked - literally. Just don't touch with both hands at the same time... Lol.

comment:
Unfortunately, I was wrong about the excellent customer service review I left for this company. I filed a return claim within the allotted time frame on Thursday, January 05, 2023 and they refused to honor their own policy. When I was able to reach them via phone on Monday (they are closed on the weekend) had a family funeral on Friday, January 06, 2023, I was told I missed my return window by two days. The fact that I started a return online prior to the two day expiration did not matter to this company. The reason for calling was to acquire a free return label that they indicated on their return form. They indicated the importance of customer honesty, meaning I should not click on defective item etc. to get a free return label if the item was in fact not defective and I was just returning it. The charge for the return postage was over $23. The amount of the purchase price I paid I have rounded to $248. The company refunded me $107 (rounded). Therefore charging me $141 dollars (rounded). They referred me to Amazon to take care of this matter and I am still waiting for a refund to this day, Wednesday, February 08, 2023. Please beware and keep this in mind if you plan on purchasing a product from this company and need to return it within the alloted 90 days!!

I purchased this computer as a basic desktop. It is worth the value, so far. The customer service is exceptional. This is by far the most important factor for me when making a purchase. Would definitely recommend purchasing from this company!

comment:
I was very picky when searching for a monitor and was very satisfied with this monitor. This is beyond perfect for the price paid. Absolutely everything is great with this monitor. The color is on point and excellent, the brightness is amazing, the monitor is absolutely humongous, and the quality of the screen display is amazing. This monitor also features 10 different preset modes which are very helpful in customizing the display. The only thing that all the techy people should know is that this monitor can only hold a refresh rate of 30 Hertz. For me it is perfect for office work and watching shows, but for gamers that would not be quite likely the best.
Overall the performance of this monitor is amazing and everyone should get one!

comment:
This is an okay monitor but a couple things to consider.

1. The obvious, itâ€™s a 1920 x 1080 res.. The screen res just feels too large when performing tasks related to video and music editing. You will feel like you still need more real estate for editing. Consider a higher res monitor that enables you to see more of the timeline.

2. I didnâ€™t know Dell made â€œeconomyâ€ level products. In other words, the plastic on this monitor feels cheap and it is. You can easily twist the bezel plastic from the screen - seriously itâ€™s that thin. I didnâ€™t try to do this on purpose, but simply noticed the thin plastic tilting the monitor.

3. This is not a height adjustable monitor. It only offers tilt. With that said, this monitor is too high compared to my other monitors.

Image Quality
Its decent, bright, colorful, and really not that bad. Text looks good too. I didnâ€™t notice any pixilation with various fonts. Albeit, I only had this monitor for a few days before returning. Iâ€™ll explain why I returned this monitor next.

Refresh Rate
So this is listed as capable of a 75 Mhz refresh rate. Weâ€™ll that didnâ€™t happen. I tried a couple different cables to make sure I didnâ€™t have a bad cable, and no itâ€™s not my graphic card. I have a sweet fully loaded MBP that is more than capable of driving a monitorâ€¦ M1 Max processor, 32 core GPU, 64 Gig memory, and a 4 TB SSD.

Conclusion
For the price itâ€™s a decent monitor. Just keep in mind the plastic is thin around the bezel, and this is a 1920 x 1080 res monitor and because of this you may feel like you need more real estate when working with video and audio timelines; at this point consider a higher res monitor.

I figured Iâ€™d give this 1920 x 1080 res monitor a try knowing it was likely not going to work for me. As a result, I returned it because I was looking for a primary replacement monitor. I ended up purchasing a 3840 x 2160 res monitor that is capable of delivering the technical capability I am used to.

comment:
I prefer Dell equipment first, second, and last.
This monitor is great - There is enough real estate that I was able to get rid of the two monitors I was using and replace them with this monitor.

I have two concerns - one the power button on the button right is very small - I would hate to break or damage the switch and not being able to power the monitor on.

Second, the monitor is very easy to move vertically. There have been times when I have bumped into the monitor when I've been switching cables between computers and it moves vertically and I have to straighten it back so it'll be horizontal - one word that comes to mind is "flimsy." I can imagine me straighten it and it breaks off the stand completely.

My previous Dell Monitor was much more sturdier (purchased used from the Dell Outlet years ago).

Would I buy Dell again? Yes but not this particular model.

comment:
Keep your expectations tempered and realize that this is NOT a gaming monitor, but it's great for most other work. The primary difference between this monitor and a similar, $600 Dell I use at work is that blacks are NOT black here; they're dark gray. I haven't had any issues even with some pretty advanced photo editing, but this is NOT a monitor for graphic professionals. If your work requires perfectly accurate colors for photo or video editing, buy something else (that costs at least twice as much).

But for normal, non-graphic-professional uses -- including photo editing and light gaming -- this is a great buy for the price ($299 is what I paid). Text is extremely clear, videos look great, and I had no issues on set-up; everything was plug-and-play out of the box.

I DO wish it had a real users manual. Instead, the "manual" supplied (and linked from the Amazon page) is just a useless "how to hook it up" set of images that most vendors would be embarassed to include. I want to expect more from Dell, particularly considering the poorly constructed menus they include on all their monitors, including the expensive ones.

One note: Despite it expressly not being a gaming monitor, it's fine for non-AAA games. If (like me) you just play older games and don't need a ridiculous refresh rate or perfect blacks, it's fine.

comment: What is there not to like about a sub $100 monitor that is anti-glare? Right out of the box, the image is washed out. I had low expectations for a $100 monitor but this fell well below my expectations. My normal process when buying any new monitor is to visit color calibration websites and manually adjust the display. The problem is this display when next to a proper display (such as my LG LG 32QN650-B (as Sub $300 1440p display) looks so bad I don't even want to use it. Furthermore, no amount of calibration can correct the image to something of reasonable quality. I'm stunned others rate this display so highly. I didn't even need to compare it to my LG to see how bad the display performed. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone. My previous Dell monitor lasted 15 years and costs $1,500 (back when HD displays cost $$$). That was a great display. This one should be pulled from the market.

I know Amazon wonâ€™t go out of business if they give me my credit off $351.00, but I would think if they do this too enough people, it will help their bottom line.

I advised the Supervisor that I will not order anything from Amazon until I receive my credit.
I also donâ€™t think they care about that at all. I read an article yesterday stating Amazon is under investigation for deceptive business practices, I think I can add to the list. I hope for their sake my money will be put back on my credit card by Friday, if not Iâ€™m closing my account. Again, Iâ€™m sure they wonâ€™t care at all, but I will keep my dignity intact as I donâ€™t deceive my clients and I donâ€™t allow others to deceive me.

comment:
The monitors are alright for the price, but this amazon listing is a mess. This has listings for about 4 different monitors, so your mileage may vary for this review. The "From the manufacturer section" for the 24 inch monitor I purchased has the information for the 32 inch monitor. It advertises 2HDMI inputs and a display port with a 3.5mm audio port as well. However, the monitor I received only has VGA and 1 HDMI, so I had to buy additional adapters to connect to display port. Make sure you're getting the right inputs for your monitor.

They are also extremely light, which might be good for some, but for me it wobble as I type at my desk. The stand is also too short for me, but I will probably get some monitor arms to adjust that.

comment: I received this monitor the other day. The description read that the monitor was in extremely great condition. I opened the box, followed the directions and fired up the monitor. What I experienced was a cursor type of indicator with a cross type of section. Top 20% was as clear as a bell. The bottom 80% was and light, very small grid overlayed over the display. Not sure what caused the defect nor can I understand how this defect got beyond QA. Regardless now I have to travel 25 miles to return this monitor. In fairness, this was refurbished so that is what I should be prepared for. Still the copy said very excellent condition.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 8950 æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - ç¬¬ 12 ä»£ Intel Core i7-12700ã€32GB DDR5 RAMã€512GB SSD + 1TB HDDã€Intel UHD 770 åœ–å½¢ã€Killer Wi-Fi 6ã€ç©ºæ°£å†·å»ã€Windows 11 Pro - é»‘è‰²
comment: Purchased this and it arrived "dead on arrival". Wouldn't boot, not signal to monitor. Called Dell and they had me attempt to boot etc. Power button was flashing an error code (four white, two yellow). Had me pull all the RAM cards and attempt to reboot. All to no avail. Dell tech said I needed a new motherboard and they send one to a tech two hours away. I was impressed with how Dell handled the situation, the motherboard arrived the next day, the technician called and said he would be at my home at around noon which he was. Installed the new motherboard and it still wouldn't boot. Technician diagnosed the problem to be one of the 4 8gb RAM sticks that were installed. It would boot with the damaged one removed. He called Dell and Dell informed him that the unit was shipped with only 8gb of RAM, not the 32GB that I received. It also wasn't shipped with the 1Tb HDD. Computer was actually shipped by Dell to a company in California and they installed the additional RAM and HDD. Dell would not cover those items so my only choice was to either return the unit or deal with the California company. I chose to return the unit. Just be aware that you are not purchasing this from Dell and Dell will not cover the items they did not install. The RAM strip they installed was Lenovo and the faulty one was not.

comment:
The computer is nice and will handle any computer game. The CPU is great as well as the GPU. In addition, it will especially handle PC VR games with your Meta Quest 2 - with no problem whatsoever. I saw this computer and ordered it on the spot. However, I thought it had a CD/DVD player inside the case. My job requires me to have a DVD player and I cannot stand a standalone USB DVD player no matter how good and inexpensive they are. I am not going to use Duct tape to mount an external CD/DVD player to my computer so for this simple and ridiculous reason, I had to return this particular computer. However, I did find a screaming Dell that I should have purchased before I jumped on this one.

I am waiting to get my refund and will purchase the following system:

Dell XPS 8950 Gaming Desktop Computer
12th Gen Intel Core i9-12900K up to 5.2 GHz CPU
32GB DDR5 RAM
1TB NVMe SSD + 3TB HDD
GeForce RTX 3090 24GB GDDR6
Killer Wi-Fi 6
DVD Burner
Windows 11 Home - I will upgrade to Windows Pro 11 when I get this bad boy!

This is what I have been looking to find for quite some time.

Hurry up Amazon, I want my new computer!

comment: I needed a new workhorse for daily use and occasional CAD work, and this machine works fine for this purpose out of the box. Very up-gradable platform if I ever wanted to. The Intel UHD 770 graphics work fine but stick with Dell drivers, don't go directly to Intel for the "latest" or you might cause yourself problems. Only has only one display port which is not a problem, if your monitors support daisy chaining. Not loaded with bloatware (although some may argue that Windows 11 itself is bloatware). I have the air cooled version and it is quiet, but I usually have some streaming music playing, so I don't hear it at all. If the room is quiet, I can hear it, but it does not disturb me. The XPS 8950 was just what I was looking for, a straight ahead no non-sense solid tower PC.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 8950 æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - ç¬¬ 12 ä»£ Intel Core i7-12700ã€32GB DDR5 RAMã€512GB SSD + 1TB HDDã€Intel UHD 770 åœ–å½¢ã€Killer Wi-Fi 6ã€ç©ºæ°£å†·å»ã€Windows 11 Pro - é»‘è‰²
comment: Tech support is worse than useless! Turns out this unit can't handle more than a 2TB hard drive in each of the 2 slots, which nobody mentioned. On-line documentation is terrible, and tech support, while they pick up quickly, is worse. Just trying to tell which of the USB slots are type 3.2 and which are 2.0 took more than a half hour on each of two phone calls. The agents kept saying "yes" to just about anything, but even with the diagram (which I pulled up while talking) the agents were unable to differentiate between "the sockets next to the ethernet port" and "the sockets above the ethernet port" to tell me which was which. After I got the unit, I decided to increase storage capacity. They said all cables were included. Dell charges twice the price for the same hard drive from Amazon, so I got the drive. And purchased the "drive caddy" from Dell. Turns out, the cables were NOT included as Dell tech support said. Anyway, machine is working, after many hours on tech support. The audio sockets I had to figure out by trial and error (icons indecipherable). But due to limited upgrade ability, I've relegated it to secondary status at the office. I will never again purchase a Dell product.

comment: The computer is as expected as far as the specs, so no issue so far. But I was surprised that it didn't have an hdmi port which in this age should be a default. They should have noted that in the description as a courtesy as I would not have bought this computer if the info was there. Or there should have been an option to upgrade and add in the hdmi port. But I see why there is no upgrade option as this is how amazon bought the unit and can't make any changes after it was delivered to their warehouse. It's not a setup where Amazon send the request for this unit and Dell sends it to Amazon after the purchase. This would be a better method for customers but may not be the best format for Amazon. I will not be buying computers from Amazon because of this, i.e., the lacking of an upgrade capability to add in a basic thing like an hdmi. My first and most likely last time buying a computer from Amazon unless they change this policy.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 8950 æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - ç¬¬ 12 ä»£ Intel Core i7-12700ã€32GB DDR5 RAMã€512GB SSD + 1TB HDDã€Intel UHD 770 åœ–å½¢ã€Killer Wi-Fi 6ã€ç©ºæ°£å†·å»ã€Windows 11 Pro - é»‘è‰²
comment:
While I did not purchase this exact model, I bought this computer almost 3 years ago to the day and it died last night. The specs on this newer model tell me all I need to know.

Dell has a habit of putting PSUs in this machine that DO NOT cover the bases of the functionality of the other parts. My PC on purchase had a 500W PSU with one of the newest Ryzen CPUs and a brand new 3060 TI. Both of those have a minimum of 550W with the recommended being higher.

I knew it was insufficient when I bought it, but 3000 series graphics cards had just came out and were going for thousands and the pandemic had just started so computer storeâ€™s stocks had been wiped. I had to buy a prebuilt.

For the first year or so, my computer would just shut off about once every week without any explanation and just go into repair mode. I troubleshooted it and found it to be PSU failure and tried to keep looking since then.

On purchase, I thought I could just replace the component eventually for minimal cost when it became a problem. If only I knew how wrong I was. Because of the XPSâ€™s compact design, you have maybe one or two options for replacement- either the same PSU with same or lower wattage, or a different brand that barely scrapes by 550W with its size.

I was also having issues with the CPU and GPU running FAR hotter than safe. (CPU clocked in at 95 Celsius once, NOT OKAY) I took the pc apart to find that Dell HAD NOT applied the correct about of thermal paste and the bottom of my CPU was starting to char after about 6 months of use. They maybe used 1/4 of the appropriate amount. I reapplied and cleaned it out very thoroughly and was still having problems. The problems didnâ€™t get better until I took the side of the PC off and jerryrigged a second fan going out. The airflow in the case is HORRIBLE.

It died after about 2 weeks of shutting off at least once a day. The PSU started making a crunching sound last night and I decided to pull the plug so that I can use the good components in a rebuild.

All this to say- donâ€™t buy this. It isnâ€™t quality. I know it is daunting, but consider building your own PC. There are so many incredible YT guides and you can save money and get exactly what specs you want.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 8950 æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - ç¬¬ 12 ä»£ Intel Core i7-12700ã€32GB DDR5 RAMã€512GB SSD + 1TB HDDã€Intel UHD 770 åœ–å½¢ã€Killer Wi-Fi 6ã€ç©ºæ°£å†·å»ã€Windows 11 Pro - é»‘è‰²
comment:
Ooooof... I wanted to love this PC so much more than I can say I do.

Obviously with such a hefty price tag you're kind of expecting it to have all the bells and whistles and do everything a normal (cheaper) model would do... Right? Well don't expect that here.

To start - there's no disk drive, not the end of the world as most installation data can be found on the web and you can always get an external CD/disk reader or burner depending on what you want/need.. But ultimately kind of inconvenient especially when my much cheaper model has one.

There's also NO HDMI Ports or connections for monitors, as stated in other reviews, it does show in the manual that there should be 4 HDMI ports. So not sure what happened there.. Instead you are left with one single Display Port connection, I attempted to not only use an adapter to connect a monitor via HDMI cable but I fact connected my dual monitor setup with the help of an HDMI adapter/splitter.. It worked, kinda.

I definitely noticed a lot of lag with the dual setup and I also noticed occasionally getting short black screens only to reset back to whatever the screen was.
This was not particularly helpful ~
if I was playing a game or doing something that requires live viewing.

Unfortunately for me running dual monitors is almost imperative and so without being able to work out these kinks over multiple adapters and attempts to get it to work properly, I also started noticing issues with running a capture card though the device and using OBS, something I double checked on my laptop to make sure it was not my capture card or headset going out for any reason, it worked perfectly on my laptop/OBS but was skipping echoing, and overall sounded awful through OBS on this PC.

Other than my OBS issues, and when not running a multi monitor setup I did notice it has a quick startup time and is fast at installing and downloading. I had no issues running many intensive games on it even though that's not it's first intended use.

I would recommend this more for someone who's intending to use it for office work or maybe even photo or video editing (as long as you are OK with a single monitor setup)
sku: processor_description: Core i7-12700memory_size: 32 GBæ¨£å¼: UHD é¡¯ç¤ºå¡

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 8950 æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - ç¬¬ 12 ä»£ Intel Core i7-12700ã€32GB DDR5 RAMã€512GB SSD + 1TB HDDã€Intel UHD 770 åœ–å½¢ã€Killer Wi-Fi 6ã€ç©ºæ°£å†·å»ã€Windows 11 Pro - é»‘è‰²
comment:
Once setup and running this computer is solid for lots of purposes. Productivity or light gaming are both fine, depending on your exact needs. Though while it has lots of memory and a modern processor, anything extremely graphics intensive will be limited. I think that's pretty straight forward to figure out based on the specs.

The main possible issues with this have nothing to do with its performance specs per se.
- The first major issue is the lack of HDMI port. While display port is a fairly common connector, given the integrated graphics it seems odd to me to skip the more common HDMI port and use display port exclusively. It really should have both kinds of ports.
-The second major issue, which admittedly might not be an issue for many people, is the proprietary internals of the system. Due to the power supply, motherboard, and case used there a lot of upgrade options going forward are locked out. While any most hardware failures will be covered by dell's warranty, it would be nice if there were more standardized internals for DIY fixes and upgrades.

Overall the specs and performance are good and it can easily work out well as a family computer, a home office computer (though kind of high spcces in some ways for those), media creation to a degree, or a light gaming computer. It just might not offer the room for growth that other computer solutions would have. And as someone that likes to tinker, I'm just not a fan of things being locked down by unnecessary proprietary redesigns of common components. With these limitations a laptop with the same specs would be a better option.
sku: processor_description: Core i7-12700memory_size: 32 GBæ¨£å¼: UHD é¡¯ç¤ºå¡

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 8950 æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - ç¬¬ 12 ä»£ Intel Core i7-12700ã€32GB DDR5 RAMã€512GB SSD + 1TB HDDã€Intel UHD 770 åœ–å½¢ã€Killer Wi-Fi 6ã€ç©ºæ°£å†·å»ã€Windows 11 Pro - é»‘è‰²
comment:
I needed a new desktop for work after coming across Dell XPS 8950 Desktop with the 12th Gen Intel Core i7-12700 processor. I've been using it for some time now, and it's been great. I have to say that I am very impressed. The processor is incredibly fast and has made my computer run more smoothly. It also has plenty of storage space, so I appreciate the 32 GB of memory, as it has come in handy on more than one occasion.

For the noise, there isn't any except when you first power it on. However, after that, the fan is very silent.

I also really like the Intel UHD Graphics 770. It's been a big upgrade from my old graphics card and has made a big difference in my work. NOTHING hasn't crashed on me.

But, when it came to the setup section and connecting my monitor. This was a problem, and it confused me. There were no pictures, just little symbols. I was like, how was I supposed to know what cord goes where? And the paper/instructions it came with was no help at all. So I had to use Google. So this part took longer than it should have.

The other downside is that it can be a bit pricey, but I think it is definitely worth the investment. Especially if you work from home and you need something with more space.

Overall, I'm happy with my desktop.
sku: processor_description: Core i7-12700memory_size: 32 GBæ¨£å¼: UHD é¡¯ç¤ºå¡

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 8950 æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - ç¬¬ 12 ä»£ Intel Core i7-12700ã€32GB DDR5 RAMã€512GB SSD + 1TB HDDã€Intel UHD 770 åœ–å½¢ã€Killer Wi-Fi 6ã€ç©ºæ°£å†·å»ã€Windows 11 Pro - é»‘è‰²
comment:
Dell's XPS lineup has been notorious for using proprietary parts and charging exorbitant prices for a mediocre performance improvement. This product exemplifies the many reasons to consider building your own PC over buying a prebuilt.

Let's talk about the things this prebuilt does right.
* The motherboard has one additional M.2 slot for a PCIE SSD and an additional hard drive bay.
* It also has a 2x16GB dual channel memory configuration instead of using a single 32GB stick. Maybe it's because DDR5 is still too new?

Unfortunately, that's about where the good parts end. Now for the drawbacks.
* This is an expensive prebuilt, yet this comes equipped with a pathetic 450-watt power supply. If you were thinking of adding a high-end GPU to this, you'll be severely disappointed.
* The CPU cooler also appears to be a generic Intel stock cooler, so even if you manage to upgrade the power supply and add in a GPU, you'll probably face thermal CPU bottlenecks due to such a weak cooler if you're playing demanding titles.
* The motherboard also only has 1 DisplayPort as the output.
sku: processor_description: Core i7-12700memory_size: 32 GBæ¨£å¼: UHD é¡¯ç¤ºå¡

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 8950 æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - ç¬¬ 12 ä»£ Intel Core i7-12700ã€32GB DDR5 RAMã€512GB SSD + 1TB HDDã€Intel UHD 770 åœ–å½¢ã€Killer Wi-Fi 6ã€ç©ºæ°£å†·å»ã€Windows 11 Pro - é»‘è‰²
comment:
I received the version without a GPU. I was hoping to throw a 3060ti or 3070 in it and turn it into a great gaming machine, but when I checked the PSU wattage I realized it's a paltry 460 watts, which is well below the recommended wattage for even a low-end GPU like a 3050. To make matters worse, it appears that the PSU and motherboard are a proprietary combination, so I can't change out the PSU for a more powerful one. So I'm stuck with an oddly powerful machine, that can only run very low-end older GPUs.

I recognize that it was purpose-built to the selected specs, and the weak PSU is weak to save a dollar, but it wouldn't have cost Dell much to include a 650-750w PSU to allow for upgrades and customizability. Very disappointed.

Aside from the PSU issue, it does run fine. Had no problems booting, and it performs as I would expect given the specs.

NOTE: it only has DisplayPort out for video, which is an odd choice. Make sure you have a DisplayPort capable monitor and a DisplayPort cable if you buy this.

comment:
1st impression: Open the box and find that there is no keyboard. Mentioned that to Dell, and was totally ignored. Fortunately I have on old one here which works OK.

2nd impression: None of my three monitors plug in anywhere. Found what appeared to be an appropriate one on the Dell website. Asked tech support one simple question: if that Dell monitor would plug in and work with this Dell Computer. 20 minutes of gobbledygook later, he said yes, so I bought it. Went to plug it in, and found his instructions were wrong. Eventually I figured it out for myself. The "documentation" that came with the monitor consisted of small pictures with the various ports only identified by a small icon with a foreign-language ID.

Third: It comes with an SSD "boot" drive, and a 2 Tb. "data" drive. However all programs you install go directly to C:, which is on the BOOT drive. Won't last long, and won't hold much.

Fourth: The CD-ROM is cheap and terrible. It appears to have irreparably damaged all the Macrium boot CDs I tried in it. Fortunately THIS old computer still works well enough that I can burn more.

So, my conclusion: DON'T buy it or anything else DELL!

-dan z-

comment:
Purchased this through the Dell website and have been using this for about 1 month. It has been running smoothly and quietly without any problems. It is affordable product so far. I will update this review if any problems arise in the next months.

The model pictured includes the water-cooled AIO, which is only available for K-type processors. Note that purchasing a non-K processor will land you the small fan that you see pictured in the product page (4th photo at time of this review). If you purchase the K-type through Amazon, you may only get the advanced air cooler without liquid cooling so be wary of this. Liquid cooling runs very quiet.

Also pictured is the NVIDIA GeForce 1650 Super, which I chose because I am not a big computer gamer. Note that the motherboard's default output is only one DisplayPort 1.4. If you wish to have multiple displays, you will have to upgrade to the RTX 3060, which includes 3 x DisplayPort 1.4 and 1 x HDMI 2.1.

I purchased this with a M.2 NVME boot drive and additional 2TB HDD (top right). This is also upgradeable with a second HDD (top left). Note that you will have to purchase additional pieces in order to add an extra HDD. These pieces are very specific, so I've provided links to the specific products available on Amazon. theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 Ultra HD/4K ä¸‰é‡é¡¯ç¤ºåŸºåº§ï¼ˆD3100ï¼‰ï¼Œé»‘è‰²
comment:
I am a grad student and like most I am having to do school from home because of covid. I have an office in my house that I setup to be equal to what I had at work when I was as an engineer. The only problem is my wife who is also an engineer is working from home and is now the primary user of the home office. This created a huge issue as I need access to the main house computer, need a attend remote grad school, and need an area to do hw. I purchased a Dell Inspiron 3493 core i5 (14 in screen) to be a mobile PC for school and to be used as a secondary main house computer when I don't have access to my primary one. I took over my wife's vanity table and converted it to my new work area. Working on a 14 in screen on the go is good, but working on it for hours is a pain due to lack of screen size. The Dell D3100 was the solution and allowed me to repurpose two old monitors I had lying in the attic. No USB 3.0 docks on the market charge a laptop because they were designed for laptops that do not have USB-C or thunderbolt ports on it (my exact laptop) which actually make them more/true universal compared to USB-C/Thunderbolt docks. Saying that I love this dock as it has allowed me to work/study without strain and my productivity isn't hampered because of lack of screen(s). The dock has also allowed my work area (a small vanity table) to be clutter free which is essential to maximize space. I have dual monitors, logitech C270 cam, wireless keyboard (logitech K360), ethernet, and dual speaker with amp all attached to the dock; plus three free USB 3.0 ports that are easy to access. change a few power settings to prevent the laptop from automatically falling asleep when plugged in and the lid closed. Don't turn the laptop off, just manually put it to sleep when you are done using it, and you can wake it up via the wireless USB keyboard or mouse which makes this very convenient. I did notices that when you use both monitors on the dock, internet speeds are reduced (but honestly it isn't noticeable) probably due to thru put of the USB 3.0 cable and the dock does get warm with use I have noticed.
Because this docking station does not charge, it is 100% universal compared to the ones that do. I noticed that all these brands of docking stations advertise how much charging power they supply ONLY to their brand of laptop but they do not state this at first or second glance. It is very misleading when they are calling it universal. 210 W charging for our brand but 90 W max only to other brands (you have to really dig for this information). You might end up sending almost $400 on a dock that is no better than a $140 dock.
My wife needed a truly universal dock to work on her HP Zbook 15 G5 and to work on a Dell equivalent when her company changes their laptops and is demanding the return of all their docking stations. She currently is using a HP 230 W dock which will only supply 90 W to the Dell equivalent laptop (same is true for a dell 240 W dock on a HP laptop) meaning the laptop will need to be also plugged into its power brick when docked. So I figured why buy a $400 dock that will require her to plug in the laptop's power brick to use it when I can buy this dock (Dell 3100) for $140 and be in the same situation but for much less money. for convenience, but buy a second power brick for $40/50 and it will still be cheaper than a $400 dock that only supplies 90 W to laptops that aren't the same brand as it is. **update: my wife's work laptop has an integrated NVIDA Quadro P2000. My biggest fear was bc of the dock being USB 3.0 vs. the others, the laptop would use the integrated graphics on the CPU only and bypass the integrated NVIDA Quadro P2000 as I have read would happen. GOOD NEWS: the integrated NVIDA Quadro P2000 GPU is being utilized and there was no bottle necking. the setup works perfectly.**
The dell 3100 docking station has been great and is an excellent value that solved all my problems and needs (and my wife's too). for those that have spoken poorly about this docking station simply haven't done research on docking stations period.

comment:
Like most of us out here in cyberspace, I used to think that if I purchased a small simply docking station I would be able to get away from large devices like these. I could have my desk setup to be mobile and nimble, allowing me to work from anywhere. Then I purchased one of those small usb devices and came to discover what everyone else already knows. They dont pack the power to be as nimble as you want.

After going through cheap device(s), I bit the bullet and purchased this for my home setup. While it may be big and I cant just be out and about like I want, I also am not carrying two (2) 4K monitors with me where I go, nor am I doing rendering on the train. This larger device is not only seamless when installed, but I was able to update my computer hardware without having to go through a million and one steps to 'make it work'. It just does.

If you have a home office setup and you want to keep it simple, this is the choice for you.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 Ultra HD/4K ä¸‰é‡é¡¯ç¤ºåŸºåº§ï¼ˆD3100ï¼‰ï¼Œé»‘è‰²
comment:
Note: I bought a Dell Inspiron 7590 2in1 laptop that converts to a tablet. I bought this doc as it was recommended by the Amazon sales algorithm of "Frequently Bought Together."

This docking station is in fact compatible with my Dell laptop and does work as designed, but it does not offer the features I thought it did. The two features I thought it had was the ability's to power my laptop and pass data back and forth to my laptop all with one cable. This dock does not do that. The docking station that does this connects to the laptop through a USB-C cable, not a USB-3 cable. Also, the second feature that I thought I was buying was that the docking station is only a 60 Wat AC adapter. I thought that could power my laptop at my desk, and then I would be able to use the AC adapter that came with the laptop as a "travel adapter." Unfortunately, this is wrong on two points: First, the dock does not power my laptop directly through the data cable, and Secondly, the laptop I bought requires a 90 Wat AC adapter. This means the AC adapter that came with the dock, only powers the dock, and the AC adapter that powers my laptop must be used at my desk and on the road. Further, this means crawling under my desk to plug and unplug the AC adapter every time I need to take the laptop with me. That is a hassle I would like to have been able to avoid. (Many a time I have left the house only to have found I forgot to bring my AC adapter. It is better to have an extra one that always lives in the laptop bag.) As a final note, I am not returning the dock just yet. Before you can use this dock it requires a driver download before first use. On the download page, it asks what OS you are using? Windows, macOS, Android, Chrome OS, or Ubuntu. As I said earlier, it does function as designed. I likely will be able to use this on a different device. Hope this helps.

comment:
My ownership of the D3100 UltraHD Universal dock is a story of dysfunction enhanced by Dell Tech Support incompetence and apathy. The dock failed to work properly when connected to my system. The source of my problems was originally not clear, although ultimately identified as the dock & Dell tech support. Here's the long version of my problem. I purchased the Dock along with a Dell XPS 15 laptop and Dell U2713HM monitor, all purchased new at the same time. Both the computer ($2000) and the monitor ($500) are made for ultra-high-resolution display (maximum 3200x1800 and 2560x1440 respectively). They do not match resolution, despite the assurances I got on this point from Dell before purchasing the equipment. Prior to purchase I was told by two separate Dell answer-line people that these three products (laptop, monitor, Dock) were designed to work together. It is obvious they were not.

Initially the monitor did not work (black screen) when connected through the dock, or directly to the laptop. Two different Dell tech support technicians spent a cumulative 5 hours (with me a hostage assistant) working remotely on my system, resetting and re-installing every possible driver and setting and cable configuration, plus having me purchase additional cables. Unfathomably, the DVI and VGA cables supplied with the UltraHD monitor do not support its full resolution; you must purchase additional cables for it to reach its full, advertised resolution.

With no help from Dell tech support I accidently discovered that the computer-monitor connection (either with or without dock) will not function if the Screen Resolution setting is "Duplicate these Displays". Any other setting works. After solving that "problem" my monitor works fine when connected directly to the laptop. Connections through the D3100 Dock work only intermittently. This includes both monitor display and keyboard communications.

After Dell Tech Support recommended purchasing additional cables, which also did not solve the problems, my case was elevated to Dell's "HD resolution specialist" who confessed having never worked with a D3100 dock before, so wasn't sure what to expect of it. After having me perform more tests and having me install more drivers, communicating only by email, she eventually concluded that either the dock is faulty or maybe I need to re-install the computer OS. It took 2 weeks' of occasional email to reach this indecisive conclusion.

It has taken one month to get to this point, the source of the problem and its resolution are still not known decisively, and Amazon is out of stock on the D3100 dock until end of February. I asked the Dell Tech Support specialist if they could handle the Dock replacement in order to expedite finding a solution to my problems and she promised to let me know. That was 5 days ago; still no response. If the replacement Dock doesn't work I'm faced with an OS re-install that also may or may not work. This is not Dell's cheapest equipment by a long shot. I expected a lot more of both their equipment and especially of their tech support. It will be a long time before I think of purchasing Dell equipment again. I can only wonder: how would Apple have handled such problems if it was their equipment?

Update 1/18/15: I exchanged my D3100 for the same product two weeks ago and the new dock has worked well during this time. Apparently my problems stemmed from a hardware failure in my original dock. I would give the new D3100 a 5-star rating if not for the fact Dell tech support was both helpless and apathetic about assisting me to diagnose what was the cause of my connectivity problems (I was on my own to figure out if it was caused by my new computer, new monitor, or new dock). I'm raising my rating to a 3-star because the hardware is good if it is functioning, but lack of product tech support and misinformation from Dell denies it a higher ranking.

Assuming you do actually want a USB 3.0 device then this device should have everything you're looking for, but I knocked one star off for the product page not being clear. I wound up having to return this and get something else.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 Ultra HD/4K ä¸‰é‡é¡¯ç¤ºåŸºåº§ï¼ˆD3100ï¼‰ï¼Œé»‘è‰²
comment:
This dock performs its primary function which is to connect my 2 Dell monitors to my Dell laptop from work. And a wireless keyboard and mouse. But there are several things it doesn't do that even my cheaper off-brand dock did:
-the connector from the dock to the laptop is USB-A. Most laptops in 2023 have USB-C (including mine). I had to use an adapter (luckily one came with my Samsung phone). The connector itself is a cable with its own port on the dock, as opposed to one that is permanently connected/part of the dock.
- the dock connects to AC power but it doesn't power the laptop! WHAT? I have to use the adapter that came with the laptop. (Again, luckily, there are two type C ports on that side of the laptop.)
- although the USB port works for my wireless keyboard and mouse, it doesn't work for my headset. I have to plug that directly Into the laptop.
- the power light is way too bright. Had to cover it with a piece electrical tape.

I mentioned a cheaper off-brand dock that this one replaced. The only problem with that was it took several disconnects and reconnects sometimes to get both monitors to work. BUT it supported my wireless keyboard/mouse and my headset at the same time, all without connecting to AC power -- it just used the power from the laptop I guess. I ordered this Dell dock out of not-getting-both-monitors-to-work frustration that just happened to peak on Prime day. This was such a good deal that I neglected to do research. Lesson learned.

comment:
So far, so good. Initially connected with Ubuntu Gnome 16.04 on a Broadwell Dell notebook, and it was terrible- a torturous, tearing fiasco like you can't believe.

Tested briefly with a Win 10 laptop (Ivy Bridge hp ProBook 6470b), and it automagically downloaded everything it needed within a couple minutes, and all was well. I decided to fetch the latest dock driver from Dell's website and push it onto the device while I had the Windows notebook plugged in. No apparent change. Switching back to Gnome afterwards was still unbearable.

So I did apt install xfce4, rebooted into XFCE, and it works really well. Tried again with clean installation of Ubuntu 16.04.1 ("normal", with Unity), and it worked surprisingly well too. I don't know what the deal was with Gnome being so awful. It's a shame, too, since I really like Gnome, and it's what I always use on my CentOS and Fedora installations.

Dock is currently connecting AmazonBasics A100 USB-powered speakers (consuming a USB 3.0 port and an audio jack), two external 1080p monitors over HDMI, and a USB keyboard and mouse over the two USB 2.0 ports. All is working as expected. I may check back in a few days after I add my third monitor.

This setup appears to have very little discernible CPU penalty.

Cool bit of kit. Kind of dense for its size, and the underside creates enough friction to keep her pretty still on a desk. Well thought out.

02.06.2017 udpate: I had trouble adding a third external display (all three external monitors are matching 1080p ViewSonic). Can't recall error message, but I couldn't populate the display on a third monitor. I just worked around the issue by running HDMI directly from laptop to one of the external monitors, and I let the D3100 feed the other two (one via HDMI, the other uses a Displayport-to-HDMI adapter for the moment). Just note you may have a problem with three displays.

Currently: Ubuntu 16.04 on Dell 5548 notebook, fully patched, tested with and without Intel-proprietary drivers, stock 4.4 kernel. I'm satisfied with the setup, and I don't intend to fiddle with it any further.

03/2017 update:
Inconsistent results coming up from sleep state or reboot. Got tired of fussing, so I sold the thing. I'll never buy a consumer-type notebook again, only business-class kit from now on. A proper dock and a computer with proper dock support is worth the spend, to me.
