comment:
I initially purchased this unit in December, 2018, for use with a Dell G7 7588 Computer, running X-Plane 11. It worked fine for several months, and then one day after not having used it for a week, it stopped working. No amount of playing with it could restore operation. Although it was past the return date, Amazon sent me a new one. 8 months later the second one also quit, and Amazon offered to have them both returned for a full refund. Meanwhile I ordered a Baseus Triple Monitor Docking station. While waiting for the Baseus, I did some research online, and someone suggested unplugging everything from the Dell, and then just plugging in the computer cable, followed by the monitor cables. Lo and behold the Dell started working again. I tried the same procedure with the first unit, and it worked fine as well. What I did find, however, is that with two monitors hooked up to the HDMI outputs, and the third monitor hooked up to the 20 pin DisplayPort output, the frame rate was only about 14-15 fps. If the third monitor is attached directly to the HDMI output on the laptop, the frame rate jumps to 30 fps.

So the takeway is twofold:
1) If the unit stops working, turn everything off, unplug all the cables, then turn on the computer and the docking station, plug the docking station into the computer, and then plug in all the monitors.
2) For gaming, plug the third monitor into the laptop directly, so the docking station acts as a "dual" rather than a "triple." For regular computer use, plugging all three monitors into the docking station is just fine.

By the way, Amazon said to just keep both working docking stations, and not to bother sending one back. Gotta love their customer service!

comment:
Well, I have been using one of these docks for almost a year now, and I have been extremely impressed. The picture quality is great, and the functionality is very reliable. I do, however, have two complaints.

Firstly, the setup is not as simple as it should be. There is firmware available on the Dell website, as well as on the DisplayLink website, but no native software application for managing the displays once installed. You are forced to use the Windows display management software, which is absolutely not user friendly, especially if you are running triple monitors or more. It takes some time to get everything set up and working properly, but once you get it done, you should not have any further issues.

Secondly, this dock has a DisplayPort output. If, however, you own or intend to purchase monitors, like my three Dell U2414H flat panels, with MST (Multi-Stream Transport) capability (aka Daisy Chaining) you will be disappointed to learn that this dock does NOT support MST. Rather than connecting multiple monitors to one display output, you have to run a separate video cable for every single monitor. What's worse, the dock only has one DisplayPort output, the other two outputs are HDMI, so if your monitors came with DisplayPort cables like mine did, you will have to buy additional HDMI cables as well...

None of these issues is a deal breaker, and now that I am set up, I am EXTREMELY happy with the end result, but just a little bit of info I wish I had known prior to making my purchases.

comment:
I have 2 screens and 1 laptop and a desktop. I regularly need to share keyboards, mice and one or both of the screens between the desktop and laptop.

I have a Dell thunderbolt connection (TB16 docking station). The TB16 only has 1 HDMI and a display port. I bought HDMI switches thinking that I could use a connector to HDMI for the display port. I was wrong.

I then found this thing. It is cheaper, has 2 HDMI ports and is compatible with every computer I use. I've used a Lenovo t480, Asus chromebook and the XPS 13 (9360). Ironically, the XPS is the one that has trouble. The XPS does not pick up the ethernet and the dimensions of the connected monitors look funny. The background image is just larger on the monitors but otherwise works well and there might be a way to fix this but it hasn't bothered me enough to figure it out since my wifi connection is strong enough.

It is otherwise truly and awesome solution and has eliminated several other more complicated solutions to share 2 screens across 2 monitors (each monitor only has 1 HDMI). It even works with my corsair k95 and logitech g502 (which can be fussy with docking stations).

BTW, I only use this for HD not 4K or any higher resolution. Also - I wouldn't recommend going used because the vendors take forever and mine came without the USB type A to type B cord. The HDMI switches that I'm using are the Roofull 5 in 1. I'm also using a USB 3.0 switch (ABLEWE).

My only complaint is I wish I would've found it earlier.

comment: Over a year ago, I purchased a Microsoft Surface Book 3 with a Surface Dock 2. For the past several months, the two external monitors attached to the Surface Dock 2 got increasing buggy, and ultimately would no longer display. I did all the troubleshooting (e.g., updated firmware, deleted selected registry items, used MS software to clean the cache). I even invested in top-of-the-line cables. Nothing worked. I suppose I could have asked for a replacement from Microsoft. But working with the sales folks at Microsoft can sometimes be a challenge. Out of desperation, I purchased the Dell USB 3.0 Ultra HD/4K Triple Display Docking Station (D3100). I left the charging port connection between the laptop and the MS docking station 2 (for charging purposes, printer connection, and external hardware connection). In addition, I plugged the Dell dock into one of my two left USB Type A ports on my Microsoft Surface Book 3 - where I connected two individual HDMI cables to the Dell dock and my two monitors. This gave me three total monitors - one from the laptop and two external monitors. Given the countless hours I previously spent trying to get the MS Surface Dock 2 to work, I was astonished that the Dell Dock simply worked. Not sure what else to say. Some days are just good days.

comment:
Been looking for a way to extend my Surface Pro 3 to my 3 Acer monitors. My Surface Pro 3 doesn't have a USB-Type C connection since this was made before USB-Type C was a mainstream connection. It only has a mini-display port and one USB 3.0 connection and there weren't many adapters with mini-display port that were going to let me extend to 3 monitors. I've found one's with dual display but those weren't the ones I needed. I however bought one that was connected through USB-Type C and figured I could use a USB-Type C to mini display port adapter to it but was not able to make it work.

So I decided to go all in on this docking station not knowing if it would work or not and I must say I am very happy with my purchase. All you do is plug the USB connection to the USB port of the Surface Pro 3 and even my existing USB hub that was previously connected to the Surface Pro 3 also works the same without issues as all you have to do is connect it to the USB port of this docking station although I don't currently have it connected anymore since I just moved everything from the previous hub to this docking station which has plenty of USB ports on it.

Right now, I am using 2 of the hdmi ports to 2 of my Acer monitors and am still using the mini-display port on the Surface Pro 3 toconnect to my 3rd Acer monitor. I plan to get a display-port to hdmi cable and use the display port on the docking station to connect to the 3rd monitor and free-up my mini-display port connection even though it's not necessary but I take my Surface Pro 3 alot with me so if I get this display-port to hdmi cable, would just mean one less connection to hook up to my Surface Pro 3 once I'm back at my desk. Basically, I just prefer more convenience.

comment: I got this device in order to allow me to use multiple monitors on a single, HDMI (NVidia GeForce powered) output laptop. Since the laptop does not have a DP, miniDP, DVI or VGA output, a TripleHead2Go device was out of the question. I used an older and less powerfull, second laptop computer with multiple display capabilities and controlled those monitor with Symergy software, a good solution for the time being, which is constantly improved by its developers. Nevertheless, I was looking for a hardware solution, so I got this Dell USB Triple Display device from Amazon. I am using it connected through a USB 3.0 port that, incidentally, has been behaving rather strange for quite some time now, since it does not recognize any USB peripheral but this Dell device. Now I am using a 40 inches monitor in the HDMI output and 3 full HD monitors in the 3 outputs of the Dell device. The 2 charging USB port on the Dell device do charge according to their outputs as well, despite the problem I just mentioned with the USB port in my laptop. The Dell Triple Dispaly works great, with one annoying inconvenience: The Displaylink software that uses the Dell device is not entirely compatible with the 8.1 OS of my laptop, and it gives me hard times when turning on the laptop every day, impeding Windows to load properly. After few attempts, it also prompts to use the recovery tool of the OS. Erratically, it starts without further trouble. That is why I cannot award 5 stars. I realize that this problem is not Dells fault, but it certainly has a negative effect in the device's usability, being bothersome to devote time to start acomputer that normally is up and running in seconds. Other that that is well build unit and at the end of the day resolved my need of multiple monitors, at a price.

comment:
I am so glad I got this!

I have a Dell laptop for work that clicks into a (Dell PR03X) docking station. I hate the docking station. It's just difficult to get the laptop connected to it and the docking station only allows for 2 extra monitors, not 3. So I had to buy an external USB video card for my 3rd monitor.

I purchased this as a replacement for my PR03X dock and it's an EXCELLENT replacement. For one thing, I can use it with all my laptops, not just my Dell. I have a Lenovo Yoga (my wife's), a Macbook Air (2011 with OS 10.9 - which required the software from http://www.displaylink.com/support/mac_downloads.php), and my work Dell laptop. All 3 work great with this little hub. And it is pretty small and lightweight.

Note: I wasn't really sure how this was going to connect to my laptop(s). It turns out it connects via a typical USB (2 or 3) port. My Macbook Air has USB 2, while my Lenovo Yoga has USB 3.0. Both work flawlessly. However, obviously the extra USB ports the device provides won't operate at USB 3 speeds if you're connected to your laptop via a USB 2 port.

Anyway, once you've connected the doc to your laptop (or desktop) via a USB 2 or 3 port, its ready for up to 3 monitors to be connected to it. Two via HDMI and a third via Dell's DisplayPort (which you can get a DisplayPort-to-HDMI adapter if needed). So with the laptop screen this gives you a total of up to 4 displays!

The One Con:
It seems like video playback might be a little choppy when watching a 1080p video clip on YouTube while connected to a USB 2 port. I'm not sure if this was the internet or a FPS limitation of the USB video throughput. However, it seems to playback video flawlessly using a USB 3 port.

So if you're considering this for video work or for gaming and you don't have a USB 3 port to plug it onto, you may find it slightly laggy and you may want to do a little more research. But again, I see no lag using USB 3.

But if you want to use typical applications like Word, Excel, PowerPoint, ect. - or in my case a text editor like Sublime Text, this little dock will work great, even when using the slower USB 2.

comment:
I just ordered this Dell D3100 Display docking Station for my spouse, who works from home on a company issued laptop that has only ONE HDMI port...no VGA...no Digital!

This laptop was recently issued to employees to replace their 'old' Panasonic laptops that had TWO HDMI ports. Frankly, we all still can't figure out why the laptops were changed when they really just just needed bigger hard drives. Everything else was fine.

Anyway, to work effectively, employees all need to use their two personally owned monitors yet there's only the one HDMI port. I'm my spouse's tech support & tried using an HDMI adapter/converter that I ordered here last week, but because those adapters are not plug 'n play as they are all advertised, it wouldn't work on the company issued laptop because software needed to be installed, and employees are not authorized to install anything, not even a printer, or a display adapter/converter.

Having worked for the same company myself, I remembered that this Dell Docking Station has been standard-issue for many years (still is) so I decided to order one to see if it would work (Thank you seller: ZRM Industries!).

I plugged everything in today, fired up the 'ol laptop and everything works! No drivers to install! True Plug 'n Play! ...if there are any drivers, they're likely already installed in the standard 'image' on all company laptops.

It's so nice to plug everything into the dock now, instead of plugging/unplugging everyday into the laptop...all USB devices, headset, Ethernet, HDMI, & DisplayPort

Not reflected in my review rating is that I got this port "used-very good" via Amazon seller ZRM Industries (order was fulfilled by Amazon). It only took three days to get here and the price fit our budget, since we have to pay for this ourselves, in addition to using our own monitors.

comment: I bought this to replace my original docking station on my Dell E5470. My old docking station only had 1 HDMI and other than using 1 USB port I was no longer utilizing the other ports. This docking station provides the dual HDMI to my monitors plus supports Ethernet and USB. It's a much smaller footprint, is super easy to set up, connect and go! The power and HDMI run to floor receptacles and I have HDMI run under the floor through the basement and back up to another floor receptacle, allowing me to put a desk with monitors in the middle of the room without any cables running across the floor. I've only given 4 stars because the power cord doesn't seat very firmly in the unit and every time I try to clean up my cable spaghetti it pops loose.

comment:
UPDATE 2/2/16: I was very critical of this docking station but the main issue has now been resolved. Finally, a tech from Dell emailed me the solution: my HDMI to DisplayPort adapter was not an active adapter. So for $20 I ordered a new one and it did the trick. There are still issues but the setup is now functional. Biggest issue now is that after waking my computer, I often have to unplug the dock from power and plug it back. Until I do, my external monitors say "No Signal". This issue is much more frequent with the 4k monitor. Also, things do lag a bit on the 4k monitor, like mouse movement. Dell was almost of no help at all... the manager I spoke to was very knowledgeable but couldn't figure out the adapter issue... thankfully, he was faithful to email me about it when he figured it out. But this took over a week.

ORIGINAL POST January, 2016: I bought this last week as I have a new Windows 10 laptop and two external displays. One monitor is plugged into D3100 via DVI to HDMI adapter; the 2nd monitor is a Vizio 4k TV. I've plugged it into HDMI on D3100 and also tried it in DisplayPort using HDMI to DP adapter. The 4k TV continually shows "No Signal" even though Windows' Display settings recognize that all three monitors are there. No setting I've chosen, however, will fix the issue. Oddly enough, the 4K gets signal if I bypass the D3100 and plug directly into laptop's HDMI port, which means nothing is wrong with the TV or the HDMI cable. Both HDMI ports on the D3100 work when I plug the DVI monitor into them.

In my research on DisplayLink's forum, I found several users reporting the same issue. One user even stated, "No 4k TV works through the D3100". Ouch. Pretty damning for a docking station that advertises it is a 4k docking station!

To top it all off, Dell's support has been a train wreck. They keep asking for some serial number that doesn't exist on their docking stations, their tech support automated system doesn't even give docking stations or accessories as an option, and once I got someone, they knew absolutely nothing about docking stations. So finally they passed me on to some sort of manager, who was knowledgeable but not enough to find a solution. He told me he would research it and get back to me by noon on Wednesday... which he never did. Terrible, terrible, terrible.

comment:
Works great, with the right understanding of HOW it works!

This unit uses DisplayLink technology. I have used another DisplayLink adapter I have used with a Lenovo Miix 8 tablet for a few years. So, understanding a little bit about USB technology properly set my expectations for the performance. If you want to play games on your "Displaylinked" devices, you will be disappointed. But if you want to connect a bunch of monitors to display photos, or for office computing duties, you should be thrilled.

A few additional observations:

1. This devices works perfectly with USB2, although you should understand the bandwidth limitations and EXPECT some issues with mouse lag, if you share the same port.
2. Ubuntu is NOT plug and play. I worked on this for about 20 minutes, and couldn't get it to work. I will update later
3. You have to download the updated drivers from Dell - NOT DisplayLink.
4. The 3.5MM sound did not work out of the box, but sound through HDMI worked perfectly.
5. When connecting to a TV, the HDMI output seemed to make the overscan/underscan worse. In other words, the edges of my display were not visible. Had to do some tuning in Windows control panel - display.
6. Network performance on USB 2 is really good - much better than wireless. This is a big deal for use with a tablet.

So the only big issues is putting your mouse on this device and sharing the USB bandwidth with video and network loads. IT WON'T WORK WELL. Use a Bluetooth mouse....

Also, I wish the newer drivers from DisplayLink would work. Relying on Dell for drivers worries me...

comment:
Overall disappointed with the performance of this unit but at the end of the day it does what's advertised... just with a lot of hiccups.
I run a triple monitor display with ethernet, a mouse and keyboard, and a 2.1 speaker setup off this display link from my acer aspire e5. It's a decently powerful laptop handles all the tasks I throw at it with ease but once it gets hooked up to my station in my dorm... well let's just say it's unreliable. It's pretty common for the display link to just choose a random port to not work whenever I turn on my laptop in the morning. Almost everyday it seems I have to troubleshoot either a monitor not picking up a signal (while simultaneously saying it is in display settings) or a keyboard just not turning on and even sometimes the ethernet just decides to sh*t itself.
The fixing aspect is sometimes very easy. All I have to do is unplug it and plug it back in... SOMETIMES, while on other occassions no amount of troubleshooting or driver updates will fix the problem. It'll just not work until it does again (sometimes a port doesn't work for a day or two and then just comes back to life.)
But the most annoying feature of this device by far is that for some god forsaken reason it just turns off and on the display of my main monitor (120hz VG248) at random times. The monitor can be under no stress or a lot of stress, it does not matter the screen will just go black and come back again in a second or two. Really irritating if I'm in a game or something which I sometimes am. (This issue did not exist before the display link)
In conclusion, I would not buy this port again but I'm okay owning it because it was really the only option I had given the specific variety of ports I need for my college setup.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 Ultra HD/4K ä¸‰é‡é¡¯ç¤ºåŸºåº§ï¼ˆD3100ï¼‰ï¼Œé»‘è‰²
comment:
For anyone who is looking to have an actual docking station - this is not for you (although it seems none of the major players are making docking stations anymore). This is basically a USB hub that will allow you to run more screens and connections than the laptop has connections for. I'm using this to support a work-issued Dell Precision 5540.

Pros : it's USB and setup initially was pretty easy. I have two monitors running extended display + the laptop monitor for 3 total monitors and they all work well. The monitor that is true HDMI has had zero issues. The monitor that is running DisplayPort to DVI will go black for about 4 seconds once in a while. My corporate IT helped me to update the drivers for the docking station but this issue did not resolve. My headsets work no problem.

Cons : this USB hub DOES NOT POWER THE LAPTOP. So you need to keep the power adapter issued with the laptop plugged in AND you need to plug the power adapter in for the docking station. For a WFH office, this will not help you reduce your power strip needs. Honestly, you could get the same performance from a much cheaper off-brand device. If this was not paid for by work, I would have returned it.

For people who need power from their "docking station", my IT person says the Dell Thunderbolt docks (like the WD19TB) should work. Please check ahead with Dell before purchasing, since this information could be incorrect.

comment:
This is marketed as a Dell product, but Dell could have sold many more of them if they said it was universal for Windows because it is. I have now tested it on a Surface Laptop, an MSI gaming Laptop, a Thinkpad Workstation, and best of all, a Surface Go Tablet. The Surface Go is significant because it only has a single USBC and the Surface connect port. As you have probably noticed, if you're researching this product, it is made for USB-3, which uses the normal USB-A port. I discovered that it works with an adapter without any noticeable change in performance, at least if you are using standard monitors.

Modern computers don't have many ports, and this easily expands the number.
5 USB ports
1 Ethernet port
2 HDMI ports
1 Display Port

It effectively turns my Surface Go into a usable computer for desktop-type work, as long as too much processing power isn't required.

The only downside is that you have to use your computer's charger. This does not supply power to the computer and not just to non-Dells. It is not designed to charge the computer. That is the main difference between a USB-3 and a USB-C dock.

comment: So I read the reviews saying this unit ate up come CPU cycles while attached and it is true. I've tested this using a Youtube video, an actual video and general spreadsheet sort of things and here's my findings. First I'm using a new Surface pro 3 i7 (1.9, turboclock to 3.3 dual core with hyperthreading) 8GB RAM with an HP monitor at 1680x1050 of so you can compare the utilization for other devices. Watching youtube, I average about 7.3% utilization full screen on the one monitor. While watching a video capiable of 1080p using VLC I averaged about 8%. to note, VLC player spiked to 10% during playback so the actual player is still utilizaing more cycles. Lastly what seems to take up the most CPU utilization was moving the mouse around wildly peaking at 30%, sustaining around 26% and droping as low as 6%. As for networking, I pulled a file steady through the ethernet adapter at 20MBps (approx 160mbps). I tested with my hootoo usb dongle as well and got the same results so this is more than likley a limitation on my network (guess what I need to track down and fix). Lastly I tested USB using a Lexar USB 3.0 drive (older) and maintained a consistant 34MBps write (approx 272mbps) and 42.9MBps read (343.2 mbps). I didn't list any CPU utilization for these as they used less than 3% at any given time. Overall I'm very happy with the dock though I've only had it for a short while I think it was well worth the money. Also you might be asking why I picked this dock over the one built for the surface. 2 reasons, first this is capable of up to 3 monitors, the surface dock isn't. ALso I have a giant protecting case on the surface which doesn't fit within the dock and I'm not the type to take it on and off.

comment:
With an Ubuntu system there are still some strange things going on. To get everything working I need to boot with the dock connected, then disconnect and reconnect to get both the audio and displays going. Once the initial faffing about is done though it's great. All the ports work, and although the on-board audio jacks have been giving me problems lately; it's not a major problem for me since there is a headphones jack on my laptop.

It works great with two 1080p screens and I have tried it with three. It was usable but slightly laggy with composing window managers. The linux drivers are still in their early stages and have some ways to go. The main complaint is that each screen effectively uses a CPU core to transfer the frames from the GPU buffer to the device. For me this means I get ~6 of my 8 available processing cores most of the time. For me this isn't an issue since I don't use most of them anyway but if you don't have hyper-threading or a quad core CPU, then you might be in trouble.

There is a noticeable lag between the laptop's internal display and the USB powered displays but unless you were playing games with it I doubt you'll care too much.

All in all I think this is a great product and I would recommend it for someone who uses a laptop but often sits a a desk. It's well build and while the included USB3 cable is tiny that can be replaced if you really need to. The included display adaptor is a nice thought and works as advertised.

comment:
I know nobody reads 4-star reviews but I have to deduct one for the nonsense around screen resolution.

This is a great dock (had it ~1 week). Plenty of ports, including 2 USB 3.0 charging ports. Pretty small, fits great on my small-ish desk, etc. If you have multiple computers (work and a personal, like me), and you have a home desk setup that you're trying to streamline, this is a great choice.

The nonsense: the Dell product page (and the Amazon one) claims this will run a single 4K monitor and 2 full HD monitors. That tells me that I can easily use a 2K and a 1080p together. What it does NOT say, is that if you plug both monitors in using HDMI, it will scale them down to 2048 x 1152. You HAVE to use the DisplayPort in order to get anything above "Full HD", as Dell calls it. You can find the truth on the "Supported Resolutions on the Dell D3100 USB 3.0 Docking Station" page on the Dell Support site.

Otherwise, it's a great dock so far.

I ordered my Dell D3100 Docking Station via Amazon and have been very happy with it. I run a Thinkpad for work and managed to successfully run 2 additional monitors from this docking station as well as a third linked directly to the laptop. Overall I have been very happy with the fact that it actually works with the Thinkpad since they are notorious for being difficult with docking stations.

All that said, I purchased this item on 1/8/2020 and today is 1/6/2022 and it suddenly quit working. It seems to be that the unit is no longer able to get power. I'm a little annoyed that it only lasted under 2 years but if you need a docking station that will cooperate with Lenovo Thinkpads then this is a solid contender.

comment:
/// July 2016 Update ///

So, I tried editing some photos in Adobe Lightroom only to discover that images were not rendering in the Develop mode. When I plug the notebook directly into the monitor, I get no issues. Clearly the driver issues haven't been worked out yet for MacOS.

I deducted 1 star for the issue and hope that it gets resolved ASAP.

/// June 2016 Update ///

The audio issue was fixed. I needed to change the audio from computer to USB Audio in settings. Now the sound plays through the speakers.

//// Original Review ///

Please make sure you have the latest DisplayLink drivers for MacOS.

I use this dock with a 2014 MacBook Pro 15-inch (running OS X El Capitan) and 2 - Dell U2515H monitors. The monitors have a native resolution of 2560x1440 and the only way to make that work with this dock is using the DisplayPort along with one of the HDMI ports. It will not support that resolution with both HDMI outs plugged in.

I've only had the dock a week, but have noticed some scaling issues when activating Mission Control. The top menu (that displays the desktops) is slight clipped. Not a deal breaker, but i hope this gets resolved with a future software update.

There is also a noticeable flickering that happens with certain video/animation playback. Before I upgraded the drivers, YouTube was almost unwatchable, especially at full screen. That's fixed (installed driver ver 2.5.1), however when I run the iOS simulator (building iOS apps), the simulator screen with flicker when I'm switching views on an app. I may try to re-install the drivers to see if that resolved the issues I mentioned above.

Performance issues aside, the dock works for my needs. I could go back to just plugging the notebook up directly to the monitors w/ the Thunderbolt 2 ports, but this dock will be used w/ a PC laptop so it will do double duty.

I will provide updates if more problems arise or the issues I have get resolved.

comment:
I had doubts that it would work since this is the only USB 3.0 dock that I can find that can support higher than 1080p resolution for one monitor, and at the same time it's also the only dock I found that can do 3 monitors. I was worried that there will be some gotchas but there are none from what I see. I'm happy to say that it works well. My ultrabook isn't very powerful and it sometimes has a hard time displaying certain things over the 2560x1440 monitor, but I'm sure if your laptop is powerful enough it'll work fine.

My setup:
- Sony Vaio Pro 11" laptop
- Asus ROG Swift 2560x1440 monitor
- An old Philips CRT monitor
- Keyboard and mouse
- Ethernet network
- External hard drives

All of the above is working, except for the CRT (but that's because my HDMI-VGA cable is broken, so it's not the dock's fault)

I highly recommend this! So much better using a dock + a portable laptop over having a big heavy desktop computer.

EDIT: One drawback: plugging in a high resolution monitor can use up a good amount of CPU. When I play a youtube video on my 2560x1440 monitor for example, I see a process called "DisplayLinkManager" taking up 20-30% of my CPU usage. Not surprising, it's probably compressing all that data to fit through the USB3.0 port. I guess that's the caveat I was worried about. But it really doesn't bother me. But good to know. I'm sure this CPU usage will be higher the more monitors you plug in though!

EDIT2: I plugged in my CRT. Still works awesome :D CPU usage didn't noticeably increase either.

comment:
I just got this thing today and had to toy around with it a bit to get it to work, but after I got it all set up, it does exactly what I need. First and foremost, Dell's provided drivers aren't up to date. Fortunately the thing uses "Display Link" so you can DOWNLOAD THE LATEST DRIVERS HERE: [...]
Pros:
- Small form factor, dosn't take up a ton of space on your desktop.
- Uses your device's native video card for processing so if you have a high end GPU you can play games and perform other video intensive tasks
- Supports 3 monitors (2 HDMI and 1 Displayport which you can attach to virtually any monitors even if you have to use adapters). Extra USBs Ethernet, headphones, yay.
- Universal, works on any device running a supported OS and has a USB 3 port.

Cons:
- Not cheap, but you can't seriously expect it to be for this type of device
- Dell's provided drivers don't work on modern OSs, you'll have to seek out and install the latest DisplayLink Drivers to make it work.
- Because it's a universal dock, you'll still need a normal power plug on your device to power and charge it.

For people like me that use it to run a work or personal laptop at a desk that already has a desktop you'll need a separate KVM switch. Once you're all set up however it works like a charm.

comment: I recently started a new job creating customized SQL procedures and reporting, and my employer provides a notebook for me to work with. While at home, I needed much more screen real estate to be as effective as possible, and I chose this solution based upon my years of experience with Dell products. This meets and even exceeds my expectations. I have 2 27-inch HDMI monitors, and a 32-inch Sharp Aquos that I use as well. The docking station provides only 2 HDMI connections and 1 DisplayPort connection, so I had to pick up a third-party DisplayPort-to-HDMI adapter. I'm using a Gigabit Ethernet connection with this, plus I've connected a USB wireless keyboard/mouse combo through one of the USB 2.0 connectors on the back of the unit. The docking station is connected to the Toshiba Satellite notebook via a USB 3.0 connection. Setup took only minutes and everything works perfectly for me; I couldn't be more pleased. At my office I use a different brand USB 3.0 docking station, but the provided software intelligently knows which docking stations is plugged in at any time and maintains my monitor preferences and defaults without a hitch. What I do doesn't require the same type of horsepower as gaming, but it does require crystal clear, FullHD visuals as I'm often working with tiny text and graphics that must be perfectly aligned in a final product. The fact that this also supports UltraHD gives me an upgrade path to support a future notebook and monitors. I couldn't be more satisfied.

comment:
Very pleased with final results. Using dual HDMI monitors with Mac mini, M1 chip.
Well executed design handling all the negations with the various I/O's invisibly.
Getting to the happy place was solo exercise due to the lack of documentation. One good tech writer could have spent an afternoon compiling a good setup instruction document. I spent a few hours learning how the Mac talks to the docking station and how to make best use of the product.
Highly recommend this product for filling out the Mac Mini's features.
I was pleased with the DisplayLink manager once I had the wires place correctly. Learning how to make the various connections with the many ports could have been a 5 minute job with a good one page setup.
When the DisplayLink Manager asks for permission to record your screen - Grant Permission! This is essential to using multi monitors.
4 stars ofr Tech Support and Overall.

comment:
This review is for the USB 3.0 Triple Monitor Dock (D3100)

I am in the middle of upgrading my desk to two identical desks to utilize more of my technology more efficiently.

I purchased this dock to be able to utilize my home set up of triple monitors with a USB cable and a power cable.

I have had this connected with a USB 3.0 B to USB C to a Lenovo work computer (Win10, i7, 16GB memory) as well as a USB 3.0 B to USB 3.0 A to an Asus tablet (Win8, i5m, 4GB memory) and to a home built computer tower (Win7, i5, 16GB memory). I'm not listing the graphics in each machine due to the lack of GPU usage for pushing the triple monitors.

The Lenovo and the tower are amazing with this system as the triple monitors in use add about 2 GB of memory usage. The tablet, though capable, does not support the triple monitors as smoothly. This is equally true with a dual display dock that I picked up. 4GB of memory just isn't enough to seamlessly use multiple monitor docks and Win7 or Win8, I do not know how Win10 deals with low memory amounts.

comment:
Ok no 5 stars here. The description cleverly says is has a displayport cable but the "what's in the box" does not. So you DO NOT get the cable you need to run 4k out the box. I'm about to pull the trigger for a 4k monitor since I set this up this weekend. Boom. No cable so you need to buy one. In these days I would expect Dell, a company I hold in high regard, to get the product description clear.
Other than that, I hook up the box to my inspiron 15 7559 4k laptop and then download the DisplayLink software. Adjust where the monitors go (in the win 10 settings). It auto-grabs the audio and pipes it to any hdmi device on it with speakers. I put it back to the laptop speakers to get computer control over sound.
However, it just works fine. I have a standard HD 32", 28" and my laptop screens all going at the same time. I'm going to order a 4k display and will need to order a cable for it. No big deal, but something to order when you order this box. You pay extra to route the 4k which is specifically the reason to buy the box.

comment:
This docked started off great, and I still use it today. However, with the latest Windows 10 anniversary update, quality has gone down. My screen now fails to redraw changed areas, and I think it's this device failing to detect the change and update my screen. I'll be editing code and switch to another file, and nothing updates. If I scroll up or down, suddenly I can see the new file, but the screen never drew the content when I flipped tabs. This happens a dozen times an hour, sometimes more, in all my applications. It's hard to describe without seeing it, but imagine you opened a web page and the top 1/3 of the page drew as if it rendered fine, but the bottom 2/3s were still white as if the page hadn't loaded at all. Then you scroll the page and instantly the entire page appears just as it should. Now imagine that behavior in every application you use, a dozen times an hour, and never know if it's a redraw issue, lag, or what, but then you realize it's a redraw issue.

If they got that problem fixed, I'd bump right back to 5 stars. It's an amazing device, frankly. For me, it's driving two 1920x1200 displays PLUS one 2560x1440. And it did a _great_ job up until the anniversary update.

As it stands, I can still work ok, but am getting annoyed. I'm seriously contemplating a new computing solution to eliminate this device, because I can't be working with that sort of irritation for potentially many more months. I work from home full-time on this machine.

I believe this redraw issue is related to just the device for 2 reasons. One, if I'm using my laptop as just a laptop with the built-in screen, I notice no issues. And two, if it were a widespread Windows problem, the internet would be in an uproar and it would have been fixed already.

comment:
The top thing that I liked about this as I was researching which one to get was that it has two HDMI ports. A bonus that it also has a DisplayPort, but using that will come later when I have another monitor. That will make it so that I will be able to have four monitors, which, as a software engineer, will be a very welcome addition. I'm only running at 1080 right now, but will eventually look to run a few 2k monitors through it. Seems like this should be able to handle that quite well.

Size is also a big positive. This thing is about the size of my hand (from the base of my palm to the end of my fingers). Given my setup, I could use a bit longer USB cord that goes from this docking station to my laptop, but that's not a fault of the device, itself, and is easily remedied. I don't mind that it doesn't have power to supply to my laptop, but to some people that might be a nice-to-have. I do also like having the 3 USB ports (including one fit for charging devices) and headphone jack on the front. I haven't used the speaker jack, so no real input on that, but the audio feeds through both HDMI cables to my monitors and provides audio that I'm perfectly fine with.

comment: I have a Dell Latitude 5500 which was not on the list but figure since this is a Dell product this dock should be able to work since the other Dell Docks are crap. I have the Dell WD15 and that is a piece of crap compare to this dock. The Dell 3.0 has 2 HDMI inputs and a displayport for your screens. Not sure why I given got the crappy WD15, when this dock is so much better and cost half the price. It seems to work on other devices too, and it was just as easy to setup and get it working. Plugged my Surface Pro into the USB 3.0 and bam, wouldn't you know it I have 3 additional screens plus my itty bitty Surface Pro working. Didn't know why I didn't go with this dock sooner. If you are looking to get 3 monitors hooked up to your laptop, this Dell dock will do the job.

comment: The new M1 chip MacBooks released by Apple is flawed given that it's new and new prototypes often go through the growing stages before later models in the next years. Since the M1 chip is new, you can't just use any docking station to connect to more than 1 monitor. As this is one of the docking stations i've came across that can connect a MacBook Pro w/ M1 chip to more than 1 monitor. Since the only 2 ports embedded in the laptop other than a headphone jack is USB-C connection, you have to purchase a USB-C to USB-A dongle to connect the Dell docking station to the MacBook. Other than that hurdle, I would say this docking station is worth it as it is functions as it advertises. It has many ports: 5 USB, 2 HDMI, VGA, headphone/microphone, and power port. I would give this 10/10

comment: Here is what I will say. It requires a driver from Dell, no biggie, just install it. Though many others dont require one, so it is an extra step. It works great and I have all my devices connected and hidden under my desk. It is very clean. The one negative I have found. If you change your devices around, I mean monitors specifically, it remembers the device is connected to a port, even if you unplug and turn off the device. The docking station thinks it is there. So anything you had on the monitor you just removed, is still trying to display on the monitor. Easy fix. Unplug the power to the docking station to let it reset. Then plug it back in. It clears the dock memory.

comment:
I bought this dock to set up my 3 monitors on my desktop. It works GREAT! I read some helpful reviews prior to making this purchase. A previous reviewer stated that you should run the software setup disc on your computer before you hooking up the monitors to avoid troublesome setup issues. I did this and the installation was flawless.

The only issue, and the reason I dropped 1 star off, is that one of my 3 monitors sporadically cuts off and on at times. At first I thought it was the monitor. However, while switching cables around a few times, I realized that whatever monitor was connected to the DisplayPort via an adaptor to HDMI was the one that would do it. So, I'm attributing this to the dock. This issue was noted in a review for the Dell Monitors I bought, but I realized that it wasn't the monitors at all. I will try to troubleshoot this issue if it continues.

Overall, I LOVE this dock. It opened up my whole desktop world. Even the 3 front USB ports are a dream for connecting phones, iPods, USB sticks, or other peripherals. And the best part is that it works with any computer. Dell got it right with this one. I'll be buying more for my kids when they are ready for multiple monitors.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 Ultra HD/4K ä¸‰é‡é¡¯ç¤ºåŸºåº§ï¼ˆD3100ï¼‰ï¼Œé»‘è‰²
comment: This device works exceptionally well, very small, light weight, and well done. I tried a few others in the past, one that had a pass through power, which didn't have enough juice to power 3 monitors, and another that was basically a conglomeration of cables and cable adapters. This box has the juice to drive 3 standard monitors using 2 HDMI and one Display port. I also (just for fun) plugged in 2 Asus USB3 Side Monitors as well, driving 5 monitors in total off this little box, and it did not overtax my laptop in the least bit. Very impressive! The unit will heat up a bit when driving many monitors, but nothing scary, just warm to the touch. When I drive the two side monitors with my other laptop directly, the videocard goes haywire trying to keep up and the fans sound like a jet engine. But this is running on a small Lenovo Yoga with only an I5 and standard Yoga video card, which I believe is an Intel on board card. Teh Triple Display box does all the video card heavy lifting. I would not try this for gaming as I believe it will render best only at low performance given the internals, but it is GREAT for standard business use when you just need additional displays for work.

comment:
I needed a couple of cheap workstations for an auto workshop and purchased two of these, a week apart. Both are functional, but the two computers appear to have been refurbished by different companies, have differing hardware, and different issues. The included keyboards and mice were also of differing brands, though these peripherals were brand new on both computers.

7050 #1
-------------
The good: Arrived well packaged in professionally produced protective padding, with labeling indicating that it was refurbished by "CNB Computers". Computer itself was absolutely pristine and looked brand new. This unit was assembled in Mexico. Opening the top confirmed that it had a new 256Gb SSD as advertised and the correct RAM. Again, the interior was immaculate and didn't have even the slightest sign of dust or wear. The unit did include an empty M.2 slot, had an internal M.2 wireless adapter, and included the wifi antenna.

The bad: The included power supply was not powerful enough to boot the computer fully, forcing the computer to run in "low battery mode" at less than 1Ghz. It was EXTREMELY slow. Connecting it to an appropriate power supply fixed this problem. The included power supply was not usable. Additionally, for some reason, the Windows installation keeps installing Spanish language components. An OS reset did not fix this problem, and a clean OS installation will be my next move. I'll update the review if this resolves the problem.

7050 #2
-----------
The good: Arrived quickly with documentation indicating that it was refurbished by "SJ Computers". Included the proper Dell power supply and booted immediately without any problems. This unit was assembled in China. Opening the top revealed that it contained a 256Gb M.2 drive, and not the slower SSD that was advertised (that's a bonus!) USB wifi dongle was attached to exterior of the case. The licensed Windows installation ran without issues or errors.

The bad: The unit was poorly packaged using cardboard and shrink wrap with very little to protect it. The case itself was FILTHY, with dust and sharpie marks on the case immediately noticeable. Someone had tried to scribble out some of the printing on the exterior. The rear of the case showed some bending, suggesting that the unit was dropped or crushed at some point. The filler for the serial port was missing, opening a hole in the back of the case. These issues were purely cosmetic. Internally, I found even more dust in the fan and air vents. It was obvious that it had been cleaned, but not nearly as thoroughly as the first unit. This unit also did not include the internal wifi adapter or antenna, swapping them out for the USB dongle instead.

Overall, I'm fairly happy with both units for the price. While both computers had minor issues and required some work before putting them to use, these are a steal for the price. Spending an additional fifteen dollars on a new power supply, or a half-hour removing some dust and cleaning up a marked case, is a small price to pay for the price/performance ratio of these computers. I wouldn't use them as my main computer, but they're a good option if you're looking for a cheap workstation or a media PC.

Update: Clean OS installation did fix 7050 #1. That computer is now working without any problems. HOWEVER. I utterly failed to notice that the case for 7050 #2 was completely wrong! Those sharpie marks I mentioned? Yeah, they were covering the fact that it's an Optiplex 5050 case. It contains a 7050 motherboard and works fine, but the USB C port doesn't fit correctly. My guess is that the PC was crushed at some point (the bent rear I mentioned) and they just replaced the case top with whatever they had lying around. It sort of works, but it's very unprofessional. Between the dust and the damage, I no longer believe that any real effort was put into refurbishing 7050 #2. If this were being installed anywhere other than an auto shop, I'd be sending it back for an exchange.

Update 2: Reached out to SJ Computers about the top not fitting and some of the physical damage. The company immediately shipped me a new system to replace the #2 unit. The replacement looks brand new. No damage, no problems. Opened the top and it's as clean as the day it was built. Absolutely no problems with it whatsoever, and the vendor was great to work with. Adding a star.

comment:
PROS: Good enough for a simple VM testbench.

CONS: Half assembled, horrible smoke/funk stench inside. A poor condition Power Brick that came from a school. Outdated BIOS <-- Real Issue

I could look pass the unit was not completely put back together.
I could look pass the horrible smoke/funk stench inside.
The Outdated BIOS crippled everything possible I wanted to use the unit for. I replaced the SSD with a new one. I installed Windows 10 32 Nit, but soon as Windows updates, I get a Blue Screen of DEATH. Dell BIOS has a security feature that is too far outdated in the Bios. I spent countless time on google to fix this. Nothing I tried worked. If I keep it offline without updating, Windows 10 32 Bit works fine. I have no interest in Windows 64-bit OS. I will use this as a Linux Box for basic testing.

Considering what mini-pc cost, this unit was NOT worth the price. My rating is a result of Dell's outdated Bios, but considering the condition of the equipment, I stand firm on my rating.

comment:
The description was very unclear on if this device included on-board wifi, or a card, or a USB dongle, etc.

Unfortunately the reviews were also very inconsistent on this.

The computer arrived and is functional, but the wifi is only a little chinese-made garbage no-name USB 2.0 wifi 'dongle' the size of my fingernail - similar to what you get with a wireless mouse/keyboard.

It doesn't have modern wifi (dual band, etc), and USB 2.0 is going to really impact possible speeds.

This also has the drawback of requiring a USB port that I might have otherwise needed.

This may be fine for some folks but removing a star because I had to buy the computer to find out, and then had to order a different modern wifi device.

comment: Dell Optiplex 7050 Micro PC is about the size of paperback book! I mounted the PC behind my 27" Planar monitor with a Mount from Humancentric. Will be looking 2 buy a 2nd Dell 7050 for other home office.

comment:
Review for: Dell OptiPlex 7050 Micro Computer, Intel Quad Core i5-6500T up to 3.1GHz, 16G DDR4, 256G SSD, Windows 10. ALthough site didn't mention it, it also came with wifi and antenna, and Bluetooth.

Cost me about $150 for above microcomputer by itself in Dec. 2022. This system looked new, worked flawlessly, and after a very brief setup ran smoothly. Setup consisted of plugging everything in and letting windows update. No codes or anything needed. I also bought a HDMI to HDMI connector (amazon basics) for around $10 and wireless keyboard with touch-pad (Logitech k400+) for ~$30 to use the whole system with my 4k tv so I can stream more easily, and use YouTube on with Firefox with "ublock origin" to effectively block all adds so my kid can watch KLT on YouTube without being bombarded with advertisements. This system works great for that. System is more than powerful enough for glitch-less operation.

comment: I love the Dell Optiplex Micro models. I have purchase them for, and referred them to, my customers. This refurbished model is an excellent value for the money, especially with prices of new computers on the rise. I had been able to purchase refurbished Dell Optiplex computers through Amazon without any concern until the past few months. It really matters which company refurbishes the computers. I had to return several because of bad memory modules, the inability to run dual display monitors using the native video adapters, or a toxic smell from paint that was sprayed on the exterior of the computer (totally unnecessary). I always swap out the used hard drive or used solid-state drive with a new, larger, solid-state drive, so I cannot tell you about the condition of the drives. This computer arrived problem free. This refurbisher is doing a good job.

comment:
Got one of these to let the parents browse with a slightly faster than on their old pentium core duo. Dad called me and said it got really hot, turned on, then wouldn't turn on, with LED light was flashing. The code indicates "dead motherboard". So I took it apart and repasted the CPU, tested different configurations of ram, etc, just to make sure before reaching out to support. I looked for the "90 day support" provider and found it was "203 Trading LLC.". I stated the issue and asked if I could buy a replacement motherboard (no cpu) because it was already outside of 90 days. They were nice and and sent new power brick out of warranty, but I was pretty clear with them that I was confident it was a dead motherboard. New power brick didn't end up fixing the issue, and then they ghosted me after I told them the motherboard is still dead.

Old PCs should keep running. This is just an example of planned obsolescence by Dell. I'm sure it's as little as poor solder cracking due to it's age, and could have been prevented by 0.002 cents of slightly higher quality component on that failure point.

tl;dr dead in less than a year, probably motherboard.

comment:
I originally bought this to use as a backup utility computer (for some home automation), as it was cheaper than a Raspberry Pi 4. After it arrived, I was so impressed that I actually let it do all of the Windows updates. Now I am using it as a secondary Windows computer to augment my Mac and Linux environment.

The computer literally looks brand new. The device will never work with Windows 11, but that is Microsoft's flaw. (The processor does not meet the minimal standards.) The date code on the device puts it age at about three years plus a few months.

So, all in all I'm really satisfied (and surprised) that this purchase worked out so well. I didn't have high expectations, but I ended up very impressed.

theproduct: Dell OptiPlex 7050 å¾®å‹é›»è…¦,Intel å››æ ¸å¿ƒ i5-6500T é«˜é” 3.1GHz ,16G DDR4,256G SSD,Windows 10 Pro 64 ä½å…ƒå¤šèªè¨€æ”¯æ´è‹±æ–‡/è¥¿ç­ç‰™æ–‡/æ³•æ–‡(çºŒç´„ ) )
comment:
The computer was well packaged with adequate bubble wrap. The included power supply is a genuine Dell 130 watt unit which is twice the power required by this device.

The computer came with the wrong front cover installed. This model has one USB-A & one USB-C port on the front panel. The included cover has openings for two USB-A ports which leaves an unsightly gap around the USB-C socket.

The vendor removed a sticker from the front panel and left a substantial gouge in the plastic. They did not remove the adhesive residue which required a few minutes work with alcohol to eliminate.

I removed the cover to inspect the internals and found a large wad of lint in the fan housing. A few toots of canned air removed it.

I fired the unit up and ran updates. Functionally everything seems fine.

Bottom line: I am not impressed by the vendors refurbishment process. Definitely NOT Excellent condition.

comment: Lots of computer for a little money. Mine came equipped better than advertised from ReviveIT. Some light dust internally, not a problem. I5 6600t. 256Gb SSD with fresh registered copy win 10 pro. Lots of updates. Open M.2 slot. 16GB ddr4 memory. WiFi/Bluetooth card with antenna. Dell 65w power supply. Cheap HP keyboard and HP mouse. Scratch on case, not really a concern at this price point especially when you factor in the upgraded CPU. Iâ€™m super happy with mine. Fairly legit computer for the price of a gimpy raspberry pi. Planning to run virtual box on it, to try out multiple OSes, sandbox environment. A lot more efficient than my normal rig (dual xenon 16 core /32 thread 1400w workstation) even though less powerful.

comment: I ordered this micro form factor computer refurbished by SJ Computers and received not long after order. My first issue is with the peripherals supplied, as someone that works in IT security there is no way I am plugging a no name USB adapter into a computer on my network that was not in a box and just taped to the top of the machine. Two days after receiving it and setting it up the computer began to not booting reliably, I believe it was a faulty power supply. This being a micro form factor computer the power supply is in the cord/ brick. I contact SJ computers as required by Amazon and was instructed to mail the "tower" back and they would mail a replacement. I reiterated many times to 2 or 3 different customer support people at SJ computers that I needed to also get a new cord / brick for the computer. The new machine shows up about 4 days later without a power supply. I call SJ computers again - request an overnight shipment of a power cord as this computer runs my CNC machine for my business. 5 days later I recieve a power brick that is not the factory power supply for the Dell 7050 but rather a Dell laptop supply with a fitting to work with the microform factor. This is not what I ordered - I ordered a refurb 7050 with the factory power supply, what I currently have is some cobbled together parts to make something work. - I would recommend finding any other refurbished retailer than this one.

comment: I bought three of these for a project. The first one booted after giving a warning about being unable to detect power adapter output. The other two refused to boot with an alert that the adapter was 90W and it required 130W or greater. While the first one did boot it cripples itself sticking the processor at .79GHz/800MHz. After some research it turns out that this is a known issue with Dell systems if the power adapter is not properly detected as the correct wattage. Getting support through Amazon is a crap shoot. No way to contact seller directly. Two separate customer support agents had technical issues according to the chat and disconnected. By the time third one showed up over 30 minutes into this, I had enough. Just going to return and try a different option.

comment: I was expecting more performance from this system. It comes installed with Win10, but it is barely usable. I performed a PassMark benchmark on it and it's in the 3rd percentile for memory performance. THIRD PERCENTILE! Even the CPU is only in the 4th percentile! I've never tested a system this slow before. My Intel NUC of an older year blows this computer out of the water by 10x. Luckily, since I'm running basic Linux services, the performance isn't a dealbreaker. But I can't imagine this thing being used for anything else.

theproduct: Dell UltraSharp U3423WE 34 å‹ WQHD æ›²é¢è¢å¹• WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 21:9
comment:
Coming from an iMac 27" 5k Retina display, I was fixated on finding a good, large 4k monitor for my new MacBook Pro M2. I finally realized even the native iMac display was set at 1440p vertical resolution (though it has about the double the pixel density of the Dell, which makes for a very sharp image). So I became less hesitant about trying a 34" ultra wide of which there are a few to choose from.

The Dell Ultrasharp throws a very nice image and while it can't match the 5K Retina display's pixel count, it still does not disappoint. Small text is ever-so-slightly less sharp and this is most noticeable with bold type. After using it for about an hour, I'm over the 5K obsession.

The wide, curved screen is excellent for business use (like editing text docs side-by-side) and the 60Hz refresh rate is more than adequate here. I'm not a gamer so can't comment on that aspect of monitor specs. Not a photo/video editor either, so no opinion on things like color matching.

The primary USB-C upstream port provides 90w of power and the MacBook immediately recognized the monitor and set the proper resolution. Scaling is flawless. The assortment of built-in ports can also eliminate the need for a separate docking station or hub, depending on your exact needs.

Finally, the one shortcoming: sound. Speakers are adequate for business use and casual music playing, but are not going to impress any audiophiles. Plan on upgrading to standalone speakers if your needs are beyond the basic.

The stand is quite sturdy and heavy, with height and tilt adjustments. Really happy with the choice so far, and the spacious screen plus Mac's virtual desktop functionality opened up a whole new world of usefulness for me.

comment:
I could not express how hot this thing gets. The battery life is also horrible.

The laptop wouldn't even be turned on for more than 10 mins and you can barely place your hand onto the back of the laptop due to the massive amount of heat that's coming off of it. I've also read this laptop would have thermal throttling. I didn't believe it until I had one myself.

I would not and could not recommend this laptop to anyone.

I had this laptop for a day and I returned it.

Besides the heat issue this laptop looks and feels absolutely amazing. I loved the sleek Ness, touch screen, and display quality.

Sadly I just wished the battery life was a lot better and the laptop wouldn't heat up so much.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ UltraSharp U2723QE 27 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
Anyone who may be struggling to read at their computer needs to try this monitor before getting reading glasses, especially if you're in your 40s and on the tail edge of needing correction when using a computer. This monitor has a much higher PPI than a standard 1080p computer screen, the text is much sharper and the images are crisp. I was looking for a comparable screen to the Apple Studio Display and this is probably the closest you will get for the price! I can buy almost 3 of these before getting 1 Studio Display, and honestly the Studio Display is VERY pretty and has 5K resolution instead of 4K but I don't think most people's eyes will notice a difference.

I am using this with a MacBook Air M1 with 16GB RAM and it works perfectly, I've never had any issues with the screen. The trick is to set it to 1920x1080 (Default) instead of 1920x1080 low resolution. With the "Default" setting you will get the higher PPI but the monitor will SCALE up so your text size does not shrink. If you set this to 3840x2160 which is the native 4K resolution, your text will be very tiny and hard to read. With the 1920x1080 (Default) setting I get the best of both worlds so I'm very happy.

I have not tried to use the hub on this, but this has a ton of ports. I already have a DisplayLink dual monitor dock (which this works perfectly with), so I did not need to plug all my USB and other cables into the back of the monitor.

This display looks very attractive, the bezels are thin and disappear into the display. I heard the speakers suck, but I don't need it for that so I've not tried it. I removed the built in stand and mounted this to my VESA arm mount and it fits perfectly.

Just get this monitor, you won't regret it!!!!

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ UltraSharp U2723QE 27 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
I bought this thinking it would be a good KVM-capable monitor. I was mostly right.

The monitor has a great picture, calibrated color, and a really nice design. I cannot fault the monitor performance in any significant way.

The KVM situation is better than almost any solution I have seen, but it has a way to go.

First, one thing that may not be obvious in the various descriptions and reviews is that this monitor does not accommodate two USB-C power/data/monitor connections or even two connections with video/peripherals via single USB-C connections.

You get one USB-C power/video/peripherals connection plus a second connection that is your choice of HDMI or Displayport plus a separate USB-C connection for peripherals. I think this should have been done differently, namely by allowing a second USB-C video/peripheral connection. If you're buying a $600 calibrated 4k screen, you're probably connecting to a USB-C laptop and a desktop that does it too (in my case, a Thinkpad and a Mac Studio).

Second, the huge Achille's heel in the KVM setup is that to send a hotkey signal to switch sources, the computer involved has to be logged in. This makes zero sense. Your keyboard is connected through the monitor, and the monitor should be capable of recognizing ALT+P (or Control-P on a Mac) and switching without relying on the Dell Peripheral Manager software (just like a hardware-only KVM would). When you are trying to switch from a host machine on its lock screen, you have to reach behind the monitor and operate the little joystick to switch sources. This is bad software design compounded by industrial design that is hostile to users. If you can't make the monitor catch the hotkey "switch" signal, at least put the source switch on the front and make it one-touch. Note to Dell: Samsung isn't good enough to copy. Look at how NEC handled it with some of their Multisync monitors.

The overall design could be improved slightly as well, hence four stars.

What is up with the port placement? Don't get me wrong - I love having a million ports on a monitor (and this is one of the great things about Dell workstation monitors), but could they be easier to access and have cord exits that are a little more logical? I get the USB-C and USB-B ports on the bottom front edge, but unless you are good with a hand mirror and have perfect coordination, you basically have to wire this monitor resting on the screen, before you put it on the desk. Otherwise, you can't rotate the screen enough to add more cables (USB-C cables and HDMI cables are very stiff, and if you have a lot of them, it can be surprisingly tough to maneuver in new ones).

Having all of the ports face-down presents another novel problem - which is that it's tough to route cables for invisibility to the user. Dell might reconsider and make all ports face straight out from the back - the idea that anyone is ever really looking at the back of a monitor is a fiction reinforced by hair salons, art galleries, and the iMacs on which their employees pretend to work but are really using to cruise the internet all day. The U2723QE is a very serious, functional monitor that is being bought by professionals, and it's more important that the various ports be visible and useful than getting too much into playing petit-Apple. A velcro-equipped wire loom (fabric tube) would work fine.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ UltraSharp U2723QE 27 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
My main monitor has been an old 2K 144hz ASUS which I have always appreciated for gaming, but I needed more desktop space to work with video, graphics and general office work. I opted for a dual-display setup with a monitor more geared towards gaming and this Dell monitor for everything else. To these ends it has been exceptional - 4K estate with pleasant and accurate colors, adequate brightness (unless you really need HDR tonality) for daytime use and night use, and a good looking frame.

When I'm using it for video and document editing I am very pleased with it - except at night when even a fairly low lamp some twenty feet behind me casts a noticeable haze on the screen. For the most part I got over it, though my old ASUS is pitch black and matte and the difference is silly. Along with this there is a slight bleed of inconsistent light from the edges when I view the screen entirely black, but it's not noticeable during general work. For video editing generally it's more than adequate and probably about as good as the many options I had spent weeks looking at, but unlike some, text and general use looks fantastic, which I really appreciate with the amount of text I am looking at. As a side quirk, the quick menu joystick is uninspiring, offering easy presets between color spaces, but if I want to change brightness (such as from day to night time), it is cumbersome.

This is not a gaming monitor, I will note, though I do not hold that too much against it because it is not the monitor I use for that. I was hopeful I could play RTS or city-management type games, that aren't dependent on fast play-style, in 4K to at least see them gorgeously, but as soon as there is any movement, the ghosting is apparent and cumbersome and ruins the benefit of the resolution. I tried a few FPS games on it, and I will say I would not bother trying them further - though perhaps I am just used to faster refreshing screens now and that has limited a regular 60 hz appeal.

But again, this is not a gaming monitor. For office use (despite the reflections) and video or visual editing (as long as you don't depend on HDR, which few monitors in this class will accurately represent), it's hard to go wrong with this monitor, and it has managed those capacities much to my delight and productive ease. Despite the many other options I chose this over, I have no regrets and comfortably use it daily.

comment: I've been buying Dell monitors for years and this works very well. My previous Dell 4K monitor needed Dell's video driver (instead of the Windows/Intel video driver) but this worked fine as soon as I used the DisplayPort port instead of HDMI as this handled 4K better. It was a good thing I had a couple of display ports on my laptop's docking station.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ UltraSharp U2723QE 27 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
The connectivity is great for Macbook Air M1. One 1-meter USB-C cable (included) does it all, but it could be a bit longer. This gets you Video + Data, audio line out of the monitor jack, and more USB ports than you'll likely ever need, plus supplies power to the Macbook.

I'm using it mainly for online piano lessons, replacing a 20 year old Dell Ultrasharp that kept disconnecting from the Macbook, probably because I had to use HDMI through an adapter to the Macbook. It was very annoying. I have to use an external monitor with the Macbook as the screen is just too small, (keep that in mind if you're shopping for a Macbook.)

I tried to monitor on both my PC and Macbook Air, and although smaller than the Alienware monitor on my PC, the 4K looked really good on 4K-youtube videos. You should keep in mind though that 4K requires a higher speed plus if you have a data limit, you might just go over it if you watch 4K everyday all day. If you buy a 4K TV to use all day long you'll probably need to upgrade your monthly ISP plan.

On a side note, I have a Kawai MP11SE digital piano and am leaning piano through Playground Sessions. Everything connected automatically without having to search through the Kawai manual to find the right settings, (unlike my Roland piano which required a lot of Googling.) The monitor's line out jack connects to the Kawai's line-in jacks, controlled by a slider to match the piano's volume. Everything was easy plug&play, especially since the monitor's audio was available through the USB-C cable. I thought I was going to have to buy cables to connect to the Macbooks headphone output.

comment:
I actually purchased two of these monitors to use alongside my Apple MacBook pro M1 Max 14" notebook. To provide me with a single cable solution I also added a CalDigit TS4 Thunderbolt Dock. I plug the computer into the dock with a single Thunderbolt 4 cable (included with the dock), and then plug each monitor into the TB4/USB-C ports on the back of the dock. Everything works EXCEPT that I have to enable a Display setting in macOS: "Battery & Energy -> Prevent automatic sleeping on power adapter when the display is off." If you don't do that, then the MBP has "issues" detecting the displays properly after extended sleep (this is not a problem with the displays, it's a known bug in macOS that Apple has so far refused to fix).

Excellent monitors. Super sharp. I have one turned to portrait mode and the other to landscape. Had to get used to it (after using an ultrawide for ten years).

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ UltraSharp U2723QE 27 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment: The monitor is everything it's advertised to be: great color, rez, size and price. HOWEVER, is you're adding sound to this monitor (there are no speakers) please make sure that your system has an available usb-c port. You will need to run a usb-c to usb-c cable from your computer to the "upstream usb-c" port on the monitor in addition to the HDMI or Display Port cable. So just to recap: if you are connecting your computer to this monitor by way of HDMI cable or Display Port cable, you will ALSO need to run a usb-c cable from your computer to the monitor in order to get sound. Another related point of frustration is trying to use the KVM to attach two computers to this monitor. In order to use the KVM, you have to prove to the monitor that each computer has an HDMI or Display Port cable attached AND that each has an upstream usb-c attached at the same time... not sure how you do that since there is only one upstream port on the monitor. Even with these technicalities, it is still a beautiful display. If your looking for something similar, but not as rich, check out the Dell S2721QS 27 Inch 4K UHD (3840 x 2160) it already has speakers built in, is half the price and is a lot less headache for the uninitiated.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ UltraSharp U2723QE 27 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
I have an Apple Studio monitor and this Dell U2723QE UltraSharp 4K USB-C Hub Monitor - 27-inch looks pretty darn good. The Apple is 5K and this Dell is 'only' 4K but the picture quality looks good.

One of the reasons i selected this monitor is the KVM capability. Besides my main Mac I want to connect an Apple Mini to it. I haven't done that yet but I think I know how.

The biggest difference between this monitor and my Apple monitor is ease of use. I hooked up the Apple monitor and it worked. I had to figure out how to hook this one up. Maybe it is because this one has the KVM but it took a while to get it to work. Dell has a lot of online manuals but I find them less than easy to understand

I do like the Dell stand to VESA mount system. It is easy to remove the stand, or not put it on in the first place, and attach the VESA plate to the back of the monitor. Unfortunately Dell put in too short screws that cannot be used with the VESA plate. I have a VESA mounting kit with lots of various size screws and was able to cobble something together. It's too bad Dell cannot provide long enough screws.

It's not perfect but I am judging it on its video quality and that is 5 star.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ UltraSharp U2723QE 27 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
I was initially quite impressed with this monitor, but then as time goes, I decided to purchase this identical model at different time for my main residence, also vacation residence, a total of three that gets quite expensive fast but I thought initially it's was worth it.

Pros:
UV Filteration Protection
Deeper black color space.
USB-C Alt Display Mode+ USB Hub built in, 1 x DP, 1 x HDMI

Cons:
* White color space is way off if side-by-side (I have 2 monitors at vacation home, hardly powered regardless its purchased months apart)
* USB-C port I can not seem to get beyond 4k@30Hz on both Dell Precision and Gigabyte Aero Thunderbolt Docking station ports with out some sort of adapter, recent discovery.
* I work hard also like to have enjoy my break time through out the day, switching to my gaming laptop input on this particular monitor is that more annoying, including DellDisplay Manager app which does not support newer AltDisplay mode to HDMI/DP through docking stations through .

Summary:
I am a Thunderbolt dedicated user, using factory short cable long cable, 70$ expensive active thunderbolt cable, different TB-Docking stations, I've done it all.

* My Dell Precision 5540 - mentioned in spec it has limited support to 4K @ 30Hz (if direct Thunderbolt connection is made as AltMode display). But depending on my Docking Station + HDMI adapter connected hardware it does allow 4K @ 60Hz (such as using Docktek HDMI 8K adapter)
* My Gigabyte Aero 15 gaming laptop (windows 11) - it should support 4K@60Hz with no issue with no specific docking required or adapter via Type-C connection

What I think this monitor truly annoying part is switching between inputs through out the day, if you are frequent input switcher between work & play be aware, you might end up needing a dedicated external HDMI switch box, that adds up even more $.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ UltraSharp U2723QE 27 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
On paper, this monitor is great. It's an Rtings pick with solid picture quality. Hardware feels solid too. The OSD is very sane and rotates 90 degrees (love that). I love how many ports are on this thing -- the sheer number of USB ports makes this thing a real dock.

I bought this as dock-monitor hybrid -- now that USB-C is picking up steam, I wanted a second monitor that I could keep plugged into my PC and peripherals that I can switch over to my work MacBook with a single cable. This is very close to solving that problem, but falls frustratingly short. After connecting it to my PC via Displayport, I switched it over to my MacBook with a USB-C 3.1 / 3.2 gen 1 / 10Gbps cable. Hooray -- it didn't light itself on fire. But this is where the problems start.

First off, the experience was crazy laggy compared to the USB-C experience on my Acer Predator X34 GS. I think that, with peripherals taking up some of the USB-C bandwidth, 4K@60hz is just too much. But even for a 30hz monitor, it feels more sluggish than it should for some reason. Making things worse, I couldn't find an easy way of reducing the monitor's resolution to mitigate this, so at work I'm stuck with a sluggish monitor. Hilariously, despite my peripherals being connected to this Dell monitor, everything felt smooth on the X34 -- maybe this is entirely on video stream compression lag.

Then, I decided to take a break and unplugged my MacBook. Now, the monitor doesn't recognize my PC over DisplayPort *at all* (still haven't fixed this), which is pretty funny since the X34 GS I'm typing this on now handled the switchover perfectly. And to make matters worse, my wireless Logitech mouse doesn't work until I physically yank and re-plug-in its dongle.

What's the point of a dock monitor if it's sluggish at work and then forgets your stuff exists at play?
