theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment:
I'm reviewing this monitor after about six weeks of use.

Good
- Wonderfully sharp display quality makes text and images crisp and easy on the eyes.
- Gets really bright, which helps those of us with aging eyes see small text better.
- Color quality is decent for office work.
- Really nice to plug in one cable that provides all the device connections and powers the laptop. USB-C hub works great with laptops that support power delivery over a USB-C connection, such as the 2020 MacBook Pro and Surface Laptop Studio (at slower 65W charge speed).
- Stand allows perfect height adjustment for comfortable all-day use.
- Can charge phones and other devices with USB-A port under monitor, even when display is off.
- Draws less energy and produces less heat than older flat panel monitors that used fluorescent backlighting.

Not So Good
- The stand, while beautiful, is wobbly. This makes the monitor and a camera sitting on the top of the monitor wobble. Shake is noticeable to those you're broadcasting to during a video call. Thankfully, the stand can be replaced.
- Display has some viewing angle issues making left and right edges appear slightly dimmer than the rest of screen. About a two-inch strip noticeable on both sides. This is not unusual for IPS monitors, but is a little more noticeable with this monitor compared to others I own.

I'm a long time Dell monitor user--bought first in 2008 (still in use in my household). I appreciate their quality, features, and price point. I purchased this monitor to replace a 7-year-old Dell P2715Q monitor. That monitor worked great, but it was time to move to something with a more modern USB hub to simplify and declutter my desk. Overall, I think this is a nice monitor with great features for the price.

theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment:
I've used Dell monitors before and liked them, and since this one was less than $300 on Black Friday, I ordered it as a second monitor for my Mac Studio. The main monitor is the Studio Display. I need accurate colors for photo editing, and Lightroom works best with 2 monitors. The was one trick need for setup. Initially, I plugged the USB-C connector for the Dell into one of the 4 Thunderbolt ports on the Studio Monitor. The Dell didn't detect a signal and the Mac didn't detect the Dell. I plugged the Dell in using an HDMI cable, and it worked fine. So then I plugged the Dell's USB-C directly into a Thunderbolt port on the back of the Mac Studio. Then in worked fine. So the Dell might have problems if there is another device between the computer and the Dell in a Thunderbolt daisy chain.

Compared with the Mac Studio Display, which is a 5K Retina display, the Dell has accurate colors, but as would be expected, they just don't have the brilliance and pop of the Studio Display, which costs 5 times as much. However, getting accurate colors after calibration with my Color Monkey is better than what I had with my previous display (Philips) which looked nice, but the colors couldn't be made to match up.

So I'm giving 4 stars for now (will revise if the Dell develops problems in the next few months) but for the price, I don't think you could get a better display. I like the number of input ports, and it also has some USB-3 ports which those using it with a laptop will find useful.

theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment:
The new display is located at the rear of my desk so it is about three feet fomr my eyes, so I was concerned that I might have difficulty reading text at the higher display resolutions. I resolved that issue by selecting a resolution lower than the native display resolution, and by using a System Settings > Accessibility setting that allows me to easily magnify the screen by pressing the Control key and swiping up with two fingers on the track pad. This works well for me and I find it very easy to make the small text easily readable for me.

It is also very easy to change to alternate resolutions through System Settings > Displays.

I connect between the display and my MBP with the supplied USB-C cable which facilitates the video connection and provides charging to my MBP. I now have only two cables to connect and disconnect to my MBP â€“ the display cable and an external (portable) hard drive that functions as my Time Machine Backup.

I tried the internal speakers on the Dell display but they were not nearly as good as the internal speakers on my MBP. I also could not easily control audio volume from my MBP, so for me, the speakers are of no value.

The display is bright and clear. I might have done as well with a lower resolution model, but this is one is working well for me.

comment:
I purchased this as an open box like new. I was watching my budget and hunting for picture quality (for future photo editing purposes), but I was also looking for a monitor with an adjustable height. The order came in a timely manner, but as expected of buying an open box, the actual package of the monitor was worn if not haphazardly taped for security. But the monitor and accessories inside were packaged adequately with no damage. Setting up the monitor came with little hassle (aside from the color configuration, I'm still trying to find that perfect match, but for now, I'm content), and two months in, I haven't encountered any problems.

I can't say much for photo editing as I haven't set up the software to test the monitor. But just from eyeballing it, I can see the quality will be more than enough for my needs. I just do photography as a hobby even if I shoot in raw.

You will need to shut down the PC to boot the Mac or awaken it from sleep to display to the monitor, though. My PC is the secondary computer that I use for things the Mac isn't the best at doing.

comment: I've been watching this monitor on Amazon looking for a sale. Then one day it was priced $155.24. I couldn't believe it. I ordered it only to find it was not packaged in a Dell box. It was warranted by Amazon. Probably a return or something. I connected it up and it worked perfectly. Superb picture but the sound was rather tinny but definitely adequate, OK for voice but if you want quality sound there is a port on the monitor to connect your own powered speakers. The quality of the picture was what I wanted. I wanted sound but it wasn't important that it be high fidelity. I got a great deal and I'm very happy with it. I bought a HDMI 2.1 cable for it. It came with a cable for a laptop which I didn't use. It was super easy to assemble the stand and it is very stable. Easily adjusts to portrait position. Highly recommended.

theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment:
I purchased two of these monitors and each one makes high pitched noises when plugged in via USB-C to a MacBook Pro. As soon as I unplug the USB-C cable, the noise stops. The noise periodically changes, too, which is very distracting and annoying.

The build quality is overall pretty good, and the picture quality is good except when viewing light colors against a colorful background- for example, dark red background with white text. The text looks terrible in these scenarios.

All things considered, I like these monitors, but the sound is driving me crazy and I may have to return them for that reason. Unfortunately, since I purchased two of them and they both do it, I wouldn't purchase this monitor again.

** Update **

An update after owning these for two months:

Again, I would never purchase these monitors again. The noise is a constant disturbance. But aside from that, another thing that I've never experienced with any other external monitor on a Macbook is that the windows become rearranged after waking up from sleep.

What I mean by this is that I have two of these monitors, and each monitor has 3 "desktops". I have different apps all rearranged on each desktop according to my preference. Once the Macbook goes to sleep and I wake it from sleep- even if I don't physically turn the monitors off- all of the application windows become rearranged to different desktops.

Its is extremely annoying and cuts down tremendously on my productivity as nearly each time I wake the Macbook from sleep, I have to rearrange all my windows to where I wanted them.

I really, really dislike these monitors!

comment:
The reviews were discouraging: tinny speaker, some kind of noise, screen briefly fades to black...I bought it because it was a Dell monitor. My first computer was a Dell. I got rid of it after 8 years or so because I wanted a new computer, not because I needed to. I never had a problem with it. I expect the same of this monitor. If there's a problem, I expect Dell to stand behind its products.

So far, I am happy with this purchase. It's just big enough. I was looking at a 32", but I'm glad I chose this 27"; a 32" would have taken over my desk.

The speakers are fine, I don't hear any noise, and the screen has not faded to black. Maybe I've been lucky, but things just seem to work out for me.

comment:
These monitors are a great economical choice. I prefer these to alternate, lesser brands.

Unfortunately the USB-C provided charging leads to over-charging my MacBook Pro.

When plugged into USB-C the laptop gets unusually hot. Even when the laptop is turned off and already charged to 100%, it gets very hot. I unplug it from the monitor and it goes back to room temperature.

There is a setting on this monitor to disable USB-C charging when the monitor itself is powered off, but that does not help me for 8 hours a day when both are in operation.

The only solution I have found is to FIRST plug into an authentic Apple wall charger, then secondly plug into monitor. This means that I never make use of the monitor-provided power, and the concept of a single-cable docking wonâ€™t work.

I have two of these monitors and they both operate identically.

theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment:
Overall, the monitor meets my expectations. Some items to note though if using on an M1 Mac with Monterey 12.1. For some frustrating reason, Apple has decided to enable VRR for external displays that support the feature by default. This means every time you wake your laptop/monitor from sleep, the monitor will default to VRR 40-60hz which is NOT desirable. Some have reported flickering, I have not experienced this, but regardless, you want full 60hz at all times. There is currently no way to permanently disable this protocol at the time of writing this review. You will have to manually adjust the refresh rate to a flat 60hz every time. There is no way to disable VRR on the monitor directly in the OSD menu. Very frustrating, and am hoping either Dell adds this option or Apple fixes this.

Second, you MUST switch USB-Prioritization to "High Resolution" in order to get full 4K 60hz RGB 30-bit. By default, it's set to "High Data Rate" which caps the output to 4K 60hz ycbcr (24-bit I believe?) which is inferior. Took me a bit to discover this as it's not explicitly stated anywhere. This does cap the monitors USB port to 2.0 speeds I believe, so there is a tradeoff involved.

UPDATE: As of Monterey 12.2, the vrr issue has been resolved and the monitor defaults to 60hz. As a side note, install the app lunar on your Mac to gain access to keyboard controls for brightness and monitor speaker audio - works flawlessly. Very happy with monitor now.

theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment:
The screen resolution is good and the features are adequate. It's good value for money if it worked. But I have had an intermittent flickering screen over USB for months. The fact that it's intermittent makes it hard to diagnose. There's also a slight burn-in and image persistence that occurs and I've had the screen for barely a year. If you use your monitor for work and need it to be dependable look elsewhere would be my recommendation.

Finally, Dell support is awful - dont expect to speak to anyone. Expect to ride the phone-carousel across their call-center departments when you call in for support. Come prepared with the service-tag number, purchase date, and other details of your case, so that they can ask you for that information and then promptly ignore all of it. Question your life choices and wonder if life would be simpler if we were all still using an abacus and stones to do our accounting.

theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment:
My initial impressions with this monitor are extremely favorable. I needed a second monitor for use with my Mac Studio and overall multimedia setup, which includes a 5.1 AV receiver with multiple HDMI sources including Apple TV, cable TV box, blue ray, etc.

I connect my Mac via USB-C to this monitorâ€™s USB-C connection and connect my 5.1 AV receiver to the monitorâ€™s HDMI 1 port that supports HDCP 2.3 (and earlier) which is needed to support 4K copyrighted content.

This monitor also has an audio output jack that can be used to connect to the AV receiverâ€™s audio input which is needed since computer monitors donâ€™t typically support HDMI ARC. I am thus able to use the HDMI and audio capabilities of this monitor and my 5.1 AV receiver as a small format home theater setup - right on my desk. Iâ€™m okay with everything being 60 Hz since thatâ€™s all the Mac supports.

When I need 2 screens for computer use, but still want to listen to 5.1 audio, watch TV, stream content, I put the HDMI input from the AV receiver into the Picture in Picture (PIP) window while the rest of the screen is dedicated to USB-C display from my Mac.

I could have also sent the Mac video through the AV receiver via HDMI to the Dell monitor, but I didnâ€™t want to have to turn on the receiver just to use the Dell as a second monitor. My main monitorâ€™s audio is sufficient for office tasks.

Iâ€™m very pleased to have found this monitor because it checked all the right boxes for my computing and multimedia setup.

comment: Built in speakers add extra value. Good size and picture.

theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment: Some of the reviewers for this Dell monitor have reported issues such as screen flickering and buzzing noises when paired to a M1 or M2 Mac mini. I have experienced NONE of those issues with my monitor connected to my Mac mini M2 Pro. I absolutely love this monitor, the screen is crystal clear and the colors are bright and vibrant. Aesthetically speaking, this is a great looking monitor as well. All of these pluses at an incredible price point! I purchased mine from Amazon at $299.00! Now if I were to give this monitor a demerit it would be this: The controls for this monitor are accessed via a series of buttons located under the bottom bezel. You navigate through the various monitor settings by pressing these buttons. This is a clunky system, usable, but a little awkward to use. I would easily pay a little extra if Dell would incorporate a remote control to control the menu functions. But at $299.00 I'm not complaining!

theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment:
These are our go-to monitors for a design studio. They work just fine for most image-heavy work as we do. However, after 11 months, one failed with a weird darkening in the lower and almost, the entire right side of the monitor.

HOWEVER, I have to say that going through Dell to get this replaced was one of the EASIER processes I have gone through. I submitted my warranty issue online, a team member responded within 10 minutes with a set of questions testing the validity of my request; then came a quick set of directions and information about the return process and a confirmation that a new one was headed my way. After about 5 days, we got the new one, and returning the broken one went off without a hitch. What a great experience. Dell really supported their product, and I have had no issues with the process. Great response from their team. Thanks, Dell!!

theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment:
Am I just that unlucky that I get two brand new deliveries from Amazon with the same problem? The first I received was beautiful worked perfectly with Del Inspiron USB C (all connections that came with monitor). But then as soon as the monitor f=goes into sleep mode, there is a super annoying high pitched "whirring or whining" electrical noise. I tried with/without anything else connected, in different outlets with/without power strip to no avail. Also I have other UHD Dell Monitors and no issues like this. I had Amazon send me a replacement for the first one and unfortunately the second replacement one has the same issues. I see other reviews on Amazon reporting the same noise and also on Dell support with no resolution. I called Dell and they say there is no service advisory for this monitor for antenna noise or such. Uhmm Okay. Buyer just be prepared to be disappointed like I was. If this monitor was silent then it would be A++++ because its beautiful picture and great connectivity. But alas... JC

....UPDATE: Okay, for whatever reason I decided to be persistent and get the monitor replaced a second time (third monitor) and this one is totally silent. All condition with household placement and power constant but the third monitor did not have the electrical noise issue in standby or power off that the first two had. So you are playing a game of chance it would seem. My odds were bad because 2/3 of the monitors I received had the noise issue. But overall based on the people who reported the noise in these reviews as a percentage of total reviews it would seem your odds at getting a bad one right now are 5-10% . Buyer be informed and good luck.

theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment:
Long time Mac user with a preference for glossy monitors. Wanted to make the jump to 4k screens and have been very pleased thus far with this Dell. Now have three at my desk and would def recommend. Side note, the USB-C cables are a bit short at 39".

I read about the flickering issue but never experienced it. However after a few weeks noticed that after long sessions in front of these I was feeling dizzy and even slightly nauseous. Weird as I couldn't see any flickering until a side by side comparison with my old 1080p monitor.

Fortunately there is a fix.

Dell Monitor Settings:
1. Display~USB-C Prioritization ~ High Resolution
2. Others~ DDC/CI~ Off
3. Others~ LCD Conditioning ~ On - run once you have changed all setting in MacOS and the Monitor

MacOS Settings:
System Preferences~ Displays~ Display Settings~ Dell S2722QC~
1. Resolution~ Default for Display
2. Refresh Rate~ 60 Hertz
3. System Preferences~ Displays~ Display Settings~ Built-In Retina Display~ True Tone~ Unchecked(turned off)
4. System Preferences~ Displays~ Night Shift~ Schedule~ Off

Been good to go ever since.

theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment:
I bought this monitor for two reasons: to upgrade image resolution and to run two computers through it to replace my 18 year old Dell with 1680x1050 resolution which developed a flicker issue. Ran a Windows 10 and newer Windows 11 computer through an inexpensive switchbox seemless with no issues whatsoever. Only had to switch one button to go between computers and everything functioned perfectly.
The only good thing I can say is that imagery on this model was as advertised-beautiful picture with excellent resolution. Sadly, after 2-3 hours of trying everything, the best I could do was to get only one computer to work through this model with a conventional hook-up. Disappointingly, I could not get it to work through the switchbox, one USB port was useless: I couldn't get my keyboard or bluetooth usb mouse to work in it. Beyond this, the mickey-mouse buttons located at the bottom of the display were ridiculously tedious to work with-just the idea of having to use those in a 3 step process to simply switch from one computer to another was a deal-breaker itself. I didn't spend $300 for something that was less easy to work with than a $20 switchbox-forget the fact that I couldn't even get a keyboard to work through it-I had to run it through my computer. One more thing-guess some may peg me a just a cranky old guy, but the hook-ups for everything could have been much easier and convenient to work with if they were simply on the back of the monitor. I appreciate the aesthetics regarding their placement, but they sure are a pain in the butt particularly since I had to keep switching things in and out (trying different cables, etc.) in vain attempts to get this turkey to work. I expected more from Dell on this one...guess I got a lemon.

theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment:
Power unit failure. Dead.
Dell support told me "this model is end of life".
You can't even pay them to repair it.
A $400 monitor isn't expected to last 2 years apparently. It also had weird video glitches using Chrome (they went away when I switched to Firefox).

Now that I know what I do, I won't be buying another 4k monitor for a while. Most streaming services don't stream 4k to personal computers (see their supported device lists). It requires 4 times to resources as full HD and doesn't look that much better honestly. You need a fast internet service and strong wifi signal, since most streaming services will automatically select the quality based on your download speed / consistency. You usually can't pause and let it buffer then come back later (youtube seems to be an exception).

I bought a PS5 a few months before this thing died, and watched some 4k movies and played some games in 4k. Yea the movies looked good, but not that much better than full HD. I hardly noticed much of a difference in visual quality in the PS5 games in fidelity mode (reportedly most games aren't even native 4k but get upscaled), yet the performance improvement is noticeable in performance mode and not something you want to give up after playing with it. I replaced this monitor with an ASUS full HD gaming monitor that does 120hz+ and has 1ms response time, and WOW playing Uncharted 4 (has a 120hz mode) is awesome.

So yea... there's not much of a reason to buy a 4k monitor unless you have a really powerful video card and play games. But then you won't want this monitor anyhow since the refresh rate and response time aren't great for gaming. And those things are more important than 4k for an enjoyable experience (imo).

comment: At least for people who use a MacBook Pro 16" (2021), this monitor may not be a great fit. The biggest issue is that whenever I use this monitor, my laptop spontaneously freezes and crashes almost every day. I sent the laptop in for repair thinking it was the issue, and even after they replaced all the parts and wiped the entire device, it continues to freeze and crash nearly every day... I wanted 4K quality for photo editing and occasional movie watching, but it is quite incompatible with streaming; everything moves almost in slow motion. Unfortunately can't appreciate the supposed quality of the monitor because it does not actually appear in 4K quality. I am not a computer gamer but can't imagine this monitor being remotely compatible with gaming... Quite a disappointment, and I can't speak to how well this works when attached to a PC or even other MacBooks, but it does not seem to function with a MacBook Pro from 2021. All of this has been happening since I got this monitor in February, but it took a while to connect the two together because I thought it was just my laptop having issues. Besides this, a pixelated box appears in the top lefthand corner of the monitor every now and then... A few too many issues to have within four months :/

comment:
Product is the svelte, 4K UHD monitor as advertised and advocated by Wirecutter. Setup was easy. Picture is good. Note 60 Hz refresh is all you get. This is for Casual Gaming only. However, for Productivity and light video-- its as advertised.

I am having *no* flicker problems using HDMI with MS Windows PCs.

CONS (All there in writing, read the description closely): Only comes with a USB-C cable. And, its not really a 'good' one. No Display Port. Although, there are two (2) 2.0 HDMI ports, there is no cable.

TIPS: HDR mode is DISABLED by default. I found the picture to be slightly better by using it? Look for it and ENABLE it. You decide. Buy a "Monoprice Ultra Compact USB Type-C to Type-C 3.2 Gen 2 Cable - 10Gbps, 5A, Black, 3m (9.9ft)", else buy a "Monoprice 8K Certified Ultra High Speed HDMI 2.1 Cable - 10 Feet" with purchase. (The Monoprice HDMI 2.0 cable is sketchy.)

theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment:
UPDATE 2: As of now, I do regret purchasing this Dell monitor. With a monitor that arrived in un-usable condition (a constant high-pitched noise when the screen is not active), I thought the replacement monitor would also be new. But it is a refurbished one with a label from Dell outlet stores. (There are many scratches on the bottom but the outward-showing parts all look new enough for me. It's the re-furbished innards that I worry about). I know it's better for the environment to refurbish, but I stopped buying refurbished products years ago because I had gotten too many duds. (Also, chances are that Dell is selling these for cheaper at its outlet store than the new Amazon price I paid.)

If this replacement monitor holds up and has a good lifespan, then maybe I will end up happy with it and with Dell. (The picture quality is excellent, and the set-up with Apple laptops is super-easy.) For now, what I can unambiguously praise Dell for is that the customer service on the phone was excellent and fast (after Amazon connected me to Dell). But if any of you also receive a defective product out of the box, I would see if you can get *Amazon* to send you a new one, and ask if you can avoid going through the Dell process.

UPDATE: It seems I am getting excellent service on this defective item. After I was unable to get through to Dell customer service from the Dell website, I clicked on the Amazon button for service (in my order history). Amazon got me on the phone with a Dell rep. And Dell is responding in a very fast and convenient way. Instead of having to go weeks without a new monitor, they are apparently sending it immediately, probably the next business day. And I can schedule a pick up of the defective monitor from my home. So, both the Amazon and Dell people came to the rescue. (When I get the new monitor, I will try to revise this review yet again to increase the # of stars!)
***

Must be nice to get one of these that works! I just received the monitor yesterday. It makes a loud high-pitched noise every second that it is in sleep mode. It even keeps making this obnoxious noise for awhile after I've unplugged it. I would have let Dell try to help trouble-shoot before writing a negative review. But I think they deserve a negative review because their customer service is not available. (When I inputted the tag number for this device on their site, none of the three contact options--email, chat, phone--was available.) I think I needed to wait about 12 days to receive this delivery (not too slow for these times). Yet, now if I try to get a replacement closer to the holidays, I fear I won't be able to get one for long past the time I wanted to be working with it.

comment:
I searched all over for a decently prices 4k monitor I could hook up to my MacBook Air M1 via the USB C connector. This one fit the bill perfectly. It's got a nice detailed picture. It's easily height adjustable and has tilt swivel. It gets way brighter than what I need. Color is easily good enough for my photography needs because most of my photos end up only online. It charges my MacBook Air just fine. Setup was straight forward and didn't take long. Dell includes a nice setup guide. Controls are easy to access.

I gave it 5 stars mostly because monitors with similar features and a few hundred more dollars. This one is a super value. It would be nice if the ports were easier to access. It's awkward fumbling around for the USB A port and I have to get behind the monitor and tilt it forward to find the USBC and HDMI ports (which I don't use). Build quality is pretty much all plastic including the base.

comment:
I have a new Macbook Pro 14" on the way and began looking for a Thunderbolt 3 compatible setup - with dual monitors...but I couldnt find a 27" that I liked nor could I find a way to swivel vertically the LG line. So I decided to try Dell - which has the most consistent and well thought out monitor line in the business. And they didnt drop the ball here. These are beautiful monitors with a simple setup. The swivel is simple to use, the plug in out of the box, they charge the Macbook with USB-C and have 2 USB ports on the backside for peripheral charging and connectivity.
My only wish would be that the image could be smaller - which I am honestly not sure what is driven by. Is it the resolution (this is 4K!) or is it I/O or is it the macbook graphics card? Anyway, for <$900 I could get 2 27" 4K monitors with USB-C charging. This saved me over 100% in spend over 2 32" LGs and I only sacrafice a smaller font/screen display and the thunderbolt 3 daisy chain connectivity. I will gladly wait for Apple's new budget 27" coming in 2022.

comment:
UPDATE:
I received my re-purchased device to find ANOTHER dead pixel. Returned and got a Gigabyte M27U, which has been incredible vs. this Dell. (I get over 60hz with the M27U.) I suppose if you are fine with 60hz and you get one with working pixels, you'll enjoy this for the price. But having gotten two defective monitors, I'm done with Dell.

Also, returning these is painful. They don't come in cardboard boxes, so Amazon makes me shell out $43 bucks at UPS to box it up. Travesty.

This monitor is simply wonderful. HDR is bright, everything is super sharp, and the menu buttons are in a great spot. I got this for my work laptop vs. two screens as my office area is limited, so having 4k meant I could better use my space. Nothing bad to say after setting it up. The next day I was out of the house (I WFH) and didn't get to really test it out until now.

Come to find an obnoxious dead pixel right in the middle of the screen. My other Dell monitor (for my gaming desktop) has no issues, so this was a big disappointment. Also noticed after running the Windows 11 HDR calibration tool that I was experiencing extreme ghosting with black text on white backgrounds. Amazon can't replace it, so I had to return and order again--another bad taste in my mouth with was to be my first foray into 4k monitors. fingers crossed the next one will be fine.

theproduct: Dell S2722QC 27 å‹ 4K USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - UHD (3840 x 2160) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,60Hz åˆ·æ–°ç‡,8MS ç°ç°è‡³ç°å›æ‡‰æ™‚é–“(æ­£å¸¸æ¨¡å¼),å…§å»ºé›™ 3W å–‡å­,1.07 å„„è‰²é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment:
Well, i've expected much more from Dell monitor. The major problem - the backlight became flickering and image become like "made from many vertical lines" when i'm using warm gamma. It can be achieved either via monitor settings (Warm color mode) or via macbook settings (nightshift mode)

In "normal gamma" monitor works well, but "normal gamma" is bad for working at the evening

MacBook Air M1

SOLUTION to the problem:
I researched a bit, try some stuff and got a solution which worked for me. Hope It will help u.
It seems like bad image quality and flickering occurs when the monitor is using YcBcr input color format (You can check it in monitor settings - OSD)
The only way i can force the monitor to use RGB format was to set usb-prioritisation to "high resolution" instead of "high data speed" in a monitor settings.
After this i got RGB input format, it solved problems with bad image quality, flickering and so on. BUT i sacrificed the speed of built-in usb ports - now they are in usb 2.0 mode, so not good for an external SSD or a usb stick connected to the monitor, but at least i get rid of that flickering.

UPD: RGB mode doesn't completely fix the flickering. It makes it better but flickering still occurs on particular yellowish gamma

UPD: after 1 month of using it, it starts to blink everytime even without night shift. So its just wasting of money. Terrible monitor. I will never buy Dell. Thats just scam which costs me 300+ $. Unfortunately i'm located outside of US and probably will not be able to return this CRAP. Never buy this monitor

UPD. After about 3 month of using it i can state that most of the time monitor works quite well and doesnt flicker. Probably because i mostly use it during daytime, so in "normal gamma". But sometimes it start to flicker and i have to change brightnes/contrast/gamma to stabilise it.
Afterall i do not recommend this monitor. It was so unexpectable that dell can make this so bad. Well, seems like dell nowadays is a different from dell which i knew. As for me, my next monitor will be definately NOT dell

comment: I have had this monitor for a month and find it an excellent companion for my 4K Dell XPS-13 9300. The resolution and color are terrific, and the multiple-image screen size is just right for my desk. It was essentially plug and play and worked beautifully right out of the box. It is also compatible with my webcam. Being able to both power the laptop and receive its video output to the monitor with a single 1-meter-long USB-C cable is a huge convenience that now leaves me an open USB-C port for use with other peripherals. This monitor functionally doubles as a laptop docking port that helps minimize cable clutter. My only complaint with Dell is that they do not sell a compatible 2-meter cable for this monitor, as I originally wanted to locate the laptop a bit further away than the 1-meter cable would allow. But the monitor is a good value and I recommend it.

comment:
I purchased this Dell Monitor specifically for processing digital pictures. Is it the best (or best for the money) I cannot address that question. With that said, the color and quality of my digital photographs went up an order of magnitude with this monitor. I find the monitor produces realistic color. The pictures are crisp with high definition. This monitor will be a great assist for me with post processing from my digital cameras.
Regarding the seller and shipping: my monitor arrived in a damaged box where something penetrated the entire corrugation during shipment. I contacted the seller who were appreciative of my suggesting that shipping this type of product with only its own packaging can lead to problems. They would be better served to put the product in an outer package. I was pleased with their interest in hearing my thoughts. They are a quality provider and I would not hesitate buying from them again.

comment:
Solid quality from Dell, a nice-looking screen overall. The stand is ok, but nothing fancy (I'm using with a 100mm vesa pivot-arm mount that's a substantial improvement). The on-screen menu is controlled by 4 physical buttons, and offers nice control over color temperature.

Be aware, however, that full monitor control requires proprietary Dell software that *only* works under Windows 10 (so says the manual). In particular, this monitor will *not* sleep or power-save on its own in the default configuration. Apparently this can be changed using the Dell software? In any case, I'm manually turning it off every day, which is annoying but not a deal-breaker. Still, here in 2022, it would be nice if new hardware shipped with sensible power-saving defaults.

This display holds its own next to my 16" MacBook Pro 2021 with "Liquid Retina" display, which is high praise! Great color, good brightness, good pixel density, and great sharpness make this an awesome match for the MacBook screen.

And, everything connects through a single USB-C cable! I just plug in my MacBook (or XPS 13, depending on what I'm working on) and I get 4k60 graphics, keyboard, mouse, and other peripherals, and power to charge the laptop.

With the quality, features, and price, I'd definitely buy this display again!

(yes, I'll admit the MacBook still has it beat for pixel density, brightness, and contrast, but unlike many other monitors, this Dell still looks solid even in a side-by-side comparison.)

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S2722DZ 27 å‹åœ¨å®¶å·¥ä½œ - é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,è¦–è¨Šæœƒè­°åŠŸèƒ½ - å…§å»ºç›¸æ©Ÿ,é˜²å™ªé›™éº¥å…‹é¢¨,USB-C é€£æ¥,16:09 å¯¬é«˜æ¯”,4 æ¯«ç§’åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“,QHD - éŠ€è‰²
comment:
The Dell S2722DZ 27-inch monitor has proven to be a true tech gem, combining innovative features with unmatched convenience, and I am absolutely in love with it!

One standout feature that immediately caught my attention is the camera design with privacy in mind. As someone concerned about online security, having the ability to put away the camera for full privacy when not in use is a game-changer. It ensures that there's no risk of unwanted hackers hijacking my camera, giving me complete peace of mind during my work or leisure time.

The camera quality itself is top-notch, delivering clear and crisp video for video conferencing or virtual meetings. When I need to use it, the camera pops up effortlessly, ready to capture moments in exceptional detail.

Another brilliant addition to this monitor is the conveniently placed USB slot on the bottom front. It's an absolute lifesaver when I need to charge or connect my devices quickly. I no longer have to fumble around the back of the monitor, searching for ports. This front USB slot allows for easy access, saving me valuable time and effort.

Additionally, the fact that the Dell S2722DZ monitor charges my laptop while it's connected is a fantastic bonus. It's one less thing to worry about, and I can seamlessly work on my laptop without fear of it running out of battery.

The monitor's overall performance and picture quality are nothing short of impressive. The colors are vibrant, and the sharpness of images is exceptional. The size is just right for multitasking, allowing me to have multiple windows open side by side without feeling cramped.

The adjustable stand is a fantastic feature, enabling me to find the perfect height and angle for optimal comfort during long work sessions. The slim bezels add a touch of modern elegance, making this monitor a stylish addition to any workspace.

Setting up the monitor was a breeze, and the user-friendly interface made navigation and customization a delight.

In conclusion, the Dell S2722DZ monitor has exceeded my expectations in every way. Its cutting-edge privacy feature, convenient front USB slot, and laptop charging capability have made it an invaluable asset in my daily work and entertainment routines. If you're seeking a monitor that seamlessly combines advanced technology with user-centric design, look no further. The Dell S2722DZ monitor is a true game-changer and gets my highest recommendation!

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S2722DZ 27 å‹åœ¨å®¶å·¥ä½œ - é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,è¦–è¨Šæœƒè­°åŠŸèƒ½ - å…§å»ºç›¸æ©Ÿ,é˜²å™ªé›™éº¥å…‹é¢¨,USB-C é€£æ¥,16:09 å¯¬é«˜æ¯”,4 æ¯«ç§’åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“,QHD - éŠ€è‰²
comment:
This is a great monitor. The QHD (2560x1440) resolution works great for this monitor size, Windows 10/11 shows the recommended scale (under settings > display settings) is 100%. I also have a 27" 4K UHD (3840x2160) LG monitor, and the recommended scale is 150%, which makes everything the same size as this monitor, but text is crisper when looking at it from 10 inches away, whereas text on this monitor is a bit pixelated. At a normal viewing distance, however, the text looks virtually identical between the two monitors. Compared to the LG monitor, this one swivels and extends up and down further, which I prefer. The LG (it's the 27UP850-W) doesn't swivel and doesn't extend as far down as this Dell, which may not be an issue for some/most users. On the other hand, this Dell monitor delivers 65W to your laptop over USB-C, while the LG delivers 95W (better for MacBook Pros), but it's also $220 more than this Dell (as of today's prices).

The included camera is convenient and works as expected. You can hide it (push it in) when not in use, which is a nice privacy feature. The quality is mediocre, though. If you compare it to your cell phone's webcam (which you can connect to your computer for free via Camo app on the phone and Camo Studio on Mac/PC), it's night and day. The included camera, which runs at 1080 resolution, pales in comparison to your smartphone's camera, which the free version of Camo runs at 720 resolution. It's like a toy camera from the 1970s compared to a modern top-of-the-line digital camera. Don't get me wrong, the camera is serviceable; it's just mediocre and low quality.

Overall, I recommend this monitor. It works great.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S2722DZ 27 å‹åœ¨å®¶å·¥ä½œ - é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,è¦–è¨Šæœƒè­°åŠŸèƒ½ - å…§å»ºç›¸æ©Ÿ,é˜²å™ªé›™éº¥å…‹é¢¨,USB-C é€£æ¥,16:09 å¯¬é«˜æ¯”,4 æ¯«ç§’åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“,QHD - éŠ€è‰²
comment: Integrated seamlessly with our wifi and Alexa right out of the box. No more need of a fire stick so we have 4 HDMI ports free to connect other peripherals, no more plugging and unplugging. Great picture quality, black tones and shadows show in great detail. I mean, for the quality we got other brands are charging twice as much or more. Remains to see how long will it last, but again, for the price we paid we were ready to try it out, so much that we got 2 at the same time.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S2722DZ 27 å‹åœ¨å®¶å·¥ä½œ - é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,è¦–è¨Šæœƒè­°åŠŸèƒ½ - å…§å»ºç›¸æ©Ÿ,é˜²å™ªé›™éº¥å…‹é¢¨,USB-C é€£æ¥,16:09 å¯¬é«˜æ¯”,4 æ¯«ç§’åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“,QHD - éŠ€è‰²
comment: It is everything I wanted and more in a videoconferencing monitor. It's hard to find a monitor with built in camera and speakers and this one surely fits the bill. I use it for work all day and take all my conference calls on it. Mic and speakers are great. I only have three wishes but I can live without them. 1) I wish it had a higher MP camera but the one it has is fine just not exceptional quality -- I love that it pops up when needed and can be hidden when not in use because it makes it easy to see that you aren't on camera. 2) I wish it had more than one powered USB-C port. I would like to connect all my computers via USB-C but there's only one powered USB-C port. Right now I have a Windows PC on USB-C, a Mac on DP and another Mac on HDMI. I can manage for now. 3) I wish it had dedicated buttons to switch between inputs (different computers for me) rather than using the on-screen menu. Again, it does much more than I expected and I am thrilled with this model. Maybe some of my wishes will be in the next version. Until then I am more than pleased with this monitor.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S2722DZ 27 å‹åœ¨å®¶å·¥ä½œ - é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,è¦–è¨Šæœƒè­°åŠŸèƒ½ - å…§å»ºç›¸æ©Ÿ,é˜²å™ªé›™éº¥å…‹é¢¨,USB-C é€£æ¥,16:09 å¯¬é«˜æ¯”,4 æ¯«ç§’åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“,QHD - éŠ€è‰²
comment:
Love this monitor now. But I had issues connecting it to my new Dell XPS Windows 11 desktop. To get display, camera, and microphone all to work, I needed to use the enclosed USB-C cable AND then purchase a DisplayPort to HDMI adapter and an HDMI cable. That got it all working. But then I had another major issue that I see another user has: the monitor screen kept going black about every three minutes. To solve this: I plugged in the monitor power cable into a power strip/surge protector https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B087N9HCHV/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?ie=UTF8&th=1

Now everything works great - love the monitor now!

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S2722DZ 27 å‹åœ¨å®¶å·¥ä½œ - é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,è¦–è¨Šæœƒè­°åŠŸèƒ½ - å…§å»ºç›¸æ©Ÿ,é˜²å™ªé›™éº¥å…‹é¢¨,USB-C é€£æ¥,16:09 å¯¬é«˜æ¯”,4 æ¯«ç§’åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“,QHD - éŠ€è‰²
comment:
My work at home is pretty standard so I canâ€™t write an accurate review for someone that is a graphic designer for a living. For me, this has been great. Connection to my MacBook is perfect with the usb c without having to buy an adapter. Sound quality from the monitor is not the best but I rarely use it. I connect with Bluetooth on my headphones or from my laptop since I always have it open.

The camera quality is good, Iâ€™m not on camera all day everyday so it wasnâ€™t that important. I also have pretty bad lighting where I work but it does a good job. It you are looking for superb video quality this might not be for you. Itâ€™s pretty average but not blurry and good for the average work from home person

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S2722DZ 27 å‹åœ¨å®¶å·¥ä½œ - é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,è¦–è¨Šæœƒè­°åŠŸèƒ½ - å…§å»ºç›¸æ©Ÿ,é˜²å™ªé›™éº¥å…‹é¢¨,USB-C é€£æ¥,16:09 å¯¬é«˜æ¯”,4 æ¯«ç§’åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“,QHD - éŠ€è‰²
comment: This Dell monitor is great for a simple home setup that avoids the need for a separate docking station to connect your laptop via USB-C for charging, display, and wired keyboard/mouse connectivity along with the monitor's integrated webcam, noise-canceling microphone, and speakers. However, unlike newer video conferencing models from Dell, this does NOT support DisplayPort daisy chaining for connecting a second display nor does it support wired Ethernet connections, both of which (and a really handy KVM function) are found on the C2722DE, so if you can find a similar price on that model, I'd highly recommend it instead. The built in webcam on this monitor has a very wide field and works great with Windows Hello using both infrared and traditional camera functions. Mine shipped with the popup camera having excessive tilting movement, but I suspect that is a one-off manufacturing defect for an otherwise well-made product.

comment: I love this large, crystal-clear display. I love the built-in camera. I love that the USB-C connection allows me to use 1 power cord to both power the monitor and charge my Macbook Pro. I love the price! What a great deal. I love that it shipped fast and was well packaged.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S2722DZ 27 å‹åœ¨å®¶å·¥ä½œ - é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,è¦–è¨Šæœƒè­°åŠŸèƒ½ - å…§å»ºç›¸æ©Ÿ,é˜²å™ªé›™éº¥å…‹é¢¨,USB-C é€£æ¥,16:09 å¯¬é«˜æ¯”,4 æ¯«ç§’åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“,QHD - éŠ€è‰²
comment:
Itâ€™s a solid QHD display- colors are good. But the video conferencing components are lacking.

The camera is acceptable but poor compared to modern video conference cameras. I do like that it can be retracted though.

The speaker quality is very poor. For video conferencing it gets the job done and is loud enough, but I would not recommend using them for music.

The microphone quality is also basic- doesnâ€™t cancel our background noise.

Iâ€™m an Apple user and a couple of little things bug me- like the fact that I have to go through a clunky menu on the display itself to control volume and brightness.

Overall, it works as an entry level setup, but itâ€™s not on the same level as the Apple display. I guess you get what you pay for.

I'm giving this 4 stars because somehow this UHD monitor with webcam was cheaper than a similar Dell UHD monitor without webcam. The webcam does not work (even after installing the latest drivers), but given that it was cheaper than the version without the webcam, there's not much I can complain about.

Screen quality is amazing for both work and watching movies, USB C connection makes everything convenient, and overall I love this monitor.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S2722DZ 27 å‹åœ¨å®¶å·¥ä½œ - é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,è¦–è¨Šæœƒè­°åŠŸèƒ½ - å…§å»ºç›¸æ©Ÿ,é˜²å™ªé›™éº¥å…‹é¢¨,USB-C é€£æ¥,16:09 å¯¬é«˜æ¯”,4 æ¯«ç§’åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“,QHD - éŠ€è‰²
comment:
I really like this monitor as a monitor. It has a good picture, but the camera isn't very good at all. The video is grainy and needs a lot of light to work at all. The speakers are weak and tinny. So I don't use the camera or speakers at all, even though I chose this monitor for those features.

If you just want a basic QHD monitor, and you can get a good price on this one, then go for it, but the extra features were a waste of money for me. I do like the USB-C connection because it made connecting my MacBook Pro very easy. The connection supplies something like 60 watts of power, so it's not powerful enough to keep my computer charged at full tilt, but it works well with a MacBook Air.

I haven't played any games on this monitor. It's obviously designed for business use. I spend 8 hours a day programming on it. It's fine for that purpose, but the teleconferencing features are disappointing.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S2722DZ 27 å‹åœ¨å®¶å·¥ä½œ - é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,è¦–è¨Šæœƒè­°åŠŸèƒ½ - å…§å»ºç›¸æ©Ÿ,é˜²å™ªé›™éº¥å…‹é¢¨,USB-C é€£æ¥,16:09 å¯¬é«˜æ¯”,4 æ¯«ç§’åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“,QHD - éŠ€è‰²
comment:
New MPB and this monitor will work together... but I had to get apple support to assist.

(1) Connect the MBP to the Monitor using the included USBC to USBC cable
(2) Pop-up the camera (obviously)
(3) Go into Photobooth. In Photobooth, under "camera" you will now see you "Facetime" camera and the "dell" camera. Check-on the Dell Camera.
(4) Go into system preferences to and choose the audio output to be the Monitor. Probably could do the microphone, but haven't tried it.

Dell support is terrible. In 90min they transferred me to one person after the other. Never again.
Apple support is simply awesome.

I downloaded Dell Display Manager, but it is useless and I think only works for windows.
I have no idea if there is firmware/drivers for this for the Mac.

60 day update; Changed to 1 star. Do not recommend for MAC users.
- The MAC keeps "forgetting" about the camera. Sometimes multiple times a day. Requires you to go back into facetime to discover it again.
- Run into a new problem where randomly the sound volume will go from 100% to 0%. Pretty frustrating when you are on a call and realize you cant hear everyone. So then you either have to change the speakers to the MBP... or reach over and toggle with the buttons below the monitor to increase volume.

No doubt this is mostly APPLE problems, but doesn't matter if it is not compatible.

comment:
Pros-
-USB-C power delivery
-Integrated Speakers

Cons-
-The speakers are not very loud at full volume. They sound tinny in meeting and sometimes will not work at all.
-The colors are not very accurate. The grays look beige with makes any design work impossible. Donâ€™t get this monitor if you need accurate colors.
-The worst thing for me is the brightness. On maximum 100% brightness this thing is a joke! Even in a dark room itâ€™s hard to see. Next to my laptop screen is looks maybe half the overall brightness.
-Only one USB-C port. It would be nice to have a few more ports for mouse keyboard etc
-No daisy chaining. You have to connect multiple monitors to a dock .

Overall I think some people will be okay with this monitor for the price. Iâ€™m going to keep looking as the brightness and speaker quality are not quite good enough for my needs.

comment:
A very nice monitor with a disappointing webcam. The screen is crisp and bright, with good colors and no flicker. There is slight fall-off of the backlight around the edges but nothing too bad. Case and product design are very attractive and the monitor would look good even when not in use. Stand is sturdy and allows for easy adjustment.

The big problem is the included webcam. Housed in a clever pop-up mechanism, it disappears when not used. The image quality from the camera is very bad. Objects are blurry and pixilated, with a good deal of noise that jitters distractingly. The camera was so bad that I thought there must be a protective cover that I did not remove.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S2722DZ 27 å‹åœ¨å®¶å·¥ä½œ - é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,è¦–è¨Šæœƒè­°åŠŸèƒ½ - å…§å»ºç›¸æ©Ÿ,é˜²å™ªé›™éº¥å…‹é¢¨,USB-C é€£æ¥,16:09 å¯¬é«˜æ¯”,4 æ¯«ç§’åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“,QHD - éŠ€è‰²
comment:
I recently got a laptop that only has USB-C ports, so instead of dealing with yet another adapter, I decided it was time to upgrade my monitor as well. This monitor caught my eye because the USB-C port also has the ability to charge my laptop, cutting a cable out of the mix. Even better, it has a built-in webcam, removing yet another cable from my workspace.

This monitor is great. It looks like a high-quality device even before it's turned on, with a super-slim bezel and a smooth back with clearly marked ports. Once it's on, the picture quality is solid, as good or better than my HDMI monitors of the same size. Colors are bright, the picture is crisp, and the height and angle adjustments are versatile (or if you prefer, you can attach it to a 100mm x 100mm VESA mount). Hooking it up was as simple as plugging it in and connecting the included surprisingly long and sturdy-feeling USB-C cable to my laptop. I didn't mess with the settings much, just enough to flip through all of the included modes and decide that standard mode looked the best. Each of the others looked off-kilter in some way.

Since this monitor is clearly intended for video conferencing, I decided to use it for my Zoom HOA meeting that night. The webcam popped up easily and was automatically detected. The 5MP camera gave a really nice, clear picture, both during the test / join window and when I was scrunched up in the corner after everyone joined. It actually took me half the meeting to realize that I should be surprised how good the picture was in the low light of my living room! The sound was pretty good, but not as good as my laptop speakers (which are actually really nice, so that's not a big complaint). The mic captured everything my wife and I said during the meeting, and nobody seemed to have any trouble hearing us.

Is this a gaming monitor? No, and it's not intended to be. This is a business monitor that helps you keep a tidy desk. It'll work for some light gaming, but don't expect it to support your next-gen AAA titles at max graphics settings. For what it's intended to do though, this is a top-tier monitor that's worth every cent just for not making me manage 2 more cables.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S2722DZ 27 å‹åœ¨å®¶å·¥ä½œ - é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,è¦–è¨Šæœƒè­°åŠŸèƒ½ - å…§å»ºç›¸æ©Ÿ,é˜²å™ªé›™éº¥å…‹é¢¨,USB-C é€£æ¥,16:09 å¯¬é«˜æ¯”,4 æ¯«ç§’åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“,QHD - éŠ€è‰²
comment:
I needed a new monitor to replace my old 10 years old 21 inches monitor and decided to get this Dell S2722DZ 27-inch which is just fantastic. Coming from a smaller monitor to this huge 27 inches is so nice.
The monitor itself is very nice, well built and even though the viewable screen size is much bigger, it is not that much bigger compared to my older monitor which had a very big bezel.

Setting it up was a breeze as all I had to do was plug it into an outlet and then connect it to the dock via USB-C.

The picture was stunning, and even though it is not a 4K monitor, movies looked amazing on the screen. I specifically chose this monitor because of the built in webcam which make it so convenient when I have my zoom meetings. Previously I had a standalone webcam that I needed to sit on top of the screen and then remove and unplug when I was done as it was not very stable. I really like how with a single press I can hide the camera or bring it out for meetings.

Another thing that I really like are the built in dual 5W speakers which sounded very nice. The dual noise cancelling microphone is also another nice addition as I no longer need to use my earbuds and people in zoom said that they could hear me loud and clear.

Last but not least, the USB ports make it very easy for me to charge my phone and surprisingly, the USB-C port has enough power to charge my ultra-book.

All in all, I really love my new 27 inches monitor which gets a perfect score from me.

comment:
This monitor is a good option for a home office especially when conference calls are frequent. I like that this monitor can be connected via usb-c port. This option comes in very useful especially since I don't have an HDMI cable. The video quality is good, and the picture is clear. The resolution is not enough for the 4k video, however. I certainly won't recommend this monitor for gamers. I wouldn't say that I was very impressed with the camera: it is tiny despite taking huge space on top of the monitor. I feel like my iphone front camera is much better than that on this monitor.
Overall this is an okay option if you don't have high video requirements, or if you are not a blogger. Otherwise, please invest in a better stand-alone camera.

theproduct: Dell Inspiron 14 5425 éè§¸æ§ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ - 14 å‹ FHD+ (1920 x 1200)ã€AMD Ryzen7 5825Uã€8GB DDR4 RAMã€512GB SSDã€AMD Radeon Graphics, Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ç¾å ´ + 6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» - éµåµçŸ³ç¶ è‰²
comment:
The Dell Inspiron Laptop arrived at my door securely packed in a double box. It was pretty much ready to go right out-of-the-box. Setup was easily done by following the prompts on the screen.

Overview:
The laptop has a powerful AMD Ryzen7 processer. It is lightweight, compact and attractive looking with a 14" display screen and a slim design. It ships with 8GB of RAM (upgradable to 16GB), and 512GB of SSD storage. There are three USB ports (2 type A and 1 type C). There is also a media card reader, audio jack, and HDMI port. (There is no ethernet port.) There are built-in dual microphones, background noise reduction, and enhanced audio speakers. The build-in camera has a privacy shutter. The keyboard is backlit.

The laptop needed a few updates to the OS, Windows 11 Pro, before it was ready to use. Once the updates were complete, it wanted me to sign in to a microsoft account to begin setup. While I have a microsoft account, I prefer not to use it every time I sign on. Since this is not a review of Windows 11, I'll just say that there are workarounds for that, just do a google search, and you will find tutorials on how to set up a local account, bypassing the need to use your microsoft account.

I have been using this laptop for the past week and it has been living up to my expectations. It is a fully-featured machine that does pretty much everything I need. I am not using it for gaming, so I can't test that out, but it does fine on the internet to access websites, pay bills, write documents (ie google office), play videos; everyday stuff. My husband is using it to do work for his job from home. It's fast and responsive and we both like it.

Screen:
The screen is bright and the colors are good. I didn't need to make any adjustments. In comparison to my older 14-inch Dell, the 16:10 screen has a bit more area. The bezels are thinner, making full use of the available screen area. The maximum screen resolution is 1920 x 1200, which is more than sufficient for using applications, the internet and watching video. The one thing missing is a touchscreen.

Keyboard:
The keyboard is comfortable and easy to type on. The backlit keyboard is a huge plus for me. When I use the laptop in the evening, it makes it so much easier to see in a low light environment.

The unit has a large touchpad. I find it difficult to navigate and frustrating to use for any length of time. Maybe it's just me. Iâ€™m not a touchpad person. If I need to be productive, I use a mouse. If I don't have a mouse, I like to have a touchscreen, which this laptop does not have.

Sound:
The audio from the built-in speakers is good, much better clarity than I was expecting. The laptop has built in dual microphones and built in noise reduction (I have not tested that yet. I will update when I do.)

Performance:
Boot-up is fast. The laptop runs quiet, with no noise from the fan. Heat does not appear to be a problem. However, I do use a stand when the laptop is on the table, so I have good airflow. The wifi connection is solid. (One of my older Dell laptops would randomly disconnect, which was extremely annoying, but that seems to have been corrected.)

Conclusion:
There is a lot to like about this laptop. It's perfect for those seeking a richly featured laptop in an affordable price range. With the addition of more RAM, this could be a desktop replacement for me.

theproduct: Dell Inspiron 14 5425 éè§¸æ§ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ - 14 å‹ FHD+ (1920 x 1200)ã€AMD Ryzen7 5825Uã€8GB DDR4 RAMã€512GB SSDã€AMD Radeon Graphics, Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ç¾å ´ + 6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» - éµåµçŸ³ç¶ è‰²
comment:
Simple yet functional laptop for everyday use that will keep good performance for the usual browsing, streaming email etc. jobs. The display is above average with FHD plus resolution, decent graphics, mediocre RAM size (upgradable) but at least DDR4 and average size SSD

You get all the usual connections like USB 3 and USB-C plus display port SD card and for some reason only HDMI 1.4 and you will probably need to use the displayport to output 4K to another monitor/tv. No ethernet port but I don't have one on my more expensive work laptop

Keyboard is comfortable enough for a laptop (i'm not a fan of laptop keyboards in general...) and its backlit. The touchpad works fine. Be ready to wait it out on startup for some updates to come in

Overall this laptop will do you good if general use is what you need (no heavy duty stuff) at a reasonable price

theproduct: Dell Inspiron 14 5425 éè§¸æ§ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ - 14 å‹ FHD+ (1920 x 1200)ã€AMD Ryzen7 5825Uã€8GB DDR4 RAMã€512GB SSDã€AMD Radeon Graphics, Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ç¾å ´ + 6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» - éµåµçŸ³ç¶ è‰²
comment:
I was super grateful and excited to receive this laptop and to be able to review it for Amazon Vine, it hasn't disappointed me either. This is a premium thin-and-light from Dell, and I just have to say that the Inspiron line is a lot sleeker and nicer looking than it was a few years ago. I think that you get most everything you would expect at this price point, except for a couple of things that I would have liked to have seen (like USB 4, 16GB of Ram, and a brighter screen with full HDR/Dolby Vision support)

As for the specs of this machine, you get a 15 watt/U-Series Ryzen 7 paired with 8GB of Ram. But don't worry because you can easily add a second stick of 3200MHz CL22 DDR4 for laptops, the bios doesn't mess up the XMP profile like some brands. Dell is using Kingston brand for the pre-installed stick, but I used a Sabrent brand module for the second one that I added because it was all I had on hand. The SSD is from SK Hynix and it's decently fast for PCIe gen 3, I got speeds of 1900MB/s for sequential read and 1750MB/s for sequential write speed. It is a tiny, little 2230 sized M.2 from SK Hynix. This supports Wifi 6 and Bluetooth 5.2, it is using a Mediatek, M.2 wireless card. I thought that it might be disappointing like a lot of the Realtek wireless cards are, but it actually seems to be almost as good as Intel cards.

There is a 54 watt hour battery inside of this laptop, and it lasts between 7-8 hours on balanced mode. That isn't bad but it's also not what I would expect from a mobile, Ryzen 5000 series processor. I previously reviewed the Surface Laptop 4 and that laptop can last for 16 hours with just a slightly larger battery (but also a larger screen). But, you do get the power with this chip, the Ryzen 7 5825U is basically their top of the line processor for ultrabooks. It should be able to handle just about anything you need it to do, so long as it is a task that makes sense for this form factor. It doesn't have a discrete GPU, even if the Amazon listing was a little unclear about that fact. It does have a decently powerful integrated GPU, although it is still using Vega in the 8 graphical Compute Units that make up the GPU of this chip. You won't see the kind of performance that you would if this was a 6000 series chip (RDNA 2 graphics), but it is still capable of 720p/60fps at low-medium settings. But please temper your expectations a bit, if you truly care about gaming on a laptop, you can do better for this amount of money. This is a thin and light and it is not designed to be a gaming-first type of device.

The keyboard is good, it has a backlight and a fingerprint scanner integrated into the home button that works with Windows Hello, this makes for a very convenient experience with unlocking your laptop. The typing experience is enjoyable with a decent amount of key-travel for a chiclet style keyboard. The trackpad is also good, it does use precision touch drivers, so it feels very responsive and accurate.

There are more than enough ports for this kind of laptop, you get a full-blown USB C port that supports gen 2 data transfer speeds, Power Delivery charging, and video output. There is also an HDMI port, a headphone jack, an SD Card reader (UHS-I), 2x USB A ports, and a proprietary barrel plug for charging the laptop with the included wall charger. You can charge this with USB C, but I kept getting an annoying message saying that the charger I was using was not sufficient for optimal use, which is weird since it was a 100w Power Delivery 3.0 wall charger that supports all the latest features (including PPS). The charger that came in the box is 65 watts and does NOT charge using USB C.

The display is a 14" 1920x1200/60Hz IPS panel, and it looks good, but not great. I think that the colors could be a little more vibrant and I wish it was brighter. I like that the bezels are thin, it keeps the whole entire laptop looking really modern and attractive. The webcam has a slider, so you can cover it to block the camera lens, for privacy/security. I also want to point out that this computer is setup properly with all of the best features enabled for security. It had core isolation and secure boot turned on, by default and the BIOS is configured in a most secure way also.

Pros+

Lightweight, beautiful laptop

Good keyboard/trackpad with backlight and fingerprint scanner

Decent battery life (although it could be a bit better)

Privacy shutter for the webcam

Good performance thanks to the Ryzen 7 5825U

Ram can be easily upgraded, and the BIOS doesn't stop you from enabling XMP profiles (so that you can get the full speed of the Ram that you are using)

Dell is using name brand internal components (SK Hynix SSD, Kingston DDR4, MediaTek wireless card)

Cons-

No USB 4

Only 8GB of RAM (IMO, it should come with 16GB), can be easily remedied

Display could be brighter and have better support for HDR video (HDR10/HLG/Dolby Vision)

Update: I just assumed that the panel they were using on this laptop was 100%sRGB, but in fact, it is actually 45%NTSC. This is kind of crazy to me, considering the maximum brightness is only 250 nits. If you spent the same amount of money on a MacBook Air, you would get a much brighter and more vibrant screen. (DCI-P3 and 400 nits of brightness, with HDR support). I still think that this is a good laptop overall, but I really feel like it should cost about $700 tops, a bad screen can really ruin the day.

theproduct: Dell Inspiron 14 5425 éè§¸æ§ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ - 14 å‹ FHD+ (1920 x 1200)ã€AMD Ryzen7 5825Uã€8GB DDR4 RAMã€512GB SSDã€AMD Radeon Graphics, Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ç¾å ´ + 6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» - éµåµçŸ³ç¶ è‰²
comment:
UPDATE: I wanted to come back and update because I feel like this is a big deal. For some reason all of my kids as toddlers have been obsessed with pulling keys off keyboards. Today my 3 year old was being suspiciously quiet and I found him hiding behind the couch pulling all the keys off my keyboard. If youâ€™ve ever been through this you know itâ€™s a huge pain because usually the little brackets underneath or the clips on the key that hold it to the bracket break if you pull them off and they never go on right or wonâ€™t even stay on. Iâ€™m happy to say that while all the keys shown in the photo were pulled off (and not carefully I might add) all of them went back on perfectly. The â€œGâ€ key kind of sits a little funny because one corner underneath did break but it still stays on and is usable. Anyway Iâ€™m super impressed that theyâ€™d keys are holding up to a toddler determined to pull them all off!

Iâ€™ve been needing a new laptop for a while now. My toddlers got ahold of my Asus and broke and pulled off half the keys on the keyboard and my trackpad buttons kept getting stuck. This is the exact same size as my ASUS but it does have less features for about double the cost. One of the things I loved about my ASUS that cost about 500 a couple years ago is that it was touch screen and the screen would open all the way up to the backside of the keyboard and function as a tablet. This doesnâ€™t have either of those features but probably is a bit better guts wise. This one is surprisingly only a little bit heavier and thicker than my Asus. One thing that I appreciate on this laptop is that the trackpad is bigger and much more responsive. I havenâ€™t lost the cursor yet and had to tap and swipe around the trackpad for a couple seconds to find it like happened with my ASUS. The fingerprint login is kind of cool but unfortunately within the first couple times of using it, it already wasnâ€™t recognizing me and I had to just enter the passcode anyway. I also feel like this laptop pretty fast and responsive in general. I donâ€™t do anything crazy but it has run my websites and my Cricut design space well that I use the most well. It also brought everything over from my Google account which was nice. I wish it would bring over all my downloaded fonts but Iâ€™m sure that will be easy enough with a flash drive. Speaking of drives, this has a usb-c port which is nice for all the newer devices. It also has an SD slot but you will need an adaptor for a micro SD card which is a bummer since almost everything is micro now. There is no disc drive of any type on this laptop which I know is pretty obsolete these days anyway but thought I would mention it. Another thing I appreciated about this laptop is that the plug for the wall is normal sized so it doesnâ€™t take up multiple outlet spaces. That of course means it has that big box about halfway through the cord but I donâ€™t mind that so much. The battery lasted about a day and a half of casual use which is acceptable. The keyboard is backlit which is nice. It also give that full clicking feeling so you know you hit the button but is still very quiet. Lastly when the top opens it kind of tips the keyboard up a bit if sitting on a flat surface. This will be nice for ergonomics as well as allowing the bottom to stay cool.
A couple things I didnâ€™t love about this laptop include that the display seems a little off to me and there are some not great cosmetic choices. When I opened my Cricut design space I immediately noticed a difference between this laptop and my old one. The colors just seem dull or off in some way but just a bit. I tried adjusting it in the settings but couldnâ€™t find anything that would let me adjust it to where I liked. I also noticed in the settings that it has a setting for an on screen touch keyboard which really confused me since itâ€™s not a touch screen. Also the apostrophe and quotations key on the keyboard looks backwards to me. I know it could technically be right but Iâ€™ve never seen a keyboard with it facing this direction. Also the top of my laptop has identical irregular dents in the corners. I noticed them almost right away so I donâ€™t think I caused them. Also the fact that theyâ€™re pretty symmetrical makes me think itâ€™s part of the design somehow but it looks awful. Lastly as far as negatives, it made a weird buzzing sound the whole time I was setting it up that had me a bit concerned but once I had all the setup done it went away. I have no idea what caused that.
Overall this is a nice laptop and will definitely work for my more casual uses. I do think itâ€™s overpriced but maybe Iâ€™m just out of the loop since buying my last laptop a few years ago. I think if I were shopping to buy a laptop I would definitely look for a better priced option with similar features and specs before trying this.
