who: Your Best Source For Unbiased Reviews!
comment: I've tested out a handful of laptops and for the price point I thought this little laptop was nice but after like 3 uses- it's majorly crashed and making me type in a factory key and everything. I've NEVER had a computer do this! I use strong antivirus, firewall, etc and I don't go to shady sites so I didn't get anything bad on the computer... But 3rd time to power it on and it won't boot up. I should have learned after the last Dell I bought, it was in the same price range and absolute junk too. I've always heard Dell is quality but I think people are under that misconception because businesses use them but I can tell you after working at various call centers, they actually use Dell because they have the best corporate discounts for computer orders. Our Dell computers were crashing non-stop at our call centers, you'd think they'd learn and stop using them! This laptops the last straw for me, I'll never touch another Dell product after this!

theproduct: Dell Inspiron 14 5425 éè§¸æ§ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ - 14 å‹ FHD+ (1920 x 1200)ã€AMD Ryzen7 5825Uã€8GB DDR4 RAMã€512GB SSDã€AMD Radeon Graphics, Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ç¾å ´ + 6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» - éµåµçŸ³ç¶ è‰²
comment:
First Iâ€™d like to say I had to contact support right after starting this laptop up. It would not accept the backspace, C, H or question mark keys whatsoever. After speaking with support from Amazon, I installed the windows updates in settings menu. Only after that did it work just fine. So on the initial start up checking for updates you have to go into settings and install more updates BEFORE this laptop will work correctly.
**also did not come charged or even half way charged, I had to charge it first.

A huge plus is that Norton360, CorelDRAW suites, Coral painter and Corel painter essentials are already paid for. Iâ€™m sure there are more but these I installed right away. So far so good with this laptop after working on it for 2 hours.

theproduct: Dell Inspiron 14 5425 éè§¸æ§ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ - 14 å‹ FHD+ (1920 x 1200)ã€AMD Ryzen7 5825Uã€8GB DDR4 RAMã€512GB SSDã€AMD Radeon Graphics, Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ç¾å ´ + 6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» - éµåµçŸ³ç¶ è‰²
comment:
I mainly use this laptop for occasional gaming and everyday web browsing.
This laptop turns on real fast. It only take seconds until main screen if fully on and everything is loaded.
This is important to me because my old laptop takes a long time to be fully loaded.
When I use this laptop on gaming, It is crystal clear and not laggy. It handles very well and fast.
Meanwhile I can still have few other programs on at the same time. They were all nice and smooth too.
This Dell laptop also provides data migrated system to transfer the data from old laptop.
But it has to be done within 6 months. It is still really good.
I can convert everything over to this laptop from my old one.
The FHD screen itself is very clear but it does feel somehow darker screen even on the brightness setting.
I love this size a lot. Small and lightweight that I can put it into my diaper bag. Bring it with me everywhere I go. I love everything in this laptop but RAM. I definitely have to upgrade it to at least 16GB RAM.
So far, it serves all my needs.

theproduct: Dell Inspiron 14 5425 éè§¸æ§ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ - 14 å‹ FHD+ (1920 x 1200)ã€AMD Ryzen7 5825Uã€8GB DDR4 RAMã€512GB SSDã€AMD Radeon Graphics, Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ç¾å ´ + 6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» - éµåµçŸ³ç¶ è‰²
comment:
Iâ€™m not going to go completely into the specs because someone else already wrote a great review including them all and going through each piece of hardware. Iâ€™m also just a general user and not 100% computer tech savvy, so this review is from someone who is just going to go over the physical attributes and some other things. Itâ€™s going to sound like Iâ€™m complaining about small things - but for me itâ€™s the small things I notice. Itâ€™s also going to sound like Iâ€™m complaining a lot but I promise overall this is a great laptop.

My very first laptop I ever owned was a Dell notebook that I used and abused, my 2nd laptop was another Dell - an Inspiron M531R that I wasnâ€™t a fan of and had issues with, then I switched to another brand I hated the computer from the day I got it. Now, I have decided to switch back to Dell and try the Inspiron again with the newest Windows software, AMD Ryzen 7, and newest hardware.

The specs are fine for a general user and should be able to do anything you need to do other than hardcore gaming. One thing I do wish it had was 16gb of ram instead of 8gb since Iâ€™m going backwards compared to what my computer I purchased in 2018 had. Iâ€™m also going from 1TB of memory to 512gb, which isnâ€™t the end of the world because I wasnâ€™t even close to using the 512gb.

I got the â€œpebble greenâ€ but I wish the color was more green. I could barely tell it was any sort of green shade when comparing it to my silver laptop of another brand.

The box has the laptop, charger, and instructions. Out of the box it was not charged and needed to be plugged in. The first thing I did after setting it up was seeing how much memory was already used by the pre-programmed stuff. Sometimes laptops come filled with a bunch of junk programs that youâ€™ll never use. This laptop had 45gb already used by programs, data, and other miscellaneous things which isnâ€™t awful.

The next thing I went over was the actual physical aspects of the laptop. Iâ€™m going from a 15.6â€ laptop to 14 so itâ€™s taking quite a bit to get used to downsizing in size so much. 2 inches doesnâ€™t seem like a lot until you put them side by side. Also because of the size it doesnâ€™t include a number pad which is something I wish I wouldâ€™ve realized earlier - but also not the complete end of the world since I can get a wireless one or one that plugs into the USB plug.

When placing my hands on the keys, the keys just seem a little far from the end of the laptop. What I mean by that is that a lot of my wrist and arm is laying on the laptop more so than my previous one and I think itâ€™s because the touch pad is so large. I will miss not having buttons on the touchpad and itâ€™s going to take me some getting used to clicking and scrolling with the newer touchpad. Right clicks are a little harder and the touch pad is a lot more sensitive. There is also a little ridge right before you get to the keypad which I think was un-needed.

The laptop opens maybe 140 degrees? Itâ€™s not a 180 degrees lay flat kind of laptop. There is also this rubber piece on the hinge that makes it so the laptop is always elevated in the back slightly. Iâ€™m not sure if I like it but I do see the pro of it never laying flat so the fan can circulate air. I think I would just personally like if it would lay flat for some reason.

As far as ports, Iâ€™m happy with what the laptop has. The charger port, one USB A on each side, an HDMI, usb C, and an SD card slot. Im happy to see the laptop still come with an SD card port because I use SD cards to transfer 3D printer files a lot.

One of the most important things to me for a laptop was battery because that was my biggest complaint with my old laptop - which literally didnâ€™t hold a charge for 2 hours before it needed to be plugged in. Iâ€™ve tested this Inspiron multiple times now without a charger and it seems on average to last 7-8 hours. That isnâ€™t fantastic but itâ€™s significantly longer than my last one so Iâ€™m personally happy with that.

The display on this laptop is sharp and clear, I always have liked the matte screen versus a touch screen or covered screen. The volume is mediocre but I dont do a lot of things with audio anyways other than an occasional zoom call or YouTube video.

The webcam is also a lot better in this new Dell and would make it a good laptop for work where you have to zoom or Skype. There is also a little privacy cover for the camera which was kind of funny to me.

Now onto the software. You get windows 11 pro which is fast and convenient. Iâ€™ve always been a windows user so I know the ins and outs and have no complaints. I donâ€™t like the windows pre programmed browsers so the very first thing I did was install Google Chrome instead.

To test out Windows 11 and the laptops hardware, I downloaded some programs I typically use including my 3D printer software which will probably be the most â€œpowerfulâ€ program I run on there. It booted up fast and saved my information over to my SD card quick as well. This laptop combined with our high speed internet is fantastic for general browsing and running basic programs.

I know it sounds like I complained about a lot of things - but they are mostly just small annoyances that I will get used to over time. Overall this is a nice, sleek laptop thatâ€™s easy to travel with and holds a decent charge when unplugged. Windows 11 pro combined with the Ryzen 7 is also a great combo that allows you to do almost anything youâ€™ll need to do.

theproduct: Dell Inspiron 14 5425 éè§¸æ§ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ - 14 å‹ FHD+ (1920 x 1200)ã€AMD Ryzen7 5825Uã€8GB DDR4 RAMã€512GB SSDã€AMD Radeon Graphics, Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ç¾å ´ + 6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» - éµåµçŸ³ç¶ è‰²
comment: Dell has completely revamped their Inspiron line of laptops. A few years ago they were very low-end machines with terrible specs and questionable quality. I wouldn't have even considered buying an Inspiron back then. But over the past year they have dramatically improved the quality and features of this line of laptops. Now Inspiron machines feature the latest CPUs and specs, and the build quality is almost as good as their XPS line. This new Inspiron 14 5425 model has one of the latest Ryzen CPUs, the 5825U. The Geekbench score is just under the Apple M1 CPU, so this is a fast machine. It also has 8GB of RAM and a 512GB SSD drive. My only complaint is that I think it should come with 16GB of RAM. But the speed seems fine with the current 8GB while running Windows 11. It weighs only 3.4 pounds, so it's very lightweight and easy to take anywhere with you. If you have wanted an XPS but can't afford it, this model is a good alternative. It's a perfect machine for either school or work use, and it also comes with a 2-year warranty from Dell. This shows how much confidence Dell has in the reliability of their new Inspiron laptops.

theproduct: Dell Inspiron 14 5425 éè§¸æ§ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ - 14 å‹ FHD+ (1920 x 1200)ã€AMD Ryzen7 5825Uã€8GB DDR4 RAMã€512GB SSDã€AMD Radeon Graphics, Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ç¾å ´ + 6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» - éµåµçŸ³ç¶ è‰²
comment: I've had my share of laptops and have used ones that are 2 core Celerons to an 8 core i7 gaming laptop. Most have their issues. I find that the powerhouses are heavy, and run hot, even with their fans going, not to mention they don't run that long without being plugged in. The Celerons tend to run slow and although I don't do a whole lot on the laptops as a prefer to use a desktop, I don't have the patience for it to be too slow or for programs to get stuck because it doesn't have sufficient RAM. This is a great compromise! The fan can run a little loud, but if I play music on it then it's not noticeable. The size of it is small and compact, enough that I'm outside right now writing this review on this laptop... it's not bulky and cumbersome to tote it where you want to go. I'm happy with the sound and the screen. Again, I don't use it for gaming or high demands so I think it's plenty for me, and better than others I've managed with. The battery seems to last awhile... it's been unplugged for maybe 30 minutes and it's at 99% still, and that's with the music playing too. The keyboard is comfortable. I like that you can close the camera as I know that's a security or rather privacy concern in today's world. Very happy with this little laptop.

theproduct: Dell Inspiron 14 5425 éè§¸æ§ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ - 14 å‹ FHD+ (1920 x 1200)ã€AMD Ryzen7 5825Uã€8GB DDR4 RAMã€512GB SSDã€AMD Radeon Graphics, Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ç¾å ´ + 6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» - éµåµçŸ³ç¶ è‰²
comment:
Performance wise... this laptop is EXCELLENT! I chose this one for my husband... mainly for watching videos and scrolling social media.

The keyboard is very ergonomic, and in comparison to my Inspiron 16, is much easier to type on.

The image is crystal clear and it runs games well for it to not be gaming computer. It also supports 4k, though I did have a bit of trouble with one 4k test video I tried.

Sound- wise, it's decent. As you can tell from the video above, it gets a bit of static at full- volume. That said, it can play through all the frequencies pretty well.

This makes a great computer for school or business but less so for music enthusiasts unless you use headphones.

Overall, we're really happy with it!

comment:
This mouse is worth $5. Sure it works - but it's 2022 and every mouse I've bought for the last 15 years has worked. The plastic is cheap, slick, and thin and it doesn't feel solid in your hand. The plastic is so thin that the whole mouse body creaks with every left click. Feels like a cheap throwaway mouse you would buy for your kids. This mouse is the equivalent of the free throwaway headphones they handout on the plane. Keep Looking.
UPDATE - had the mouse 26 days and the bluetooth quit working. 20 min on the phone with Dell technical support, and they replaced it because it has a 30 day warranty. So my first impressions were correct - I wonder if it will last longer than 26 days this time.

comment: Mouse looks and feels good. Movement and clicks are clear and clean. Advertised battery life is fantastic. But it doesn't wake up on scroll wheel action! Wakes on mouse movement and clicks. Dell forums indicate this is a problem with other Dell mice, so apparently it is by design, but it's very annoying, enough so that I'll be acquiring a replacement. If you don't do much reading on your computer, this may not matter. Like many, I often read a page and then scroll, so the scroll wheel is the only thing I'm touching.

The other mice were difficult to keep from firing click events from the right controller which can lead to lots of unpleasant interruptions with unwanted dialog boxes and possible unintentonal modification or delete actions.

I highly recommend this mouse from Dell because of the control it brings as well as no stringy USB wire. *

* Battery Included!

comment:
Best Mouse I ever got.
It is small and lightweight.
The buttons are awesome, and scroll wheel is good.
Best part is that the dpi is high and so the mouse feels very responsive.
I got it on 17/01/2021 and on 19/01/2021, the mouse got a software update and now in the dell app you can change dpi settings of the mouse between 1000/1600/2400/4000 dpi.
Also i can't really tell the difference between the responsiveness of this mouse and g305.
The g305 has 1ms rated response time and these non-gaming mice are generally rated between 3-5 ms response rate so your eyes can hardly tell the difference.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Inspiron 15 3000 15.6 å‹ Full HD ç¬¬ 11 ä»£ Intel Core i5-1135G7 12GB 256GB SSD ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦
comment:
Bought this thinking that it came with Windows 10. It does not. So it's misleading in that regard.

It is also NOT a touch screen. Despite being listed as such. Not sure if it's a setting or not, but I have not been able to get it to work. GET IT FIXED/UPDATED!

That said. I still enjoy the laptop and functions as any laptop of this caliber should. Gets bogged down just a little when running 3 monitors for my work station, but it is very minor. It does a fantastic job running more than a few programs like Word, Excel, Chrome, etc. at the same time. It's super light, the keyboard feels crisp, and the track pad is big where I don't feel like I run out of real estate moving the pointer.

2 stars for the false advertising.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Inspiron 15 3000 15.6 å‹ Full HD ç¬¬ 11 ä»£ Intel Core i5-1135G7 12GB 256GB SSD ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦
comment:
Pros
Compact.
Enough performance for everyday works and some more (development, virtualization) if it is with SSD drive. Otherwise (in my case laptop came with HDD which is not in description) it will work very slow.
Ergonomic full keyboard. Screen has good vewing angle and quality.
Cons
No RJ45 and Type-C ports (In description they was).
Cooling system is noicy when CPU load is more than 50%
Quality of keyboard and touch-pad is not a top.
Overall the plastic is very cheep and keeping fingerprints. You need to clean it often.
Warnings
Be careful when opening screen when laptop placed on desk as the bottom-back edge of screen cover can be scrubbed.
Overall
Not bad choice by performance/price.

P.S.
I have added M.2 NVMe 256 GB drive and replaced HDD with SATA 3 SSD 512GB drive. Works perfectly! Many thanks seller.

comment:
(Review, Dell Inspiron 15 3501 -- i5-1135G7, 12GB RAM, 256GB SSD -- 5 stars!)

This is an excellent budget PC for daily use -- thin & light design; super fast; brilliant & crisp display; always cool while working; and enough ports including legacy ports. And, in terms of design & performance, it compares very closely, and favorably with another great PC that I also use, the highly user-rated HP 15, model 15-dy1043dx (i5-1035G1, 12GB RAM, 256GB SSD); whose current version seems to be: HP 15-dy2021nr, also highly regarded!

Having used my Dell PC for several months now, I am super happy with it for daily work (mainly Web-based stuff, Zoom meetings, phone links via the MS Your Phone App, and plenty of MS Office Apps, mainly Word & Excel.) So, overall: 5 stars, STRONGLY RECOMMENDED!

In terms of design and performance, this Dell PC also gets high user and expert ratings. (For info: this same PC is rated at an average of 4.7 stars by many customers of Best Buy. It is also rated by Windows Central Reviewers as the Best Budget Dell 15â€ PC of 2021!)

By Kim Mems

comment:
I added WD Blue SA510 as my secondary drive and was facing the problem of intermittently losing my drive in "File Explorer" and could not access my files.
I made several phone calls to Dell technical support and they were directing me to Dell sales team and refuse to go to sales team as I am technically competent enough to make simple upgrade like this.
I kept on asking what kind of drive it takes in the secondary drive slot (2.5 inch with SSD cable attached MB) Dell has provided.
I was told that may be because of compatibility issues of SSD I am using, so I asked give me the compatibility list or the drive type it takes (the drive types are made with industry standards). Again I was told that our technical team is not trained to answer this question.
So all in all Dell wanted to sell me paid technical support for the information they are supposed to provide and sell hardware and installation service.

THIS IS TOTAL EXOTRTION OF MONEY AFTER SELLING THE PRODUCT!!!

comment: I purchased this as a business computer. Everything seemed to work well until Friday morning when I turned on the computer and opened my email and could not connect to the internet. The computer is not showing any sign of wi-fi access. There is no way to manually turn wi-fi on or off. I called my IT guy and he searched and searched and said it seems that the internal wi-fi card is damaged. I purchased this laptop in November 2021!!! Now I am forced to use an ethernet connection which limits the mobility of my laptop and I will have to purchase a wireless adapter, more money, more money. I will be contacting the seller, but Amazon should also respond since I purchased off of this site. I'll let you know how they respond, but for now don't buy unless you plan to buy again in three months or not use wifi!!!

comment: I purchased Dell Inspiron 15 from the Dell's website paying over $1000 2 years ago. The problems started within a year of purchase. It still continues. Dell fixes the problems you shouldn't have in the first place. They don't care if you don't have the extended warranty. A person who pays more than $1000 shouldn't worry about the problems of the laptop. Dell simply rips you off by selling you messed up computers and making you pay for the fixes. What a problematic company! I will never buy from this brand again.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Inspiron 15 3000 15.6 å‹ Full HD ç¬¬ 11 ä»£ Intel Core i5-1135G7 12GB 256GB SSD ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦
comment:
Not bad for a budget laptop - big screen, good keyboard, good battery life, fairly light weight. It is a good value laptop, its functionality not to be confused with a gaming laptop or a high performance general laptop.
The biggest annoyance - it came preinstalled with windows 11. No choice, just installed itself after turning on. Windows 11 takes away many of the look-and-feel customizations, and the default design as well as many of the preset themes are ... childish? I don't know how to describe the bland default colors, it seems like the designers think a white piece of paper without edges, and barely visible dividing lines - when present, are some sort of eclectic design cue that they must follow. No offense, but the border-less look is not practical at all, and not pleasing to the user.
The second biggest annoyance, there is no contrast adjustments, hardware or software. And if you search for a solution, it seems like the entire web is plastered with tips on how to adjust brightness, and the only "adjustment" to contrast are recommendations on using one of the preset high-contrast themes. And boy... they are ugly.
But I kept mine and didn't return it.
After a couple of days I couldn't take the ugly windows 11 anymore so I bit the bullet and installed Linux Mint, the third version which is supposedly the lightest. Amazing how a free operating system would have three versions to help users get the most out of the system.
Anyways, great experience, minimal research before or after install, and the battery life was not adversely affect... That I can see. I use it to browse the web 3 to 4 hours at a time, and I use less than 1/2 the battery. I don't recharge it because then I use it again in morning for sounds an hour. Still left with lots of power.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Inspiron 15 3000 15.6 å‹ Full HD ç¬¬ 11 ä»£ Intel Core i5-1135G7 12GB 256GB SSD ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦
comment:
Was happy at first - but after 15 months of fairly light usage:
- Keyboard is disintegrating - several letters have come loose, others have to be keyed multiple times to be register.
- Case is disintegrating - screen surround has worked lose in lower left corner, screen can no longer be closed.
- Keyboard markings have been wearing off since new.

Can now only use it in 'desktop mode' with an external keyboard and mouse, but I'm not expecting it to remain operational much longer. And it's a little light to be repurposed as a boat anchor. Admittedly, the price point was good - but for Dell to put their name on this pap shows they're no longer interested in maintaining customer satisfaction or loyalty.

comment: I just got mine yesterday January 19, 2022. The most striking feature is how far back the keys are from the front of the computer. It is uncomfortable. I have to actually rest my arm on the front of the laptop to reach the keys. I've had a lot of laptops and that is really odd. I also like my keys to be more raised --they are very flat- but that pales in comparison to how annoying the long reach to the keys is. If the normal reach is 4ish inches this would be an extra 2ish inches from the front of the computer to reach the keys. I was surprised that it thinks it is anti-glare. A striking feature was that it hurt my eyes right away. I immediately bought an anti-blue light protector on the second day. Other than that it seems decent. Booted right up. Had that new computer zippiness. Connected to the internet fine.

The ON LED is at the bottom and is supper small so unless sitting next to monitor it is hard to know if it is on (and asleep).

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 24 è¢å¹• - P2422H - Full HD 1080p,IPS æŠ€è¡“,ComfortView Plus æŠ€è¡“
comment:
The monitor is excellent.

Of the three cables delivered with the monitor, none is useful, hower. The power cable is very short and the two others do not connect the monitor to my laptop.

It would be better to sell the monitor without cables and suggest a choice of cables that are suitable to the buyer's setup. The current solution of sending three default cables creates a lot of unnecessary trash (unused cables) and extra cost to buyers.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 24 è¢å¹• - P2422H - Full HD 1080p,IPS æŠ€è¡“,ComfortView Plus æŠ€è¡“
comment: You want these for work, to give out to people, largely better than the much cheaper ones by virtue of the stand. You can get a similar quality out of lots of cheaper monitors. But these come with the very sturdy stand so your employees can all generally fit things in without stacking up reams of paper or whatever. They are generally a little more solidly built than the cheap-o monitors. I gave up trying to save $100. The stand alone is worth half that if you try to replace it, and half the really cheap monitors won't even mount on a VESA stand. They don't have the holes.

comment:
I have been using Dell laptops for more than a decade and I trust thus brand. However the cables included with this monitor do not function. I bought two of this monitors and called up the Dell monitor queue for support. They performed troubleshooting for 30 minutes to rule out monitor issues. It ultimately boiled down to faulty cables for BOTH monitors. Dell refused to send me replament cables saying these "cables are complementary sir, we don't replace. We can take back both your monitors and send you refurbished (used) ones."
How absurd! I refused.
I called up Dell laptop support queue to see if my laptop had issues. And they told me the cables included with the monitors are NOT meant for connecting the monitor to a laptop for display! I had to spend my own money and buy HDMI cables!
I can't believe Dell does this to their customers!

comment: I had mixed reaction to this laptop the fan is on the bottom of the machine and is very loud abs make the device run hot. However, I was able to fix this through the Dell Assistant support AI bot that told me to update my BIOs - problem resolved. It is not a touch screen device either. However, it is robust and easy to use with W11 and M365. All my setting came over from my other device. It is lightweight! I am liking it more than I did originally. theproduct: Dell Inspiron 14 5420 ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ - 14 å‹éè§¸æ§é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,Intel Core i5-1235U,8GB DDR4 RAM,512GB SSD,Intel UHD Graphics,Intel Wi-Fi 6E,Windows 11 Home - é‰‘é‡‘éŠ€
comment: Before even turning it on for the very first time I yanked out the 512GB SSD and 8GB stick of RAM and upgraded it to a 1 TB WD Black SN750 nvme and 64GB RAM (G.Skill RipJaws Series 64GB (2 x 32GB) 260-Pin SO-DIMM PC4-25600 DDR4). After verifying all the new hardware was recognized in the BIOS I proceeded to install Win 11 Pro and the Dell driver assistant software which automatically installed all the required drivers. It also upgraded the BIOS as well (which took about 20 mins!). It's mostly been used for coding projects and running multiple VM's under Hyper-V. It's quite insane it comes with a 2k screen and actual RAM slots in a 14" laptop!

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 34 å‹è¶…å¯¬,WQHD(å¯¬å››é«˜æ¸…),æ›²é¢ USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨(P3421W),3440 x 1440,60Hz,3800R æ›²ç‡,1.07 å„„ç¨®é¡è‰²,å¯èª¿æ•´,é»‘è‰²
comment:
My general thoughts: I am very satisfied with this display. I did a lot of research on the best fit for my situation. I wanted something that appeared somewhat professional and sleek, and most of the options in the price range are tailored for gamers and look like gaming monitors. I first looked at 4k monitors so that the resolution would be that far off but there just arenâ€™t many ultra-high res options for less than $1,300. I forget exactly how I found this display, but I am glad I did. At the time of purchase, it was $679. I noticed as of a few days later the price went up above $700. I am sorry to see that for anyone interested in it. I was a little nervous about the resolution but had to remember I was still stepping up from a $150 1080p 24â€ monitor. I plan to use this connection to a new MBP, I am still on the fence about waiting for the possible updates next year. For now, I am using a windows 7 machine that I built like 8 years ago. Anyway, back to the resolution, 1140p looks good compared to 1080p and the fact that the screen is enormous is a real game-changer for productivity. I use mine for school and work and man itâ€™s amazing having the windows side by side. Where I work, I have 2 monitors set up, I just prefer this so much more though. Itâ€™s clean, using less power, fewer cables, and does the same thing. You can even get â€œsuper ultra-wideâ€ but I think itâ€™s a bit overkill, at least for me. I recommend reading all the specs and features because there are many. You might find more info on dell.com.

Connectivity & settings: I plugged it in using a DP (display port) and it calibrated itself. I dint not change any settings, the aspect ratio was perfect! Color calibration and all settings are perfect. I will not be adjusting any of it. Thatâ€™s cool to me, I mean I spent hours adjusting my 70â€ 4K TV. I still mess with it after years of ownership. Donâ€™t forget this display comes with HDMI and Thunderbolt inputs with a few USB ports. So you could have this running your laptop and keeping it charged to boot.

Image quality: It might be that my old monitor just sucked, but I am so happy with this purchase. The image quality and clarity are fantastic for what it claims to be. This monitor is not advertised as UHD so if you expect UHD, itâ€™s not. But seriously, most people out the can relax about that. This is not comparable to say, an iMac retina display. So it would look out of place next to one, but as your primary display and laptop in clamshell mode, this is not going to disappoint. I downloaded a ton of high res ultra-wide images for my backgrounds. They look awesome. I ran a couple of color and gamma tests and this display was calibrated perfectly right out of the box. Plug and play, in my experience. Oh, it is worth noting that it is pretty bright, no complaints about brightness.
Build quality: I like the design of the display because it looks great at the home of the office. I am not a fan of gaming-style displays, they just look a little cheesy to me with added logos and lines. I think of this monitor as a conservative luxury design like a BMW 5 series vs. a Honda Civic Type R. Nothing against the Type R, itâ€™s an outstanding automobile and an engineering marvel. It just looks like a cartoon. The bezel is about 1 CM and it has a Â¾â€ chin at the bottom. It comes out of the box with a film on the screen. Most people wonâ€™t even notice it, and it is hardly noticeable except for the very edge and appears to be protecting the screen so I will be leaving it on unless it starts to peel naturally or something.

Included in the box: It came with several cables! I was thankful for that. I think it had a power cable, HDMI, DP and a USB-C, and some cable management accessories. The box was the least impressive part for me. It is very generic, just regular old cardboard, and the lady sat it down on its side in front of my door. Wind could have blown it over or something. Hey, she got it to me in working condition, so all good.

Bonus: I also ordered a new desk pad and Logi mouse. Both are awesome!

Desk pad: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B08DG8Q2FH/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Logitech MX Master: https://www.amazon.com/Logitech-Master-Advanced-Wireless-Mouse/dp/B07S395RWD/ref=sr_1_2?dchild=1&keywords=logitech+mx+master&qid=1625000349&sr=8-2

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 34 å‹è¶…å¯¬,WQHD(å¯¬å››é«˜æ¸…),æ›²é¢ USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨(P3421W),3440 x 1440,60Hz,3800R æ›²ç‡,1.07 å„„ç¨®é¡è‰²,å¯èª¿æ•´,é»‘è‰²
comment:
Update: the latest firmware (M2B207 - July 2022) corrects the issues I had experienced with the KVM. My one remaining quibble is the KVM only supports two devices, even though the monitor itself can connect three (HDMI + DisplayPort + USB-C) because there are only two upstream connections (USB-B & USB-C) for devices to access the monitor's ports. So if you want to share a keyboard and mouse amongst multiple devices, this monitor can handle two but not three. I rate it 4.5 stars with the latest firmware.
----
The P3421W is my first ultrawide and first curved screen, but I bought it specifically for its built-in KVM. The size is a reasonable replacement for dual screens, though it is still noticeably smaller than two 1080p's, as you might expect based on the resolution. The curve looked strange for about a day and after that I stopped noticing it. What drives me crazy is the KVM. I use it to switch between a Mac and a PC. I do not use the PIP/PBP features (it really isn't big enough for that). But it's always a gamble whether switching from one input to the other is going to find a signal, particularly if one machine has just woken from sleep. Switching back and forth between inputs can put the monitor into a state where neither its joystick nor its power button produce any response, and the monitor needs to be unplugged to reboot it. Clearly the monitor's firmware is buggy (I've updated to the latest). Unless this is fixed, I can't give it more than an average rating overall.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 34 å‹è¶…å¯¬,WQHD(å¯¬å››é«˜æ¸…),æ›²é¢ USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨(P3421W),3440 x 1440,60Hz,3800R æ›²ç‡,1.07 å„„ç¨®é¡è‰²,å¯èª¿æ•´,é»‘è‰²
comment:
Very pleased with this monitor now. Even though I can't run it at full resolution due to my ancient nvidia GT3somthing. Even at 2560x1080, the picture looks great. Usually when you run a monitor lower than it's native res, it looks really grainy. This one, while not as sharp as the full res, does not look all that grainy.
My big problem when I first plugged it in was that my mouse was extremely jumpy. I look all over for help and solutions and found none. Everyone said it was the mouse driver, which I knew wasn't true because when I lowered to 1280x1024, the mouse worked perfectly. Dropping down to lower widescreen resolutions didn't help though. So I spent some time messing around in all the various settings apps and discovered that nvidia, by default, was treating this as a television. Meaning refresh rate was 24hz! No wonder my mouse was so choppy. So I changed it from TV to monitor mode and it brought the refresh rate up to 30hz at 3440Ã—1440 which was better, but still choppy. So I switched to 2560x1080 and that brought the refresh rate to 60hz. And now my mouse is perfect again.
So, I guess I have to get a new computer to take full advantage of this monitor. But Dell or nvidia or microsoft or somebody should change this monitor profile to default to monitor mode. Not TV mode.

comment:
As more content becomes 21:9, the viewing experience is greatly appreciated with a wider screen.
The pixels are noticeable if you look close enough. I ran the monitor through various monitor tests and did not see any dead pixels on 10bit mode without sub-sampling. The power button indent is much appreciated. It makes it easy to turn on/off as opposed to the feeling for the small numb on the U3417 and like. I generally can fit 2 windows comfortably side by side (perhaps 38" would provide the much needed space for 3 windows). The curvature is quite high (large number / less curve) that I find myself turning from side to side instead of moving my body.

The placement of the ports is somewhat low and thus prevents you from shifting the monitor to its lowest position without going too far and pinching the cables. Small incremental movements are hard to pull off and often end up as some jerking motion.

comment: If you are wanted a great monitor for the imac mini this one is great. I really love the monitor. Running at 60hz it meets Apple's requirements. If you are thinking a 120hz monitor is better, those are not compatible. This is the one to get. Some things to know, the PBP works good but the monitor switching is done using a hardware switch like joystick. The software to manage the screens is not designed to work on mac or linux. But there are some third party open source options. I found it just easier to have more then one keyboard for multiple computers in a mixed OS environment. You may be able to get the drivers working easier on linux. Running 3440 x 1440 on the M1 imac.

USB-C port stopped wiring after 2 months.
Spend an hour and 6 phone calls with Dell to try to get it resolved, but they cannot find the Service Tag number as it is not bought directly from Dell and therefor they are not supporting it. The reseller says it should be supported by Dell and is not providing any help at all. Amazon is letting me hang in the middle with a defective monitor that should still be within warrantee, but no one to handle the warrantee.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 34 å‹è¶…å¯¬,WQHD(å¯¬å››é«˜æ¸…),æ›²é¢ USB-C é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨(P3421W),3440 x 1440,60Hz,3800R æ›²ç‡,1.07 å„„ç¨®é¡è‰²,å¯èª¿æ•´,é»‘è‰²
comment:
I received the monitor and tried to register it through Dell to confirm that I was eligible for their standard (and highly regarded) 3-year warranty on all new products. However, the service tag (the unique code Dell uses to track the products they sell) is invalid, so Dell does not recognize this unit as a valid Dell product. So I'm not sure if this monitor is a bootleg, or the seller acquired them illegally or what, but I do know that it means no warranty from Dell.

I see that some other reviews mention the same issue so I know it's not unique to the unit I purchased. I would highly recommend purchasing this monitor directly through Dell - a little more expensive but worth it to avoid future headaches. I don't know why Amazon allows 3rd party sellers to sell illegitimate products on their platform...

I went around-and-around with several Amazon agents, Dell, and the reseller. The reseller couldn't help me because this order was "Fulfilled by Amazon". Dell told me exactly what Amazon need to do, but of the several agents that I was transferred around to, none of them had a clue what I was talking about.

Now, I am very suspicious of how this monitor came into Amazon's possession. Perhaps that explains why it is so much less expensive here than at other (more reputable?) resellers...?

comment:
When the monitor arrived and I used it for a few minutes, it flickered wildly. With lots of web searching, I found that by reducing the response rate of the monitor and using LCD conditioning, I was able to reduce the flickering.

The flickering is a well reported issue for anyone using this monitor with a Macbook. Dell does not support this monitor with Macs. In fact, they don't support most of their monitors with Macs. So, they were of no help for me in dealing with the issue.

Summary: do not buy if you are planning to use this with a Macbook. It's working for me for now, but I don't know if it will stay that way; and I know Dell will not help me if it doesn't.

comment: This is a gorgeous monitor, elegant and professional looking. I canâ€™t stop looking at it. Lol! Set up is a breeze, was able to do it all on my own in 10-15 mins. I connected it to the display port and I was able to use it right away, no set up needed. No dead pixel, no bleeding, no IPS glow. Day1, it felt a little too big though I am coming from three monitors - 17/19/20â€. But the next day it feels normal and it has so much real estate that I donâ€™t miss having multiple monitors. I use the comfort view preset mode and itâ€™s really easy on my eyes. I donâ€™t need to use my blue light glasses anymore. Brightness is really good, I had to reduce mine from 75% to 53% cause 75% was too bright for me that I felt I was getting headaches (I have sensitive eyes to light). I use this monitor for work only - mostly emails and spreadsheets and itâ€™s really pleasant to use. Text is sharp enough for what I am using the monitor for. Canâ€™t complain with the pictures either though I do not use this for photo/video editing. It doesnâ€™t have a speaker but I am planning to get the Dell slim soundbar soon. I havenâ€™t tried the KVM/PIP/PBP features because I donâ€™t have the need to do so as of the moment. My only minor complaint is that itâ€™s hard to reach the ports at the back of the monitor. I have mine set up close to the wall and when I tried to use the HDMI/USB-C cable to test them, I had to move the entire monitor to see and reach the back. Also I wish itâ€™s a little more curved, but I didnâ€™t want to spend $300-$500 more for the Dell U3421WE model. So I decided to go with this P3421W monitor. I really want to stay with Dell monitors because of the quality. I have a sit stand desk and a very stable stand is a must so it wonâ€™t fall forward or move everytime I adjust my desk. And 3600R is not bad at all. Itâ€™s still comfortable to use, I can still see all corners without moving my head which is important to me cause moving my head left to right (even little movements) strains my neck. I love that height is adjustable, it tilts and swivels too. Makes it easier to customize for a more comfortable position. Yes, Iâ€™m very happy with my purchase!

comment:
After a good research on the best screen for a productive setup to work from home (not gaming), I decided to buy my first ever curved ultrawide monitor.
What I love the most of the P3421W is the resolution, build quality and design for a productive setup as its soft curved screen (3800R) provides such uniform visual focus that I can work on my spreadsheets comfortably. I adjusted immediately to its soft curve to the point I did't notice it after a couple of minutes of usage.
The only thing I'm a bit disappointed with and the only reason I don't give 5 stars to this product is that when I connect my Dell XPS 15 via the USB-C port, it doesn't provide enough power to my laptop. Hence, my laptop's system warns me that it couldn't not run at its full capacity. This doesn't happen when connecting laptops with similar features from other brands so I would be expecting a seemlessly Dell user experience. I believe Dell should consider to cover those different power requirements from their own laptops to connect these type of monitors via the USB-C port.

comment:
As a year 12 this year the main reason why I got this monitor is for two things:

Ultra-wide: I was looking for an ultrawide monitor so that I can have multiple docs or websites opened at once without having to switch between screens. This is really especially for online classes as you can have your meeting up as well as your schoolwork.

USB-C: With the low connectivity macs have these days, USB-C is about the only way to display your screen without using adaptors. Not only does it display my screen but also charges the laptop.

I keep my brightness at 75% and that's more than enough to use throughout the day, sometimes I have to tone it down at night because it's so bright.

For the price, this is a great monitor for doing casual browsing, entertainment and schoolwork, so much so I've bought this twice!

comment: The only thing I had to overcome with this wonderful docking station was the ability to tie in to thunder bolt and the high speed "C" connections. I was migrating from an older Dell Docking Station dependent on USB 3 instead of going through the more advanced infrastructure this docking station enables. Reccomend getting one of the multiple "C" and Thunderbolt hubs with hi speed cables if you are connected to multiple drives like I am.

theproduct: Dell ThunderBolt 4 æ“´å……åº§ (WD22TB4),é»‘è‰²
comment: The sound splitter that pulls audio out of the HDMI signal for 3.5mm jack for external speakers would not work with this docking station as it skipped a bunch, and I had run the same exact splitter on my xbox with no issue. Since I was running a KVM and USB hub outside of the docking station, I broke the five hop USB rule so my I could route USB though this as the doc took up two hops. This worked fine with my Lenovo docking station not so good with this one. Sound quality out of the dock (HDMI or Thunderbolt) was much worse than the laptops 3.5 mm jack but part of that could be attributed to different drivers (Nvidia vs Realtek). With all these issues I returned it. Not worth spending my $220 bucks on something that halfway worked for me. Disappointed indeed.

comment:
This review is for the seller, not the product.

The unit I bought does not recognize any USB devices tried plugging in. I tried with two different wireless mouse/keyboards and my phone. After updating all the drivers, and rebooting everything, my computer doesn't recognize the device as a Dell product. I did all of the troubleshooting steps, and called Dell tech support. According to Dell, this product was supposed to be sold in China and the warranty is registered in China. So I have to transfer the warranty to the US, return the product, and then get sent a new one from Dell. This process will take a month! Why would the seller send me a product that is supposed to be sold in a different country?

comment: This device does not satisfy the power requirements of my Alienware m16 gaming laptop. I haven't found one yet that does, but this was the closest and I took a chance on the Dell-proprietary power mode working - I still think it would, but this laptop needs *more* power. theproduct: Dell ThunderBolt 4 æ“´å……åº§ (WD22TB4),é»‘è‰²
comment:
Brand new, absolute top of the line Dell gaming laptop with Thunderbolt 4 port. Bought the only thunderbolt 4 dock made by Dell. Unfortunately, I cant start the computer with the dock plugged in.

My start up process: 1- power on /2- open laptop since it won't go to monitors until I clear error message /3- clear error message in bios that says dock is trying to provide power to non-power port /4- shut laptop and wait for it to go to sleep. 5/ wake it up again so it boots to external monitors. Same results with or without manufacturer power cord.

It will sound like an exaggeration, but I genuinely spent 3.5 GRUELING HOURS ON THE PHONE WITH CUSTOMER SERVICE. I was passed around to exactly 13 CUSTOMER SERVICE AGENTS. Dell hung up on me multiple times and sometimes just put me on hold until I gave up. The determined that my docking station was not compatible though several agents suggested that it should work fine. They offered to send me the exact same, non-compatible unit as a replacement. The main part of my experience involved an agent from one of three departments (Customer Care, Tech Support or Sales) telling me they could see that my dock was incompatible and that if I talked so someone from another department (one of the 2 others) that they would be able to create the proper notes/documentation/case number that would allow me to return my dock. Eventually, a sweet technician named Kristina offered to stay with me during my handoff to another department so she could help get it resolved. She was no more successful than I was. She asked if we could escalate to a manager and they tech support guy said he could file a claim to escalate the refund process and that someone would call me (not email, I clarified) to help me get this taken care of. Instead, I got a ONE SENTENCE EMAIL a couple days later telling me that I could purchase a dock on their website. He included a link to the docking station section of their website, not to a specific dock that would work.

Now I have PTSD and still no compatible docking station. Dell is terrible. I'm convinced they know how bad they are since I am not able to leave a review for either product on their website.

theproduct: Dell ThunderBolt 4 æ“´å……åº§ (WD22TB4),é»‘è‰²
comment: Does exactly what it's supposed to do. Port replication and high-speed charging on compatible laptops. Dell Docking station - and I assume other vendors solutions - are just an elaborate adapter to break out your laptops ports to provide more flexible connectivity options for network, video, sound, USB peripherals, etc. Anyone purchasing this because they think it is an external video card that will have or add on to the capability of their existing computer video card or other hardware is seriously misinformed and this is not the fault of Dell or anyone else. Also, if your device does not have thunderbolt 4 and you have a lackluster experience with this device, keep in mind running it in USB-C mode will only yield the capability based on the bandwidth of USB-C and not Thunderbolt. Long story short - you need to understand what you are buying before you buy and give a negative review.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Inspiron 3583 15Ã¢'Â¬ ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ Intel Celeron 128GB SSD 4 1.6GHz - UHD Graphics 610 - Windows 10 Home - Inspiron 15 3000 ç³»åˆ— - å…¨æ–°
comment:
I've always LOVED Dell Desktop computers. I've had several throughout many years. But I'd never heard anything about Dell laptops. Knowing that Dell makes the best desktops (in my opinion!), I decided to try the laptop. I couldn't believe how fast I fell in love with this laptop. I've had it for over a month now, using it for several hours each day & I have only found 2 problems with it:
The color on the display is dull. Not the correct colors. I mean, I don't know the technical terms for all this, but it seems like the coloring that the display shows, is of low quality. It isn't HDR so it's kind of upsetting. I like to have brilliant color.
The 2nd problem is the keyboard. The keys are cramped together so it's hard for me to type because I have big fingers. I usually type 95 wpm but on this keyboard I make so many mistakes that it's like I can't type at all!! I'd like the keys more spread out. All laptops seem to have cramped keys, but this one is worse.
But, even with those 2 annoyances, I LOVE THIS DELL LAPTOP!!! The price for it was unbelievable! I'm only going to buy Dell's from now on. The customer service is Old School, which means they care. I will add to this in a couple of months so you can see that I will still love my Dell!!
January 22, 2022 - I've had my Dell for almost 5 months now. Like I said, I STILL LOVE MY DELL!! I'm getting used to the keys a little bit but I bought a keyboard & attached it to my laptop & it works great. Like I said in my earlier review, Dell's are the best desktop computers, & now I can honestly say that they make the best laptops too. It's worth it to spend a little more because you'll have your Dell for WAY longer than any other brand. Soooooo, to sum it all up, I LOVE MY DELL LAPTOP!!! LOLOL

comment:
This is a perfectly adequate, boring PC laptop. It came loaded with Windows 10, upgradable to Windows 11. It has no touch screen, but we knew that coming in. 15-inch computers are passe in 2023, and they're heavy to carry around. All of which I can live with.

But this thing is so damn slow. We bought the 4G RAM, and I'm about to upgrade to 8G. I hope that fixes this, because it's nearly unusable - my wife gets up and walks away, to return to find it grinding its way through an app.

UPDATE: now it works well with an 8 GB RAM upgrade. It was fairly easy to install, and now the computer runs at a normal speed. It's still big.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Inspiron 3583 15Ã¢'Â¬ ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ Intel Celeron 128GB SSD 4 1.6GHz - UHD Graphics 610 - Windows 10 Home - Inspiron 15 3000 ç³»åˆ— - å…¨æ–°
comment: The Dell model 3583 is specified (Dell Specs p.12) with an 8th generation Intel core i3, i5, or i7 CPU. I suspect due to the 'chip shortage' Dell was forced to dive into the ol' parts bin and ship this particular 3583 with an older - and MUCH lower specs - Pentium Gold 5th generation CPU with limited cache. To try to compensate, Dell also shipped this unit with a M.2 SSD rather than the spec'd spinning HDD. That was very good of them. But the mis-match seems to be creating some lag in 'getting things done', although not critical. I may (probably) be wrong about this, but then I'm not a computer whiz. It would be great if Dell eventually tracked this order and in future shipped us a comparable Core i3 CPU with a realistic cache. Hey, I can dream! In addition - 3583 comes spec'd with Win 10 Home (not S mode). S mode sucks and the time it takes to dump it is a pain. 2cts.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Inspiron 3583 15Ã¢'Â¬ ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ Intel Celeron 128GB SSD 4 1.6GHz - UHD Graphics 610 - Windows 10 Home - Inspiron 15 3000 ç³»åˆ— - å…¨æ–°
comment: What this is: A super lightweight laptop with a descent set of ports and a workable screen at a fantastic price with the latest Windows version. What it's not: a high-end speedster gaming laptop. This is an extremely power efficient, slower processor ensemble that easy to upgrade. It's is tuned by default to super power saver. IMO, that makes it almost unusable in real life. Set the power mode to performance, and it becomes a great media consumption, email, social, writing machine with a good 6 hrs of battery. Oh, there is an open slot to put any 2.5" (7-9mm) laptop drive inside and you can double the RAM memory for about $25. I'm buying two more to use as Linux machines. I was hesitant about this at first but very happy in the end.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Inspiron 3583 15Ã¢'Â¬ ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ Intel Celeron 128GB SSD 4 1.6GHz - UHD Graphics 610 - Windows 10 Home - Inspiron 15 3000 ç³»åˆ— - å…¨æ–°
comment: We were looking to get a second laptop as the pandemic had pushed both my partner and I to be working from home. We weren't looking for anything fancy, but we needed more oomph than a Chromebook. This Dell fit the bill. It's not going to wow you, but it's got enough power to support web browsing, doc and presentation creation, and graphic design programs all at once. It moves along at a nice clip, as well. It's not incredibly heavy, but it's certainly not designed as a "lightweight" solution. My one real complaint is that the mouse touchpad is awkwardly positioned and configured, which can slow me down while I'm trying to switch between applications. All in all, I'd recommend it as a basic and affordable option, but don't expect it to turn heads.

comment:
I ordered this laptop in June for a new job I started. I was to be working hybrid, home on Tues/Thurs and in the Office MWF. My old laptop was a janky Lenovo from college that just needed to go, so I did some digging and found this laptop. The reviews were solid, and the price wasn't steep at all so I went for the purchase.

Worst. Mistake. Ever. When I say this laptop is slow, this laptop is SLOW. I've done every update possible, checked for out of date drivers and updated the ones that needed updating. I've installed software for security, and mostly use this laptop for work and my own personal work, so nothing dodgy is ever downloaded onto my laptop.

It takes about 5-7 minutes for the initial log-in to load, another 7-10 minutes for the laptop to 'wake up' and what feels like 20 years to load apps, such as Chrome or what have you. Even while typing this review, the lag is just ridiculous. The cursor is currently stuck on the word 'even'........ and it's still stuck there.

Just slow slow slow all around since day one of getting this laptop.

Now here's the kicker... this week and next I'm working from home again, and I decided to check with Dell's website to see if there are any additional driver updates I can find. Now according to the Amazon listing for this laptop, this is a Dell Inspiron 3583. I went to the Dell support website and did a search for the Inspiron 3583, but the website said that this search didn't yield anything. I went to my Amazon orders to make sure I had the correct model, but again the search didn't bring anything up. SO, I put my laptop onto it's monitor to look at the model number that comes on the laptop.......... the laptop I received is AN INSPIRON 3502!?!? Can you say false advertising?????? I'll definitely be filing a complaint with Amazon.

Do yourself a favor, and just skip onto the next laptop if you were considering purchasing this one. I've seen other reviews mentioning just how slow this laptop is, and they are absolutely correct. If you have a 5hr work day, you'll be waiting 7hr just to get this thing slightly up and running. Definitely not a recommended product.

comment:
First thing to know is that this is a 2020 model and Dell warranties are expired.

I ordered this product twice. The first time, I received an Inspiron 3510, which had a slower processor and only one ram slot.

Second order, the correct model was delivered, but product details indicate this PC has BOTH a 128 GB SSD and a 500 GB HDD. It has only the 128 GB SSD. Seller's response was that this was a "typo" despite it being in several places on this listing (and this model PC CAN have both). They offered a $10 credit, which is laughable considering its missing an $80 part. It's being returned and I'm done here.

Note: the listing has since been modified to take out a few of the references to a 500 GB HDD (I believe this was done at my own request during a customer service call--seller did not seem to care) but it still appears there at least once as of 9/20/22.

comment:
I did not discover until I got through setup that this machine has Windows 11 Home installed, not Windows 10 as advertised. That matters because Windows 11 may not work with some of my legacy apps on a hardware platform as limited as this. There was NO indication on the box or the machine itself as to which version was installed. It even arrived without ANY paperwork inside the box, not even a rudimentary setup guide.

Also, the product description page shows a 500 GB HDD in the specs (twice, plus in answer to a user question); and there is clearly no mechanical drive in the unit, only the 128 GB flash drive. For the price I did not expect miracles, but I did expect to not be so flagrantly misled about I would be receiving.

comment:
The computer is refurbished with 1TB SSD and 32GB RAM. It came with USB keyboard, USB mouse, USB WiFi adapter and port display to HDMI adapter. It seems to run great even if it's very old. Dell website shows it was shipped in 2016 and probably manufactured earlier because it also says the originally installed OS was Windows 7. I hope it may work for a couple years more.
The setting wasn't easy as windows was locked and asking for Walmart email or security key. I have a laptop running on dual OS (Linux and Windows 11). I erased Windows with the Walmart credentials nonsense from the refurbished Dell drive by installing Linux using a bootable USB. Downloaded Windows 10 Pro and created a bootable USB using my laptop's Windows 11 (it's hard to create Windows 10 or 11 bootable USB using Linux. I get files larger than 4GB error).
I reinstalled Windows 10 Pro using the bootable USB and removed Linux. Trying to install Windows from USB while the desktop still has the Walmart locked Windows wasn't working. That's why I used linux to override that mess and go back to remove Linux. An option suggested on Dell website to do a clean reinstall or recovery (Support Assist OS Recovery) doesn't show up in the BIOS. The refurbished computer is now working fine but I think USTechno should have made sure Windows setting is straightforward.

comment:
My 2016 Dell Inspiron was slowly dying. I could no longer get support on it....and finally I got a new one here last month from Amazon. This one is good. Windows 11 is a learning curve...but getting there. I had to buy a new printer/scanner/copier too....so I had an IT guy come and hook everything up and make them all talk to each other. Seems good.

I barely ever moved the old laptop....it's my work/office set up with a remote bigger monitor and wireless keyboard, so I think this one will just sit in my office too...but it is nice that it is a laptop if I ever DO have to take it on the road with me.

I suppose it's just my history....but I've had good luck with Dell and this one I hope will be the same.

comment:
This review is for the Dell 2022 Inspiron 15 Laptop, 15.6" HD Display, Intel Celeron N4020 Processor, 16GB DDR4 RAM, 1TB PCIe SSD.

The laptop arrives with Windows 11 installed. As some other reviewers have stated, the laptop is very very slow out of the box, and it does appear that Windows 11 is the cause. I didn't realize this until it arrived and I tried using it, with poor results. Every simple action took a very long time, so I read the reviews and saw that others were reporting slow response times.

I decided to see if the speed could be improved by installing Windows 10, and it did. It's not a simple process at all, especially if you are not familiar with how to do it. You basically need to create a USB boot disc with the full Windows 10 installation pack loaded, and perform a clean installation of the hard drive, completely wiping out what comes pre-installed. It took me the better part of two days, but once it's done, the system is much more responsive and works with the speed you would assume of a sub-$400 laptop.

Is this a good buy? It really depends if you want to go through the hassle of removing Windows 11 from the unit and putting the effort in. Here's a Tip: Be sure to know what drivers you may need, as I struggled with both monitor and wi-fi drivers at some point during the installation process for Windows 10.

Good Luck!

comment:
I've bought 6 dell laptops over the last 2 years and EVERY SINGLE COMPUTER has issues with the hinge. The hinge breaks just from opening and closing the laptop a couple times a day. This causes problems with the screen, it cracks the base of the hinge, and the back of the screen starts to pop out. Dell also won't do anything about it even when they know it's a chronic problem. They decided to use cheap plastic for the hinge and it will break the entire computer.

There are much better laptops on the market, so there is no reason to buy this terrible option. Don't be deceived by the reviews from people that just got their laptop, they will be broken after 1-2 years of light use.

comment:
The 15.6-inch Full High Definition (FHD) Touchscreen Dell Inspiron 15 3000 Series 3511 Laptop with an Intel Core i5-1035G1 processor and an outstanding 32GB of RAM was a recent purchase of mine. I must say that in every way this laptop has surpassed my expectations and is now an integral part of my everyday life.

This laptop's primary strength is its outstanding performance. Thanks to the Intel Core i5-1035G1 processor's lightning-fast performance and responsiveness, I can run a wide variety of programs simultaneously with no effort. The 32GB of RAM significantly improves performance, allowing you to work efficiently and without interruptions even when using busy programs.

The 15.6-inch full-high-definition (FHD) touchscreen is a joy to work with. Images and videos have never looked so crisp and detailed. The touch features are quick and precise, making my work much simpler and more pleasant than before.

The sturdy construction and long lifespan of this laptop further amaze me. The construction is sturdy, and the style is sleek and modern, giving off an air of professionalism. The keyboard's layout and key spacing make for a pleasant typing experience.

The Dell Inspiron 15 3000 Series 3511 has an excellent battery life. I'm not interrupted by the need to look for a power source, so I can focus on my work for longer periods of time. This convenience is especially useful for people who are frequently on the go.

This laptop has a plethora of ports, making it ideal for use with a wide variety of peripherals. I appreciate the ease with which I can transfer and access my files thanks to the inclusion of USB ports, HDMI, and an SD card reader. I would definitely recommend this laptop to anyone looking for a solid, dependable laptop.

comment:
I'm comparing this machine to my old Windows 7 laptop. The keyboard is too small and the keys are too sensitive. It lacks a RW/CD so, if you're into burning or ripping audio cd's, you'll need to an external drive.
Now for the pluses. This is as very fast machine, even though it's Core 5 processor is old technology. My old Windows 7 Inspiron took about three minutes to fully boot up where as this Windows 11 Inspiron is fully booted in about 10 seconds. LOVE that. Speaking of Windows 11, Very powerful version but a steep learning curve.
So far, I've bought a RW/CD and am looking at external keyboards. But, not the machines problem. It's mine.

theproduct: Dell Inspiron 15 3000 ç³»åˆ— 3511 ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦,15.6 å‹ FHD è§¸æ§è¢å¹•,Intel Core i5-1035G1,32GB DDR4 RAM,1TB PCIe SSD,SD å¡è®€å¡å™¨,ç¶²è·¯æ”å½±æ©Ÿ,HDMI,Wi-Fi,Windows 11 Home,é»‘è‰²
comment:
The laptop specs are good if you know what it can do. I mainly got this laptop due to the high RAM and 1TB of space. I've been using this as a new laptop for less than a month, and its okay. I'm using it to run apps, app and web development, running virtual machines, etc. photo editing, and light video editing without any issues yet. You can run games such as CS:GO as long as they're not on the highest graphics settings, but my intention was never to run serious games on this.

The laptop housing and keyboard is cheap, and it shows. It doesn't take much pressure to bend the laptop chassis and keyboard. I've had keys get stuck with less than a week of using it. The keyboard also doesn't have a backlight, which is a bummer. With the screen not being able to flip all the way back and convert it to a tablet, I'm not sure what the point is having a touch screen. I think the money spent on a touchscreen might have been better spent on a better keyboard and chassis.

Overall, its an okay laptop. The laptop specs is good for the price.

comment:
Looks new.

Processing power is good

They have upgraded to 16 gig ram and 1 tb ssd

Original is 8 gb ram and 256 ssd.

All works fine

Only problem is for heavy load, fan sound is kind of high. But only reaches high cpu usage for heavy load only like code building, windows updates etc. culprit is windows anti malware and edge( chrome is surprisingly less cpu eater recently)

theproduct: Dell Inspiron 15 3000 ç³»åˆ— 3511 ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦,15.6 å‹ FHD è§¸æ§è¢å¹•,Intel Core i5-1035G1,32GB DDR4 RAM,1TB PCIe SSD,SD å¡è®€å¡å™¨,ç¶²è·¯æ”å½±æ©Ÿ,HDMI,Wi-Fi,Windows 11 Home,é»‘è‰²
comment:
Bought two of these and had to return both. The first one arrived and had a defective wireless card and would not connect to a network, which is required to set up Win11 (no ethernet port on this laptop). So I returned it and purchased another one same day as I shipped the return because I could not wait 3 weeks for an exchange. The second one arrived 3 days later and I did manage to get it set up and it worked fine for a couple of days. Then it would no longer power on. Completely dead. Tried leaving it connected to charger overnight. Still dead next morning. So I returned that one as well. And bought an Acer instead (which works great!).

Be careful to review the return policy. Amazon does clearly states the return policy, but buyer beware. Both of my purchases were from Amazon Marketplace sellers, marked with Amazon Prime and "Shipped from Amazon". Amazon will not refund computer purchases until after they receive the item back and have time to inspect the product. Then it takes 7 days to go back to your credit card. It is not like most Prime purchases where you get the refund almost immediately after UPS scans the return package.

On my first return, it took 3 weeks. That was from Seller "Snow Bell" and I eventually got a full refund. Then the second return took another 3 weeks, so I was carrying $1200 on my credit card while having to purchase a third replacement elsewhere (another $700 on my credit card). And now I am fighting with Seller named "AmazingDeal Arrived" on the second return as they are trying to charge me a $231 "restocking fee" despite the fact the laptop was damaged/defective and the restocking fee is inapplicable. Very frustrating and basically had to put $2k on my credit card and carry $1200 for 3-6 weeks waiting for refunds.

comment:
I ordered the setup with touchscreen, 32 gig ram and 1 terabyte HD on Windows 11. I will probably not use the HD too much for storage as I save a lot to Onedrive.

The laptop is incredibly light, which makes it easy to carry around and use. Typing on it is fine but there is no backlit keyboard. You gotta have some lack of perfection for the very low price.

I had to remove the S mode scheme which Microsoft now has on by default. The so called S mode prevents the loading of non-Microsoft software right away I use Firefox, which S mode won't allow to run. Disabling S mode was easy.

The laptop has worked flawlessly since I bought it a few months back.

I knew I was buying an older machine, 11th generation Intel, but I didn't know it was used. There were no statements in the description of the product that stated it was used.

Overall I am happy everything is as advertised. However, originally sold in September. Therefore one year warranty expires in November 2023. This laptop looks and acts like a new computer. So, I am happy but disappointed that the fact it is used was not detailed in the information. Also, the camera does not support facial recognition.
Without the used would have been 5 Star.

comment:
I tried to install malwarebytes when i first got this laptop but the site would not load for me, it turned out that the .hosts file had EVERY single antivirus/antimalware site blocked from my access. A few hours after installing chrome my Amazon account was hacked, followed by my twitter/hoyoverse/spotify/youtube/gmail/telegram, as of now i have permanently lost my genshin and honkai accounts and a warning from youtube because the hacker posted fraudulent content. Money was stolen from my amazon but I was able to rectify that. After changing the .hosts file i was able to run a scan and find over 14 trojans, as well as both malware and spyware and I hadn't downloaded ANYTHING, I hadn't even had the computer for three (3) days.
I contacted them for a refund and they want me to return their faulty product that I had to repair!! They blamed my network being hacked but I am one of four people in this household with computers and no only have we run network scans that come back clean, I am the ONLY one who's been hacked and it started a few hours after I received this laptop. BE WARNED. DO NOT RISK YOUR PRIVACY.
Oh and the colors suck and can't be fixed.
attached is the .hosts file listing every antimalware/spyware site so i was forbidden access to make repairs as well as a hitmanpro removal of the spyware.

comment: As a lifelong Dell die-hard, I have to say this is my last one. This model is made of cheap plastic. It was in use for about 1 year and the lid hinge broke. I was quoted $210 to fix one ($420 for 2) with no guarantee that it would hold or that the other one wouldn't also break. I was cautioned by the tech that it is a known issue that Dell does not take responsibility for unless still under warranty which mine was not. The actual part itself might cost $1.00 to make but the fix requires replacing perfectly good parts due to this design flaw. :( I was able to fix it myself but not before spending about $70 and taking the laptop apart as demonstrated in a YouTube video. My fairly new laptop was junk if I hadn't been able to do it myself all because of a tiny plastic part. Complete garbage.

comment:
Terrible computer! I had Dell computers before so I was pretty confident buying this model as soon as it came out. What a mistake! Honestly probably will never buy a Dell again.
Here are the main things that happened since I got this computer exactly one year ago:
1. Screen was screwed up and jittering right out of the box - had to send it to get fixed.
2. Camera is jittery and very low quality, sometimes has a purple "filter" that covers the entire screen. I'm the joke of all Zoom calls.
3. The screen frame got stuck on some piece of plastic in the hinge and it got partially pulled off. Had to get it fixed, and now the screen is all crooked.
4. Now the screen is getting stuck again on the other hinge.

Having said that. The computer is lightweight and fast. But still, my recommendation is DO NOT BUY THIS PIECE OF JUNK! You can get the same specs on other computers for the same cost without all this BS.

comment:
I will not be ordering expensive equipment like this from Amazon again. Lesson learned.

Long story short, I work for a very small non-profit in a rural community. We hired our first employee outside of my position and I purchased a laptop for them to use. The employee started a few weeks after I bought the laptop and started using it minimally (basically just email and internet searches). As his workload and responsibilities increased, he needed to use the laptop more. I ordered him a wireless mouse and keyboard. When we went to plug in the devices, none of the three USB ports worked. We tried various USB devices and no luck. At first I thought it was user error and tried to problem solve, eventually realizing that they just don't work.

It is now about 2.5 months since I received the laptop and I called to see if I can get it fixed or replaced. Amazon connected me with the seller and they said nothing they can do because it is outside of the 30 day window. After, I spoke with Amazon and asked if they would provide a replacement and they declined, as well.

So...now we have a laptop with no USB connectivity. Basically, we just have to deal with it.

I am disappointed and expected better. I understand they have policies about returns, but we clearly received a defective laptop and replacing it for us was the right thing to do.
