comment:
Replacing a 42-inch 2K Fire TV that I used as monitor. I am not really a gamer, mostly I use it for work. So far, I regret the decision and it's not because of any issue with the monitor (maybe one ... more on that later).

I thought the Ultrawide would allow me to work more effectively .... however, it's much smaller than to old TV. I used to be able to work without my readers. The type face on this is so small, I need to wear readers. If I expand the font, then the lack of space become apparent.

It appears to be a nice piece of equipment, but the simple fact is that did not know what I was buying in to.

The only issue, this is an ultra0wide and very modern. I work from home and use my company's Dell laptop. The driver loaded is for generic monitors and it does not recognize the wide aspect. Getting the driver has been a bit of a pain. It will happen but something to think about if you are going this route.

In any case I own it now and need to make it work. Will update here as I go forward.

comment: First off - this monitor is amazing. BUT when I plugged it in via HDMI from my Lenovo Thinkpad the resolution was unbearable. This is the same problem with any UWS HD monitor especially if you are using it for work (which I am). I searched countless articles and videos on how to resolve and nothing worked but I figured out the solution so I'm saving others my pain. First my laptop is corp issued, under powered and locked down to the point that I can't download .exe drivers. To fix the problem I bought a Startech.com Display port adaptor which has a small GPU installed in it to increase the resolution (about $100 on Amazon). Out of the box the Startech solved the problem but I did have to install the Display port driver from Displayport.com, and thankfully display port offers 3 different formats for the driver including .MSI which bypassed my .exe block on my corp computer. The monitor works perfectly and is totally game changing. So if you are stuck trying to drive it with an old or underpowered laptop get yourself the adaptor - was literally plug and play out of the box with the driver install and the monitor is perfect.

comment:
First - the good news:

Got this monitor on Prime Day after a LOT of research - reviews here, through online articles (PC Mag, CNET, etc.), and watching YouTube videos. I use it for work (business analyst) and in a graphic design capacity (hobbies). It's basically like having two monitors in one and the color, clarity, response time, and flexibility of the display was a huge upgrade from what I had been tolerating (Westinghouse 32" TV).

The bad news is I'm taking away a star b/c somewhere along the line, I was led to believe this monitor had speakers AND the menus and setup kind of lead you down that path as well. Sorry folks - no speakers on this monitor :(.

Since the listing never mentions sound or speakers, I take full blame for making that assumption. HOWEVER - the monitor was automatically recognized by my laptop as an audio output device, was made the default audio device, AND the monitor has audio controls on its menu. So for a minute there, I was SUPER stoked! Alas, after a quick chat with Dell customer care, they confirmed that the monitor is speakerless...

Overall, this is a GREAT monitor. Not much of a gamer but the ultra-wide format and the extra few inches made it seem like I was adding two monitors to my workspace instead of one. Plus, the extra screen real-estate in full-screen mode significantly reduced the need for scrolling in spreadsheets and design software.

comment:
So I got this open box after I returned a similar LG monitor with the same specs. Lemme tell ya, this is waaaaay better than the LG monitor. The Lg whined so loudly when the brightness was up. Amazon was unwilling to assist in the matter so I just returned it and bought this one open box. So if you're stuck between the comparable LG and this, GET THIS.

It is in great shape, minus 2 screws loose on the inside rolling around making a hck of a noise. I removed those by popping the back panel off on one side to ensure the screen didn't self destruct someday.

This is definitely due to the previous owner tampering with it and forgetting to reinsert all of the screws....I feel if Amazon took care of their workers more, things like this wouldn't slip by so much. Have had the worst luck with Amazon orders recently and that's on them, but after removing the screws, this dell monitor is the bees knees. I'm willing to take the defective screen on for now. You guys need to do better. This holiday season has been a nightmare here.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S3222HG 32 å‹ 165Hz æ›²é¢é›»ç«¶é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - Full HD (1920 x 1080) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,1800R æ›²ç‡,AMD FreeSync,4ms ç°ç°ç°ç°ç°ç°åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“(è¶…å¿«é€Ÿæ¨¡å¼),1670 è¬ç¨®é¡è‰² - é»‘è‰²
comment:
Pros:
So this this monitor might have the best VA panel I've ever seen. I game a considerable amount and I can honestly say this is a great gaming monitor! The black smearing which VA panels are notorious for are almost non-existent and I say almost only because I was intentionally looking for them! The response time is spot on, so much so that I don't notice it. The curve is perfect for immersion and if you are coming from a flat panel after a few hours you may not be able to go back to flat panels. The menu controls are exceptionally easy to navigate, the stand is sturdy, and the overall build quality feels very premium. Truthfully I can't say enough good things about this monitor!
Cons:
While there isn't much negative to say, nothing is perfect. There is a small amount of backlight bleed, but I only notice when I put a black screen on! Honestly if I had not done that I would never notice it. The stand is only tilt and height adjust, but I knew that when I bought it and personally I have no need for swivel and rotation.
Other Thoughts:
My previous two monitors had been a 144hz 1440p flat panel and early 35 inch 2560x1080 curved ultrawide and I don't miss either one of those. I could have easily gotten a 1440p curved display but with gpu prices going crazy with no end in sight and wanting to run game at a high refresh rate with high details I opted for 1080p (which still looks amazing even on a 27 inch display). I have zero buyer's remorse and hope this review helps anyone on the fence in regards to this particular monitor. Also g-sync worked right out of the box and I only needed to make some very minor adjustments to get the picture I wanted.

comment:
I had some quality issues at the beginning with my unit, but Dell has been great with dealing with me and supported me more than any other brand I thought would've.

Those looking for G-sync can enable it in the Nvidia control panel but be warned that with this panel you may experience flickering on games (most notably with Apex legends). I have gotten used to it, but the device isn't certified to work with G-sync, but for most games it is fine.

Overall, Dell has done a fine job supporting me with problems on this monitor and the monitor itself can be a great introduction into the ultrawide landscape.

I have this hooked up to my 3080 and am lucky enough to experience most games at 144Hz at this resolution; recently Halo Infinite has been a blast and games like Microsoft Flight simulator are a wonderful experience, second only to VR.

The monitor is a VA panel, so expect common problems with it - but since it is curved it still does a much better job in viewing angles compared to most TNs on the market.

The monitor is light, relatively speaking, for a 34 inch ultrawide with these features as I am able to use my VESA monitor stand at the end of my desk. The included stand is fine with it being height and angled adjustable - but a monitor stand with VESA should be the way to go.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S3222HG 32 å‹ 165Hz æ›²é¢é›»ç«¶é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - Full HD (1920 x 1080) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,1800R æ›²ç‡,AMD FreeSync,4ms ç°ç°ç°ç°ç°ç°åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“(è¶…å¿«é€Ÿæ¨¡å¼),1670 è¬ç¨®é¡è‰² - é»‘è‰²
comment: I almost returned this monitor, as the picture quality was garbage when gaming, with significant blurring and color bleed/smearing with any kind of motion at all. It took me a while to realize that this monitor's response time just isn't good and doesn't work well with Freesync. So, I enabled MPRT for the response time, which automatically disabled Freesync (as it should), and all those above problems went away. With my current GPU I get 85-100fps running with the 144Hz refresh rate, and don't experience any screen tearing at all, and with MPRT enabled it's a very smooth experience. I'd expect with my upgraded GPU (on order) that I'll get near 144fps to match the refresh rate and it will improve all that much more. I don't know if this experience was specific to me and my build, but just sharing my experience for any out there struggling with the advertised quality of this monitor.

comment:
This is a really great monitor. I picked it up on a Black Friday sale for ~$200. Because it was so cheap, I honestly didn't realize it was going to be so big! (which is not a complaint, the measurements are right in the title). I was replacing a small tv monitor that i had been using for work & gaming. This is a huge upgrade.

Pros:
- it's not a weird widescreen resolution, so websites don't get stretched oddly
- the stand allows for a lot of control on height and tilt, right out of the box.
- Really good clarity and color balance without much adjustment
- a simple cable management hole in the stand made all the difference in keeping my desk neat with a wired keyboard + webcam. Really a nice touch.

Cons
- It is VERY heavy once set up. It can be difficult to adjust on a desk because of that. If you have noodle arms like me, a second person might be helpful to have around if you need to pick it up and move it off the floor.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S3222HG 32 å‹ 165Hz æ›²é¢é›»ç«¶é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ - Full HD (1920 x 1080) é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,1800R æ›²ç‡,AMD FreeSync,4ms ç°ç°ç°ç°ç°ç°åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“(è¶…å¿«é€Ÿæ¨¡å¼),1670 è¬ç¨®é¡è‰² - é»‘è‰²
comment:
While this monitor is certified FreeSync Premium Pro, if you set it up using the included cables and Dell monitor drivers you'll notice that anytime the refresh rate adjusts while gaming intense flickering will occur. After some investigating I found a fix and it is:

1. Purchase an upgraded VESA certified display port 1.4 cable. It seems not all display port 1.4 cables are created equal and since 1440p at 144 hz is near the cables maximum bandwidth, any deviation in quality can result in poor performance and cause flickering.

2. Don't install the drivers supplied by Dell for the monitor, for some reason they mess things up. Instead, just install your AMD video card drivers and the Radeon control center. Also, use the Windows Generic PnP monitor driver that's enabled by default. I think doing so disables HDR, but it's a small price to pay in my opinion.

Of course, being a VA display its still susceptible to flickering on game menus, loading screens and when framerates drop really low (like 60-70 fps). I also notice flickering on any game that caps the framerate at 60 fps and doesn't let you change it (such as Sim City). But the vast majority of gameplay is flawless (for instance Call of Duty Coldwar with framerates constantly adjusting between 115 - 135 fps). And if you do encounter a game that has lots of flickering (which is unlikely with first person shooters and any other games optimized for high end graphics cards) you can easily disable FreeSync through the Radeon Control center at the touch of a button. Finally, just a note to add, I am using a RX 6900 XT.

comment:
So this monitor looks great! It plays games really well and has great color/saturation/brightness/etc. HOWEVER, I have some complaints.
I ordered this monitor to replace an older Spectre one that was starting to get lines at the bottom.
When I ordered it the first time I plugged it in and it looked great. Played some games and had fun with it. My PC fell asleep while I was afk and when I came back to wake it up, boom, the dreaded lines and a dead pixel popped up. This was the SAME DAY I had just gotten it.
So I changed the DP cable to see if it was that and nope, it was in fact the monitor.
I ordered a replacement and it arrived the next day. I'm currently using this new replacement monitor and when I took it out of the box I had a few more issues.
I ordered a new DP cable just in case and swapped it out beforehand. When I loaded up a game it started showing a bit of back flashing so I researched and finally saw it could be the NIVIDIA G-Sync. Turned that off and boom no more back flickering. Also would recommend turning down the sharpness as it can make some text look a bit pixeled.

All in all its a great monitor for the price and looks awesome for games. If you're using it for 144hz make sure to have a Display Port cable or it will not get the max framerate. Also if you have some back flickering try turning off your NIVIDIA G-Sync. If you're willing to deal with a bit of issues its worth buying.

comment: I moved from a dual (1 IPS 27 2k and 1 IPS 24 4k) panel setup to this panel and the 4k 24in vertically next to it. This panel does have more washed out colors than the IPS panels, but the darks are SOOOOO nice and crisp, it makes up for any color loss, i love it! Also the 'expected' VA smearing is so well handled it does not bother at all in gaming, and I play Star Citizen, which is mostly in dark space areas. I have mine set to 'very fast' per what reviews recommend and what my own testing also showed to be the best setting. People who say once you go wide-screen you cant go back were not lying, it is an awesome experience, especially for immersive games like star citizen. I kept the 24in 4k in a vertical orientation next to the ultra-wide to be a 'accessory' screen for things like discord and obs while I'm gaming. I watched a lot of reviews ahead of purchasing this panel and they were all helpful in selecting this over others, i'm ultra happy with my decision on this ultra-wide :)

comment:
I tried the UHD 4K flat-panel version of this monitor in my dual monitor setup. Had to scale UHD to 175% to make the text readable for my older eyes. The flat panels, when angled to each other, were difficult to keep all areas in focus as well. This QHD 2.5K monitor at no scaling matches the pixel density of the scaled UHD. The gentle curve of this monitor removes the need for too much angling of the flat panels and keeps everything in sharp focus in all areas of the screen. I do complex software development and so need the real estate of dual monitors. Text is clear throughout.

One drawback with these when used as dual monitors though. While the power button is still below the panel like on the UHD versions, the monitor settings buttons are on the back of the panel. So out of reach on the left monitor when used as dual monitors. Luckily, I do not need to reach the buttons often (for example, to switch the input source).

comment:
The seller: Great, no complaint and fast to ship. I am reviewing the Dell product only, which has nothing do do with the seller. I knew what I was was purchasing and this review is not a reflection on them.

Dell KM5221W Pro Wireless Keyboard and Mouse Combo
I bought to replace a similar Logitech keyboard/mouse combo that inexplicably stopped working correctly with my work issued Dell laptop after some Windows 10 updates which wouldn't work right no matter what I tried to do to remedy the issues. I had hoped that by installing the DELL hardware combo, I would get better results and fewer bugs using it with W10. In this regard, it does work and I am not constantly dealing with weird interoperability issues anymore.
But I have to say, that the design, ergonomics, and just overall "feel" this Dell set is not nearly as nice or as comfortable to type with compared to the Logitech variety. The Dell keyboard is very plain, small and the keys aren't contoured, they're just flat. The function keys are 1/2 size of normal keys. The set is a bit disappointing and basic, especially given it cost approximately $20 more than my similar Logitech version. Overall, I am underwhelmed with the Dell set, but at least now I have a working non-buggy set!

theproduct: Dell Pro KM5221W éµç›¤èˆ‡æ»‘é¼
comment:
Great set with one USB input to PC. happy6 with the slim smaller keyboard. As the headline states, no lighted key indicators for caps or numbers, but luckily there is a momentary pop up at the top of the screen to tell you cap on/off- you just have to bother hitting it. If you really are a keyboard person your eyes aren't always on the screen.
Happy I got it.

theproduct: Dell Pro KM5221W éµç›¤èˆ‡æ»‘é¼
comment:
I have used basic wired Dell keyboards for most of my last 20 years working as an IT pro. This keyboard matches other Dell keyboards in terms of layout, which was my goal. But one thing I didn't notice until I bought it and started using it is the F-Keys are different. On this keyboard the F-Keys require use of the fn key. I use F-Keys quite a bit in my work and therefore I'm going to search out a different unit to use. This won't affect most folks though - but might be a consideration if you're an IT pro or otherwise use the F-Keys a lot.
Otherwise a very nice keyboard...quiet keys...worked the first time I plugged it in...

theproduct: Dell Pro KM5221W éµç›¤èˆ‡æ»‘é¼
comment: First things first - THERE IS ONLY ONE USB DONGLE LOCATED IN THE MOUSE OR THE KEYBOARD. Windows 11 recognized the keyboard but with a different name, hence the battery reporting was not accurate (I had to replace batteries twice). I was about to return this keyboard but I gave it one more chance and went into the Dell webpage and found a firmware update for Windows. After installing the update the system immediately recognized the part number and start reporting the battery life accurately. I'm so happy now that I got rid of two cables in my workstation, now I can put other junk instead ;).

theproduct: Dell Pro KM5221W éµç›¤èˆ‡æ»‘é¼
comment: I was hoping for a small pressing distance and quiet keys but unfortunately that wasn't the case.

theproduct: Dell Pro KM5221W éµç›¤èˆ‡æ»‘é¼
comment:
I am not sure why they call this *PRO*. The keyboard has a nice typing feel to it - it does not take a lot of effort to type and types with ease accurately. However, the mouse is so poorly designed - it is a round, fat mouse, and difficult to hold and use. I have a logitech mouse that has rubber sides for easy gripping, and a curved middle to fit nicely in your hand. This mouse is the cheapest mouse I have ever owned.

Even though I used this keyboard with a different mouse (logitech), I still decided to return this keyboard because the labels that are on the keys are faint and cannot be seen easily. The worst are the function keys which I use all the time with my applications. You simply cannot see the function keys' labels, which they made fainter than the labels on the other keys. The keys themselves, are shiny, causing the faint "Fx" symbols, which are tiny and faint, to be nearly invisible. The ceiling light in the room makes the keys even more difficult to read. Because the function keys are smaller than a full-sized keyboard, I can't rely on memory for where the function keys are placed; I would keep missing the keys and hit the wrong function key because of the size of these function keys. I would therefore have to stop typing and look closely at the function keys to make sure I pressed the correct ones.

I can also tell that the labels on the regular keys are not going to last long. The "F" and "J" keys are already starting to get that very over-used/old shiny look and starting to wear out.

While it's nice that this keyboard is wireless, it is not worth the price and inconvenient function key usage, and glossy looking keys whose labels won't last long.

Got a wired Macally keyboard instead. SX scissor keys are the ones that feel most comfortable for me (not straining my fingers).

theproduct: Dell Pro KM5221W éµç›¤èˆ‡æ»‘é¼
comment:
At the time of this review, I've had this Dell combo for almost 4 months. At the time of purchase, I had looked at multiple options for keyboard/mouse combos and landed on this one. There were a few reviews at the time that caught my attention, "keys stick," "mouse issues," etc but at the time I assumed they were one-offs. This product being a Dell, from Dell was enough for me to take a chance. I wish I had not.
I'll start off by saying this combo is being used in an office setting during a normal M-F 9 to 5. There is no excessive wear and tear. Almost immediately, I started receiving a "mouse battery low" error, that is lovely enough to be shown as a pop up window that won't time out. You have to manually clear it from your display every time. This error came within the first two weeks of use. At first I thought, no problem, the batteries that shipped with them wasn't name brand, may have just been bad batteries. So I changed them to Duracell Pros. I still continually get this error daily even with the first set of new batteries and an additional set. Plus the pop up is annoying to have to clear multiple times throughout the day. Second issues with the mouse is that it looses its mind at least three of the five working days. It jumps from one portion of the screen to the other, 'double clicks' when I only click once so every email I click on opens up or pages/items move when I don't want them to, etc. Overall, bad mouse.
The keyboard does not fair better. The keys do stick. Badly. Again, this started happening early into the purchase, probably a month. It's annoying as well especially when its the function keys or Enter, then all kinds of background tasks are trying to open and I can't do anything except for turn the keyboard off and rake the keys trying to unstick the one that's stuck.
With the issues between the two devices this combo is definitely a distraction and not in a good way.

Plus the rechargeable set is also multi-device which is a beautiful touch.
All in all, this did the job as it should and I appreciate my time with it, but itâ€™s time to move on to something that makes a little more sense. Good value for the money tho

comment:
I bought this set and within a couple minutes of setting it up I realized that I'm not a fan. They keyboard keys are too stiff for me and the sharp edges are uncomfortable. It feels like a laptop keyboard but with too much travel and a bit of a squishy, imprecise feel. It also seems to miss or repeat keystrokes regularly. I experienced quite a few typos just typing the first couple sentences of this review and I'm a pretty proficient typist. I also find that my arms get fatigued very quickly using this keyboard.

On the other hand, the mouse is garbage. While it "works," I find that the buttons have nowhere near enough resistance so I'm constantly accidentally clicking when I'm simply resting my fingers on the buttons. I'll be returning this set and buying something else that works better for me.

A couple other things to note: this set does not come with rechargeable batteries, so get ready to regularly replace the batteries. It is also not bluetooth-enabled so you'll need to use the USB-A dongle, which is a pain if your laptop only has USB-C ports, which will require an adapter (not included).

comment:
FINAL UPDATE - 2 1/2 months in and the mouse died.

SECOND UPDATE ~ Down to a 1-star review now. Another month of using this keyboard and it has another problem. Keys randomly stick and continue typing dozens of the same character until I hit the Esc key. It's not just one or two keys. It happens with multiple number and letter keys. If I still had the packaging I would return this in a heartbeat. It's horrible.

UPDATE ~ I've had this keyboard for 9 days and for the first 5 days things were wonderful (see my original review statements below). However, the keyboard is now lagging/skipping characters. I'm also experiencing issues with my mouse and keyboard not working after my computer comes out of sleep mode or I've been inactive for 5-10 minutes and the computer hasn't even entered sleep mode. I have to remove the USB doggle and plug it back in to get them to work. Very frustrating. I can no longer recommend this product.

Original review - I hate the "sharp" click of many keyboards. This dell is quiet and has a smooth feel. The mouse is lightweight and glides easily. Set up was as easy as inserting batteries into the devices and plugging in the USB doggle. No lag whatsoever.

I really should have returned this but have missed the return window by 2 days.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ OptiPlex 7040 å°å‹é›»è…¦ Intel Quad Core i7-6700 é«˜é” 4.0GHz,16G DDR4,512G SSD,Windows 10 Pro 64 ä½å¤šèªè¨€æ”¯æ´è‹±æ–‡/è¥¿ç­ç‰™æ–‡/æ³•æ–‡(ç¿»æ–°) )
comment:
For the price its amazing. Came well packaged and I got it up and running without much hassle.

The PC itself runs well and has decent specs. The small form factor is a pro and con since, while it has a PCIe port to potentially connect a low profile graphics card for those budget gamers, the slot is right next to the PSU so your options are:
1. Get a riser cable and put the GPU somewhere else, since there's not much space inside.
2. Get a single slot GPU, but it will be right against the PSU, it will most likely run hot since there will be minimal airflow.
3. Place the PSU out side and jank your way into placing the GPU in its place. (please don't do this)

For some reason, the PC rebooted when I connected headphones for the first time, and did it again each time I did it, until I used window's SFC to fix some files. I assume this was just a corrupt windows installation, since its hasn't happened again.

Now, the PC comes bundle with a mouse and keyboard and for those:
The keyboard couldn't be worse, the keys are hard to press and feel like your grinding plastic everything you press down.
The mouse was dead or arrival.
The little USB bluetooth/WiFi dongle does the job, but I don't expect it to be reliable.

Overall I'm pretty please, thou I would've rather they sold just the tower without those useless peripherals. Maybe that would've cut the cost a good 20 bucks.

comment:
We bought 10 for replacements within our office. The seller had a minor issue with meeting our needs and reached out to confirm that an upgrade at no extra charge would be acceptable.

Best packaging I've gotten on a bulk buy of computers. Each computer was wrapped with care and consideration for shipment.

After formatting and updating the computers to me given to our agents, I didn't find a single problem. Both aesthetically pleasing, clean cases and great hardware inside. No scams, all of the hardware inside is exactly as listed. Our agents have been using them for a few weeks now and we've had no issues.

Currently ordering a second shipment so we can continue to upgrade for our office.

Opened it up and found the heat sink hadn't been tightened down completely, but once that was done, the unit is quiet and very fast for the price. As for the unit itself, it arrived as described, was very clean inside. It looks new. It is fast to start up, runs fast once it is booted up too. Once I was set up, I decided to get a storage SSD for all my files and Aaron at SJ Computers helped me to get it ordered. All communication with the seller was quick and spot on. I'd recommend not only this computer, but the seller as well.

comment:
Replaced an 8 year old dual core early i5. This machine flies on Windows 10. No bloatware on it either. Cosmetics are good, I can tell it was an off lease office machine but for the price, it's an excellent value versus some low quality consumer junk box at Best Buy. These corporate machines were designed with 5-8 year life spans and are easily to upgrade things like RAM, adding a video card, etc.

It is my primary work at home machine and has been on continuously since it came out of the box in July and it is mid December, not one issue, blue screen or problem. Handles everything I can throw at it like Office 365, web browsing, YouTube even at 4K, etc. I am not a gamer so I have no idea how well it would handle a modern game, but I imagine you would want to put a better video card for that purpose than rely on on board video.

These machines have plenty of life and are built to last. It keeps them out of the landfill and you get a much better box than some black Friday wonderbox at Best Buy filled with bloatware and bottom end hardware that will barely hold up past it's 1 year warranty.

comment: This computer is not for networking on a domain. I am an IT Admin / Systems Engineer / Technology Consultant / Computer Builder. The computer was placed in a box and the styrofoam packing was just thrown in the Box. If you're going to pack a computer in styrofoam, it needs to be taped around the computer. Upon startup, there was a glitch on the screen with several horizontal lines on the bottom. So I shut it off and pulled the cover to see that there is a KimgFast SSD. I replaced it with a Samsung 870 EVO SSD, since KingFast is not on the approved list of SSD's. Put it back together and fired it up using a USB flash drive with Windows 10 Pro. During setup on the domain, the computer ran super slow. The two other refurbished PC's with the same exact specs from another refurbisher fired up on the domain immediately. I also noticed that the fan speed in the PC was running very high for over 15 minutes. But these computers are used for testing imaging software in the healthcare industry. Once it performed all of the driver updates including a firmware update , it ran a little bit better. One thing to note, it does not have a DVD-RW drive. I know that some refurbishers use the cheapest Hardware to get the biggest bang for their buck, but packing a PC poorly will only result in returns and a bad reputation. So I would not recommend using this computer for domain networking. And I probably won't be purchasing another refurbished computer from this seller. First impressions are always the most important.

who: Just give me what I paid for.
comment:
I used this computer for about 6 months and its time to say goodbye already. I dont do gaming, but some wordprocessing, accounting, emails, and some youtube on this machine.

Since this morning I've been getting the dreaded BSOD (blue screen of death) and being a computer engineer myself with decades of experience in both software and hardware, boiled down to the issue that caused it. A bad hard drive. After several tests, the conclusion was a bad hard drive, re-confirmed by a Dell systems hardware diagnostics test which proved the failure point.

What do I have to say about the machine? I know things do break down, but with no support or warranty beyond 90 days, you are on your own. Hope others are more lucky than me. That's all I can say. But not too bad a deal for the price I would say. For serious work, best to get a real machine.

comment:
Update 3-1-23: Another computer just died. Hard drive failed. Amazon will direct you to the manufacturer for the â€œ1 year warrantyâ€ again. but the manufacturer will tell you it expired in 2019. Avoid purchasing from this seller because he sells junk. Again, Amazon wonâ€™t do anything about it. Now I have two computers on my desk.

I purchased two of these computers less than a year ago and one of them stopped working. I contacted the seller and he said there wasn't anything he can do. Contacted Dell for the " 1 year refurbish warranty" and they stated it expired a while ago! My IT guy said the driver installed in this unit was a very cheap driver (approx $20) and that is the reason why It failed so soon. I would avoid purchasing if possible.

Little annoying that it doesn't come with a Wi-Fi card so grab a USB or PCIe card too (I didn't have much luck with a USB card myself but a 30-dollar PCIe card seems to work fine). Also doesn't have BlueTooth which isn't a huge deal for me but just something to be aware of. The hard drive is a little small, but it looks easy enough to add a second drive. Can go to the dell site to download the drivers for the Intel components inside if you want. Overall am very pleased with the purchase.

comment: My sincere apologies for my previous panic over lack of a Product Key. Blue Cloud PCs just went to the top of my list for PC-related needs.

comment: Arrived in shrinkwrap inside a box too large with misfit hard chunks of foam packing that allowed it to float around significantly inside the box. the HDMI port doesn't quite work 100% of the time and for some reason I can clap my hands within a few feet of the unit and it causes the screen to flicker. I first noticed this when I dropped a charger plug near it and the screen flicked off for a split second. Got it through the start up process, and been having nothing but problems trying to keep the screen on. Not too happy with it at the moment. Restarted and the screen stayed on for all of 5 minutes past startup before flickering off. have run several updates (turn off, turn on, hit update with auto restart as quickly as possible, rinse repeat.) I'm hoping to get past this problem with updates or with the display port adapter I ordered hopefully arriving tomorrow. still a big issue that my wireless keyboard dongle won't function if the dongle is plugged into the rear of the computer, and if my Wifi adapter is plugged into a rear port it runs VERY inefficiently. front ports are the only reason I haven't smashed my keyboard on the ground typing this review. plenty of issues. I would rather have received a unit post "setup" with all the proper drivers installed as this has been a major headache of an experience considering I ordered this to make online classes easier.

comment: Like others have mentioned, I don't think the alpha tech company sold me a new unit. While attempting to register the dock station with Dell, a screen came up showing the dock was shipped from China and registered July 2022 and its now Sep 2023. Everything came wrapped as if it was new but now I'm unsure if the item was tampered with, otherwise why would it have been registered over a year ago. As far as how it works, it seems fine. Its a laptop docking station that also charges my cell which is great, although many people seem to think its an expensive phone charger. It worked immediately with 3 different laptops and there's no ticking noises like others mentioned. I also didnt attempt to use the usb ports while the docking station is disconnected from the laptop, I dont have a use case for that. Its simple to hook up and it feels heavy/sturdy although its a small item, compared to docking stations I've used in the past. Only tried it with Dell laptops but it seems Mac books are fully compatible. If it wasn't for this used thing, I would give it another star.

comment:
First and foremost, the charger had a constant ticking noise. Every 5 seconds there's a ticking noise, it's not super loud, but it's loud enough. I'm using this in my home office where I work in silence most of the day. No way I'll be able to focus with the constant ticking.

On top of that, I saw another review had the same ticking complaint and mentioned that they searched Dell's warranty page to find that their docking station was used. Sure enough, looked mine up today (5/15/2023) and the Dell warranty for my dock started on July 22, 2022.

Aside from the annoying ticking, I actually did like the docking station. I only wish it had 2 HDMI ports, but I'm returning it anyway so it doesn't really matter.

comment:
I needed a dock that provided 3+ USB ports for work from home so that I could use an external display with a keyboard, mouse, and a USB headset simultaneously. I thought the Qi charging was a nice bonus to help reduce the number of chargers and cables at my desk as well.

Unfortunately, when used with my M1 Macbook air, after sleeping for 5-10 minutes with the laptop closed the USB ports are no longer functional and I have to unplug and reconnect the dock to my Mac for the USB ports to regain function (note, the charging and HDMI functions work fine while the USB ports do not). The dock seems to work fine if I leave the Macbook open 100% of the time, but most times I prefer to use the external monitor only. I've used several other docks and hubs with the same laptop and have not ran into this problem.

Another downside is the built-in USB-C host cable cannot be disconnected from the dock. I would like to have the dock on the left side of my monitor, with my laptop on the right. Unfortunately, the built-in cable cannot even reach from one side of a 24" monitor to the other comfortably. Would have preferred a separate USB-C cable to connect the dock to my laptop.

Overall, some quirks when used with a Mac and some room for improvement.

comment:
This review is for the Dell Dual Charge Dock (the USB Type C option). The dock has a wireless charging stand, four USB-A ports, one HDMI port, one DP port, one RJ45 port, and one USB-C port.

Iâ€™ve been using the dock for about a month, and I like it. The dock does have a larger footprint than a small hub, but Iâ€™ll take the bigger size in exchange for a wireless charger that works and reduced cord clutter. The bulky cables (power for the dock, HDMI) plug into the back, so I can put it at the edge of my desk and regain some space. Two of the USB-A ports are accessible on the right side.

I use the dock with my 2017 MacBook Pro and an external monitor. The refresh rate is 60Hz. The dock powers my laptop and charges the battery when needed. The dock gets warm while using it, but not scary hot.

I use the wireless charging stand for my phone and headphones, itâ€™s probably the best wireless charger Iâ€™ve tried. It just works -- I never have to fiddle with positioning. I have a Note 20 Ultra and the camera bump can make finding the proper positioning difficult. Not so with this stand. I just stick my phone on the stand and it charges. I use a thin TPU case, but have tried thicker Casetify cases and they work.

There is a tiny white LED light under the edge of the stand, it turns on when a device is being charged. The angle is perfect so the light isnâ€™t in your eyes while working on the computer, but easily visible to check charging status.

I really wish the dock had a power button. The power cable for the dock has a bright blue LED light, so I see it whenever I walk by my desk and in the middle of the night. I like to turn off some electronics when Iâ€™m not using them, so I have to physically unplug this one from the power strip. There is a power button but it only works with Dell laptops, it has some function with them.

comment:
I am currently using Dell Latitude 5530 with a thunderbolt dock. I have tried a several different Dell Docks and this would be the first one that have the Qi charging capabilities. I am pretty like that idea since I can charge my phone and use it as a stand as well for my phone.
On the back, it will have 1 display port and 1 HDMI port which can support for 2 4k Display and both can be at 60Hz. But that would be the maximum it could go. I wish it could be both display ports not HDMI. The USB C on the side was just for the charging or reading the data not able to connect to the 3rd monitor. I have not try with Daisy chain for 3rd monitor and I will try it soon with my new set up complete.
It is just plug and play and no drivers require for Dell Laptop. However, each of Dell Dock will have the service tag. I would highly recommend to get the tag and go to support Dell page then download all of the current firmware and driver then up to date for a better performance.
There is also a Power button to turn on your PC instead of opening the LID then press the power on the laptop.
If it can equip the SD and microSD card reader then it will be fantastic. However, I never seen one on Dell Dock.
For the price, it is pretty decent price to run dual 4k monitors. Overall, it is working as it should.

comment:
Depending on whether you are connecting this to a computer or to a wall outlet, this docking station can be somewhat compact or an unwieldy, clunky string of cables. If you want to connect to a wall outlet, you must deal with an (included) power adapter.

If this fits your Dell device(s), your space and logistics, the docking station itself is sturdy, good-looking and concise.

Using the 3-prong plug power cord: Definitely take into consideration that there is a 3 foot long, thick and unwieldy black cord that connects the hefty power adapter (not shown anywhere in these pictures on the product page) to a wall outlet with a 3-prong plug. The power adapter is 6.25" x 3" x 1". On the other end of the adapter there is a permanently attached thick and unwieldy 6.5 foot black cord that connects to the docking station. That is a lot of cord and a bulky adapter! Maybe you need that length, and good for you. But I don't have room for all that unsightly cord.

For powered devices: You can use your own cables (none provided) to connect to the back of the docking station, and you won't need the power adapter.

Then there is a permanently attached USB C cable coming from the docking station and it goes to your laptop.

Also be aware: This is not compatible with Dell AIOs.

comment:
DELL Dual Fast Charge Dock

Impressive desktop cell phone/device charger and hub. Beautifully designed, built and thoughtfully engineered to reduce clutter. It may be the only Phone charger/Device HUB you need. Dellâ€™s Dual charge dock provides up to 90 watts of power delivery, takes up just a bit more surface area than a deck of playing cards and features 9 standard ports for interconnecting your components. In addition, itâ€™s built in Qi-enabled can charge your earbuds or smartphone on its charging stand. The stand itself is sturdy at more than 23 ounces so when working as a hub it sits firmly on your desk.

It should be noted that this charging/hub has the USB C in 2 formats. On one side of the charger is the standard USB C connector and for convivence there is also a permanently attached USB C cable affixed to the rear. It is about 3 foot in length allowing you to bring any USB C powered device over to the hub and charge with the built-in charging cable. Very practical. Here is a charger that you can use that you do not need to first find a cable to use it.

Pros:
â€¢ The hub features: 4 X USB Type A, 1 USB Type C, HDMI 2.1 Port, USB-C 3.2, DisplayPort 1.4, RJ45 (Ethernet)
â€¢ This unit will support MAC address pass through. Video Resolution: (Dual Displays) 8K -30HZ or (Single Display) 4K -60HZ.
â€¢ Watching a movie...? This unit will charge your phones battery in a vertical or horizontal position.
Cons:

â€¢ Fully utilized this small hub could be charging your phone while supporting dual Monitors with your laptop while sharing the internet and powering other peripherals. That is allot of cables. But that is both the downside and the beauty of this as a hub. Just how neatly the Dell Dock keeps connections tidy and organized.

Highly Recommended!

comment:
Post covid world is floundering. Products are flawed, people are desperately selling anything, and the quality graph line is dropping on everything. With that said let's dig deeper.

I knew ordering this during a monsoon season here in CA was on me, and the usual great Dell box was wet and not looking typically awesome. I have an older rare Dell white IPS 32inch monitor, and was $150 a few years ago. Classy looking monitor. It even auto switched activated devices. Cables could easily be pulled and changed in a second or two, and no bells and whistles. The controls are a Rubiq's Qube to navigate though.

This Dell, like my Samsung 4k 32inch monitor, are nightmares when trying to change HDMI, DP, and other wires. Who is designing computers, monitors, and labeling things, BLIND PEOPLE FROM OTHER COUNTRIES. OMG. Why does everything require a flashlight, headlamp, mirrors, 3000 lumen beams, while holding all these things precariouly leaning over the equipment, and desperately trying to shove the stuff in a dark slot before falling over on it? I defy anyone to perform cable installation or changing before the calendar year flips. I do not think I'm alone in my complaint here.

A few good things, price dropped like a rock to $350 with $100 off(why? Stay tuned), picture is high quality with no adjustments out of the box mentioned by others, speaker output is perfectly placed and easy to plug in and out, USBs are fairly accessible on the bottom with some fiddling, on off button is lighted and easy to activate, base is heavy and make the monitor feel somewhat stable and firm, and not nearly as wobbly as my Samsung 32inch. Nice thing about this 2560x1440 Dell, the Windows 11 fonts, sizing, and graphics are much easier to read than my Samsung 4k tiny print. Windows XP AND 7 were a dream for having one place to change how everything looked or made readable. Windows is dumber, less fun, and more complicated, as cell phones become smarter and wiser.

LASTLY, here's why, IMHO, that the price dropped by $100. This Dell, unlike some others I've owned, does not allow you to adjust the monitor's physical leveling. The monitor only moves horizontally and vertcally, but not from landscape to portrait mode. Why is this important, the monitor is about an 1/8th to 1/4 of an inch off from being level!! Have never seen this. You cannot adjust it to level. After much contemplation, loosening screws and retightening, shimming, NOTHING WORKED, and I'm am very good at fixing stuff. How did I fix it? I put one taller base foot temporarily on the right side to mitigate the drooping on that side. Sanding down the rubber feet on the left may work too. OK, on to other problems. I decided to keep it and not return it. Your welcome Amazon. Still a good deal for $350.

comment:
I was initially disappointed... but I since learned that the things I disliked about it are generally normal for IPS panels. You'll get the typical pros and cons of an IPS panel with two notable exceptions:

Pro: It has really great response time for IPS.
Con: The color temp is skewing yellow out of the box (lower the "Gain" for red (R) and green (G) in the monitor's menu by 5-10% each to correct for this)

Another thing of note is the box it ships in is well designed (has long has nothing sharp breaks thru the bottom). My box came with a rather large hole at the top but luckily the monitor was far enough away not to get damaged. The screen is supported by a strong cardboard frame and to assemble, you just leave the monitor in the box and clip on the stand (very easy to set up).

After tweaking the yellow tint away has explained earlier, you'll have an excellent well built display, just be sure you know what you're getting into with IPS panels, they excel more at brightly lit environments where color accuracy is important. I got mine at 46% off, it's well worth it at that price (especially if you are in need of a second monitor).

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ é›»ç«¶é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ 32 å‹,165Hz,Quad-HD å¯¬è¢å¹• LED LCD,IPS é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,USB C,(QHD) 2560 x 1440p,HDMI 2.0,DisplayPort 1.4,1.07 å„„é¡è‰²,1æ¯«ç§’(ç°è‰²åˆ°ç°è‰²),ç„¡é‚Šæ¡†,G3223D - é»‘è‰²
comment:
This monitor is outstanding for the money! Large 32" display, IPS (1ms!), 165hz, amazing color, vibrant, 1440p. I wasn't sure how much I would like this monitor due to 1440p being ideal for 27", but after playing games and general use, my fears were put to bed. This thing is AWESOME! Games look colorful, sharp, and just AMAZING! Given the quality of the screen and features, this monitor is an amazing deal.

Pros:
-Colorful IPS screen. Colors look vibrant and whites look great!
-1440p (What I was looking for to allow high framerates on my Nvidia RTX 3080).
-Fast! 165hz, 1ms. No ghosting on the extreme setting. Very nice!
-32" big screen
-Bright!
-USB-C connectivity for laptops, consoles, etc.

Cons
-HDR 400. I tested this, and it's not good. At this price-point, you have to expect this. After testing the HDR, I just ended up turning it off.

NOTE: The monitor has 2 USB-A ports to plug in peripherals. These only work if a computer is plugged into it via the USB-C port. I wanted to use these to plug in a drawing tablet and USB headphones for my PC. I found out that the only way to make this work is to plug in a long USB-C to USB-A 3.1 gen 2 cable. I plugged the USB-C end of the cable into the USB-C port on the monitor and the USB-A end into the back of my PC. I got an annoying USB message from Windows, but ignored it. All USB devices, included hard drives, now work great plugged into the monitor.

If you're looking for an upgrade from a smaller screen size, don't want to go to 4K just yet, and want the satisfaction of getting a good value, look no further!!!

comment: For such a low price, this monitor is great. I'm used to 60 hz monitors and when I switched my main for this, I could definitely tell something changed, and it wasn't the green-ness. I would recommend this, but I would advise some caution for color-blind/shade-blind people. The monitor comes with a heavy green tint, and you will have to play around with your settings to get it the way you want it to; and if you have issues seeing color correctly, it's basically impossible. But if you do find that right color setting, which you probably will find something you can handle, it's a really good monitor and definitely a steal at this price.

comment:
Really nice monitor for Xbox One S. Set the resolution to 1080p and 120hz. Using it also for a PC with a RTX 3060, display port 1080p 165hz and G-sync. The gaming picture quality is really nice considering it's not HDR.

Got this on Black Friday 59% off sale, so it was definitely worth every cent. No dead pixels also.

Only issue was the delivery. The postman delivered it to neighbor across street during a heavy rain shower. Water off the roof was dripping on the box. Luckily I got it quick enough before water was able to get inside the protective crate.

comment: Does this monitor work? Yes. Also, there is no usable viewing angle. Even staring dead center, all four corners and edges of the screen start to fade. There's no way this is a 1ms monitor. I have a 4ms monitor that had less motion blur than this (same test, side by side). The coating makes all the pixels take on a rainbow "haze". At max brightness, you wish you could double the brightness. And the locking mechanism on one of the display port cables was snapped off and loose in the connector's housing (could hear it rattle). This isn't a negative review; this is a recommendation that Amazon de-list this item. I wouldn't pay more than $20 for this.

comment:
The first monitor I received was unfortunately defective. There was a connection issue interior to the panel which causes a line to appear across the screen. The return process was smooth and I promptly received a replacement monitor. I am using this monitor as a second monitor, as I needed a 144hz monitor to match my main display so that I can play games in windowed fullscreen without issue. For this purpose, the monitor is great. The stock stand has a small footprint, the bezels on the screen are very thin, and the overall build quality feels solid.

EDIT:
The monitor ended up breaking after 6 months of use. Never had a monitor break before no matter how cheap it is. The connections in these are just faulty, what a piece of junk.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ é›»ç«¶é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ 32 å‹,165Hz,Quad-HD å¯¬è¢å¹• LED LCD,IPS é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,USB C,(QHD) 2560 x 1440p,HDMI 2.0,DisplayPort 1.4,1.07 å„„é¡è‰²,1æ¯«ç§’(ç°è‰²åˆ°ç°è‰²),ç„¡é‚Šæ¡†,G3223D - é»‘è‰²
comment: buy the monitor its the best priced monitor without some stupid draw back that makes no sense for its price, Alright let me get on to why this monitor is good number 1 freesync premium pro and g sync this means no matter the card you get low frame rate compensation 48hz to 165hz and no longer need v sync or experience stutters. the back light is really high quality at first i thought i had back light bleed at first but nope it's great so far and no dead pixels. number 2 hdr is okay its hdr 400 which means it has the certification but only does 400 nits, this is important cause hdr needs brightness to work well but i mean it does add a little flare to how much color you can see but dont buy it for hdr. Number 3 is that this monitor is pretty sharp idk the pixels per inch but on the 32 inch its great, I have to put my face within like 6 to 7 inches to see a pixel so for the most part it looks sharp and smooth. the 1440p is the only drawback i can think of cause it looks great, I have tried 4k and 1080p for long periods of time and i gotta say its just like everyone says its a great middle ground and you will notice a bit of an upgrade. Only thing is this sacrifices like 10-15 fps on my 2060 which I dont really care too much but when im running cod maxish settings dlss set to balanced and im only getting 60 I had to adjust my settings but its fine i like it looking sharper then the graphics looking cleaner but just a word of warning for those on lower end (tbh I'm on a 115w 2060 so keep that in mind). another thing to keep in mind set the speed of the monitor refresh rate to the second option i it was called super fast, It has no draw backs and from reviews ive watched online makes the image pretty much have no ghosting and makes the response time around 2.2ish milliseconds but remember don't do the third as you will get overshoot and dont do the first as its a has a little bit of a trail to it (couldn't even notice the slight trails before but the millisecond difference between the first mode and super fast is immediately noticeable). Another thing this monitor deserves praise on is the buttons thank god they use a joystick in the back cause before when you had to memorize what every button did was a nightmare. Well thats about it, the monitor is great its also freaking massive I don't think it registered in my brain how big 32 inchs is cause I thought well thats only a 5 inch difference from my old one so thats another thing you should know but if you do end up buying it you wont regret it.

comment:
The monitor works fine, but new ones come with a protective plastic film covering the screen and edges that have to be peeled off. This one had none and no documents inside the box even giving specs and adjustment instructions. I had to clean the screen before turning it on.

The problem is I paid a new price for a slightly used monitor. When I complained no adjustments were offered, simply told to call Amazon. Can you find an actual customer service number? I can't.

comment:
I really like this monitor. Itâ€™s a well-designed monitor with a bright, crisp display thatâ€™s going to be really tough to beat without spending significantly more money. And, even if you do decide to spend significantly more money for a better monitor, the difference in picture quality isnâ€™t going to wow you.

Now, with all that said, once you get this monitor up and running, you will definitely need to make several adjustments to it to get it dialed in exactly the way you like it. So, plan on spending about 45 minutes or so changing settings, making adjustments and fine tuning the picture. And, once you do that, I canâ€™t imagine anyone being anything but happy with this monitor.

However, if I *had* to complain about something, it would be about the onboard speakers. There are none. And even though onboard speakers are generally pretty awful, I do still like having them as a listening option for office settings where good-sounding external speakers arenâ€™t necessary.

Other than the minor speaker thing, I really couldnâ€™t be more happy with this monitor. I think itâ€™s a very solid choice if youâ€™re looking for a 24â€ budget-friendly gaming monitor.

If you have any questions about this Dell G2422HS gaming monitor, please feel free to ask, and I'll try my best to answer. I hope you found this review helpful.

comment: I needed something in between huge and tiny to replace the, basically TV sized, monitors my employer sent. I switched out one of the 27 inch ones with this one, and the other 27 inch with a 20 inch (which used to be my favorite). Less than 24 hrs later I have a purchased a second one of these. I don't game, can't speak on performance or anything like that. It works great in a dual setup, rises up way higher than any other one I've used, and the eye strain settings don't equal loss of color or quality. Absolutely no issues what so ever using this for various boring office and customer service work. My 2nd one will be delivered Sunday (3.13) just in time to set it up and use both of these for a new/incoming class.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
PROS:
A "one cable" solution! I personally have a total of three items plugged in my mac at all times.
A male audio jack for high-fidelity audio output.
The included MagSafe Macbook charger to allow smart charging.
The USB C cable from the D6000

I can run AND control all of the following devices on my M1 Macbook Pro Max with ONE cable to the device.
3 Monitors
Webcam
Screen Capture of a Xbox Series X
Screen Capture of a Nintendo Switch
Thermal Label Printer
Elgato Wave 3
Key Lighting
A MagSafe Phone Charger
A High Fidelity Speaker System
Ethernet

CONS:
So far I've only been able to identify two cons and the device is wonderful. If both of these were fixed in the future with Display Link software updates it would be an instant 5-star review.

FPS issues - I have three monitors of two different brands. My primary monitor which I use for gaming supports 240 FPS but is capped at 30 FPS with no options besides downgrading the FPS. My side monitors support 120 FPS, and although they are the same model and plugged in in the same manner one allows me to select 120 FPS while the other has no options for changing frames.

Wake Screen - This is a heartbreaker. I typically keep my MacBook docked vertically in clamshell mode in order to provide the best possible cooling at all times, but I have found out that whether I use a keyboard plugged into the device itself or into the D6000 I no longer have the ability to wake well the MacBook is in clamshell mode. If I hold down keys I will get a flicker as if it unlocks but after a few seconds, the screens revert to blank. At the moment this is solved by opening the MacBook from clamshell mode and then just shutting it right away. I have submitted a ticket for this instance and truly hope this is resolved. If you don't mind opening and closing your Macbook Pro once in a while this is by far the best option on the market for it all in one docking station.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
As some other reviews have mentioned, make sure you properly install the drivers and follow the directions carefully if you plan on using this with a Mac. Otherwise, this dock has been working great for me. I usually only use it to connect 1 monitor to my MacBook, but I have been able to use all 3 additional monitors. Finally, if you have to use adapters to convert between cable types make sure you are using an ACTIVE adapter, otherwise it will not work.

UPDATE: This review was originally written for OSX 10.14 (Mojave) and for the most part everything went smoothly. After upgrading to OSX 10.15.4 (Catalina) I ran into a few problems but still got everything to work. You can find the full instructions on their site but I'll summarize them here to hopefully save people some effort.

1. To get the Dock to work with Catalina you MUST upgrade to the latest device firmware. Unfortunately this can only be done from a Windows machine. Also pay close attention to the upgrade instructions, if you do not close all applications on your computer before starting the upgrade it may cause the upgrade to hang. Additionally I read that trying to do the upgrade via USB C causes issues. If your upgrade hangs, you can right click on the application icon and click close, this will start a rollback. Do not disconnect the power or USB until prompted to do so.

2. When installing the driver on your mac you must allow the system extension. This can be done through "Security & Privacy" and must be done within 30 minutes of attempting the install. See their site for more details. If you do not approve it within 30 minutes you can try installing it again to get the prompt again. To check if the extension has been denied you can check "About This Mac > System Report" and then check under "Software > Disabled Software" to make sure that the extension is not blocked. Additionally, under "Software > Extensions" you can scroll down until you see "DisplayLinkDriver" and verify that it says "Yes" under the "Loaded" column.

3. The last step is to allow the driver to record your screen in "Security & Privacy" settings.

Once again it's important to read all the instructions carefully otherwise you can run into issues like flickering screens, black screens, or just being unable to detect your monitors.

Hope that helps.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I'll start by saying I'm an IT Professional that troubleshoots end user issues with all sorts of hardware for a living, for years now. This is not an end user issue.

The product works well, but not if you want to drive 3 monitors from your workstation / laptop in a business environment where you'll be moving the laptop to meetings or home for the night and/or you have good habits / are required to lock your PC and timeout displays.

I will be returning this product and getting another D3100 and a second power adapter instead (as the 3100 doesn't chargeback).

TLDR:

I recently bought a MacBook Pro 15 and got a Dell D3100 dock to go with it ($120 or so, on Amazon). It worked amazingly well with one issue - no chargeback as that one is USB3.0. Getting tired of hauling my charger out of my bag... I got my boss to spring for this model that does 3 monitors as well and has chargeback.

I connected this device via the USB-C connector on the 'convertible' cable they provided.

First problem I ran into was right away, it wouldn't recognize all 3 monitors. I had the most updated driver already (same for my 3100) but I reinstalled it anyway because why not. It did drive 2 monitors plus my laptop screen like a champ, but the 3rd one didn't recognize at all. If I unplugged one of the DisplayPort connectors, the HDMI lit up and was fine - but as soon as I replugged the DP, HDMI went blank. After a decent bit of research and findings on the displaylink forums, I updated the firmware on the device and got pleasing results. All the monitors now work.

The second (and ultimately the last straw) issue wasn't apparent immediately. The device drove all the monitors and had chargeback just like I wanted, didn't overheat or anything and seemed pretty solid.

Then I went to a meeting with my laptop, and when I brought it back and plugged the dock in (with windows at lock screen) it didn't recognize my keyboard... but it got all my monitors and my mouse, so I figured it was a fluke. I unplugged the keyboard and reseated it, and was good to go. Never had this issue with ~6 weeks use of the 3100. This happened several more times over the next few days.

Then I went to lunch and left the laptop locked. My org power settings shut monitors off after 10 minutes on the lock screen - never been an issue, never was on the 3100.. but when I woke the laptop up, the screens went all flickery and the audio tweaked on all 3 monitors as they individually re-recognized and the display re-extended to them in sequence. Probably about a 20 second process before windows was responsive enough to log me in... this is huge already and happened literally every time I had to wake my displays.. but THEN, the 3rd monitor from my first issue would randomly be sitting at 800x600 and greyed out to change to the 1080 setting it was supposed to be at - necessitating me to unplug the dock altogether, wait for it to finish uninstalling the 9 things attached to it, then re-plug it and wait another 20 for it all to get straight again before I could work. Killing my network connection and suspending sessions with my PSA and other DB tools with improper dismount.

I've only had the thing for 4 days now and I think in that time I've spent more time futzing with it than I did in more than 6 weeks of having to plug in my power adapter alongside the 3100.. and I had zero issues with undocking / hot-docking / locking / waking with the 3100 at all, it worked right out of the box and I only had to buy a usb-c to usb3.0 cable to supplement it.

I did some research on that and it led me to a few settings that are obscure and I tried them to no avail. I attempted another firmware flash from a different PC and again a driver reinstall - same results when waking from locked/display off state.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
FIRST IMPRESSIONS
PROS
Much smaller than the Dell E-Plus docking station.
No legacy ports. Two Display Ports and one HDMI.
Four USB 3.0 ports (4) and 1 USB-C port
It seemed to work well with a Dell Latitude E7240 even when connected to a USB 2.0 port driving two Dell U2412M monitors @ 1920 x 1200 each.
CONS
1. It does not have an On-Off button. So, I have to open the lid of my PC to turn it on, while with the Dell E-Plus docking station, I could keep the lid closed and turn it on or off using the docking station button. I just read that there are workarounds about this, but I did not find any to be as convenient as Power button in the docking station.
2. It is not Plug-And-Play as it requires downloading and installing third party drivers by DisplayLink, so that meant a call to the IT Tech Support Team for my company provided PC (but not for my own identical PC).
3. I just read that the video signal gets compressed by the PC and then decompressed by the docking station (or something like that) and that this has its own pros and cons.

UPDATE 04/13/2019
I had ordered this Dell docking station D6000 to let's say "upgrade" from my Dell E-Plus docking station in my home office. Soon enough, I started noticing that there was a lag in the mouse's response time. Initially, I attributed it to the mouse's batteries and changed them by a new set. It was not it. So, I looked it up online and found that this is one of a number of known issues, and there were several recommendations in DisplayLink's support page... Update the PC's BIOS, check and update drivers, etc, etc. On a company provided computer such as my main PC, this means calls to the IT support team, remote support troubleshooting sessions, multiple-restarts, questions such as "what was wrong with the company provided E-Plus dock?" (Answer: nothing really, I just have a case of "upgraditis"), and there would be no guarantees that the issue would be solved after all those updates. So, together with the lack of Power on-off button, it's starting to look like a "no-go" for me.

comment:
I bought this dock to replace a Dell WD15 dock that broke. The feature set is good, but it did not have an on/off switch, unlike the WD15 dock

The way I use a docking station is that I dock my laptop and it may stay docked for a few minutes, a few hours, or a few days. I can then use the on/off switch to turn the laptop on and off without opening the lid, so the laptop acts like a desktop when it is docked.

I returned this product, and bought a Dell WD19TB dock, which does have an on/off switch. So far, the new dock works.

Unfortunately, the web page for this dock does not address this issue. I not that some of the competing docks have an on/off switch (Dell WD19, Lenovo dock) while others don't (Belkin, etc.).

The bottom line is that if you want to use a dock where you turn your laptop and all of the docked peripherals on and off by opening the lid of the laptop and using the laptop's on/off switch, the Dell 6000 should be a good dock for you. That's especially true if you use the laptop's screen along with the other peripherals. I give the Dell 6000 four stars.

However, if you want to keep the laptop closed while docked, and rely on one or more monitors instead of the laptop screen, you want a dock with an on/off switch.
