comment:
UPDATE 11/3/2018:

So it has been a few weeks with the dock now, and it hasn't given me any trouble. I turn on the laptop, both of my 4K monitors are working fine along with the peripherals.

=======================================================================

I have been a tech enthusiast for the last decade and my first week with this docking station was frustrating.
My rig is an Alienware 17 R3, Win10 64 bit, 1TB NVMe M.2 2280 SSD for boot and applicaitons, 1TB SSD for storage, 32GB DDR4 RAM, 970m GPU, and i7 6700HQ CPU.

The purpose of purchasing this specific docking station was for the horizontal design, USB C capability, and its 3 x 4K port connectivity. I am only utilizing 2 of the ports (HDMI and displayport) and my set up keeps switching from 4K resolution to 2048 x 1152 or 1920 x 1080. I thought this would be a simple driver issue so I uninstalled the displaylink driver I already had from my previous docking station and updated it to the most recent version. Still didn't fix the issue. So I tried a few different setups...one worked out fine with me by using the USB C portion instead of the USB 3.0 adapter alongside a Displayport to HDMI cable and HDMI to HDMI cable, both supporting 4K resolution. I haven't had any issues for the second week now and I will update.

PROS
+small, horizontal design
+affordable (cheaper than the typical 200 dollar docking stations with USB C)
+optional USB 3.0 or USB C connectivity
+4 USB 3.0 ports, 2 DisplayPort, and 1 HDMI

CONS
-illogical design between the docking station and the computer
-nonremovable USB C cable...
-troublesome set up

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
My friend and I use these docks with our Dell Latitude 7480 ultrabooks, both of which are Thunderbolt 3 equipped and capable of passing display info, USB and charging over the same USB C cable. After installing the DisplayPort driver on both laptops per the enclosed instructions and rebooting the PC, everything was plug and play, with a couple of quirks, which I'll outline below:

First, the docking station does not have an on-off switch, which means you need to connect it AFTER the computer has been turned on. While you can restart with the dock attached, you need to follow this "reconnect" procedure any other time the computer has been shut down, as not doing so can result in some of your devices not being recognized by the dock.

Second, there are some scenarios where Windows 10's ability to support multiple monitors with different font scaling and resolutions can be a bit buggy when using this dock. While my setup, which has a 1080p display on the laptop and two 1080p external monitors plugged into the dock worked as expected (being able to set font scaling separately for the laptop and my external displays separately without a problem), my friend's laptop, also has a 1080p display, but a U3415W as the external monitor, was a bit more quirky.

When we plugged the dock into his computer for the first time, his external monitor displayed 1080p as well, which is well below the native resolution of the monitor (3440x1440). To get everything to work correctly, we set the resolution and font scaling for the external display in Windows, then disconnected the laptop from the dock, and reset font scaling for the laptop's smaller display. From that point forward, the two displays worked as expected when used separately, but when the laptop is plugged into the dock with it's display open, it still tries to match the scaling of the larger display. While this was not a deal-breaker in my friend's scenario, be aware this could happen with your setup as well, particularly if you're trying to mix and match resolutions between the display on the laptop and any external displays.

Overall I'm very happy with these docks and would recommend these (or the  Plugable USB-C Triple Display Docking Station with Charging Support/Power Delivery for Specific Windows and Mac USB Type-C and Thunderbolt 3 Systems ) to anyone looking for a good Thunderbolt 3 dock.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I have two laptops, personal Lenovo X1 Carbon 6th Gen (Thunderbolt 3) and from work Dell Latitude 3490 (USB-C 3) and I was looking for a dock that drives both laptops with 2x QHD displays (HP Ellitedisplay 240q). Before trying the Dell D6000, I tried CalDigit TS3+ and Cable Matters USB-C docks and non of them drove my dell, but worked with my Lenovo.
And finally I got the dell D6000 that detected both laptops like a champ and drives my displays at their highest resolution. I mounted it on the back of my display so no cable is visible on my desk, just a USB-C cable that charges my laptop and provide connectivity to my mouse, keyboard, webcam and boss speakers.

If I want to mention disadvantage of dell D6000 they would be lack of ports (comparing to the CalDigit):
- Lack of fiber audio port for my Boss speaker, I should use USB connection instead (a little lower quality)
- Lack of number of USB-A ports. D6000 offers only 4 USB-A ports which are already utilized.
- Lack of SD Card slot - I have to purchase a separate USB-C to SD Card connector and attach it to D6000.

However, as long as it worked for me and addressed almost my requirements (with some workarounds), I would be happy to give it a 5 star considering my bad experience with CalDigit and Cable Matters. I have not done speed test yet though that is my real concern anyway. So I give it a pass.

NOTE: The CalGigit dock is a Thuderbolt 3 dock and it is not supposed to work my dell Latitude 3490 by design (my mistake to buy it in first place). So if you have laptops that support TB3, the CalDigit might be a better option considering its variety and number of ports. However it comes with a high price $304.

NOTE: The Cable Connect dock, on the other hand was a USB-C dock that did not work with my dell latitude USB-C port which was disappointing. Thanks to Amazon Prime, I did not have to worry about return.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
After days of excitedly awaiting, I finally got my D6000 to use with my 16 inch Macbook Pro. One USB-C plug to run 3 monitors, handle sound, and even charge(except in my case, the 16 inch MBP needs a slightly higher wattage, so I would have used my 96W power adapter anyway).
I got it all set up and installed the software to run 3 montiors. Beautiful. I moved on from using 2 dongles + manually plugging in my speakers, to running all of that on one dongle.

But shortly after, I wondered "why is the display I plugged in via hdmi showing my nightshift/f.lux but the two displays I plugged in via display port not working with it? This is going to hurt my eyes if I don't fix it."

I looked it up online, and for years(yes, at least 3 years), people have constantly asked the dell displaylink support to fix this issue so that nightshift actually works with this dock, but this has never been fixed. After seeing that Dell would not fix this issue, and that I'd be stuck without using nightshift if I wanted to continue using this dock, I decided instantly that I wouldn't be keeping this.
If it's having nightshift on all my monitors and plugging in 3 total cables vs having two of my monitors not usable with nightshift and plugging in 1 cable, I'll easily opt for the having to spend an extra few seconds to plug some cables in to save my eyes.
I also tried f.lux and that had the exact same issue as nightshift.

Another thing I don't like is that the two displayport monitors are software driven. So you have to run the displaylink software whenever you want to use those two monitors. In other words, those monitors won't even turn on until the displaylink software is started while using the D6000 This doesn't happen when I use my two dongles each handling their share of my 3 monitors.

You almost had me Dell, but please fix your nightshift/f.lux issue and maybe I'll reconsider.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
At work we use Dell, that is where I found this product. I purchased this product to use on my personal HP laptop as a docking station that connects via UNB-C.
I have had dual monitors (Display port connection) connected to the D6000, and it works great on my HP laptop. At work I had a computer connected with 3 monitors (dual display port + HDMI) and the laptop screen was still fully functional. Giving me 4 total monitors functional at the same time.

I love this unit, USB's work, and it even charges if you have a Dell Thunderbolt connection.

Why do I like it, well I learned that Dell outsources production of this device (D6000) dock, and therefore it's compatible with many/most computers. I have tried other models in my HP, and none of them work. (Note: I have not tried 3 monitors connected to my HP laptop, but I've been told by tech support that it's able to support it.)

I don't really understand why companies make devices that only work with their stuff. Meaning they could sell more and make greater profits if (like this device) it's compatible with anything. So if you're someone looking for this kind of compatibility, this is a great device. I would highly recommend it.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
Works great with my Dell XPS 9560 (Win 10 Pro) and my MacBook Pro (Retina, 13-inch, Early 2015).

I installed the DisplayLink drivers and the Dell recommended drivers and have enjoyed it ever since. In fact, I jut bought my second one to use on site for my contract jobs.

It *DOES* charge the 9560 but you'll get the BIOS power adapter warning, but you can turn it off (as well as set the AC power to primary use to prolong your 9560 battery life). As for the MacBook, I downloaded the DisplayLink driver and used the USB-3 adapter on the plug (I have the USB-C models) and the built-in display and both Dell monitors look fantastic. It's great only having 1 plug (or 2 if you need the AC for intensive use) to grab-n-go.

I have occasionally experienced mouse hesitation but it's only evident without the regular AC adapter plugged in. I also used the Alpha DisplayLink Drivers for my Dell and that helped.

The sound is good, I can use Gigabit Ethernet on my laptop and have extra ports and much neater cables. I'm glad got it and I'm sure it'll work for other laptops later.

I got a sweet deal using a site that rhymes with Hamill x3. Check the Warehouse Deals too, that's where this one came from.

UPDATE July 2018
After living with it for a while, I need to dock some stars...
It can't handle 4k very well. If you text edit or browse using _only the dock for power_ you will literally hear it screech from pain while trying to keep up and render content. YouTube will lose sync in full screen making it look like an old dubbed kung-fu movie. If you use CorelDRAW! or the like, it will crash frequently because the dock's video chip can't handle it. Using the laptop's HDMI out solves these issues, but that's not a lot of help with a dual-4k setup.

If you need graphical performance while driving a pair of 4k monitors, I'd have to steer towards using an eGPU chassis and a Quadro or GTX 1070 with a Thunderbolt 3 out to reconnect LAN, Sound, etc.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I have been using the D6000 for a year now with a HP laptop, two Dell monitors, a Logitech Unifying receiver and a RJ45 cable at 1.0Gbps.
The network is steady, no issues there.
As for lags, the station itself is working well but I did notice the following shortcoming
The Dell D6000 It won't stand a things like connecting an CF card reader with RAW files on it. Once I did that, the typing functionality of a wireless keyboard connected to the station's USB2.0 port was gone. The typing lag was impossible to work with.
Also, I did notice a slight lagging when moving a page (some program or a browser windows) from laptop screen to the monitors but it wasn't significant.
MAC: I tested this station with a Mac Pro laptop. Display link driver is required, also need to make sure the driver is loaded upon startup. It took some support reading on the web but it worked eventually.
The firmware was recently to the latest A03 firmware hoping it will solve the keyboard lad when reading a CF card, it didn't.
The bottom line is this is a very practical and easy to use DisplayLink docking station but it has its limitations.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
Short answer: Worked great until the Sep 2020 driver update which we just got, and now we cannot profile the connected monitors (for photo editing). If that doesn't matter to you, this is a very good dock solution. If it does, then this is not going to work.

Initially May 2020, connected to Dell XPS 15 and two Samsung 27" (2560x1444) monitors via DisplayPort cable, the two monitors would work but not the laptop screen, or the laptop screen and not the monitors, so we kept the screen closed enough to disable the screen. Since the computer was used for photo editing, including portraits, we used the ColorMunki photospectrometer and software to create color profiles. All is fine.

Now comes late October and the system crashed and could not recover. Dell checked the hardware and found OK, so had me download a new factory image for the drive. Computer, as far as it knows, is brand new. After a week of installing software, Windows updates, Dell updates, etc. now the two monitors connected to the D6000 will work at the same time as the built in laptop screen. Only one problem--we can no long create monitor profiles, as the ColorMunki fails in a couple different ways. My best guess is that when we reinstalled everything, we must have gotten the latest DisplayLink driver for the D6000--and that fixed one problem we didn't care about while creating a new one that rendered the computer-dock-monitors setup unusable for its intended purpose.

comment: I have an older Dell XPS 13 (5th gen i5) and the little Dell adapter I was using to connect HDMI, LAN, and USB...started having issues. I purchased this D6000 universal doc and from the get-go, it works fantastic. theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
This Dell Docking station replaced a Plugable USB-C dock that I could never get to work quite right. With the Plugable I had to download drivers for both Mac and Windows (Bootcamp) to get it to work and only about 50% of the time would I just dock my MacBook Pro and everything would work, would regularly have to power cycle the dock when ports would just randomly stop working.

I unplugged everything from the Plugable unit and directly into the Dell unit using DisplayPort to HDMI adapters for 2 of the 3 displays and EVERYTHING worked the very first time I docked it! All 3 of my displays powered up, both of the webcams I have plugged in were recognized and both bluetooth dongles for my Windows KB and mouse.

I couldnt be happier with this setup, it works perfect for running 3 1080P displays plus some peripherals. Specifically I am using 3 Dell H2419SE 24" displays, one just straight HDMI into the Dell dock, and then HDMI from the other 2 displays into Starware DisplayPort to HDMI dongles (the ones that look like flash drives). Then just a single USB-C cable from the Dell dock into my HengeDock(now Brydge) MacBook Pro dock. Macbook Pro is a Late 2016 15" TouchBar.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I purchased this docking station after a cheaper one didnâ€™t work properly. I am using it with a Dell XPS 15 9570 and have attached a 4K monitor, 2 external hard drives, Power for my laptop pad, and my Bluetooth mouse and keyboard.

Overall it works great after getting it set properly. My main issue at first was that it wasnâ€™t indicated to use DisplayPort if you want a 60hz refresh rate at 4K resolution. I was using HDMI and only getting 30hz. Once I switched over the problem was fixed.

Besides needing to switch my display wire the only minor annoyance is that my computer was giving me a warning on boot that the power adaptor wasnâ€™t Correct because the voltage was too low. While this is true, it still keeps the laptop charged so itâ€™s a nonissue. To remove the warning you just need to go into BIOS settings on start up and turn off the power adaptor warning.

Overall this is a great docking station and it definitely does the job. I like that it has support for multiple monitors as well as fast USB 3.0 to transfer data to external drives. If you are someone with a laptop that likes to use it as a desktop this is the item for you.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
We got these docks at work with new Dell laptops, and I liked my work one so much that I bought one for home. It's so befuddlingly simple that I'm telling everyone I talk to to buy one. I can plug my work computer into it, and it even charges the thing by USB-C (this seems to be a Dell/Dell thing). I plug it into my Asus laptop, and it works just as well (but doesn't charge). I can even plug it into my ancient Asus Transformer 100, and everything recognizes and works just fine.
Heck, I can even plug my USB-C PHONE into the thing, and use the keyboard and mouse on my phone. The one catch with the phone is that I needed to install a Displaylink mirroring app, and it doesn't automatically recognize when I plug it in like the app claims it will.

The cord has an attached USB-C to USB-A adapter on it, which works well, and it also works with a USB-C to Micro USB adapter - at least as far as recognizing monitors, keyboard, mouse, etc.
The only thing I have gotten to charge using the dock is my Dell (work) laptop using USB-C. I think this is a limitation in the things I'm buying rather than the dock.

It's great. Dead simple, and great.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
This thing is amazing. I work at home from time to time, and I managed to get a branded doc for my laptop. My mother in law visits frequent from cross country and she just got a new laptop to travel with her so she can work remotely. Rather than work off the laptop I figured I'd try a universal doc.

It has two Display ports and one HDMI and can drive all three monitors over usb-3 or usb-C. The monitors I'm running on it now are a pair of Dell Ultrasharp U2715H monitors at 2560x1440. Not sure on the frequency. The spec says it can drive one more monitor over HDMI. It also has ethernet, audio, and usb ports to attach a handful of peripherals. I'm using this for what I would deem casual web browsing on the personal side, and office productivity on the work side, no gaming or heavy video for me.

I bought two other brands of universal docs, and they couldn't match the display resolution this one does. I't is very small and unassuming. The attachment to your laptop has a native usb-c connector, and attached to it is a USB-3, no hunting around for the right cable to connect it up.

If you want to drive 2 high resolution office productivity monitors from one usbc/usb3 connection this is the way to go, just make sure to get quality video cables for it to work optimally. Cheap cables can flak out on you causing more trouble than it's worth (I speak from experience).

comment:
Update on 12/14/2020: It's been a solid product and with the money. I've been getting the use out of it daily and it's been a seamless experience.

Update on 9/4/2019: It's still going strong and haven't had any issues connecting. Solid dock! Also works with my Galaxy Note 9 - Samsung DoX interface provide windows desktop kind of experience. Keyboard and mouse work seamlessly as well. Adding couple pictures.

Original Review:

Bit expensive but love the fact that you just have to plug a single USB-C or USB 3 cable (comes attached with the dock; USB-C converts to USB 3) and you've got everything working smoothly. I attach USB-C cable from dock my 13.3" laptop to get all of the below benefits seamlessly...

1. Two 2K monitors at 60Hz (had two 4K monitors attached earlier but wanted to upgrade to 2K, trust me - for a computer screen 2K feels upgrade as it's so easy on eyes) along with laptop screen.

2. Worked keyboard & mouse

3. Headphone

4. It automatically charges laptop back with the same cable (at 90W Dell power supply)

5. External drive (flash drive)

I'm still left with few USB ports on the dock to use for other things. There's no compromise on speed with anything and there's no conflict. It's just fantastic!!! My desk is well organized with just a SINGLE cable!!!

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
This dock is featured on the front page of the official DisplayLink website, and headlines a 2018 pamphlet alongside wireless VR. It's probably featured elsewhere on DisplayLink's website for good reason: it's probably the best solution a home user can get as a TRULY universal dock. And at a good hundred dollars less than other USB-C docks with Power Delivery. It's worked with most everything I've plugged it into, even older USB 2 devices. Just remember that you HAVE to install software from DisplayLink for this to work.
Also there are some hell devices that just won't work, no matter how excellent the DisplayLink standard is for universal compatibility. An old Nexbit Robin I tried using just refused to work. Had the software installed and all set up just like other phones I tried this on...no dice. I guess Nexbit was too garbage to implement the USB standard correctly, as that is the LITERAL only way it would fail to connect right. Last thing that wouldn't work is super-old systems; DisplayLink runs off of the CPU and can get intensive to run. So make sure to test it within the return window with everything you want to connect it to! That said, there isn't another dock at this price that supports DisplayLink and Power Delivery through USB-C. Get it!

comment:
Tried to give this dock a chance. It was nice to use 1 cable to charge the MacBook as well as use as an additional port replicator / video output. However, on each boot up, you must unplug and re-plug in the USB-C cable. Otherwise, the video, and all USB devices do not work. In fact, the MacBook does not even detect the dock. You are better off doing this:
Apple USB-C to USB Adapter
Apple USB-C Charge Cable (2m)
Apple 30W USB-C Power Adapter
Apple Power Adapter Extension Cable (for MacBook Pro, MacBook, MacBook Air)
Dell USB 3.0 Ultra HD/4K Triple Display Docking Station (D3100), Black
Total Cost: $252.67

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
The Dell D6000 is a great usb-c dock. It includes a power source so the USB isn't throttling my peripherals at all.

I have a mouse, keyboard, external hard-drive, controller dongle, microphone and headphone all plugged in at the same time. Think about plugging all those in one-by-one every time i returned from classes. It would be a nightmare! This saves the time by connecting all of those through one USB-C port. This dock is made for Dell laptops, so my Razer Blade 15 does get power pass through so that's a bummer. The included power adapter is a humongous brick so its kind of a wasted opportunity.

The only thing that makes this a 7/10 product is that the display adapter for the HDMI port is not the best. Gaming off of the dock is a stutter-y mess and makes every game unplayable. So instead of just plugging in the dock to my laptop, I have to plug in the dock and my HDMI cable which creates more of a mess of cables on my desk. If you aren't into gaming then good news, the dock should fit your needs just fine!
7/10

comment:
I had issues with my previous dual monitor universal docks. This one works much better and seems to be compatible with my monitors out of the box. The one feature that is cannot live without is the USB plug, which connects to my computers. The plug is great because it has a built in USB 3.0 and USB-C adapter. This allows me to easily switch between my desktop computer (which predates USB-C) and my newer Dell XPS laptop, which only has USB-C ports.

Of note, this universal dock can charge USB-C devices at the same time that it transmits display data-- meaning I only need one plug to both charge my USB-C compatible laptop and connect it to my displays. Occasionally, I will have connection issues on my main monitor. Unplugging the universal dock's power supply fixes this issue. This problem occur maybe once every three weeks; enough to dock a star rating, but not enough to cause any true issues.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I've purchased 15 or so of these in the past year to replace existing docks and have found them to be about as good as you can get for usbc docks that support 2+ monitors. Given we have all dells, a mix of inspirons, xps's, and latitudes, i've found these work equally well with all.

I've tried cheaper sub $100 usbc docks like Wavlink and MediaGear but have not been consistent as this one. Typically with those docks you are going to have more problems with devices being recognized or monitor and peripherals that just stop working.

The two issues i've found with these docks are DOA and need for occasional reboots.

I've had 2-3 instances where the dock power plug needs to be removed and inserted again to reset the device and the ports - to solve monitor and peripheral issues. However, this is great compared to some of the other docks i've tried.

And i've had to send back two or three of these that were dead on arrival. Then again it seems like any docks other docks have this issue to so just be aware. This is the best usb-c dock for dells of any type though if you want multiple screens.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
Finally, a Dell or USB-C Dock that works.

In the past, I've used the TB15 (a Thunderbolt dock that was a poor design, rarely worked, and was quickly replaced by the TB16), the TB16 (a bit better than the TB15, but only a little), the WD15 (a non-Thunderbolt USB-C dock that also had RF issues and was quirky in general). I tried them all and sent them all back.

This is basically a WD15 (USB-C, plus video over Alt-mod), with a 6000-series Displaylink hung off the USB hub, driving two display outputs.

It all just works. I'm using two 4k monitors.

Before buying, do understand the limitations of Displaylink: It's great for general usage, but not usable for performance intensive games. The Displaylink video goes over USB, so it competes with ethernet and everything else except for the alt-mode video.

Alt mode on HDMI drives my 4k monitor at 30Hz, which is fine for my general office usage. It claims to be able to do 60Hz, but honestly, I've not tried and I'm using a crappy HDMI cable, so it might be possible.

Also, the Power Delivery output itsn't enough to power some power-hungry laptops. Know your specs before you order.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
Everything seems to work as expected, the quality of the headphone amplifier is good, better than the one in the laptop and much, much better than the one in the Dell AE515 soundbar, however the audio device does not disable when no headphones and/or line-out is connected. It also does not cut the line-out when the headphones are inserted.
Setup : Lenovo Yoga 900/Dell U2417H monitor/Dell D600 dock/Dell AE515M Soundbar/Windows 10
The expected behavior is to have the Dell D600 as the default audio device. If headphones are connected sound should go to it.
If headphones are not connected and the line-out is not connected the audio should go to the next device in the list (The Soundbar).
The problem is that the D600 dock shows always as enabled even if no headphones/lineout is connected.
In contrast the microphone in the D6000 shows as disconnected if no headphone/lineout is connected.
Trying to find alternative workarounds using other soundbars shows another problem:
If you connect headphones to the D6000 and you have a lineout device, the sound is not cut to the lineoutput device. So you get sound from your speakers and headphones.
I tried the latest Dell driver (From 2019) and the latest drivers from the DisplayLink association (From 2020) without luck.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
This dock really does seem to be universal. So far, I've connected a Galaxy Book 12, a Dell XPS 13 9370, an Intel NUC6CAYH, and a Galaxy S9. All worked out of the box without needing drivers. (I did later download the drivers, 'cause I'm obsessive like that... and also, why wouldn't you?).

Currently connected to a Dell U2414H via DisplayPort, and a 28" Dell via HDMI. There's a free DisplayPort connection that I'm not even using. I'm not busy or important enough for three monitors, I guess. I have a wireless keyboard and mouse connected via one of the USBP type A ports, and those work with no issues. I didn't bother with the ethernet connection, as the wireless adapters on the devices above are all hella fast.

If I had a complaint, it's that the USB 3.0/USB-c wire that connects to your PC, laptop, whatever, is not replaceable (at least, you can't unplug it from the dock itself). If that wire goes, you're hosed unless you are very handy with wiring. The end of the power cord that plugs into the dock lights up bright blue when the device has power. I'm not sure that's necessary or helpful.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
Well, it works - sort of...

I this D6000 when the WD-15 I had finally died. A couple of things you need to be aware of:

1) The Intel UHD graphics software on my computer doesn't see the D6000. Period. Can't configure the monitors through the Intel software, so I had to resort to using the built-in Windows 10 software (not as robust).
2) This unit does NOT support D-port daisy chain. You have to plug each monitor directly into the D6000.
3) The USB C-to-A adapter is permanently attached to the cable, for some reason. It's awkward and takes up space. You can cut it off if you're connecting to your computer via USB-C - but Dell should have make it removable so you don't have to pull out an Xacto knife to cut off the damned adapter.
4) The cable from the dock to the computer is permanently attached, meaning you're stuck with that length cable. Period.
5) Don't even think about trying upgrade the D6000 firmware through a non-Dell computer. The installer is written so it looks for a Dell computer configuration first, so if you've got a non-Dell computer (like me, I've got an HP), you can't do it.

I'm sure there are other docking stations out there, but this one was relatively inexpensive ($130), even though it has quirks. On the plus side, the monitors don't flicker like they did with the WD-15.

comment:
This dock is amazing for what it delivers. I was going back and forth for a couple weeks trying to decide what dock to purchase for my HP Spectre X360 13.3-ae00xx. I ended up purchasing this since I knew we used these at work and they work pretty good. I've had nothing but good experiences with this dock. Download the driver from the DisplayLink website, install and you're good to go. I was slightly worried since most reviews continue to say it only powers up to 60 W instead of the advertised 65 W. theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
Disappointed.... Both due to charging and audio issues.

Before ordering, I contacted Dell customer support to see if this would work with my new Alienware 17R5. The specs say it will send 65W to charge, and the Alienware takes a lot more than that. I decided to skip at first, but then saw a few people claiming it would in fact charge my Alienware. I was dubious, so I contacted Dell technical support via online chat. They told me that, yes, it would indeed charge the Alienware. So I went from "nope, can't get a dock like I want ever" to "found a dock that'll work!".

Then the product arrived, and sure enough, it did not charge the laptop at all. And yes, I was using the USB-C connection. Googling a bit more I came across a FAQ on Dell's own site that confirmed that the dock will NOT charge the Alienware. Wish I had found that before contacting Dell techs support.

Given the relatively decent price and easy connection process (ethernet and hdmi for now), I figured try it out a bit, maybe I won't care about the lack of charging (tho part of the reason I like legacy docks was a single cord / connection). Unfortunately it didn't take me long to find a different problem - audio. When I perform a speaker test on the audio sent via the dock to my HDMI monitor, only the left channel came through. I swapped HDMI cables to see if that was the issue, but unfortunately I couldn't resolve. I then hooked it up to a friend's laptop, and had the exact same issue. Switched the cable back to my desktop and audio to that monitor worked fine. I'm guessing this was a defect in my particular unit, but can't swear to that.

At this point I've initialized a return, which is a bummer - time and money wasted due to Dell tech support.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: This is a solid brick that feels nice to the touch. The cable has both USB 3.0 and USB C support which is fantastic. However, after fully updated (firmware) with a Windows 10 Dell laptop purchased in 2018, it still had some feature bugs. For example, the laptop does not support charging over USB-C and it would notify me every time that this dock was plugged in that a non-compatible device was plugged in via the USB-C port. $1100 Dell notebook. After skipping this message the dock connects properly. It does not play nice with all types of USB devices though, as I have a DAC which needed to be unplugged and plugged back in every time this dock was plugged into my laptop. Other devices such as a keyboard and mouse had no issues. If you want a trouble-free dock I suggest you keep searching, but the features on this dock are above-standard and I feel it is worth the cost.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I purchased this item refurbished from Amazon warehouse it was shipped and received promptly within two days. The box and item we're in great condition all peripheral cables etc where in good order. Everything was really easy plug and play headed over to displaylink.com to download the drivers plugged in the Dell display link, attach my monitors using the HDMI and displayport ports my dual monitor setup immediately came up and worked.
A few notes when using this and combination with a USB port weather at 3.0 or USBC on my particular laptop a Lenovo IdeaPad the hardware accelerations in the graphic card are not engaged so some functionality particularly in Photoshop is not available. Also I did notice some lag and some choppiness in the displays.
After using the display link for about 78 hours I came home to wake up my computer and the device was no longer functioning. The status light would not stay illuminated and my computer could not identify the USB port as in use. I contacted support through Amazon and was breeded by a friendly and helpful tech who had limited knowledge of the device itself but was eager to help. And currently waiting on my second display link to arrive and hopefully everything will go as planned with no additional issues, I will update this review after I received the new unit and this is in use for a few weeks.

Update replacement unit came in once plugged in and monitors were attached everything worked perfectly but not for long. After about an hour and my monitor went in to sleep mode I tried to wake it up and my laptop was only recognizing one display one that was not attached to display link. After a bit of investigation the display link had calrapped out again with no indicator light even after a hard reset.
So in closing I wouldn't not recommend this as a solution as I've gotten a little less than 78hrs usage out of two separate units combined.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: Iâ€™ve been using this dock with 2 monitors and they withstand a pretty high refresh rating

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I just received this the other day to use with my mmnew M1 Macbook Pro. I wsmas initially upset and irritated because it still couldn't drive my 2 external monitors - especially at the ultrawide aspect ratio... I spent about an hour before I realized that they have a very recent driver that fixed the issue. Now it works like a dream!!

Only issue I've found, so far, is that it doesn't output a very high refresh rate, but since I'm only using my monitors for my sound studio, I don't need graphic-heavy utilization so it works fine.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: I've had this for about 2 weeks now, and so far it's working fine. I am using it with a Dell Inspiron Model 5584 laptop computer (with Windows 10) and 2 external monitors. One external monitor (4K resolution) is connected to the dock's HDMI port and another (much older) external monitor is connected to one of the DisplayPorts by using a DVI - DisplayPort converter cable (purchased separately). (The older monitor did not have either a HDMI port or a DVI port - thus the need for a converter cable.) Following the instructions, I downloaded drivers from both the Dell website and the DisplayLink website, and installed the drivers. Then I powered up and connected the dock to the computer, then connected the monitors to the dock, then the other USB peripherals to the dock. All of this went smoothly. I do not do gaming, however, so cannot comment one way or the other how this dock would perform for that type of use.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
The dock worked well while I had it, except that it did not work consistently with 3 external monitors (sometimes all three monitors connected, sometimes only two), only with 2 monitors. But for 2 external monitors it worked reliably for both a Lenovo PC laptop and a Macbook pro.

Then after 7 months it suddenly died. Dell's support told me that warranty for this model is only 6 months, and regardless they will not honor it if it is purchased on Amazon or anywhere else other than Dell's website. They also said that this dock was discontinued. So I was out of luck.

After this D6000 deck died, I researched replacement options including other manufacturers and ended up buying the Dell UD22 on Dell's website with 3-yr warranty. The UD22 has pretty much the same outer case as this model but apparently newer internal components. So far it works well.

I was not inclined to buy again from Dell given this experience, but I was not able to find any other better option for a universal deck. I am out $200 on the D6000 and am pretty disappointed at Dell over this. They need to honor warranties across all retailers so people can buy products where it's most convenient for them.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: I needed a way to connect my work laptop (Lenovo without a USB-C port) to my dual monitors and also wanted to be able to use it for my other computers. Other than needing to visit the dell website and download the driver manually, the dock was basically plug and play. Note: if you want to run both monitors off the dock you will need at least one HDMI to display port cable. You can run two HDMI only cables, but one will have to be from the laptop and not the docking station. If you want to minimize connection switches you'll want the display port cable. And I appreciate the adapter for the USB-C to USB-A is connected to the cable so I don't have to worry about losing it when I don't need the adapter.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
Just purchased for use with a Dell 9570 XPS 15. Downloaded the drives from the dell site, plugged in and worked without any issue first time through.

At least for my model, the USB C is not powerful enough to power the laptop so I still ahve to use a charger. I'm sure there are some laptops that will charge over USBC, which would be a huge plus. Dell/Windows is at least nice enough to have prompted me onscreen that there wasn't enough power.

I like the USBC cable comes in a USB3 adaptor thing. Not sure what that's for exactly, I suppose if you jsut wanted to use it as a hub instead of doing displays.

Device does get warm, which is slightly annoying, but I don't have other docks to compare it to.

It would also be nice if windows (and adobe) would autodetect the hub has been connected and automatically switch over the audio profiles to use the hub (or use the laptop when disconnected).

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: So far, so good. I'm using this to connect a Surface Pro 4 (Core m3) to two Dell 24" 1080p Display Port monitors, and it works just fine. There does seem to be a little lag at times -- such as when using the wired keyboard attached to the dock and when dragging windows across displays -- but it's minimal and the pros far outweigh the cons. I downloaded the standard DisplayLink drive for Windows 10 off the DisplayLink website, installed them, and connected the dock. It was as simple as that. It also works with my Dell Latitude laptop, so I'm happy to be able to use either my work-issued notebook when working from home and my personal computer. It also charges my Android phone pretty quickly, and I can also charge my vape pen. :) The design is also appealing: a very simple, small black box with a subtle power/status LED. All-in-all, I'm very satisfied with this product. While a little pricey, it has the 2x DisplayPort outputs that really cleaned things up -- no need for weird cables or adapters, etc.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: I like that you can extend/expand to 3 monitors and more usb ports. I wish that the docking station would allow the laptop to turn on automatically when you plug the usb-c into the laptop without having to open the laptop and then pressing the power button on. Other than this, docking station works without a problem. Another thing is that you can leave the laptop open and use the laptop monitor in addition to the 3 monitors.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: We have these dock stations in the office. A really solid product. The key feature that it can work both with thunderbolt USB-C and USB 3.0 ports - there's a permanently cord-attached adapter between the two. Usually you have to choose one of the two. Indeed, one would hope for two HDMIs and one DVI, but one HDMI and 2 DVIs are OK. Ethernet port, sound ports, 4 USB 4.0 ports. It's somewhat pricey, but solid. Don't regret buying it.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I use this dock for my Microsoft Surface Pro 7, and it works for the most part. I installed this without installing the software, and it seems to work fine. Keep in mind, you will need a 4K monitor (which I do not have) to get the fullscreen capability.

One slight downside is that, sometimes, the connectivity will intermittently go out, particularly the sound. However, those issues only happened a while back and only very briefly (for maybe 0.2 seconds) go out here and there, but it's been working good since.

Also, remember that the two USB jacks operate differently, depending on what you're using them for (i.e. to access data vs. charging), so keep that in mind.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: This product was the perfect solution for Appleâ€™s major issue of its brand new M2-based MacBooks ONLY supporting ONE external monitor. I have a three monitor setup and almost passed out when I realized my brand new MacBook would regulate me to only one monitor. Dell and DisplayLink to the rescue. Product works great.

comment:
I got a new work laptop and needed a new docking station. The one at the office has a power button, this is always on.

The multiple monitors was a bit of a pain to set up, but works fine now. I'm never going to use 4k just my big ol Dell monitors.
Overall my desk is a bit neater and I have no complaints other than the lack of a power button. I have had no issues with my wireless mouse or keyboard that others mentioned.
I probably wouldn't buy again, i'd go with the cheaper version.

Power 2 monitors

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: The dock works well for my non-dell USB 3.0 A form-factor laptop. One thing I wasn't aware of was that you only get two screen outputs on USB A devices, the third screen is reserved for thunderbolt/type-c laptops. While this is noted, it was hard to see, and I didn't find out until after I had ordered and read the instruction manual. The actual dock, however, is great. I'll continue using it for work, and have just added a single extra USB 3.0 to HDMI dongle to my laptop. Note that you can't get away with plugging this into the dock as well, it just won't work. My best guess is this is due to a bandwidth limitation of some sort with USB 3.0 A, not the dock itself.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: I bought this dock for my home office. I have three external monitors that I wanted to use with my work laptop (Dell), but I also have a MacBook Pro (13-inch Mid 2012) that does not have a thunder port. I was skeptical that this dock would work, but with the included USBC -> USB adapter, I was able to download and install the DisplayLink drivers onto my Mac and then plug it is. Instantly I have 2 external monitors for my Mac! It was awesome! The fine print on the materials that come with the dock indicate that only 2 external monitors will work with the USB, but that 3 work with the USBC. I have found this to be the case. None of my monitors are 4k monitors, however they are all HD monitors and the display is crisp and flawless. Overall I am very pleased that I have a dock that works perfectly for both my personal and work computers.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I am using this with a Lenovo E580 laptop for work. I was looking for a USB-C dock that would allow me to have one dock to hook up to USB receivers for wireless mouse and keyboard, two external monitors, external speakers, Ethernet, and power. This allows me to do that and has worked great. I work primarily with documents, so I cannot speak to how this would work for people who work with a lot of video, but I've seen no issues just watching videos.

The dock comes with a built in USB-C and USB-A cord to hook up to it, so you don't need to buy an extra USB-C cord just to hook up to the dock.

I bought this for $129.99. That was expensive but seemed fair compared to my other options. It looks like the price has increased to $149.99. That seems bordering on too expensive, and I might consider researching other options at that price.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I cannot speak towards using this dock with a Windows machine, but for a Mac laptop, I would say just get a slightly more expensive dock because it WILL work better with a Macbook Pro.

I've been using this every single workday for at least 7-8 months now, and I can sat that this one is a pain in the butt. They never got the driver and firmware updates right, and when I plug in the Thunderbolt connector, sometimes the laptop will get power and sometimes it won't. Generally, I plug/unplug it 2-4 times and then it will finally get power.

Overall, getting power to all devices can be slightly finicky sometimes when plugging and unplugging the cable to the laptop from the dock.

Using the DisplayLink drivers, my two monitors work fine, but with DIsplayLink the delay when booting up or plugging in the dock is very slow. Once the monitors are up it's fine.

Really, once the dock is plugged in correctly it seems to work fine, but I just VERY. very often have to plug/unplug it to get things working correctly after the laptop has been disconnected from the dock.

comment: I used this docking station for my home work area - two Dell monitors and an Acer laptop. I connected using a standard USB port - both monitors came right up. Opening the box to up and running took about 3-4 minutes. Great purchase for a non-tech savy user.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: This dock works great with my Dell XPS 9500. I plugged it in and it immediately automatically installed the proper drivers and worked flawlessly. theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
Firstly this is the best product I was able to find to do the job. It does the job okay at best. It was very difficult to find comparable docks with the same features.

I have asus ultra wide 34 inch 3440 by 1560 it's not 4k but having this hooked up gave me a refresh of 60hz via display port. I still run another monitor a old Dell ultra sharp 2005 1680 by 1050. I hooked it up via the one HDMI available on the dock and my ultra wide asus dropped to 30hz not good. To resolve this, I bought a display port to HDMI 2.0 cable and connected the 2005 ultrasharp to the other available display port on the dock. This still didn't give me 60hz on my Asus but it gave me 50hz which is just about good enough not to be annoying. The ultra sharp monitor had no issues running at 60hz the whole time.

The reason for the 3 star rating is the chart on dell's website indicated I should be able to run both at 60hz no problems.

I'm using a hp spectre x360 - 15-ch011nr, power delivery to charge it works great.

comment:
I ordered this after using this same docking station at work. It is a nice size that doesnâ€™t take up a lot of room on the desk. It supports multiple monitors and other accessories. I like the simplicity of the USB-C single connection to my computer for power, displays, and accessories.
Update Dec 2022 - The docking station failed 83 days after I received it. I still gave it two stars because I believe I received a questionable docking station. The mnfg date on the docking station is Dec 2019 (3 years prior to when I received). I purchased it from a third party Amazon seller and they would not support the Dell warranty. Next time I will order from the Amazon Dell site which does support the warranty on their products.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I use this at work to attach my 2013 MacBook Pro to two additional 24-inch monitors via Display Port. Because the 2013 MacBook Pro only has USB 3, I use the included USB 3 type A connector cable (vs the type c cable) and it allows for my external mouse and keyboard to be hosted on the built in USB ports, and the two monitors to extend my Mac's desktop. The extra two monitors are great for putting code windows, extra browsers, log files, you name it as long it's mostly static 18pt+ font text.

The downside: I use the iOS simulator for many hours every day, and I simply cannot have the simulator on those external screens. It may be the drivers or the hardware doing video compression on the images going to those screens, but the colors and pixel alignments are not cut out for detailed design work.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I've had an intermittent issue with this for the last 6 months. I bought it in October of 2018, and use it nearly daily. It sits atop my desk, and I have 2 monitors plugged into it. and when I work from home, I plug my laptop into it via the USB-C port and charge my laptop through it.

As far as the issue, it will occasionally lose power, or reset, and all the USB devices, and monitors attached to it will disconnect, then reconnect after a second or two. There are also times where I am on my laptop, and then the mouse or keyboard will suddenly disconnect, then reconnect. It started a few months after the purchase, but it would only happen once a day or so, not enough to really complain, just enough to be slightly bothersome. It's been happening more frequently lately though, pretty consistently a few times a day now, and sometimes 2 or 3 times in a minute, then it will be fine for a short while. I'm assuming that it has to do with overheating, since when it starts doing it frequently, if I unplug and leave it be for a few minutes, then plug it back in, it seems to work fine for a while.

I do not have it covered, it sits out in the open in front of my keyboard. There is no fan or venting on it, which I have made sure of, and I have tried keeping it in several different places to try to avoid it from getting too warm, but it hasn't made a difference where its at, it still flickers several times a day. I'm looking for an new one, but I might try ordering the same one again since there aren't too many other negative reviews on this, I might have just received a poorly built one.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I got my Dell D6000 Dock station after I had bought my 6th Dell Laptop. I am a professional who reviews licenses, map, satellite photos, and mountains of data, on three computer flatscreens that span @ 16 square feet. I have to add cordless mouse, cordless keyboard, 2 printers, power supply, 2 flatscreens and monitor, and THEN keep all those wires off my desk. Then not let all the wires get tangled under and behind my desk. Dell Customer Service and my computer guru buddies BOTH recommended the D6000.

One plug and done. CLICK! Done! I save 2-3 aggravating minutes daily with it . CLICK! Programming and set up was a cinch. I'll save in labor time the cost of it in a half year, ..... and my desk looks perfect!

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: I'm using this dock in conjunction with a Lenovo T580 Laptop. I have a Lenovo dock that I use for work and it has support for three monitors and it actually works. This dock says it can support up to three monitors, but it doesn't with my laptop. There are three ports, but if I try to use all three, the HDMI port doesn't work, if I unplug one of the DisplayPort plugs, then the HDMI works. I've updated the dock, and installed the latest version of the drivers on my laptop and it had no affect. My work around is to plug the HDMI cable directly into my laptop. I read up on this and there is a very specific protocol that the dock uses connect the third monitor that doesn't seem well supported. If you are wanting to use this dock with three monitors, beware.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: This dock is nothing short of amazing. I recently was granted work from home status. We already have an office set up at home, but it runs my home custom-built desktop PC. I didn't want to have two different computer workstations so I started looking at solutions. I wasn't 100% sure this would work with my desktop PC and work issued HP laptop, but it's flawless. I now have a single USB-C cable that I hot swap between the desktop PC and laptop to provide full use of my monitors, speakers, web-cam, mouse and keyboard. I had to pay for it out of my own pocket, but it's well worth it. I installed the DisplayLink drivers on my Windows 10 desktop through the DisplayLink website. The work laptop connected without any additional driver installation.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
Doesnâ€™t work with dual monitors. I purchased an extra adapter for the hdmi and it does work on my other office computer. I tried hdmi cables on both monitors and I know the monitors work, since they are brand new. So I am thinking the port where the hdmi adapter plugs into had gone bad. I just bought this docking station a month ago.

UPDATE: I went on YouTube and found that I needed to install a driver call DisplayLink from the Dell website onto my MacBook Pro. Then you have to go into your Preferences under Private to check the box so you can actually display onto the monitors and bingo, it works!

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: This docking station is great, but it connects to your laptop via a USB-C cable that is easy to bend. If you bend the USB-C cable (happened to me twice now...once when I dropped my laptop while connected so totally my fault, but the second time through normal office use), you have to buy a new docking station. Although it is fairly easy to open the docking station (four little screws) and remove the USB-C cable, you can't buy a replacement cable anywhere. So, I'm switching to a docking station with a longer cable, preferably one that plugs into the station externally.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
Previously I have not been a fan of Dell due to everything being proprietary, this dock is great and works well with Mac.

I used this dock from my previous IT job and it worked well with a Dell laptop. I could not find a dock that is comparable for my new MacBook Pro so I checked and this dock is compatible. I just needed to install the Displaylink drivers on my mac.

Pros:
This dock uses a single USB-C type cable to:

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
This dock is great!
I work from home and travel frequently.
When I come home I connect the thunderbolt port on my laptop to the dock and have three 27" monitors, my Jabra speaker, Logitech camera, wireless keyboard and mouse, printer, phone charge all connected and ready to rock.
Disconnect the cable, grab the Jabra and I'm ready to hit the road.
All three monitors are 1080P, I like the size for readability.

If there was a criticism, and it is minor, it is that there is no way to turn on the laptop from the dock.
Not a big deal for me, I need to enter my encryption credentials anyway, but a really minor annoyance.

All in all, I highly recommend this dock.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I got this to work with my HP Envy. At first, it seemed I could only connect two Displayports or one HDMI, but not both. While I had initially installed only the Dell drivers from the Dell website, I was able to get all three ports to work after installing the DisplayLink driver from the DisplayLink website. The name of the driver was called "DisplayLink USB Graphics Software for Windows". Additionally, I got three monitors to work with 2 Display ports and 1 VGA to USB adapter, which provides another option. Only thing I didn't get to work for my HP Envy was the charge through the USB-C port.

I've found that if you can't get your third monitor to display, you should also try specifically using an "active" adapter.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment: I liked the long usb-C cable and overall design. Had a bit of pain with monitor connections, but with the new DisplayLink version, all works fine (Windows 11). So far recommend it.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
I bought two for my Dell Latitude 5580, one for home, and one for work. The home unit works brilliantly. One plug into the laptop. It charges the laptop. I have two monitors, camera, sound, keyboard, mouse, etc... no issues.

At work, I have three monitors. The two that use the displayport work brilliantly. The one that uses the HDMI port flickers. Dell sent me a new dock and it does the same thing. I've replaced cables etc. If I plug the third monitor directly into the laptop it works great. Dell is working on the problem for me, but have no solution. Not a show stopper, but annoying.

comment: Use it to drive 3 monitors from a 5591x. Windows 10. Does exactly what I want it to. Only needs a single usb-c cord to the laptop to drive my monitors and all usb and Ethernet connections, and power the laptop. I just turn on the laptop in the morning and everything comes up, with all the monitors in the righ positions and resolutions. Two are 1920x1200, one is an older and smaller monitor so the monitor only does 1600x1200. Very happy with the dock. At first I was disappointed with the 5591x as dell does not include a â€œrealâ€ docking connector anymore, but this works out better as now pretty much any laptop for any brand that I buy to replace the 5591 in the future should work with this same dock.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
Absolutely awesome. Light, small, and compact. Easier to install on Mac devices. HP took a bit of issues, but were overcome as long as you upgrade the Intel USB Hub Controller 3.0 drivers. Took me a while, but since handled, easy peasy.

The down side is there isn't clear instructions, very vague and missing. They point to 2 sites: Dell and DisplayLink. Need to go to DisplayLink for the download. Do not plug in the dock until DisplayLink drivers are installed, follow the prompts, and plug in when notified (goes a lot better, trust me).

After figuring out the driver installs and updates it is great to use and has become very handy. I have tucked mine on a bracket on the back of the desk given the minimal design and allows for that clean desk look.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
The dock works well, charges & makes it easy to connect accessories to a Macbook Pro as well as connecting a couple external monitors, no problem.

My main problem as the title suggests is with the design. The USB-C cable coming out of the doc that connects to your device is a proprietary USB-C crossover cable of some sort that, once damaged in any way, renders the doc completely useless. No other USB-C cables will work. Dell, of course, won't sell just that cable, so be prepared to buy another one if something happens to that cable, or ideally find something else. Can't help but feel the cable was designed that way specifically to sell more docks if you damage it somehow.

If they fix that design in a later version I'd recommend it highly.

comment: I did my research and identified that this was the dock I needed for a second set up with double monitors (since we will be working from home for a while now). I took a chance and ordered this dock as a Warehouse Deal instead of NIB to save a few $$$. It arrived in the original Dell packaging and included the dock, power supply and original shipped documentation - plus an extra install guide for a Samsung gaming monitor. Plugged in the dock and it worked like a charm! The power cable and power supply were still minty new. Advice: don't hesitate to order the Warehouse Deal when you can! Plus Amazon's return policy provides peace-of-mind. Very happy with this purchase!!

comment:
This is a pretty good little device but it suffers from 2 flaws which cause the 3 start review.

1. This device does not work with Pre-OS Screens. So if you need to access the bios or have any kind of disk encryption (bitlocker) you have to open the laptop and type that in before the OS will load.

2. I have a crap laptop for work that I purchased this for. I am using it to drive 2 4k displays and it can cause some lag while at the same time you can not watch 4k video on it. If you have a powerful machine I imagine it would work well but my POS it kind of sluggish with it. It is totally usable for business applications (Word, outlook web browsing) but sometimes if you're machine is getting dragged down by it's running applications you can tell things get slower/lag with the displays as well.

I would think that it would run 1080 perfectly but for 4k I think it is to much for this device.

comment:
This is a quality USB-C docking station. I have all three monitor ports in use along with the native laptop screen. This thing will power your laptop in addition to expanding the available ports (assuming your laptop supports USB-C charging.) This has all the features of the higher end docks from days past when they needed proprietary connections but all nicely standardized with USB C.

That said... this is definitely not for gaming or any such thing. For my uses as a software architect where productivity software and screen real estate are the main goals, this is perfect.

comment: This Dell D6000 dock has worked great for us so far. We have used it on a Dell M5520 and Dell 5289 Laptops with the USB-C connector and it works great with multiple monitors and also charges the laptops. I also used the dock with an older Dell E7470 with the USB-A 3.0 connector and it also worked great with the exception that you need to charge with the standard charge port, so you will have two cords. comment: We bought this so that we could use our laptop essentially as a desktop for most days. We wanted a dock so that we could arrange everything on the desk and not have to open and close the computer lid all the time, and to reduce the number of cords that have to come through the solid back of our incredibly heavy, non-moveable desk and hutch. Well, this doesn't power the laptop, so we still have to move the laptop to open and close it to turn it on. So, we had to thread yet another power cord through the cluttered and impossible to access holes in the desk, and the only benefit we get from having this is just having to pull forward fewer cords when we move the laptop to power it up. Basically, this seems pretty stupid. I just hate to have 6 things plugged into our laptop and pull them forward and back each day because those connectors wear out from torquing pressure on them all the time.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ 452-BCYT D6000 é€šç”¨åº•åº§,é»‘è‰²,å–®å€‹
comment:
Worked perfectly with 3 external monitors for 2 weeks, then the Dell 1708FP monitor on one of the DP outputs stopped detecting the signal. Now it remains in Power Save mode. What follows may be the most ridiculous thing you'll read today, and if I were you I'd think the author was insane. But I have two electrical engineering degrees and have been building electronics for 40 years, so I'm hoping this isn't a PEBCAK issue.

So... the hub is connected to a Chromebook, mouse, Ethernet, USB headset, 3 monitors, and its own power supply. The monitors are connected via DP -> DP, DP -> DVI, and HDMI -> DVI. All the equipment works fine except for the Dell monitor (DP -> DVI), which remains in Power Save mode. Switching from Auto Detect to Digital Input makes no difference. Disconnecting everything from the hub (literally every cable, incl. laptop and power) and power cycling all the equipment makes no difference. Swapping ports on the dock makes no difference: the same monitor remains in Power Save mode. Swapping cables has no effect, regardless of which monitor is connected to which of the 3 outputs. The monitor works fine if it's the only one connected, and with a second monitor if one is connected via DP and the other via HDMI. Oddly enough, disconnecting the monitor from the hub disables one of the other monitors!

So now I need to keep the inoperable monitor connected, or I'll lose one of the working (and higher resolution) monitors as well.

I was worried that additional software may need to be installed but everything was true plug-and-play. The laptop with USB-C connector charges thru docking station whereas the laptop with USB 3.0 connector requires external charger. Overall, a solid product that addressed my needs. Before buying, I wasn't sure if I would get the value for the money but I think the price is worth it.

comment:
This review is as of June 2019.

Setup:
2 1080p monitors connected to the DisplayPort connectors on the dock.
Logitech Universal Adapter for wireless mouse and keyboard.
Ethernet cable to dock.
ScanSnap ix500 via usb to dock

Dell Latitude 7748 Win10 with DisplayLink Driver:
All works as expected with USBc its USB3 connectors.

MacBook Air Mid 2013 Mojave with DisplayLink Driver:
All works as expected including both monitors in extended mode. USB3 only.

MacBook Pro w/Thunderbolt Mojave and latest DisplayLink Driver:
All works as expected including both monitors in extended mode with both USBc and USB3 connecters. Charges over USBc.

iPad Pro Latest Model:
Only keyboard works. No screen mirroring.

comment:

comment:
I already own the Dell TB16 which has its issues, but I needed a docking station that worked off of USB as I use a Thinkpad X240 for remote work.

comment:
This device seemed to be perfect for what I needed: A docking station that could connect my identical HP ZR2740w monitors with DisplayPort outputs to my work Dell Latitude 7290 via USB-C and ideally to my personal 2015 Macbook Pro via USB 3.0 A. Both monitors worked (DisplayPort to DisplayPort via the Dell PR02X) and old work laptop. The monitors also work when connected from DisplayPort to Mini-DisplayPort into my Macbook. Both displays also work with the Dell WD-19, although not at the full resolution which is why I didn't buy it for home.

When I plugged my monitors into the D6000 dock and connected it to my laptop, only the right one was recognized with the work Dell laptop, personal Macbook, and personal Sony VAIO laptop. After switching the cords, ports, etc. the left monitor was never recognized. Iâ€™ve had my work's IT make sure all the drivers were up to date and the firmware on the dock up dated and nothing worked. Dell's support was useless because there is no service tag on the device so they refused to help me.

After returning the D6000, I purchased the HP USB-C/A Universal Dock G2. I plugged everything in and am able to get both monitors working to their full resolution.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 7050 SFF æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ Intel i7-7700 4 æ ¸å¿ƒ 3.60GHz 32GB DDR4 1TB SSD WiFi BT HDMI æ±ºé¬¥é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨æ”¯æ´ Windows 10 Pro å“è¶Šç‹€æ…‹(çºŒç´„)
comment:
When I selected my Dell Optiplex 7050 I in particular paid attention to the reviews of the third party suppliers and MST MEMORY SOLUTION INC. although relatively new by supplier standards, had scored high in Amazon reviews. So had hoped for the best and so far have definitely not been disappointed. I checked again, and their rating is still very high, and well deserved.

For starters I placed my order with Amazon on 28 June. Delivery schedule was for 5-6 July. My Dell Optiplex 7050 arrived on 30 June. In great shape.

Connecting the computer to my new Dell monitor was effortless. My first experience with using HDMI instead of VGA. I'm only using one monitor, so of course am having no issues. However while I was Googling a variety of Dell Optiplex 7050 to-do's I noticed a few users having issues with installing two monitors. There is only one HDMI that really works - as far as I can see.

A great and very welcome surprise was the DVD drive. In the photo of the Dell Optiplex 7050 at Amazon it looked as though it would not come with a DVD drive. So what a wonderful surprise that was. Have used it a few times and it works as it should.

I thought WiFi would be internally built in, and must have misunderstood. There is a WiFi Adapter USB that is included with the computer but the WiFi is not internal. This was not an issue for me as I had been planning to use an ethernet cable anyway - my preferred mode of WiFi for desktop computers. I also didn't need the mouse and keyboard, although brand new and of good quality. The keyboard and mouse that came with the Optiplex were wired, and my preference is for wireless, and I had that ready and waiting for including with my new computer.

Windows 10 Professional worked well from the get go. Definitely a tribute to the high quality tech input of MST MEMORY SOLUTION INC. It was effortless to set it up. Only headache is one that all Windows 10 users experience, which is how to get rid of the automatic startup page of Microsoft Edge. Took me some time to figure out, without needing to go into the Registry. Thanks to some savvy high-tech sources on the Internet.

I haven't gone high tech on my Dell Optiplex 7050 yet and it is probably early days with working with it. I know Dell has a great Website for updating Bios and everything else, but thought for now I didn't need it. Everything is working super fast and feels updated.

One thing I had to get used to is that all of the 1 TB SSD space came unpartitioned on C: only. I'm used to a partitioning of the disk with programs on C: and data on D: After some Googling on the subject looks like it doesn't really make a huge difference with SSD (like it would have with HD) and that partitioning isn't really needed. So looks like I need to beef up on how to optimize Windows Explorer App for arranging my D: files for easy reach.

So still early days using my Dell Optiplex 7050, but very happy so far. Thanks to MST MEMORY SOLUTION INC.

comment:
UPDATE: After five days of testing and troubleshooting this computer with three different technicians at the seller, I have had to send it back. It never worked as it should for more than a matter of hours, and displayed a wide variety of problems (see below for a sample). The last straw was when I closed the Chrome browser and the whole screen went black. The mouse pointer was visible, but nothing else. There was nothing to click on, so I couldn't even shut it down. After a couple of hard reboots this problem persisted, so the machine is now on its way back to SJ Computers. No one is to blame -- there's just a ghost in this machine.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
Bought the Dell i7-7050 SFF. It arrived in good shape two days early, but I didn't have the correct video cables (VGA to Display Port), so I didn't turn it on for a couple of days. Once I had the cables I fired it up, set up Windows and left it running for several hours, when it began to display various display anomalies: When I opened programs, the window would display for a second or two, then disappear. Later, the whole screen began flashing on and off. The Start button didn't work so I had to shut it down with the power switch.

With the machine unusable, I called SJ Computers (the seller). This was on a Friday, and I spoke to two techs, Alex and Logan. Much troubleshooting was tried, and eventually the machine seemed to be stable and I was told to use it over the weekend and call back with a progress report on Sunday. I used it as much as I could, and it randomly logged itself off several times. When the "disappearing window" symptom reappeared on Sunday I thought I needed a replacement, and I called to ask for one.

This time I spoke to Aaron, a third tech, who logged into the machine remotely to try and resolve the issues. He ran some diagnostic and repair tools, and in the end suggested a complete reinstall of Windows. Since I had not installed anything on the computer, I agreed to that. I now have a completely fresh installation of Windows that seems to be working, and I'm hoping all will be well over time.

AARON WAS THOROUGH, COURTEOUS AND PROFESSIONAL DURING THIS LENGTHY PROCESS, and put my mind somewhat at ease by offering to extend the 90-day warranty for an extra thirty days. He went the extra mile by calling me back an hour or so after the Windows reset to make sure all was well. This computer will be used in mission-critical situations and I can't afford random shutdowns or on-screen controls that don't work. Since these problems were intermittent I can't honestly say that it's "fixed," but I fully expect it to be.

For the past couple of hours this computer has been working fine, but I will update this review if there are further problems with it.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 7050 SFF æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ Intel i7-7700 4 æ ¸å¿ƒ 3.60GHz 32GB DDR4 1TB SSD WiFi BT HDMI æ±ºé¬¥é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨æ”¯æ´ Windows 10 Pro å“è¶Šç‹€æ…‹(çºŒç´„)
comment:
First I will say the PC itself works as I expected, after the add-ons were replaced. I bought it for basic functions for running basic word documents, spreadsheets, and paying bills etc. and am pleased with it. Takes an extra second or two to open a second spreadsheet, but I am okay with that. However, this is advertised as WiFi and Bluetooth. These features are not internal but done with USB adapters. The WiFi adapter they sent me was VERY slow, when it worked at all, making the PC appear very bad. My router is about 20 feet from this computer and my work computer, TV's, and everything else works just fine on fiber optic internet. I connected an Ethernet cable straight into the PC and it is like a different machine, opening web pages very fast. Second, the Bluetooth adapter they sent would not transmit past my monitors 3 feet from the PC. I literally had to hold my headset behind the monitor to get it to connect and it would loose connection when I sat down. Total junk. I ordered a $12 Bluetooth adapter and I can go to the next room. Third, the power cable they sent me did not hold into the plug on the PC very well and if you moved the tower, it would loose connection and shutdown. I have multiple power cords and simply replaced it and the issue is solved.

In conclusion, for the money the PC is great and does what I want it to but only after I made the upgrades to the accessories. If they would send a decent quality WiFi adapter and Bluetooth adapter I would have given it 5 stars. The plug I don't see as a regular issue, but unless they upgrade the adapters they send you, plan on ordering those for yourself.

I ordered another one because it came very clean and painted so cosmetic looks 5 star. The unit did run very well except for shut down problems. I did replace the MB cmos battery which was at a very low voltage but apparently Dell has had a few problems with random shutdowns and start button being difficult to start. I believe this is something that I'm willing to buy another and hope it works fine. These are nice desktops and with some TLC are well worth the roughly $230 at this time. Parts are widely available and inexpensive so hoping this new to me unit works as well as the half dozen or so refurbished computers I have bought in the past. The second computer is up and running and after two days no problems. Hats off to the Microsoft refurbisher great job, nice desktop computer. this is updated 081523

comment:
I wanted to dedicate a fast machine (3.6 GHz i7 7700) with 32GB RAM and a 1TB SSD to run a DAW (digital audio workstation). This arrived pretty much ready to do that.

The BIOS needed some updates and needed to be set to use hyperthreading. Windows set up worked great. The keyboard and mouse supplied were the cheapest quality imaginable - no, cheaper than that. But they worked, I just would not want to use either.

Things are going well with the machine. I'm using it with two displays - a 4K 32" curved Dell plugged right into the display port and another display in the VGA analog port. Adding a display adapter would require a short one - the case is compact. You could add a couple more SSD's. I won't need more storage for this machine and I probably won't add a display adapter.

I would recommend this recycled computer as a great value. It is amazing what you can get for so little money.
