comment:
I was skeptical about buying "renewed". Afraid I would get an old, beat up system as seen in some pics posted, but for the low price and most other positive reviews here, I decided to give it a shot. Boy am I surprised and happy I did!

What I received is like-brand new (see pics). No dust, no visible defects, everything looks and functions like new.

Fast i7-7th Gen, 32GB RAM and generic 1TB SSD. Plugged it in and Windows booted right up. Very simple setup process and after 3 weeks, no issues so far. This system supports 3 monitors too! I use for work and day trading and extremely pleased with the speed. I came from an i5 11th Gen laptop with 24GB RAM to this and it's a noticeable improvement. I highly recommend if you want a good, fast system that's 3-4x less than a brand new, i7 11th or 13th gen system.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 7050 SFF æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ Intel i7-7700 4 æ ¸å¿ƒ 3.60GHz 32GB DDR4 1TB SSD WiFi BT HDMI æ±ºé¬¥é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨æ”¯æ´ Windows 10 Pro å“è¶Šç‹€æ…‹(çºŒç´„)
comment:
Overall I'm as pleased with this machine as can be expected with a refurbished unit. Being one who can't leave well enough alone, I immediately added a second SSD, which required ordering some cables--splitting the power and connecting to a second SATA port. Scavenged video and sound cards from the computer this replaced, and everything works great. All the specs are correct. In general, a good deal. (Since reviews sometimes get applied to different products on this site, it's the Dell Optiplex 7050 SFF Desktop PC Intel i7-7700 4-Cores 3.60GHz 32GB DDR4 model I'm talking about.)

The only trouble was temperature issues. The CPU and mainboard started running hot--not right after the additions, but a couple of weeks in. Weird temp spikes came and went. From a comfy low 40s C, leaping for no reason up to 70, 80, and once passing a frightening 95 C! I don't do any gaming or heavy lifting, and the temp freakouts happened under low loads and seemingly at random. Not a speck of dust to clog things up, either. I feared my upgrades had messed something up... I reset the fan control in the BIOS so it'd stay cranked all the time, and that helped, but it was LOUD! Tonight I realized some old thermal paste was in the electro-junk drawer, so I pulled the fan out, cleaned the old gunk off and re-pasted it. Set the fan BIOS back to normal. Bam! Sitting now at 41C for the CPU, 37C mainboard. Otherwise, I'm a happy camper.

If I were less brash with digging into the components, I might have given up and returned this one, or not have known it was cooking like an air fryer in there until it was too late. So, the 4-star rating is a stretch. It's 4 stars AFTER some fiddling around.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 7050 SFF æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ Intel i7-7700 4 æ ¸å¿ƒ 3.60GHz 32GB DDR4 1TB SSD WiFi BT HDMI æ±ºé¬¥é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨æ”¯æ´ Windows 10 Pro å“è¶Šç‹€æ…‹(çºŒç´„)
comment:
My old Vista era desktop computer died after many years of upgraded service. I bought this to replace it as a media center attached to a large flat panel TV. It has plenty of ports and the built-in video card can handle two 4k displays simultaneously. One point to note is that this system processor does not seem to meet minimum specs for Windows 11. The processor is a quad core I7 with tons of memory and a 3.6 GHz speed rating. Not sure why Windows 11 can't handle that, but then again...

Update: After about three weeks of daily use I started getting Blue Screen of Death (BSoD) crashes. They were happening on a daily basis. I had read one other reviewers experience with this and it was related to processor core temperatures. When I checked my unit, all four cores were running hot. I ordered some silicon thermal grease from Amazon. I pulled the chiller and there was not much grease on the processor at all. I cleaned everything thoroughly and applied an ample amount of grease to both the processor and chiller. It has been a week now and no BSoD crashes. I originally gave this system a five star review, but lowered it to four because of the added cost to fix the thermal issue.

comment:
The system was very easy to plug and play and get it up and running. A couple of things to note for potential buyers:
-System does not meet system requirements for Windows 11 so Windows 10 (which is installed) is as far as the OS can go.
-The included keyboard and mouse are very basic and must be plugged in. It's nice that they are included, but recommend spending some of the money you save on upgrading both of these items.
-For bluetooth to work it includes a USB adaptor. It works fine and I haven't had any problems with it, but it does take up a USB port.

Overall very impressed with what I got for the price and have not had any problems with it.

comment:
As a retired computer tech I was not worried about possible hardware difficulties with a rebuild, figuring I could diagnose and repair them if necessary. Those skills were necessary to get this unit operating. First off, the only video output provided (by the onboard integrated chip set) is HDMI, which I was not expecting, since all monitors we can access are VGA or DVI; after ordering an HDMI-to-VGA adapter, which will arrive in a few days, in the meantime I connected the unit to a widescreen TV for setup.
Unfortunately, the only message displayed was "NO HDD OR OPTICAL DRIVE DETECTED." Accessing the BIOS Error log showed that this unit left the rebuilders in that condition.
After opening the case and verifying that an SSD was, in fact installed and cabled up, I connected a SATA DVD drive in its place to verify the SATA I/O, which began booting up the Windows disk I supplied. Reinstalling the SSD with cables properly inserted appeared to restore operation, and when video was reconnected, Windows 10 installed and activated successfully. My only disappointment now is that the laptop optical drive is too thick to be installed in the slot provided: suppose I'll have to acquire an Optiplex-compatible optical drive from Dell....
If the unit had worked out-of-the-box I would have given it a higher rating, since I'm very pleased that the hardware installed is as advertised, and appears to be very peppy! The USB WIFI adapter supplied by the rebuilders is also very fast.

comment:
I purchased this machine to run Blue Iris for a security camera system. No issues and a perfect fit for this project.

I did run the Benchmark 24hour burn in test and it passed with a few errors that are maintenance related. CPU thermal compound needs refreshed/ replaced. After that, temps dropped by 10Â° C.
My take away:
If you need a power machine for an appliance, that is what you will get. No idea about gaming or routine tasks. The SFF has some inherent cooling issues due to the small form factor. Inside was very clean with no dust.

Some things to think about and consider:
-Free keyboard and mouse are very basic. Plan on replacing them
-You will need to order video adapters, if you want to plug in a monitor. Iâ€™d rather see the package include this instead of the mouse/keyboard and wireless adapter.
-1Tb SSD is manufactured by Suneast. Chinese brand with not much documentation, would not 100% rely on it. Consider a name brand replacement.
-Perception of shipping package is not great, no dents and machine was in working order.
-If you are considering this a cheap buy to put into a new case and build up, look for a mid-tower unit instead. Too many Dell proprietary connectors that will need additional adapters.

Overall 5 star for a power user. 3.5-4 if you are a novice.

comment:
The computer was shipped fast and was very well packaged. Out of the box, it boots fast and had the typical Microsoft set-up routine that basically is easy to follow. On boot-up a pop-up required updating the OS from version 21H2 to version 22H2 that is easy to do from Settings. Overall it is a nice computer if you want to only continue using Windows 10 as the attached photo shows, The PC does not meet system requirements to upgrade to Windows 11.
It's possible that the only thing may be the graphics compatible with DirectX 12 or later with WDDM 2.0 driver, however would like to confirm with tech support if it can be updated. Problem: In trying to contact the restorer; Nakshatra tech proved impossible to do as I could not find any way around Amazon's blocking access to the seller, or even be able to discuss the situation with a Amazon agent as that isn't an option offered.

comment: I bought this to replace my aging PC that I used for software development, running Linux. This refurbished PC is a terrific upgrade, especially as I ordered an M.2 SSD for 2TB of storage at a blistering 3,500MBytes/sec (confirmed using gnome-disks device benchmarking). The small form factor means it fits under a monitor stand very nicely, with extra room for a mac mini next to it. If you're a developer, you'll probably also want to trade out the included budget SATA SSD for a higher performance or larger SSD. The USB ports are plentiful enough, but if you need lots more, a cheap PCIe expansion card can use one of the two available PCI slots (low profile only, remember). The 7th generation Intel i7 CPU also gives great Intel QuickSync (QSV) video transcoding performance if you use handbrake or ffmpeg.

comment:
Suprisingly pleased so far. Its only been one day but so far so good. Box that in came in was a mess, computer was loosely inside at a weird angle. Luckily no damage was done.

Quick and easy to set up and suprisginly good performance out of the box.

Few things to mention. The computer has a really old wifi card in it. Im only able to download at 10mbps on the 2.4 ghz band on my modem. I ordered a wifi usb adapter should solve this issue.

Like mentioned you also need a usb adapter for bluetooth, luckily this computer has 8 usb ports.

The graphics card is onboard and seriously lacking so thats prob the only thing worth upgrading.

Overall good machine and for the price tag of 300 bucks the hardware is unbeatable, the processor alone is worth 275 bucks. 32 gb of ram and a 1tb ssd all amount to a good value for your money.

comment:
Got this to just replace an old work desktop that died, and what I think is a good price.
The Intel i7-7700 is not approved for Windows 11, but I like Win 10 anyway.
No built in sound. The supplied Keyboard and mouse work, but are really cheap quality.
It is a work desktop, not a gaming desktop so it shares memory for video.
Has a card expansion slot if you want to try adding a graphics card.
When the fan cranks up to high speed it is a bit loud.
It did not come with a DVD drive. Got one off E-bay less than $20.
If you have an old VGA monitor, need the adaptor for the PC display port(s).

comment: 5 stars for the Tech support from the seller. 3 stars for the system. I will correct the review of the system if they are able to resolve the issue. The system worked fine for the couple of days. It started showing issues of restarting on its own. The restart happens after each restart and keeps on going until the system is completely turned off. Called the SJ computers and the technician was able to identify that the hard drive is faulty. They sent me a return label to send the hard drive to the seller and promised that they will send me a new harddrive in 3-4 days. Waiting for the New hard drive now. Got a call from Sarah from the tech support and informed me that they are working on the new hard drive. so the customer care seems to be good as off now. Will update the review once I get the system up and running.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 7050 SFF æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ Intel i7-7700 4 æ ¸å¿ƒ 3.60GHz 32GB DDR4 1TB SSD WiFi BT HDMI æ±ºé¬¥é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨æ”¯æ´ Windows 10 Pro å“è¶Šç‹€æ…‹(çºŒç´„)
comment:
no one buys a computer for the peripherals, but when a seller says something will be included and it's not, or broken it's not good. So the computer arrived and is in working order, but the windows 10 was YEARS old and required HOURS of updates (there goes my bandwidth for the month). This alone is enough for me to tell you not to buy this computer unless you know what your doing, as it is so out of date that it throws errors when trying to update.

The included mouse was dead on arrival and wouldn't click, but I might be able to repurpose as a maraca as the rattle of internal broken parts is quite loud.

The keyboard was packaged in a plastic bag and placed directly on the computer, so that when the box got flipped upside down the full weight of the computer damaged the keyboard and even tore open the bag. When I saw it I though wow, fight with a blender recently?

the promised WiFi and Bluetooth adapters are completely missing, no empty bags or boxes, not already installed, completely missing.

but like I said, you don't buy a computer for the peripherals, but and extra layer of bubble wrap and the mouse and keyboard would of arrived in good condition, if this had gotten one good jolt in shipping with a lose keyboard and mouse in the wrong position and the computer would of been dead or badly damaged on arrival.

side note: power supply is 180w and the PCI slot is limited to ~7 inches long and about 2.75 tall clearance.

comment: I absolutely love my Dell laptop computer. It has the quality and feel of a real laptop. For almost three years I settled with a lower quality competitor's laptop that made me think twice about my life. Lol! It was plasticky, had horrible resolution and I thought I was being critical, until I received my Dell laptop. It is night and day. The laptop is super sturdy (has a heavier feel which I like), resolution is superb, and the quality far outweighs the cheap competitor laptop. Many years ago, I used a relative's Dell desktop and was pleased with the feel and performance of the computer. I kept a mental note and never forgot my experience. Fast forward, I am now the proud owner of one. I would not hesitate in purchasing one for my use, whether personal or job-related. Go out and get yourself one. You'll love it.

comment:
I've owned this laptop for 118 days. At day 92, I had a processor problem that required a system reset. That same problem is beginning to reappear now. Yesterday, the left screen hinge broke after opening and closing it probably 100 times or less. Dell requires that you box up the laptop ( with all your personal/Financial/Banking/Password information- unless you do a factory reset to erase everything) and send it off to them where they will repair it and send it back. I am not a fan of giving someone the ability to copy my hard drive (which they will do) and possibly have God only knows who, obtain a copy of all my data. They will not offer an ETA on the repaired laptop even if I were to agree to that.

I've bought Dell's for 30 years for my entire family. This is an absolute pile of garbage. You get what you pay for. Shame on me, I almost bought a MacBook because of reviews I read- but I saved on price. Now I am paying the "Cost".

I bought this after several days of reading reviews and looking for the one that would best suit my needs after my laptop of 10 years crashed on me. I wanted something lighter, faster and ready to handle the student workload I have right now.
So you can imagine my surprise and frustration when I got it and the led screen is dull and not bright at all. My old Dell has a better brighter picture than my new one.
WHEN I can get the battery to charge itâ€™s holds for about an hour and half before itâ€™s almost dead. And thatâ€™s only after I discovered that the charging cord they sent with it isnâ€™t compatible and in bad shape. So I used my old oneâ€¦it worked. In the pic above Iâ€™ve had it charging for over an hour already.
I am very disappointed in this expensive purchase that I now have to deal with because of the payments Iâ€™m having to make on it. Iâ€™m also in a remote location that does not have big box electronics stores where I can just walk in and look at another one. Ordering is our only option.
If you are not computer savvy like myself I suggest you donâ€™t order from this company because you are trusting they will send you a quality product and may not get what you were looking for.

comment:
I bought this because my new Dell XPS only has USB C ports. My wireless mouse employs a simple older USB dongle. In hindsight I should have spent the money for a non-dongle bluetooth wireless mouse. Iâ€™ve used a couple of the other ports (HDMI and second monitor), but with a lot less frequency and urgency than I thought I would. Overall I might not have needed this in the first place.
My biggest complaint is the tether. If Iâ€™m using an external (wireless dongle) mouse I essentially have to use my laptop as a desktop because of the adapter hanging off one of the ports. I canâ€™t really use a lap desk and sit in the lounge chair or on the couch using my laptop as a laptop. An adapter like this that uses either WiFi, bluetooth, or some proprietary micro dongle technology to leave the adapter on a desk (or coffee table) and free my laptop from the desk would be much more useful and appreciated. (Though it would require its own power source, I know.)
Overall itâ€™s an adequate and useful device, but it really does physically restrict the usefulness of a laptop.

comment:
I picked this up at a retailer yesterday and I'm returning it today. This has issues with Apple M1 despite Dell's own documentation saying it is tested to work with Apple M1. Ethernet is capped at 200 megabit despite forcing it to 1000 base t full duplex. single display output works but will not even let you connect a second display if a display is connected to the hub. Even if you connect that second display directly to the free USB port on the MacBook Pro. Pass through power seemed to work ok.

But the bigger takeaway is if you have Apple M1 in your computer, pass on this usb hub. I'm sure it's fine with windows as Dell's hubs are usually super good. That's the reason I bought it. I know them to usually make great usb hubs and docking stations. But this hub was a disappointment.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Dock - WD19S 130W é›»æºä¾›æ‡‰å™¨ - 180W AC
comment: First I bought a refurb, trying to save some money. That immediately proved to be a bad decision, and I returned it and bought a new one. Unfortunately, this one is very glitchy as well. USB ports, particularly for my keyboard, constantly glitch out and reset (keyboard stops responding or repeats a key into infinity until I pull the USB and put it back in.) About once every 2 weeks, it will fail to recognize one or both of the 2 external monitors plugged into it, requiring a restart of the dock. Sound devices are a total mess, sometimes completely losing track of the devices being routed through it (USB headset, audio via HDMI in the monitors, etc.) I paid up for the Dell dock in the hopes it would perform better with my Dell laptop, but no luck. Do yourself a favor and look elsewhere. Pros: it can power the laptop via USB-C so there is only 1 connection to the laptop, and it powers 2 4K monitors when it's not glitching out.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Dock - WD19S 130W é›»æºä¾›æ‡‰å™¨ - 180W AC
comment:
Please note - I love Dell docking stations, and have been using them for 10+ years in all the various revisions. They just work the best with Dell systems (duh!). This review is not against Dell Docking stations! They are bar none great!

My issue is what was actually SENT to me! I ordered three of these. While I did receive THREE Dell Docks, it was not the correct model. I was sent THREE Dell WD19S Docking Stations. Note the "S" on the end of the model number. The "S" designates there is not a physical audio port. And we use the audio port on all of our setups, so this was a bit disappointing.

TLDR: The Dell WD19 has an audio jack, the WD19S does not. I was sent the WD19S.

I think I'll have to purchase from Dell directly now, so I know exactly what model I am getting!

Third WD19S purchased from Amazon and Dell, none of which WORK.
I have another 2 at home, both issued by companies. One does not reliably operate its USB ports, the other is flawless.

Picking a USB laptop dock is serious business, seems like there is a lot of bad product out there. Just have a look at the "refurbished" on Amazon and "used" on eBay to see what I mean. You stand a strong chance of getting something with some, majority, or critical functionality not working, and if you are lucky, you too can damage a monitor or two with your purchase.

Save yourself the trouble and spend the money on name-branded products elsewhere, but the Dell WD19S, either direct or on Amazon, is not the product you want!

It happens with other USB input devices as well, but it most noticeable with the mouse. I moved the dock into the cable storage tray under the desk, which helps with the noise, however, it's very hard plugging in external devices now as the dock is hard to reach. I would have returned the unit but it's hard to find a dock that can charge this Dell laptop due to charging power requirements. The noise appears to be a well noted issue for this series of dock, not just the specific model.
Pros: It charges my Dell XPS laptop which has a wattage power charging requirement and is pretty stable so far. Lost sync to the monitor only once in the short time I've had it (weeks).

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ Dock- WD19S 90w é›»æºä¾›æ‡‰å™¨ - 130w AC - 90 W
comment: This particular dell docking station (also known to be a port replicator) has on onboard power button 3 HDMI ports, 2 USB ports, 1 mini USB (rear), 1 Ethernet port, and 1 mini USB on the right side. It was an easy install and adapted well to my Dell Latitude 7480. It helped me get back to a dual monitor setup (with laptop screen as an optional 3rd) and save desk space and wire clutter (can't stand either). It is fairly well priced for the features and arrived quickly compared to many other units being out of stock. Only down side I would say is it's somewhat bulky. You have the port replicator portion which is about 3"x6"x1" then there is also a power block along with chords for both which you'll need to find a home for. All in all I am very satisfied with the purchase and performance so far.

comment: Using a original OEM Dell 65W powersupply (DP/N 74VT4) with this dongle to a Dell XPS 18 1820 AIO computer, the XPS 18 does not properly detect the 65W through the dongle. Instead, there is a power supply warning during POST, indicating a 65W power supply is required. I checked this with both the Dell 65W powersupply and a Dell 130W powersupply, same result. As long as the power to the XPS is adequate, I guess it does not matter. I am going to purchase another dongle to test whether the first is defective--not worth wrecking my XPS battery if it is. Otherwise, this dongle is a great find, as it means I can use any of the Dell laptop powersupplies I have laying around for the XPS.

comment:
I was pleased by the nice tight fight of the 7.4mm adapter to the plug of the 130 watt, 19.5v power supply I was using. I have plenty of the older 7.4mm supply units and it is extremely frustrating when I accidently leave the 4.5mm brick behind. This solved the issue.

comment: I was ready to are return it. It would not hook up properly and I realized that we have an Assurion place here in town so we took it to that shop. The young man said some of the wrong parts had been sent with it and he replaced them and hooked it up and got it up and running for us. I thought it would be like my old dell with a Radeon graphics card as my grandson likes to play games on it but it really GLITCHY!! Checked it out and it says the graphics card is good? theproduct: Dell Optiplex 9010 SFF æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - Intel i7-3770 é«˜é” 3.9GHzã€AMD Radeon 1GB åœ–å½¢ã€32GB RAMã€1TB SSDã€DisplayPortã€HDMIã€DVIã€DVDã€Wi-Fiã€è—ç‰™ã€TDL - Windows 10 Pro(æ›´æ–°)
comment:
Although photo shows Display Port x 2 and VGA Port -they should tell you those ports aren't active since the graphics card is installed. All you've really got to work with are the Display Port and DVI port at the bottom on the graphics card. It also doesn't have an HDMI port. They send an HDMI adapter to plug in the other port. The instruction sheet that comes with it is also misleading in that it tells you to plug your monitor into any of the ports - including the VGA and non-existent HDMI (and shows pictures of them.) At the least - they could have explained this on the instruction sheet. I contacted technical support and they did contact me quickly and explained what was going on. They said if I wanted to use the other ports I would have to remove the graphics card. I was really wanting to hook 3 monitors up so may try that.

My package was also missing the Bluetooth adapter. They are supposed to be sending that to me.

It did seem to boot up really quickly - but it took me a considerable amount of time before I found the only working Display Port plug and initially thought it wasn't working at all. Anxious to see how well it performs.

comment: So after buying it and running the dell service code I discovered that instead of an optiplex 9010 I actually got a 7010.. either way there old and end of life. I was mad, video was terrible and glitchy, packed it up ready to send it back, was in bed and it dawned on me they had installed an aftermarket video card. Got out of bed, unpacked the computer AGAIN, pulled the video card out and plugged into the stock display port, display is actually working properly now. The amd card they installed was terrible lol. Maybe the proper software might make it work? Never liked amd cards.. what ever that alls worth to you lol.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 9010 SFF æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - Intel i7-3770 é«˜é” 3.9GHzã€AMD Radeon 1GB åœ–å½¢ã€32GB RAMã€1TB SSDã€DisplayPortã€HDMIã€DVIã€DVDã€Wi-Fiã€è—ç‰™ã€TDL - Windows 10 Pro(æ›´æ–°)
comment:
I do video editing using Davinci Resolve and my old computer just wasn't able to quite handle it smoothly so I purchased this one. I knew I was taking a chance - while the specs on paper were better, buying refurbished felt like a gamble, and this PC is several years old at this point. Experts would have told me to get a new PC with better specs I'm sure, but I was willing to take a chance at this price. I didn't want to have to pay around $1,000 for a good PC if I could avoid it.

I had an initial hiccup - Davinci Resolve kept crashing within minutes of me opening it up and trying to do something. It seemed strange because it loaded a lot quicker and seemed to have much better handling than my old PC before crashing. It went from seemingly great to dead in an instant - not like it was struggling to begin with.

I almost gave up and was considering returning the PC, but I decided to try updating the graphics card driver. When I went through the device settings, it told me I already had the most up to date driver. But I went online and downloaded the driver software and ran it anyway, and it looks like there was actually a newer version of it. Thankfully, this seems to have fixed the issue. I tested it out a bit and did a render without issue. I suggest everyone do this if you're getting this PC. See what the graphics card is under device manager, search online for the most up to date driver (preferably from the manufacturer's own website and a third party website) to make sure it's up to date and you have no issues.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 9010 SFF æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - Intel i7-3770 é«˜é” 3.9GHzã€AMD Radeon 1GB åœ–å½¢ã€32GB RAMã€1TB SSDã€DisplayPortã€HDMIã€DVIã€DVDã€Wi-Fiã€è—ç‰™ã€TDL - Windows 10 Pro(æ›´æ–°)
comment:
I recommend this computer for someone on a budget, but who needs performance. The 32gb of ram helps to offset the age of the computer. Also, the SSD makes it pretty fast at otherwise demanding read/write tasks.

Mine didn't come with an HDMI adapter, but they worked that out for me. The tech guy was very nice and helpful. The only other negative is that mine wouldn't boot up, but I deleted all partitions from the SSD, and reinstalled Windows 10 Pro (it can be downloaded). A bit of a pain, but for what I paid, I have no right to complain ;-).

It was packaged very well, and even survived reshipping overseas.

I've run demanding up-to-date graphic apps and it seems to run fine so far.

I will definitely buy from these guys again!

comment: I love everything about this computer except for the fact that it does not support Windows 11. That is really my fault for not researching supported components. Otherwise, the machine is perfect for my needs, with a price to match. The computer came exactly as advertised: clean and in great shape, with the correct configuration - including licensed Windows 10 - a keyboard, mouse, a USB WiFi adapter, and even an HDMI-to-DisplayPort adapter. I toyed with returning the machine when I learned about the Windows 11 incompatibility but a renewed Windows 11-capable machine was nearly 10 times what I paid for this model. For that savings, I'll make do with this one and explore other options after Microsoft drops Windows 10 support in October 2024. When it is time to shop, I will definitely buy renewed and check this company first.

comment: This computer came with no cables to attach to the monitor or anything else. It was also missing the wi-fi adapter to connect with the internet which is necessary to activate the software. Even if you could connect to the internet, you couldn't see what's happening. The Amazon page for this problem of missing parts gives you the number for Dell, but when you contact Dell your name doesn't appear on the order so after the time it takes to get one of their support people and go through their routine, they refuse to help! Going back to Amazon, and being passed around to at least 3 different departments, the only "solution" any of them could offer was to ship the whole shebang back to them and have them send another which might not have all the parts. I'm in MEXICO. I already paid customs and extra shipping and all I need is a $3 part! I've already paid an expert to come and figure out how to patch the proper wire, also not included, to the router to access internet and get the computer set up. Now send it back and cross my fingers? Because that's the solution for all problems? That's more in shipping costs than the computer costs. Can you get me the part number so I can track it down on my own and buy it from somewhere? NO! Send the whole thing back. Eat what you are out and go back to square one where you were 3 weeks ago, cross your fingers and hope the one we send has all it's parts and works, etc. etc. IT'S OUR ONLY OPTION! Any compensation for time, effort, or what I'm going through for someone's oversight in not packing the part in the box? No! You work for us now!

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 9010 SFF æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - Intel i7-3770 é«˜é” 3.9GHzã€AMD Radeon 1GB åœ–å½¢ã€32GB RAMã€1TB SSDã€DisplayPortã€HDMIã€DVIã€DVDã€Wi-Fiã€è—ç‰™ã€TDL - Windows 10 Pro(æ›´æ–°)
comment: Although there was a small hiccup when the computer arrived (had to purchase a DVI to VGA adapter), once the adapter arrived, everything works as advertised. Came with Windows 10 Pro installed, but since I don't trust Windows, Google, or Apple with a toothpick, I wiped Windows off the hard drive and replaced it with Linux. Even with it's outdated i7 processor, the 32GB of RAM and 1TB SSD handles everything I've thrown at it so far, including full blown audio production (Steinberg Cubase 12 Pro) and video editing (Open Shot, ShotCut, & Vidiot). It's small form factor is convenient for those who like to keep things neat and tidy. Boot time is quick, averaging about 8 seconds from Power press to login. Comes with the power cord, keyboard, mouse, wifi & Bluetooth adapters, as well as an HDMI to Display Port adapter. Seller's contact information is also included and customer service is very responsive and helpful. Overall, this was a great experience and I recommend this computer and/or seller. Buy with confidence. Just be sure to purchase a DVI to VGA adapter before you checkout...just in case.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 9010 SFF æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - Intel i7-3770 é«˜é” 3.9GHzã€AMD Radeon 1GB åœ–å½¢ã€32GB RAMã€1TB SSDã€DisplayPortã€HDMIã€DVIã€DVDã€Wi-Fiã€è—ç‰™ã€TDL - Windows 10 Pro(æ›´æ–°)
comment: When I opened the case there was not a speck of dust on the fan blades or anywhere. I ran HD Sentinel which showed Zero hours on the HD. This unit must have been sitting on a shelf and never put in to service. The bios was set to legacy boot so it wouldn't boot till I changed it to UEFI. I had to find and instal video drivers for the HD7500 to get HDMI sound and proper resolution. AMD only listed legacy drivers and Catalyst Software for HD7510, but they work fine. Setting this rig up is not for a novice. That said I am still giving it 5 stars since it is brand new.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 9010 SFF æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - Intel i7-3770 é«˜é” 3.9GHzã€AMD Radeon 1GB åœ–å½¢ã€32GB RAMã€1TB SSDã€DisplayPortã€HDMIã€DVIã€DVDã€Wi-Fiã€è—ç‰™ã€TDL - Windows 10 Pro(æ›´æ–°)
comment: As stated I am pretty happy with this purchase. That said I did have an initial bump in the road with the GPU but was not an issue and they had sent a replacement that I received a week later. Otherwise I made 2 additional upgrades in a RX550 GPU and an additional SSD for a combined $75 on eBay. Has since been able to handle any game I have thrown its way at 1080p 60 fps. With Batocera running on the second drive it has been great for emulation also.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 9010 SFF æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - Intel i7-3770 é«˜é” 3.9GHzã€AMD Radeon 1GB åœ–å½¢ã€32GB RAMã€1TB SSDã€DisplayPortã€HDMIã€DVIã€DVDã€Wi-Fiã€è—ç‰™ã€TDL - Windows 10 Pro(æ›´æ–°)
comment:
Several issues, even though I gave it a 5. The first issue is that the 4 USB 3.0 ports were dead. Online Dell drivers didn't work. I had several driver disks from USB 3.0 cards, and one of those worked.

This computer has no HDMI port but uses (3) DisplayPort connections and a DVI port on a plug-in card. They sent a display port to an HDMI adaptor. I didn't bother to check the USB WIFI unit.

Now the rest is very positive. It came with a new Windows 10. All the user has to do is register and add the programs they use. The computer is fast and works great. Most importantly, it runs very cool temperature-wise. The power supply gets just a little warm. That greatly extends the life of the computer.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 9010 SFF æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ - Intel i7-3770 é«˜é” 3.9GHzã€AMD Radeon 1GB åœ–å½¢ã€32GB RAMã€1TB SSDã€DisplayPortã€HDMIã€DVIã€DVDã€Wi-Fiã€è—ç‰™ã€TDL - Windows 10 Pro(æ›´æ–°)
comment: This is the second refurbished computer I have purchased through Amazon. The last was three and a half years ago and this one is a great improvement, especially with the solid state hard drive and much better processor. But I paid about the same. The mouse and keyboard that came with it are about as cheap as you can get, but they sufficed for setting up the computer and transferring files from my old computer. I moved my better keyboard and mouse to the new unit after setting up. It came with a USB wireless connector which worked fine for setting up, then I went ethernet when I was finished getting it ready. It accepted the ethernet automatically, and I plugged in my USB printer and it worked without any extra effort. I should have checked closer on the monitor connections, this one uses DisplayPort (it does say this in the description online but I missed it), I was expecting HDMI. But getting an adapter took care of it. The instructions are very limited but if you have any computer setup savvy it shouldn't be difficult. The silent SSHD is nice, and all my programs run quite fast. Since I am not playing any sophisticated video games, I don't know how well this would work, but for a home office computer it is a great machine.

comment: Oh, I know what your thinking, â€œBut I can save $28.50 on that same refurbished computer from that other seller.â€ Well Einstein, when you buy refurb what you're really buying is 1) the computer AND 2) customer service AND 3) a guarantee in case you need it. But, you say, â€œWhat about the Amazon return policy, blah blah blah.â€ Look, it's NOT enough if you need likety split dial-up customer support. I ordered a Dell Optiplex 9010 and needed help. Dialed the S.J. Computers support number and a LIVE Super Tech answered. We chat, he resolved, replacement a part shipped, and all was good. YMMV but my experience S.J.C., the Super Tech and customer service were all five stars. BTW, I'm VERY (note caps) happy with my refurb Dell.

comment:
The product I got is NOT SAME as its description.

The advertisement on Amazon website was like below:
"Dell Optiplex 9010 SFF Desktop Computer - Intel i7-3770 Upto 3.9GHz, AMD Radeon 1GB Graphics, 32GB RAM, 1TB SSD, DisplayPort, HDMI, DVI, DVD, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, TDL - Windows 10 Pro (RENEWED)"

First, the device I expected should be "Dell Optiplex 9010 SFF", however, the one I got turned into "Optiplex 7010 SFF". 9010 is absolutely NOT equal to 7010.

Second, the advertisement claimed that the computer did have HDMI port ( my monitor had HDMI cable ), however, it DID NOT have such port thus I had to buy an extra cord to get the monitor connected.

Third, the ad said there was both Wi-Fi and Bluetooth, however, what I found in the package was Wi-Fi adapter ONLY. There WAS NO bluetooth adapter inside.

comment: Purchased this computer to replace one that was struck by lightning. Every picture in this advertisement shows this computer as a vertical "Tower" computer. Spent two days uploading all my pictures, music, documents and APPs. When I went to use the DVD drive, it turned out to be a horizontal type drive. In order to use it, you have to turn the entire computer SIDEWAYS. When I contacted customer support for a vertical replacement drive, I was informed that it was NOT a Tower, It's an SFF and the computer is SUPPOSED to be SIDEWAYS. Way too much hassle to remove all my personal data and TRY to return it. Looks like I will be rearranging my office this week to accommodate this mistake ... Looks like a picture is no longer worth a thousand words after all ...

comment:
Purchased for my daughter. She needed something a little bigger than a chromebook, and I decided to start her with one of these. She was able to use it (not regularly) for about 3 months until it blue screened and would recognize the hard drive. Fast forward, my husband replaced the hard drive since the warranty was gone, (he built my computer, so he knows what he is doing), and it worked for about a month, then started doing the same thing. Not worth it to attempt to replace parts and hope you find the issue.

It also turned on every night at 2 am. We had to keep it unplugged from the time it was purchased.

Not a year later, and I'm looking for another computer for both my daughters. Don't think I'll purchase one of these again.

theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸
comment:
It was a bit shocking to see that even though it's suppose to support 130W power delivery via the type C connection, and that the Dell G7 15 that I have supports power delivery over type C, it did not work with this docking station. In fact, in order to use my laptop and this dock, I have to have 2 power supplies.

I know/understand that my laptop to be fully supported needs 210W and that this only would have delivered 130W at most. But because I'm not running the laptop at full blast all the time, I would have expected it to use 130W while consuming the battery for the remaining amount and while the laptop is idle slowly charge it up and such.

Instead, what happens os that the dock provides 0W of power to the laptop and of course the dock doesn't work without a power supply of its own so I ended up having to have 2 big power bricks in order to use the dock with my laptop and have to (un)plug in 2 things instead of 1.

Taking off the 1 start due to the unclear and confusing verbiage that implied that I could make some use of the power delivery system even if at lower power when really it delivers 0 power instead.

theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸
comment: Absolutely perfect ğŸ‘Œ exactly the best docking station for my Dell laptop. I added a wireless headset, keyboard and mouse to my setup. Thank you for the speedy delivery.

theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸
comment: sturdy and reliable. so much so that I recently bought my third one. the first two are still working great going on two years now; I just have multiple use cases.

theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸
comment: I've used a Dell docking station several times and each one was great.....up until this one. Maybe I received a faulty docking station because the screens kept cutting out on me. As I write this, it has cut out ONCE already haha. I am going to return this one and purchase a new one because when the docking station works, it is super convenient to have. I keep my portable charger in my backpack and i never have to take it out. My screens just cut out on me again for the SECOND time haha. I do recommend this product but hopefully you receive a good working one. It just cut out on me for the THIRD time. Oh! I even changed out the hdmi/display ports multiple times. Problem is still there.

theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸
comment:
Right now it can be pretty hard to find a good thunderbolt dock for the new M1 Macbook Pros due to some docks not being compatible with Apple Silicon and etc. I'm happy to say this does work with my M1 Max MBP, but there is one quirk.

The good:
It charges! The ports work! Getting great transfer speeds! It's built well and hasn't had any problems so far. I'm running 2 displays off of it, one 2k 60hz via DP, and one portable 1080p ProArt via the thunderbolt in the back of the WD19TBS. I'm also running a USB hub, and a 4TB SSD directly from it via the USB C Gen 3.2 in the front. No disconnection issues that i've seen.

The bad:
I can't run 3 monitors off of the dock. It should be possible, the included instructions show how you can do even possibly up to 4 displays off the dock with compatible computers, but something isn't compatible via Apple. Thankfully, there's an HDMI out on the Macbook Pro so I can get my 4k screen via that, with the other 2 monitors off of the dock.
Only one of the two DPs and one HDMI port in the back will work for me at a time. If I use 2 of those, it looks like it splits the signal and mirrors it on both screens. You can get around that by using a USB C to DP cable and plug the second monitor in via the thunderbolt port.

It was between this or the Razer TB4 dock, since the new Caldigit docks are impossible to find right now. I've heard there has been some bugs with the Razer, so I'm glad I went with this. It may not be a perfect fit, but the Dell products I have owned over the years are all still working flawlessly, so I have more trust in them than Razer.

theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸
comment:
I have a Dell XPS 15 9550 with Windows 10 Pro that works rock solid for 5 years. There was always need for a good dock at home and after having immense troubles with TB16 and other manufacturers like Accell and Startech docks, finally paid premium price for this one from Dell WD19TBS.

First power delivery of 130W requirement for 9550. Initially I had TB16 and was never even close to charging fully. Had terrible issues with it Dell support amid compatibility issues, this one delivers 130W perfectly over Thunderbolt 3 port. Other docks as mention above do not even come close to charging the laptop!

Secondly as you have seen in above photograph, XPS 9550 along with WD19TBS drives 3 4k displays, 2 of them at 60hz while third one at 30hz (but then it is monitor limitation) along with native UHD resolution of 9550 itself. This is like paradise to me working from home as my job demands it!

However, I have to say that its not all bed of roses with straight plug-ins and up you go! Had to go over firmware updates on 9550 including the software update for TI chip over power delivery and Intel chip drivers, microsoft hid drivers that do not show up in regular SW update check. Mind it that these drivers or FW updates do not even show up straight in Dell Drivers either! It took me 4 days to get the system up and running.

So far the system has been running for a solid week and it has neither crashed nor blinked while working! I am a happy camper with this one finally and don't think of changing laptops for long time...

theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸
comment:
I've used name brand and cheap brand docks in the past and I can tell you for certain, you get what you pay for on these items. This Dell brand Thunderbolt dock does the job for my HP work laptop, the wife's Lenovo work laptop and my personal Dell laptop.

Doesn't matter which device we connect, the dock is recognized by the laptop fist time, every time. This is the perfect accessory for working remotely or just connecting your laptop to a full size monitor, network, etc. without worrying about tons of cables and what goes where.

theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸
comment:
I've had one of the ~$50 USB-C hubs for a while now that connected my laptop through a single plug to dual monitors and a printer. It worked ok, but it could only show resolutions up to 1080p on my dual monitors, I got "low charger current" warnings on my laptop when it was plugged in, and while my personal laptop displayed on both monitors, I could never get my work laptop to display on more than one.

So I was apprehensive about shelling out $250 for something that filled the same function as what I had, but I'm glad I did. This Dell one works seamlessly. It outputs to both my dual monitors at their max 1440p resolution, charges my laptop at full strength, and does so with both my personal and work laptops. I'm not fidgeting with the connection and checking drivers every so often - it just works. There's a quick fan noise right when you plug it in, but it runs super cool and I've never heard the fan kick on otherwise. The one thing I wish it had was a SD card slot, but that's easy enough to get a cheap little dongle for. Recommended.

theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸
comment: Recently tried a Dell D6000 all purpose dock. It did not output enough juice to charge my laptop. The WD19TB is the approved dock for this laptop so this WD19TBS works fine. All hooked up and driving 2 monitors, pulling network connection and a shared mouse/keyboard dingle between my laptop and desktop. Love it!!!

theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸
comment: I read another comment where they said it works for Macbook Pro's also so I gave it a try. To my surprise, it does work! Although, there's a caveat. I am running (2) 28" HP 4k monitors in addition to my Macbook Pro. I got them both up and running smoothly, but I can only plug (1) of my 4k monitors into the Dell docking station. The other monitor is plugged directly into the HDMI port on my MacBook Pro. I have my keyboard, mouse, headphones, and etc all plugged into the docking station and they are all working beautifully. To top it off, I am powering the MacBook Pro through the Thunderbolt port. So to my Apple family, IT WORKS! Just know that you'll have to use the HDMI port on your mac in addition to the Dell docking station if you are wanting to plug in a dual monitor setup. I was originally looking for the CalDigit TS4 Thunderbolt dock, but it has been sold out for a few months now. This is a safe alternative.

theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸
comment: This Dell Thunderbolt docking station worked flawlessly with a Dell XPS 15(2020 version) and 2 Dell 24" monitors using Display Port to HDMI cables. A Display Port to Display Port cable worked as well. This docking station has the ability to attach 4 monitors: 2 using Display Port cables, 1 using HDMI cable and 1 using a USB C cable. The Dell XPS 15 is running Windows 11 and had no issues with this Docking station and monitors. It's great to have 3 additional USB ports along with a USB C port, which was used to attach a 5TB USB C portable drive. Highly recommend this product.

comment: Good for a home set up, but no 3.5mm audio jack. Going to have to get some USB or Bluetooth speakers.

theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸
comment: Despite talking to Alienware multiple times, they still recommend this docking station. While it does sort of work, the power supply for the docking station provides around 130 watts of power. Of that, only 90watts is actually delivered to the laptop. Here is the problem: The newer Alienware laptops, and specifically the higher end laptops, required a 330Watt power supply. While the laptop will adjust, BIOS will complain about it, and it will slow the computer performance. After talking to tech support (Not sales) i learned that Alienware branded machines do not currently have an "approved" or "compatible" docking station. They expect you to use the ports provided on the laptop itself and just plug everything in every time. Best advise? buy a 2nd power supply for travel, and forget about using a docking station. Its a really nice idea, but Dell sales is not going to give you the correct info. This is not the fault of this seller in the slightest. this is a problem with Alienware/Dell sales promoting products that are not actually intended to work together, and the only reason for this low review. I am sure the product itself works fine for most of the Dell branded, lower performance laptops.

theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸

comment: I am convinced this 3rd party supplier provides refurbished, rather than new equipment. Avoid them at all costs. This is the 2nd Dell docking station I've purchased from Amazon. The first was wonderful and worked for 5 years under difficult conditions without skipping a beat. This one is buggy and often cuts off power or the video feed with my second monitor lapses at inopportune moments. theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸
comment: I bought this dock for use with a 16 inch MacBook pro with the M1 max SoC, and it was nothing, but problem after problem. First, all USB ports would randomly disconnect, and you'd have to disconnect, and reconnect the dock in order to get them working again. This INCLUDED the ethernet port, as it is connected to the USB controller on this dock. Given the price of this dock, the fact that the onboard LAN was nothing more than a USB ethernet adapter is really disappointing. Something else that'd already been stated was the fact that only one of the three display connections could be used at a time on the M1 pro and M1 max based Macs. All of that said, the power requirement of the M1 max was met; which, makes this one of the only docks that can supply sufficient power to this particular laptop, but given the compatibility problems, it's just not worth it. I'm hoping that those who bought this thing to be used with a PC are having better luck, but if you're considering this for a Mac, look elsewhere.

theproduct: Dell Thunderbolt Dock- WD19TBS 130w é›»æºå‚³è¼¸

I am updating my previous positive review to let you know that this is a China registered product, with a warranty registered ONLY in China as well. I have two of these, one that I purchased from Dell directly, which is working fine. This one failed after only 7 weeks and, when I reached out to Dell for support, was advised that I had to go to China for support, which was not in my near future plan. An alternative was to get the seller to transfer the warranty to the USA, which I am attempting to get done now.

I am not advising anyone not to purchase this product, as my original one of the same model is older and is working fine. Just make sure that you are aware of its region of registration before you make the purchase. If its disclosed on the Amazon site, I missed it in January and still missing it now, at least at clear and obvious disclosure.

Hopefully the seller will come through and do the right thing. Just buyer beware... If you buy one, try to search the Service Tag on the Dell support page.

This is an excellent monitor to purchase if you want to functionally create a desktop without spending a large amount of money on a brand new computer. I used purchased this to connect to my laptop to create a functioning pseudocomputer for studying/working.

Pros:
- Very affordable compared to other monitors of similar quality
- Simple assembly and attachment to the stand
- video quality is great. (it was a little bright for my taste so i reduced the brightness to 40% to limit eye strain
- There is no delay between the input on my laptop and what i am seeing on the monitor

Cons
- you could definitely find better picture quality at higher price points

Disclaimer: I only use this for working so this review is based on that. I cannot comment on how good this would be for gaming or graphic design.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S2421HS Full HD 1920 x 1080,24 è‹±å‹ 1080p LED,75Hz,é™„å¯èª¿å¼æ”¯æ¶çš„æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,4 æ¯«ç§’ç°è‡³ç°åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“,AMD FreeSync,IPS æŠ€è¡“,HDMI,DisplayPort,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
UPDATE - Flickering issue. My excitement with this otherwise high quality monitor was premature. A very subtle flickering is going on. At first it seems perfect. But as you work and stare and glance down at your keyboard, you realize there is a subtle flickering going on - at all times. I tried switching out cables (both DP and HDMI) - no difference. Same flicker. Then I connected to a different computer - still flickering! So it's definitely the monitor - not the cables and not the computer. I'm returning it - which is a shame because I otherwise like this monitor and need a good 27" one - just without flicker! (Left it at 5 stars because I'm giving Dell the benefit of the doubt. I'm assuming I just got a dud. We'll see when I reorder . . . . )

This is a great everyday monitor - but the screen settings it ships with are very bland. When you first plug it in and connect it up, you'll get a mediocre image. Go into the screen settings using the little buttons hidden on the underside of the front right edge of the monitor. Play around with the different choices and adjust brightness, contrast, RGB, mode, etc. until you get the bright crisp image you want. That's what I did and I'm very happy with the results. Plus the stand is great. It raises, lowers, tilts and swivels. Connections are good too - offering both HDMI and DP ports. All this for $170 is a darn good deal. Just be sure to adjust the image in settings after you set it up.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ S2421HS Full HD 1920 x 1080,24 è‹±å‹ 1080p LED,75Hz,é™„å¯èª¿å¼æ”¯æ¶çš„æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,4 æ¯«ç§’ç°è‡³ç°åæ‡‰æ™‚é–“,AMD FreeSync,IPS æŠ€è¡“,HDMI,DisplayPort,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
I measured the diagonal screen size and it's closer to 23 and a bit inches corner to corner. Nothing about this product is 27 inches. iruler.net, which detects your monitor and puts a real size ruler on the screen, says the monitor is 22.9" but either way, it's not 27. And it's not the frame size vs viewable, on the top and sides there's maybe 3/16 of an inch of black frame outside the screen, and at the bottom maybe 5/8. But nothing that inflates a 23 inch monitor 4 inches so they can call it 27" in the item description.

It is a perfectly good monitor from what I can tell, I just expected it to be 4 or 5 diagonal inches bigger than the old one I replaced and it's about the same size and resolution. Glad it was on sale. Feels like false advertising though.

[Follow-up] Gotta point out, on the box the monitor is packed in, it has a little plan-view of the monitor from the top, side and front, and the front view has a suggestive diagonal line with 27" printed next to it A 27 inch diagonal monitor would literally not fit in the box. Dell is a pretty major brand, I'm still stumped by this false product claim that is refutable by anyone with a tape measure. You'd expect they would know someone might, you know...check. The only reason I'm not returning for a refund on principle is that they were on sale and they are "big enough" for my needs. The fact remains though, that from the Amazon ad to the shipping package, the dimensions of the product are bogus.

comment:
For $140 you get a good monitor, but not a great monitor. The monitor lacks in contrast, as it does not have dynamic range to make true blacks. Also the monitor brightness is low. Blackness and brightness work against each other. To get a bright picture, you crank up the brightness and as a result a black background is grey and video seem washed out.

As a Windows PC monitor for surfing and some YouTube you are fine. But if you heavily consume video, look for something else.

comment: Would rate this 5 stars except for a quirk that seems to be plaguing of Dell monitors like this. Mine is plugged into my laptop via HDMI through a hub. After logging off and shutting down my laptop, if I don't also turn the monitor off it goes into power saving mode. When I power the laptop back up, the monitor will claim there is no HDMI device plugged in. Get the same message if I turn the monitor off and then back on. The only work-around is to either unplug the HDMI cable and then plug it back in, or make sure the monitor is turned off when I boot the laptop up. This second method only works sporadically. I've checked multiple forums online and this seems to be a persistent problem with no clear solution.

comment:
I needed/wanted a better quality second monitor than the (unnamed) one I've been using for a long time and I didn't want to pay a lot for it. This Dell meets my expectations/requirements for performance/cost balance. The color fidelity is excellent and refresh rate is also excellent. Both are much more than satisfactory for my use case

The big negative for this monitor for me is that the resolution settings choices are severely limited. You get two or three default resolution setting choices and that's it! It is not possible to meaningfully decrease item display size by choosing a higher resolution (there are no useful higher resolution settings to choose from). This is actually a big deal for me and it still has me on the fence deciding whether to keep the monitor or return it. Considering what I paid for it, though, I suspect I'll end up keeping it

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment: This is really an awesome product from legendary Dell. I have not had a single problem with it. Small, lightweight, fast start by lifting cover/screen. Hours long battery life, touchscreen helps speed usage over mouse or touchpad. Keyboard excellent. Windows 11 a bit different but quickly got used to it. What I hoped the Chromebook was but will never be. Biggest change for me is the new smaller USB size but Dell provides an adapter. Two USB ports, one for power supply, the other for mouse, monitor or printer as needed. Has Bluetooth and synchs with my cell phone. Professional level PC. Would buy another one if needed.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
Love this machine. As a chemistry lecturer, i wanted a laptop for backup in case something happened to my desktop. My university is still work from home so being able to stay online is very important.
My final choice was between the M1 macbook pro and this but decided to go with the xps 13 because certain software I use doesn't work on mac.
The laptop is everything i wanted and then some. It's extremely quick, and adjusting windows 11 has been easy. The build is premium and the keyboard is superior. It wasn't too bogged down by bloatware (mainly antivirus which i quickly uninstalled).
The battery life is average thus far and the quality from the webcam is below average.
Overall I'm very happy with my purchase and hope it continues!

comment: Was trying to purchase this laptop but multiple listings appeared. FYI, the other listings are from third-party sellers or distributors. Nothing wrong with third-party sellers and if you want to purchase from a third-party seller that is up to you. If you try to go to other listings and go under the "Buy Now" buttons, third-party sellers will have a section that says "ships from/sold by". This listing does not, so it is sold by the actual Dell store. Also, if you can, buy this laptop when it has a discount. I bought it at an unfortunate time and the price dropped $200 after it shipped. I was able to return it and repurchase with the discount.

comment: I liked the small form factor and sleek outward appearance of this laptop but have been disappointed with the performance, battery life, and how noisy it is. I can live with the battery life and performance issues, but the noise is really intolerable. I was replacing my old ASUS 17 inch laptop and wanted to order reasonably high end specs, but even though the specs are higher end than my old system, it barely seems faster, and at times there are inordinate delays in responsiveness. I suppose I shouldn't have been surprised at the short battery life of the system because there isn't much room to fit a battery in such a small package, and that actually isn't that big a problem since I mostly use the system at home and can reconnect to power whenever I need to, but its still disappointing. I seem to get 3-4 hours from a full charge. The really annoying issue is that the cooling fan seems to run noisily when I am barely doing anything with the system, and once it starts running it doesn't want to stop unless I turn the system off. I regret purchasing this system and I haven't even finished paying for it yet.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment: I purchased this computer brand new for my job as a consultant (WFH). The computer itself is nice - looks sharp, well made, excellent keyboard, great screen, nice touchscreen, good battery life, etc. However, there's one major issue - the wifi will consistently drop when I am web conferencing. It's happened enough times in enough meetings (Google, Zoom, Teams) now that I can't trust the machine anymore. Multiple calls with Dell tech support have not resolved the issue. If you Google 'Dell XPS 13 wifi connectivity issues' you'll see there are lots of people reporting the same problem. Wish I had known that before. At this point, I'd just like my money back, as I had to purchase another machine from a different manufacturer so I could do my job.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment: This is a high functioning little laptop. However, in researching this model it stated this was a great model for photo editing. That is not true at all!!!! I am extremely disappointed in this computer. I shot photos in RAW and you can't even get the entire Photoshop display in the window. Nor can you easily move it back and forth. I thought I was having issues with Photoshop because I couldn't get all of the functions to show up. Today (after 4 months of playing with it) I discovered that it wasn't Photoshop but my computer that didn't show all the panels of photoshop. There aren't enough ports on the computer for downloading photos are working with the photos. I called Dell and asked which monitor and docking station was recommended for this computer. You can't use the monitor without the docking station. The docking station they recommended only makes the computer jam. So basically the only reason for my purchase is a complete bust. I have a $1700 dust collector. I thought Dell was the best, this frustrating experience has proven otherwise.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment: I paid up for this laptop to replace an HP Spectre that had worked well for several years but was struggling to handle the increased bandwidth needed to support multi-tasking. While certain features work well on this Dell (bluetooth connectivity, local speed), network functions and camera quality are very poor for a "high end" laptop. I use this machine for work (microsoft suite, chrome-based software system, and zoom) and have a dual display monitor port connected. The machine has serious lag time, poor wireless network connections, and a grainy camera for zoom/teams meetings. Also, it has lost wifi connectivity multiple times requiring the network connection to be reset weekly. My HP was nearly half the cost and had half the specs (8gb ram, i5 processor, etc), but performed as good or better in nearly all facets. Seriously disappointed in this model and won't be returning to Dell after this experience.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
Backlit keys, beautiful screen, Robocop shell, long battery life.

I absolutely love the XPS line. I have the 17, and it's a monster workhorse. It's the only laptop I have that can compare to my desktop. I wanted something a little smaller to easily carry around, and where battery life wasn't a concern. This was the obvious choice.

I'm using the Windows 11 version, and I'm very happy to report that it doesn't feel like a big leap from Windows 10. Almost everything on it is an intuitive transition. The only thing that was weird for me was the centralized taskbar, but I found that there's a setting to put it back on the bottom left like I like, so I'm happy.

The screen is as sharp and bright as I've come to expect from the XPS line. It's absolutely beautiful, and it makes watching YouTube feel like a clean experience. I really like the 16x10 aspect ratio as that extra space makes doing work and browsing web pages so much easier.

It uses WiFi6, and it automatically detected it from my router, so I'm running full WiFi 6 with no effort on my part. Pages open immediately, and everything feels very responsive. It feels like a solid Ethernet connection.

I used Crystal Disk Mark and I'm getting around 3 Gigs for both read and write. The hard drive is definitely no bottleneck.

It upgraded the laptop bios without me having to do anything special. That's really cool to me because low level security problems need to be taken care of, and most people can't do it. This literally did everything for me just by hitting Windows Update and then restarting the computer. In my opinion that makes this one of the best laptops for people that don't want to have to think about it.

I have to talk about the case. It's such a heavy duty feeling laptop just because of the thick aluminum case. Anyone that picks it up is surprised by the rock solid feeling on it.

The keys on it feel like a luxurious soft material that my fingers love touching. It's a beautiful typing experience. It's a 13", so there's no numpad, but the keys aren't crunched together. I have big hands, so that's a big deal for me, and typing on this feels very natural.

The touchpad is just like my 17 in that it's the best touchpad on the market today. It's responsive, it registers exactly like I expect, it clicks when I press it, and it makes for a normal feeling experience. These are the only types of touchpads that don't frustrate me into grabbing an external mouse.

I tried Far Cry 6 on it just to see how it could handle gaming. I was getting artifacts, but I chalked that up to new game, new computer, new operating system. I expect a patch soon for it. I tried my favorite Far Cry title, Far Cry 4, and I could run that at 720 with 50 fps, or 1080 with 30 fps.

Overall this is a beautiful premium laptop that's fully capable of taking on my work.

Highly recommended.
