comment:
Dell XPS 13 9310 Touchscreen Laptop 13.4 inch FHD+ Thin and Light. Intel Core i7-1195G7, 16GB LPDDR4x RAM, 512GB SSD, Intel Iris Xe Graphics, Windows 11 Pro, 2Yr OnSite, 6 months Dell Migrate â€“ Silver

This Laptop Is stunning. It's sleek and is very well made. Summary is, we are very happy with this laptop despite Dell and their bloatware.

The XPX 9310 measures 0.58 by 11.6 by 7.8 inches and weighs just over 2.5 lbs. The display is 1,920/1,200-pixels and looks beautiful. It's not quite as vivid as Retina display but it's really close. The 16 by 10 aspect ratio feel really good on this size laptop. The XPS 13 has only to two USB Type-C ports with Thunderbolt 4 support. If you have a lot of stuff, you'll need a dock or hub. Performance is great and we have had zero issue with the CPU or Ram getting bogged down in Photoshop or blender. It's not as desktop so it's not as fast at rendering but does a pretty decent job keeping up with my 4 year old loaded out desktop.

My biggest beef is how difficult Dell makes it to remove the bloatware. Some of the software is stubborn, but some is pretty near impossible to get rid of. I tried doing a clean install from a usb drive and Dell blocked it. So, thanks Dell, you get one star off.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
The Dell XPS 13 9310 Thin and Light Touchscreen Laptop is a great option if you're looking for a fast, lightweight tablet/laptop combo that's perfect for taking while on the go. A touchscreen laptop is something I honestly thought was overrated until I tried it - having the work functionality of a laptop with the ease of navigation of a tablet, I found myself loving being able to type of my work then quickly tapping buttons and parts of the page on the screen without having to fuss with a mouse. The laptop has an excellent display, a fast processor, and boots up/shuts down amazingly quickly so I can wrap things up and easily take it on the go. It's so lightweight that I feel like I'm carrying a tablet, albeit one that comes with a keyboard built-in and closes like a flip phone to protect both the screen and the keyboard. It only has a few things about it I don't love, but for the most part, I would still purchase this laptop again simply because it gets our family's tasks done and done well.

The display is excellent and images come back very detailed while the touch screen works without any flaws. The picture quality is pretty amazing - it comes through very clearly with clearly defined details and I was able to watch Ytube videos in 1440p60 as well as 4K HD without any lag. As for the touch screen capabilities, it works as well as any other touchscreen device I've used. It's very responsive and many of the finger motions such as pinching open to zoom in/pinching in to zoom out are the same as most tablets and phones. One thing to note is that the screen does not rotate when the laptop is turned on its side nor can you fold the keyboard behind the screen - if you want that capability, there is a 2-in-1 version where you can do just that. As for using a stylus/pen, this laptop does not support the Dell Active Pen, but you can use normal passive pens for more precise taps on the screen. I personally found using my fingers was suitable enough, but like most tablets, I also found myself having to clean the screen more frequently than on my normal laptop.

The camera on the Dell XPS 13 9310 is absolute garbage. At not even a megapixel, everything recorded or photos taken with this laptop will look like photos taken on digital cameras from the 90s (and I would know, I owned a crappy digital camera in the 90s!). While it works well enough for a last-ditch work meeting under the proper very bright lighting, as any light dimmer than a spotlight on you will make you look as grainy as a face buried in the sand, you're probably better off using your cell phone for any important virtual calls.

Similarly, the speakers on the Dell XPS are only average at best, although I didn't test them very much since I like to use headphones with my mobile devices. With that in mind, headphones connect very well via Bluetooth, and if you want to use wired headphones, there is a headphone jack on this laptop. Speaking of inputs, there are relatively few connection points for peripherals â€“ just two USB-C ports (one of that you will need at some point to charge the laptop), a microSD card reader, and a headphone jack. If you need to connect any other device via wired connection, you will need to get a USB-C Multiport Adapter. Luckily there are many available on Amazon and they work great with this computer.

The software on this computer works as well as any other Windows-based computer. There's the inevitable push to pay for McAfee Security and some general bloatware in there, but everything you don't want can be easily uninstalled and nothing really slows the computer down. The battery life on the Dell XPS is fairly good and I've been able to run it for several hours without needing to stop and charge it. Battery life does vary depending on many factors including how bright you turn your display on, what programs you're running, and if you're running peripherals on it (just for starters!), so your mileage will vary. I've found I had no problem running this computer for 6 hours before I plugged it in - it still had some charge left when I did so, and I've never tried to run it into the ground. Finally, one last thing to note is that the computer does run fairly hot. I'm not sure if this will be an issue in the long run, but this laptop runs hot enough where I don't want it sitting on my lap while working unless I'm in a cold doctor's office or a ski lodge near the door. So far it hasn't caused any adverse issues with my computer, it's still concerning and an inconvenience to put the laptop on a table or on a book while using on my lap.

Overall, the Dell XPS 13 9310 is a great quality computer that is very lightweight and great for travel. I like how portable it is, how quickly it runs, and the picture quality on the display. It's convenient to be able to use the screen like a tablet but have all the functionality of a standard laptop. While it's not perfect, it's still a good quality laptop that's worth considering.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
updating my review to take a star away and mention the fact that it gets SO hot on the bottom. So far it hasn't caused any actual issues but, I do not see how it will survive getting this hot. It happens after about 20 minutes to half hour of use and just gets worse from there the longer you use it. Will update as needed.

It's a tough little thing that performs great in almost all areas - I don't do any kind of gaming or photo editing, so I can't comment on those areas, but for everything else it is great.

Case feels very solid, durable, and protective.
It boots up and is ready to go almost instantly.
Responds instantly.
Pages load instantly.
Handles many pages and apps at a time without lag or hesitation.
Streams perfectly.
Screen is beautiful.
Still getting used to windows 11 even on my other laptops, but not a whole ton different. Not enough to make it feel like I don't know where anything is or what to do, so it isn't a huge transition if you've still been on a previous version.
Battery life is great. I've left it sit for a few days in a row on the same charge with using about 2-3 hrs a day for typical internet use before it warns me that battery is low.
Initial setup was pretty quick and very easy.
Not much to go in and delete/uninstall to save space. All was done in a few minutes.
No issues with wifi or bluetooth connections.
I haven't come across anything to complain about.
I'm picky with keyboards and how I want them to click/feel. I am happy with this keyboard. Feels good, not too clacky. Very smooth, but plastic-y.
Cord feels cheap for the device. It is very rigid. Plug looks and feels very generic and again very plastic-y. USB c charging on either side is a huge plus.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
I was looking for a smaller laptop to replace my Dell G3 i7. I was happy with my laptop but after I got this I discovered that I was missing out on so much! Below, I will talk about the main points I always look for when I'm buying a laptop, and I hope you find them helpful.
- The laptop was very welled packaged. It came in a nice small all black box. The box contains the laptop, a charged and 2 USB C; one of them is thunderbolt 4 which is compatible with the most recent docking stations. You can also connect it with most monitor's using the thunderbolt 4. It also comes with a dongle from USB C to universal USB port; which you probably won't need with the most recent devices, but it's still helpful and good to have
- The charger is small; compact and light. Which makes it portable and good for travelling. The charger is USB C.
- The setup was very easy and convenient. It took less than 15 minutes to get the whole thing up and running. It was also very easy to migrate my files from my Dell G3 to this one.
- For the display, it's very bright full HD touchscreen. I'm usually not a fan of touchscreens on laptops cause I've had my experiences of ones who would take a look of charge and power from the laptop for the touchscreen to function; but with 16 GB DDR4 Ram; you will not face any issues. The screen functions very smoothly just like a tablet or a mobile device. The maximum resolution is 1920 x 1200. The beauty of the screen is that the black is VERY dark and the brightness outdoor was great. It's very comfortable for the eyes and VERY clear.
After using this for a while, I can tell that the most powerful piece about this laptop is the display screen.
- One of the nicest feature about it, is that the turnoff power is connected to the screen. After you shutdown, once you open the lid, the laptop will be turned back on. It takes only seconds to be turned on
- It has face recognition & finger print technology. You can use either technology to operate and they both work so smoothly and very convenient. You will still need to setup a pin even if you choose one of these technology.
- The laptop is super thin and light; it weighs around 2.8 pounds. I didn't realize how heavy my old laptop was until I got this. Usually, smaller/thinner laptops don't function as good; but this is a beast.
- Has Intel Iris XE graphic card which is decent. 2.00 GB shared dedicated memory. Obviously, this computer is not for gaming; as you can get everything in such a thin/small/ compatible laptop, however, you can still run some games on medium/low quality; such as The Witcher 3, Civilization 4 or similar games smoothly with 30 - 60 frames per second. Which is pretty good for dedicated graphic card. But, bear in mind that the laptop may get hot due to the processing power required for such games if you decided to use for gaming or for designing programs such as 3D max, Rivet and Autocade
If you want to turn this laptop into a gaming one, you can purchase a external graphic card with your required specifications.
- Sound quality is good. Loud and clear. and I think it's more than enough with a laptop with this size.

Overall, I'm very satisfied with this laptop; it's great for my needs. It's everything I was looking for in a laptop when it comes to size, weight, processor, display screen and I did read some negative comments about the camera, but this is not something that I'm concerned about at all, as I'm a type of person that keeps their cam OFF in meetings. So this is my least concern.

Do your research before buying a laptop at this price; but from my use and experience in laptops; this is really good and it's way better than expected. Worth every penny!
Hope you find this review helpful!

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
The 13â€ laptop comes with a nice luxurious packaging design which is very easy and cool to unbox. First impressions, the build quality from the aluminum covering on the outside to the carbon fiber composite on the inside gives the laptop an overall premium look and feel.

The speakers sound quality and clarity are not bad for a laptop this small. The keyboard is quiet, a little clicky but has a nice balanced pressure and was comfortable to type on.

My Specs:
-Intel Core i7-1195G7
-16GB LPDDR4x RAM
-512GB SSD
-FHD+ Touchscreen
-Intel Iris Xe Graphics
-Windows 11 Pro

The FHD+ 1200p choice provides quite high enough pixel density for such a small display size and I believe it also helps with battery life more than with the optional 4k UHD+ display. This screen size gives an overall 16:10 aspect ratio providing more vertical space for more efficient work. The panel is non-reflective one, IPS equivalent â€œwide viewing angleâ€ that has an efficient brightness level and is good for outdoor activities. Contrast and colors are very accurate. The screen has a refresh rate of 60 Hz.

The power adaptor supports input voltage 110 â€“ 240 which means it is universal and supports different types of electric volts worldwide.

This 11th Gen Dell laptop offers the ability to upgrade your SSD for up to 2 TB. I had 408 GB storage free out of the box. I did the SSD storage speed benchmark test (2 runs) using Crystaldiskmark 8.0.4. Results were around 2-2.5 Gbps for both read and write. These numbers are quite fast and you might not easily find a faster device, storage wise.

*My total all core render Cinebench R23 score is: 1ST pass: 3301 / 2nd pass: 3804 (average for this specific processor).
*3D Mark Score: 1240 (lower part of the curve among gaming laptops scores).

In short, this is a great business level laptop from Dell that I will choose for some color photography work and productivity. For more professional color-sensitive photography work, Iâ€™d definitely recommend the 4k or 3.5k optional upgrades. But, if you are a battery nerd like me, you may want to sacrifice some higher resolutions for a better overall battery life.

Recommendations?
Camera quality can be improved and itâ€™ll be also great to see a camera shutter available in the future.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment: This is just about my ideal laptop and even the few things I don't completely love aren't that much of a pain. The whole thing has a premium feel which is great in a world where so many laptops are all plastic. Aluminum plus a soft touch carbon fiber look is a win here. The screen has all the detail I want with plenty of brightness. Viewing angles are great so while this isn't exactly cinema size if you have someone else looking on they can see no matter where they are. Performance wise I've been able to get everything I needed done: Light gaming, browsing, high def video. No problem. For a laptop the keyboard is just fine. Not mechanical feeling but a crisp click nonetheless. Ports are a bit limited but I have to say I've gotten very used to only having USB-C and a headphone jack. They do provide a small dongle so if you will need something plugged in while you're out I find just keeping the dongle attached to whatever the device you're bringing is or keep it in a bag. The only real complaint I have is the battery life. Somewhat understandable in something with an i7 in it but don't expect to be out all day using it if you dont have somewhere to plug in. I don't find myself out like that too much so realistically it's not a problem but it does mean the battery is something you have to be conscious about. Beyond that it's a powerful, small, and well built laptop that can just be carried around like a small paper notebook. The compact size means I actually take it around with me as opposed to a 15" that I only move if I have a specific purpose. It really is a sweet-spot in my opinion and I'd have no problem recommending this one to anyone.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
They aren't kidding when they say this is thin and sleek. It has such a slim profile that it's sized like a small folder, so it's incredibly portable and easy to work on when traveling. The 13 inch screen in perfect when you need something bigger and easier to work/type on than a tablet, but don't want anything too big or bulky.

Comparing this to my Acer Spin 5, the actual screen viewable area seems to be larger. The bezel frame around the Acer is wider, so the super slim frame around the Dell offers even more screen viewing real-estate.

The touch screen is very responsive and I'm pleased they included a backlit keyboard. My Acer that's similar in style and design doesn't have a backlight, which has been an issue since the start. I never thought it would be a big deal, until I didn't have the backlight and I realized how difficult it can be to type in low light with black keys that have nothing to light them up.

One thing that's very different between the systems is how few ports this computer has. This Dell has just a single type C port and an SD card slot. My Acer Spin 5 has two type C ports, an HDMI, two USB ports and an SD slot. However my Acer is a tiny bit thicker than this Dell. So you sacrifice additional ports for having an ultra slim design. Something to keep in mind when deciding on a computer, since what you connect to this Dell will be limited.

The speakers sound quite good for such a small machine. The screen is bright and the colors are rich. The included graphics card has been able to run everything smoothly for me so far. While I don't game with this Dell, I do some video editing with it and the software has worked well without any lagging or crashing. About the only thing I could think of changing would be the inclusion of a single USB port, for use with some small wireless travel mice.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
As a former XPS 9570 owner, this laptop is basically a smaller, lighter, power conscious version of it focusing more on productivity and less on gaming. There is no discrete graphics, only Intel's Xe graphics for light gaming at low resolutions. This laptop is perfect for mobile users that want a fast processor with plenty of RAM and good battery life without the need for power hungry discrete graphics.

CPU: Intel Core i7-1195G7 2.9GHz/ 5.0GHz boost 4 Core/8 Thread Processor
This is the latest 11th gen, 10nm chip for non-gaming portables. You get the increased power savings from shifting to 10nm process node. This is not an 'H' chip usually on gaming laptops but the G series for better heat and battery management.

RAM: 16GB DDR4 4267MHz Dual Channel
Plenty of RAM, even for Chrome, the faster clocked RAM is a nice plus.

NMVe: Micron 2300 NVMe 512GB M.2
The only replaceable part in this system. The rated R/W speeds are 3300/2700MBps. Uses Micron 96 Layer TLC NAND.

LCD: 13.4in 1920x1200 panel, 500 nits brightness
Dell has the brightest screens of any laptop brand. The FHD+ screen is much better for battery life than the 4K OLED screen. Text can be a bit small when viewed at 100% setting, you might need to bump to 125% or 150%. The touch screen was responsive and the sensitivity was good. 100% sRGB coverage but only 90% DCI P3.

VIDEO CARD: Intel Xe
Don't expect to play any recent AAA titles on anything higher than 720P. This is just barely faster than basic Intel UHD graphics. If you really want to game, this laptop is not meant for you.

WIFI: Killer 1650s WIFI 6
This is a rebadged Intel AX200, which in my opinion is a good thing. Killer makes placebo cards at best and even worse software. Do yourself a favor and uninstall all Killer software and watch your network issues disappear. Install the Intel AX200 drivers and you will be all set.

PROS
- Premium aluminum case and feel
- Lightweight at only 2.8 lbs
- 2x Thunderbolt 4 ports
- Ultra bright screen
- Windows 11 Pro NOT Home!
- Comes with a USB-C to USB-A converter

CONS
- Only replaceable part is the M.2 NVMe drive. RAM and WIFI is soldered.
- Webcam is only 720P

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
The laptop is amazing, but windows 11 really takes away from it.

Setup - Quick and Easy!
Touchscreen - is easy to use and very responsive.
Price - on par with similar brands.
OLED Screen - Wow, just amazing and crisp. 4k video's look amazing!
Noise - I have not noticed any noise minus a slight hum in a very quiet room from this laptop.
Battery Life - Excellent lifespan
I love the USB-C power cable and the fact that it can be on either side is amazing!
Wifi and Bluetooth are awesome - I have connected a multitude of devices without issue.

I have my laptop set up with a secondary monitor and run 4 Chrome Windows each with a few tabs - some pull more data than others and I don't have any lag or issues at all.

Windows 11 - There are some issues here that make any computer not as easy to work on. The taskbar for one (you cannot resize it, you cannot ungroup the icons, you cannot have smaller icons, it doesn't show the time on secondary monitors and you cannot move it.) Setting the default browser in Windows 11 is very difficult. You need to set your default under HTTP and HTTPS. Zero offline local accounts. The interface requires too many clicks and it is not straightforward. And of course the main settings app doesn't include everything in any older Control Panel.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
Ok so I am not a big computer person. I use one every day all day but I am not the person to throw specifications at you.
I have a MacBook Pro (several years old) that I use when I need mobility and I like it but it was time for a new laptop. I like to change them out before any issues arise and I loose every thing.
This dell has a nice feel to it and I like the feel of the keys. The screen is crisp and clear but dose have some bleeding around the edges.
The speed is superior to what I was using. I do a lot of CAD design work related to 3d printing and this can be too much for some computers but this dell handles it just fine.
I find the battery life is about what I would expect. It fluctuates with what I am doing but I can count on a good solid 4 hours before I need to charge it.
I wish the screen was bigger but that has to do with my budget (and eyes) not the computer.
My MacBook Pro was hot on the legs after about 20 minutes and this one is the same but that is to be expected when you think of all that is going on in there.
I try to not use any lap top on my lap for several reasons. First off It can't be good all of that electrical field held up to you're body. Second heat kills things. You're legs are a great insulator to hold in that heat and just cook things.
I like this Dell lap top and I can recommend it based on my needs. If the specs match you're needs then I think you will like it too.
5 STARS

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
The laptop is tiny at 13 inches, and very lightweight. I ordered it for my college student son, and he loves how lightweight it is compared to his older 15 inch laptop. It looks beautiful, with clean shiny lines. He likes facial recognition sign in.
Aside from appearance, it seems to be good quality laptop. It is powerful, and his CPU and memory hogging applications run smoothly. You can barely hear the fans coming up with higher usage, but it is nothing at all as loud as his Predator laptop that sounded like a jet engine taking off. They most definitely worked hard on making it quiet and cool.
The screen is bright and the picture is amazingly clear. It does work well for online classes and zoom, but the webcam is not the best quality especially in the low light, which came quite as a surprise for such high priced laptop. it is only 720p, so not even full HD camera. Kind of annoying that it does not have a USB port. It has two Thrunderbird ports and they did include USB-C to USB-A adapter. He does not mind, but I would be livid, I have too much stuff that uses USB-A and having to mess with adapter is just one more point of failure when it gets lost or broken.
It can run some games, but it is clearly more for productivity or business and it excels at it.
So far, overall it is great laptop.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
It's been many years since I allowed myself a new laptop, and as I usually go for a lightly used older model I'm fairly easy to please, and hardly the harshest critic of the most up to date technology.

That said, the moment I pulled this laptop from its box I was in love. At a little over 1KG it's incredibly light, though because it's less than 12" wide and 8" deep that weight is quite concentrated. It feels dense in a way that no laptop I've ever used has felt, a hint that lots of exciting technology has been crammed into this tiny package.

I don't do much intensive work day to day, but every few weeks I need to fire up Photoshop to do some fairly complex stuff that absolutely annihilates my old laptop. With 16GB of RAM and the Intel Iris Xe Graphics card this thing can stroll through the kind of work that would cause my old laptop to grind to a halt. What's more I can keep multiple processes working in the background while I work, so graphics work is no longer a grind.

If you're looking for a small and extremely portable laptop that can handle anything you can throw at it, the Dell XPS 13 9310 is an excellent candidate. Yes, it's expensive, and I'm sure you can get a laptop with similar specs in a slightly less portable package for less, but I've never used a laptop with this much power that's small enough to toss in a tote bag. My only slight complaint is that it runs a little hot when you start to push it, because the heat needs to go somewhere and there just isn't enough room to dissipate it effectively. It's not enough to knock this down from a 5 star review, though. Just buy a cooling pad or raise it off the surface.

comment:
Iâ€™m not going to talk about specs because they all clearly listed on the page but more about an experience I have had in a past week with this laptop.
First of all I never had a laptop with touchscreen so Iâ€™m getting used to it a little bit considering Iâ€™m a mouse kind of person but it sure is handy when you donâ€™t have one or when we will be flying.
Sizing is perfect for us because this is our household laptop and take with us traveling, itâ€™s light, fits perfectly in my purse or hubbys backpack, sizing is super universal.
Everything I streamed so far have fabulous performance, very enjoyable clear picture and sound just right, again very useful in a car or plane for our son.
Iâ€™m technically behind I think so I couldnâ€™t figure out how to plug in the mouse but there is adapter that comes with it from USB to C that you can utilize but we also have Bluetooth mouse that works perfectly with it.
Speed is fantastic, no lagging, just smooth and fast, I mean I canâ€™t ask for better experience. Iâ€™m utilizing it with my office products for some work stuff and home, really we using it for multifunctional purposes because it just can handle it on, small but mighty!
Itâ€™s quite, I use it with no issues when my baby snoozing next to me but it tends to get a bit hot when using it proactively with multiple things running, I might look into cooking pad for it at some point but I really try not to use it too much in bed.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
OVERALL
This is a really solid productivity ultrabook, with nice features that make it feel high end. It's designed to be lightweight, and push wireless connectivity. The largest issue I have with it however, is temperature management. To fully take advantage the capability of the CPU, this laptop needs some assistance with cooling.
TEMPS/COOLING
When pushing this laptops CPU (which is a great CPU) the temps get pretty high. I played Civ 6 on this PC which it could handle (see more about graphics below). But Civ can get pretty CPU heavy the farther into the game you get. I've got a screenshot here with temps and you can see it sometimes got as high as 95 C. At one point when playing and charging at the same time, the entire game crashed and the laptop rebooted â€“ I have to assume this is about the temps so from then on I had to be more careful. I also use this laptop in bed and it'll make my bare legs red so it definitely needs a fully flat surface like a tea tray or something â€“ ideally with a cooling pad.
POLISH/QUALITY OF LIFE FEATURES
There are a lot of quality of life features that I really enjoy. The fingerprint reader for sign-in is nice. I don't care for facial recognition in my technology for a lot of reasons so having the fingerprint option is great and it works very reliably. You can also add multiple fingers to it. The touchscreen is very responsive and accurate, being able to swipe to go back in a web browser for example, is really nice when just browsing. It is very thin and super light so it's portability is excellent. There are some Dell features that might be worth your time, they might not â€“ an integration for using your cell phone with the computer is one of them. There is quite a bit of bloatware out of the box which is annoying. The charging cable has a light at the end so you know if it's plugged in which is a small thing, but adds to the polish of the product. Overall it feels like they tried to make a product that could compete with a macbook air and while I am not a macbook person, I do feel like where they landed was not as premium as a macbook air, but still a VERY good ultrabook.
IRIS XE
I also ran a timespy benchmark and my numbers were better than the other reviewers. I am not sure what on earth could be contributing to such disparate results. The Iris Xe is being marketed as integrated graphics that don't make compromises. While this isn't a gaming rig and I would never use it as such, if you are a gamer who travels and you want to be able to game on the road this might work if you temper your expectations. If you are a PC gamer you can also stream games to it from your gaming rig while sitting on the couch in another room so that's also an option, depending on the game. I have had a good experience so far, but I've also only tried games that I felt comfortable it could handle (like turn based games). I did try to push it and loaded up Valheim and was met with an atrocious 9-12 fps.
In addition to the integrated graphics, the other limiting factor here is, can you mitigate the heat? Because gaming is a battery drain, you'll be probably using it while plugged in, also while the CPU is cranked up. So a cooling pad is probably going to be necessary unless it's in short bursts like a 30 minute train ride for commuters.
PORTS
The I/O on here is super bare bones. Just two thunderbolt ports, an aux, and microSD. It IS nice to be able to charge from either side of the laptop. But because of the streamlined I/O and the fact that this is a productivity laptop first and foremost, you'll probably need a hub or docking station to make this usable in an office environment. I have been using a Bluetooth mouse and that's been very responsive so cutting cords with peripherals is an option but connecting to power and multiple screens will likely still require a dock.
STORAGE
To my knowledge the storage is not expandable but it is replaceable. So you could ostensibly upgrade to a larger NVME if you'd like but you're looking at migrating all your stuff and reinstalling windows etc. to do it. 512 GB is not a lot, however with increasing amounts of cloud storage being utilized, it might be find for a typical productivity user that doesn't focus on video or photo.
BEST POSSIBLE USE CASE
So who is this laptop for? I imagine it's for a commuting office worker first and foremost. The compact size is really only necessary if you will be moving it around. If you'll have it plugged in to a dock and mounted all day every single day, then I really don't see the point in accepting so few ports. Not being able to plug in even a USB flashdrive without an adapter (it does come with one) is a huge pain for some people, so the portability really needs to be worth it. Otherwise, I'd get another laptop with similar specs that has a better set of ports on the side. It IS forward thinking with the Thunderbolt ports though and as technology marches forward, we will see more accessories and peripherals that rely on USB C/Thunderbolt. Like I said, if you won't be traveling with this laptop or taking it home with you regularly, I'd suggest a slightly thicker, slightly heavier laptop with similar specs but that's just me. Overall, this is an excellent laptop. It performs very well for what it's made to do â€“ which is primarily productivity work. The display is lovely, the touch screen is responsive. All the features work without having to fight to get them to. The camera is pretty terrible in low light, it's less atrocious when you're well lit. Also the bezel is so thin that I don't think it would be easy to find a shutter small enough to cover the camera and not block any part of the display.

I bought this laptop as a birthday present for my wife five months ago. It never worked. The battery runs so hot you canâ€™t touch the laptop, it runs out very quickly, and the laptop expresses all the signs of overheating: slow processing and constant shut downs for no obvious reason. It took about two months of hassling Dell before Dell acknowledged the problem.

It took another two months of constant texts with Dell support before they sent somebody to look at it.

The person they finally sent spent half a day at our house without fixing the problem. Now we are back to texting Dell trying to get them to replace our laptop.

Bottom line: Dell sold us a broken laptop and refuses to fix it.

comment: I use an XPS 17 as my workstation. For going places though, this super small laptop can do everything I need. It has 2 Thunderbolt 4 ports (USB C) and a micro-SD card reader. I use the reader with a 1TB micro-SD to store all my reference files. This makes the 512GB SSD more than adequate. My XPS 13 has 16GB ram which is more than enough for the purposes for which I use this machine. My only wish is if one had a 5G option so I would have to use a Hot Spot connection. The 1920x1200 display resolution is perfect. The XPS 13 is too small to really use 4K properly and battery life on 4K laptops is significantly less than these HD+ machines.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
I found the design of this laptop to be lightweight and elegant, taking up little space. Though the laptop itself is slim and compact, the touchpad is pretty big and the keyboard has large buttons, both of which is convenient for me because my eyesight isn't very good. The top of the keyboard also features the video control buttons (such as play, stop and volume controls) which make it convenient to control from the keyboard instead of the screen, as well as a keyboard illumination button, screen button, etc.

The touch screen display is responsive and worked with no issues. I found the overall image quality to be superb and the sound quality to be decent. The camera quality wasn't perfect, but was okay for me. I also liked how the main screen was uncluttered and just had the internet browser and recycle bin on it, with the rest of the buttons on the bottom of the screen. Navigation was straightforward and I've had no problems with Windows 11. This laptop also features a fingerprint reader, for quicker logging in, which is nice. Overall, this laptop was high quality and I liked that even though it's small, it's powerful enough for my needs.

comment:
Dell XPS 13 9310 Touchscreen Laptop 13.4 inch FHD+ Thin and Light. Intel Core i7-1195G7, 16GB LPDDR4x RAM, 512GB SSD, Intel Iris Xe Graphics, Windows 11 Pro, 2Yr OnSite, 6 months Dell Migrate â€“ Silver

I couldn't believe how small, light, and thin this laptop was when it arrived! It feels like it weighs less than an iPad but is a full laptop.

It starts very quickly and smoothly. It was quite easy to configure. It is incredible how easy it is to set up a new computer these days - I remember the immense hassle that used to follow in the wake of setup disks and making everything the way you like it... Now, with this Dell, it was super fast and easy to set everything to our existing settings.

Once the ubiquitous bloatware was removed there were no pop ups and smooth sailing. It is a very fast machine, although we are using it mainly for cloud-based activities, so have not stressed the hard drive much. We are quite pleased with it!

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
TL;DR: This is a fantastic machine in almost every way that matters. It's not a gaming laptop, but you can play a lot of mid-spec games just fine. It's an awesome business device, and it can handle just about anything that would be considered "heavy" use at home.

I like my laptops on the small side. I was big into "netbooks" back in the day, and rarely aim for a screen size over 13 inches. More often than not those criteria mean that I'm stuck with something that's underpowered and underwhelming. Not so with this little beauty.

The processor, memory, etc. are all top notch, but you can see that from the listing. I'm guessing if you've read this far, you've probably done some research already on the "hard" specs, and now you want the more touchy-feely impressions.

So here goes: Getting it out of the box, everything screams quality, from the packaging itself to the shiny aluminum chassis to the slightly rubberized wrist area that helps hold your hands in position for typing. The screen goes almost edge to edge, with only about 1/2 cm lost to the bezel on each side. Turning it on for the first time was ridiculously fast, and even during setup everything felt snappy and responsive, whether I was using the keyboard and track pad or the touch screen. Both support all of the standard touch / pinch / etc. controls that we've all gotten used to. The touchscreen is responsive enough that I haven't fat-fingered anything on it yet, which happened often with some of my "budget" machines. Even better, the screen must be made of something that repels oils, since I haven't had to clean smudges off of it nearly as often as my last laptop (or my phone, for that matter).

On that subject, even on the highest battery optimization settings the screen is colorful and bright. Everything I've watched or done on it looks sharp and rich. That said, the screen doesn't angle back as much as I'm used to, so unless it's sitting on something on my lap, it can look a bit washed out unless I hold it at the right angle. That doesn't seem to be a problem from the sides, just from above. The sound is also surprisingly good for something this tiny. I listened to a few music videos on it at around half volume, and my wife could hear it clearly downstairs. I think they might even be louder and clearer than the ones on her gaming laptop.

Speaking of gaming, like I said, this isn't a gaming laptop, but the integrated Intel Iris graphics keep up surprisingly well for anything short of current gen AAA games. If you're playing within your specs, the image is sharp and clear, with no tearing or artifacting or anything else that would show the machine is falling behind. It also does a good job when used as a base machine hooked up to a larger monitor. Since I don't tend to do a lot of processor-heavy tasks like video editing, my other benchmark for use has been editing and slicing files for 3D printing. Files that took 30 or more seconds on my 4 year-old HP Elite Book with 8gb RAM and a core i5 processor take literally a few seconds on this Dell. My largest file of a dragon that took around 3 minutes before was done in less than 20 seconds.

Do keep in mind that this machine only has 2 ports for whatever you want to connect to it, one on each side. That said, they're both USB-C Thunderbolt ports, so a decent docking station can take care of any peripherals. Also, as a bonus, this means that you can plug the USB-C charger into either side, which solves one of my own annoyances with a lot of other machines. Maybe it's just me, but having the charger on the "wrong" side for however I'm sitting just throws me completely off, and I love not having to deal with it here. There's also a micro-SD reader for more memory, and a 3.5mm jack for headphones.

If I had to find anything to nit-pick, it would be the keyboard. The keys are nice and responsive, even though the travel is kind of shallow. But successfully making the bezel on the screen so small means the real estate available for the keyboard feels (to me at least) just a tiny bit cramped. I can still type my usual 70wpm, but I make a couple more errors than I do on a full keyboard, especially on any keys my pinkies hit. I also have to take an extra second when I need to use the 'delete' key (which I just did while typing "delete") because instead of being in the upper right corner like on most laptops, it's one key in from that. The upper right corner is the power key, which has caused me a headache or two when typing too fast. They wisely made that key just a bit "stiffer" than the rest, so a casual press won't shut off whatever you're doing, but I've still managed it a few times in around a week of use.

Battery life is good, even when I turned off all the battery saver options. I've used it unplugged for 4-ish hours and still had more than 1/3 battery life left. Heat management is also good; it gets warm on my lap after 30 minutes or so, but it's never been uncomfortably hot. Wi-Fi 6 is amazing if you have a router that can keep up with it. Even graphics-heavy pages load in blink-and-you'll-miss-it times.

So again, this machine is just awesome for anything but hardcore gaming. The price is an investment in a no-hassle everyday experience, with several perks thrown in. You won't be disappointed.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ XPS 13 9310 è§¸æ§è¢å¹•ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ 13.5 å‹ FHD+ è¼•è–„ã€‚Intel Core i7-1195G7ã€16GB LPDDR4x RAMã€512GB SSDã€Intel Iris Xe Graphicsã€Windows 11 Proã€2 å¹´ä¸Šç«™ã€6 å€‹æœˆé·ç§» â€“ éŠ€è‰²
comment:
This laptop has the latest, greatest new release Tiger Lake lntel Core i7-1195G7 processor. And it's a great looking laptop w/great specs. Build quality seems excellent. The screen is both bright and responsive. The keyboard feels good, although it has a slightly lighter touch than I prefer.

But...

It runs extremely hot, both on the surface and underside of the computer. You wouldn't want to use it on your lap or sitting on your chest, which by the way, is exactly how I often use it.

My MacBook Air with the M1 chip blows it away. Not sure which has better performance specs, but the MacBook Air has no fan, doesn't get hot, and takes everything you throw at it.

With the MacBook Air, you may get 14 or 15 hours of battery life out of it, with this Windows-based "state of the art" laptop, you might be lucky to get 3-4 hours.

And the MacBook Air was almost 50% cheaper than the Windows-based laptop ($899 vs. $1,700).

If you're in the market for a laptop and don't need to necessarily run Windows, the choice is clear. Otherwise, other than the issues mentioned, it's a perfectly fine computer and it's quite gorgeous. Is it worth the current asking price? Not in my view. 3 star rated.

comment:
I received a Stargazer STC5 E352372 2.5A 125V~ power chord cable. This is different from 7A shown in the seller's picture. This difference in the current rating didn't matter as the my adapter (DA130PE1-00) is rated for an input of ~2.5A, 100-240V, 50-60 HZ. The cable had 3 strips as shown in the image and fits well into Dell Inspiron 15 7567 Gaming's adapter (130 W DA130PE1-00).

The quality is quite good. Shipping was fast and secure. I can't comment on durability without using it for an extended period of time. I deducted one star from overall rating for providing images with misleading current ratings.

comment: Product is as described. It came with a display port to HDMI adapter. The reported Bluetooth and WIFI are accomplished with a provided USB dongle. It also came with a new keyboard and optical mouse. The whole package appears as new. I downloaded a more recent BIOS and drivers from Dell before also updating the Windows 10 Pro OS. I'm using this to replace a large tower. I love the small size. More recent CPU's and memory are available in some other low cost e.g. Precision 7060 and 7040, but this one had more memory, larger storage, SSD and Win10Pro. All I need. Very happy so far.

comment:
Technically, the system works, but this isn't what I expected. The shipment came with a 90W power adapter instead of the Dell 130W adapter. You will receive a message in system BIOS stating the adapter is the wrong size and the computer will run at less than optimal speeds. There is no way to contact the seller directly. Amazon will only offer a full refund instead of trying to correct the problem. I bought two of these computers and both have the wrong-sized power adapter, so I can only assume that going through the return process will yield yet another underpowered 90W adapter.

As a note, the solid state drive is a 2.5" SATA drive, NOT the much faster NVMe drive that is supported.

comment:
Purchased from STG Global (renewed units are lumped together so reviews are seller specific). Packaging was better than expected. Included was cheap mouse, cheap keyboard, tiny usb 2.0 802.11n wifi dongle and a brand new Dell 65w adapter.

Not going to complain about the mouse or keyboard, never planned to use them.

Easy to replace the sata SSD, m.2 NVME SSD and two DDR4 RAM. Only one knob screw to remove the cover by hand. One disappointment is there is no screw mount to hold the end of the NVME SSD. It ends right where the mainboard is affixed to the case with a screw. There is an extra M.2 connection for wifi/BT module (no built-in antennae). USB 3 ports transfer speed meets specs.

The unit is great for office work, browsing, watching media. It can even run PS2 emulator at 30-50 fps on most games with default settings but it gets hot quick. If you're going to do light gaming in a warm area, be sure to use a desktop fan to force air circulation. I'm in Philippines where we mostly use fans not air conditioning, ambient temps about 80f.

Was going to install Linux, but it works so well with a debloated Windows 10. Why fix it if it aint broke?

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 7070 MFF å¾®å‹å¤–å‹è¦æ ¼æ¡Œä¸Šå‹ç¬¬ 9 ä»£ Intel Core i7-9700T 8 æ ¸å¿ƒè™•ç†å™¨,16GB DDR4 RAM,512GB SSD,Intel UHD Graphics 630,Windows 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
I bought 15 of these for my workplace as it wasn't quite in the budget to buy new. The machines came as advertised, or at least as I expected them. Three had some damage to the connector for the wireless antenna. I could probably work it a bit to get them on anyway, but these are all using wired connections in my environment anyway. Some have noticeable fan noise, but some of the new models have this when you get in the micro form factor. The only truly disappointing thing about this purchase is the fact that every single one of them shipped with a defective power adapter.

I have spent several hours trying some way around it, but I've settled on postponing the hardware upgrade until the new adapters arrive. This is partially Dell's fault, to be fair. There is a chip in each adapter that "talks" to the machine and verify's that it's OEM and sending the correct voltage. If that communication fails (and old ones even if they're OEM often do), then the CPU will drastically underclock every time it boots. I know whoever refurbished these is aware of it because they intentionally disabled the warning that shows on POST in each of them. Resetting BIOS to factory settings made it start popping up again.

If you get one of these and aren't willing or able to buy a new adapter, there is a workaround I've found that won't work in a business environment well, but might suit you. Download ThrottleStop. Then from an admin account, create a scheduled task to launch the executable on any user login. That will bypass the CPU underclock, but it won't help things that take place before the first login (like Windows feature updates for example).

Another time I might be more lenient and give it higher than two stars, with all things considered. But I just finished wasting several hours on this trying to get these rolled out to a remote location... I'm more than a little miffed about it at the moment.
sku: å°ºå¯¸: Manufacturer Refurbishedæ¨£å¼: Micro Tower | 256 GB SSD | 8G Ram | I5

comment: To be honest the pc was is a very good condition. Had almost no scratches and the insides where very clean. Came well packaged with mouse and keyboard. However I can't give it more than 1 star. The system during the setup was kind slow for what it is. I noticed that the cpu was running @ 0.79ghz instead of 2.70ghz. Though it was throttling but temps were around 52Â°c. Runned a dell system upgrade tool, updated drivers and BIOS and nothing about getting the clocks back to 2.7ghz. Turns out, this issue is caused by 1- bad ac adapter 2- bad ac plug 3- motherboard/bios. Did some research and dell has some things going on with those small form factor pcs. Tested 02 ac power adapters from my old dell laptop and same problem. Did a bios reset and same issue. Checked bios alert history and it seems this has been happening since 2020. The thing is, if you are not aware about pcs, clocks, you may thing your pc is running ok and it is kind slow because it is a "old device" but in fact this system is well capable when runing at the correct speed. comment: Purchase this unit for a very low workload task, turns out the SSD drive crashed on me the second week, I opened the PC as I have a tech background and the drive was open with the void warranty sticker removed, and the manufacturing date back in 2015. So, a message to the seller, FYI all SSD drives have the ability to read and write a certain amount of times, as all blocks in the drive become unused through time of use, so please stop selling garbage. I initiated the return but was a challenge even trying to explain to the support team what was going on. You don't really get what you see. Don't waste your money.

comment: Itâ€™s an awesome computer! Lightning fast, big memory, big storage, latest WiFi and itâ€™s a DELL! I just want to draw attention to the fact that this is NOT a purchase from Dell. It was originally owned by PROTECH PC and a buyer canâ€™t register for the Dell warranty until the â€œownership transferâ€ process is completed. Then you learn thereâ€™s only 20 days left of the Dell warranty. I was able to extend the warranty for a year for $149 plus tax. Not a happy memory. So buyer, beware; there are surprises when you donâ€™t buy direct from Dell. Iâ€™m still satisfied, as the price from PROTECH PC was nice, and the product I received was awesome.

comment:
I received this computer on October 9 2023. The computer is very nice but I have only had it for two days. The problem should have "rang a bell" when I tried to use the keyboard and it was a UK keyboard. I also put the Service Tag into the Dell system and it showed that my "new" computer was originally shipped to the UAE on July 10 2022.
The computer was received by me after the 1 year Dell warranty had expired.
The Amazon product description should clearly indicate that while this is a "new" product it is outside of the normal Dell warranty.
I will probably return it to Amazon since the description of the product was misleading.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 7050 Micro Desktop,Intel i7,16GB RAM,256GB SSD,WiFi,éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,Windows 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment: So i work as a IT Director, i have built hundreds of desktops even Micro ITX. I wont say this product is completely perfect. However when taking to account that the CPU was thermal throttling really hard even when the computer was just idling temps were at 57 degree C. That may not seem entirely outlandish with a small desktop like this. However it can be concerning over a period of time. The Thermal paste was completely dry its really not hard to unscrew the cooler off and remove it and apply new paste. The two i bought work perfectly fine other than that. It came with a clean installation of windows 10 pro key was on there too. This system comes with a wifi antenna. Just be careful if you know what your doing i would advise making sure you put fresh thermal paste, if not ask someone you know or go to a pc shop to have them do it.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 7050 Micro Desktop,Intel i7,16GB RAM,256GB SSD,WiFi,éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,Windows 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment: Crazy fast, I mean, for a 4 years old PC this machine is really quick. Booting time is faaaast! My Dell came well packaged, clean, with no visible scratches, and the Wireless/Bluetooth internal card was installed. The USB Wireless adapter was included as well because they don't guarantee that the internal card will be present. I didn't used the included mouse and keyboard, instead I used a Logitech wireless combo, and I plugged this mini PC to a Alienware 34 ultra wide monitor. My micro PC has three video connectors, two DPs and one HDMI. I am currently using the HDMI and everything works fine so far. The AC Adapter that was included in my package is not a Dell Charger (the advertisement says DELL CHARGER), it is the universal type that you can change the tips, so mine came with the appropriate Dell tip. Just to be clear I am reviewing the Dell Optiplex 7050 Micro Desktop (Core i7 6700T + 16 GB DDR4 RAM + 256 GB SSD). This is a very capable office computer, or a you can use it as a media server or as a HTPC. Very powerful for your money!

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 7050 Micro Desktop,Intel i7,16GB RAM,256GB SSD,WiFi,éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,Windows 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment: I was almost discouraged from buying this from the few negative remarks but.... I found it to be complete with no missing components. The wifi and antenna were present and in working order. The power supply and jack were there and appropriate for this unit. It fired up first time and updated for bios and win10 right away. I've paired it with a 24 inch Acer display and it works perfectly for my needs. I suspect that it wouldn't run resource hungry games but the graphic card is more than adequate for my needs. It loads up quickly and programs run with no glitches. It's too old for Windows 11, but for as long as they support Windows 10, I'm happy with it. Recommended.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 7050 Micro Desktop,Intel i7,16GB RAM,256GB SSD,WiFi,éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,Windows 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment: I love the Dell Optiplex Micro models. I have purchase them for, and referred them to, my customers. This refurbished model is an excellent value for the money, especially with prices of new computers on the rise. I had been able to purchase refurbished Dell Optiplex computers through Amazon without any concern until the past few months. It really matters which company refurbishes the computers. I had to return several because of bad memory modules, the inability to run dual display monitors using the native video adapters, or a toxic smell from paint that was sprayed on the exterior of the computer (totally unnecessary). I always swap out the used hard drive or used solid-state drive with a new, larger, solid-state drive, so I cannot tell you about the condition of the drives. This computer arrived problem free. This refurbisher is doing a good job.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 7050 Micro Desktop,Intel i7,16GB RAM,256GB SSD,WiFi,éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,Windows 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment: On December 5th we notified the seller that the unit was not functional and going into shutdown mode. His solution was for us to fix his faulty product. He did send us the part, however the machine again failed. Again he asked us to repair it, sending us a $20 credit to find our own part as he had none available, yet again the machine continued to go into shutdown mode. After several attempts to reach the seller both through the Amazon message center and the email provided on his customer profile page the seller never responded. I filed a claim against the seller. Amazon even gave him a 48hr time to respond to them in which he did not, I gave him an additional 48hrs, still no response so a refund was requested, he magically appeared and requested me drop the request and guess what AGAIN he wanted us to fix his faulty product. He then proceeded to tell Amazon he would replace the item not mentioning to them it was only the part he wanted to replace that we have already replaced 2Xs he wanted to send us... not and entire functioning unit. I appealed the claim as I felt he lied to Amazon to get them to drop the request. Then he appeals stating it is out of the return/refund window. IF HE HAD DONE THE RIGHT THING ON DECEMBER 5th it would not have been. He gives Amazon a tracking # around February 5th for the part he wants us to replace for a 3rd attempt and guess what it is now February 21st and the tracking shows it has not even shipped. He claims it is because he is moving offices...I am too and my customers are still my priority. I have again appealed the claim and hope the seller does what is morally and ethically right as a seller and just give us a refund so we can purchase a functioning unit.

comment:
Like:
- Small compact simple PC.
- Runs well.
- HDMI Port and DP

Dislike
- Faulty power adapter plug, had to use my own Dell laptop adapter to power the PC.
- No built in wifi.
- Requires Ethernet to startup/setup
- No bluetooth, had to use the given keyboard with stucked keys rather than my own BT keyboard/mouse. I had to order a bluetooth adapter just for this.

Anyway I am too far to do any exchanges (additional cost involved) so just use the overseas shipping fees to get new replacement items would be more cost effective for me. Just hope seller thoroughly check their items and make sure its working before sending for consignment with Amazon.

It was fortunate for me that I had some old compatible stuff laying around. What if someome who was expecting a plug and play and ready to go PC? It is just depressing, feels like being deceived.

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 7050 Micro Desktop,Intel i7,16GB RAM,256GB SSD,WiFi,éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,Windows 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
Rather deceptive - the seller placed a piece of black tape over the nameplate of the PC. When I removed the tape, I see that it says "Dell Optiplex 7040". This means it's got an older Northbridge set, potentially slower memory and lacks a USB-C port (I should have noticed that part during unboxing). The CPU is a 4 core i7- 6700T so the performance shouldn't be that significant.

Not a significantly different machine, though I was looking to have a USB-C on all of the machines I upgraded. The biggest concern was the tape over the model number, which looks like an overt attempt to mislead. Next time I buy systems I'll make sure they aren't sold by TekRefurbs...

theproduct: Dell Optiplex 7050 Micro Desktop,Intel i7,16GB RAM,256GB SSD,WiFi,éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,Windows 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
I bought this to use as a Plex server and to serve files to my home network from some external hard drives attached to it. It works great for that.

The unit I received was clean inside and out, and well packaged with a Dell 130 watt power supply and a new-in-box Logitech wired keyboard and mouse set. The processor in this machine was an i7-6700. The internal drive was a Lexar 2.5" SATA 256GB SSD with a fresh Windows 10 Pro on it. The 16GB RAM was a matched set of SK-Hynix DDR4-2133 modules. (I believe that this motherboard will use 2400 speed RAM, but this is good enough for what I'm using it for.) There was no internal WiFi or Bluetooth in the computer but they sent a no-name USB Adapter that says "600Mbps 802.11ac" with it. I haven't tried the adapter since I just plugged this machine into an ethernet hub.

It would have been nice to have an m.2 SSD and the higher speed RAM, as well as the built-in WiFi and Bluetooth capabilities, but this does come with everything that the description says it does and it's working well so far.

I did notice that the CPU temperatures were running higher than I like, about 60C-70C during low usage (pretty much idling), so I pulled the heat sink and found the thermal past to be a little dry. After replacing it the temps are now about 30C idling and 55C-60C during moderate usage.

All in all, a nice little machine that I can leave on all the time and not worry about the power bill.

comment: If you're looking for a dainty little dock that fits in your pocket, this dock is not for you! I ordered this for my Dell XPS 17 (9720) after going through 2 other docks (WD19S and D600S) as they were not powerful enough to get fast charge and full running power/performance. I think the WD19S may have worked as far as power goes, but the seller put lies on their description and made me angry enough to return it. This thing has a 210W power supply and 2 USB-C charging cables that are lined up perfectly to plug into my laptop. It appears to be working great so far and there is absolutely no degradation in performance due to lack of power. The power supply is huge, so be prepared if you're concerned about space/clutter. I would definitely recommend this dock if you have a newer gaming/performance laptop. My only issue with it is there are only (2) USB-3 and (1) USB-A connector(s).

theproduct: Dell æ•ˆèƒ½åº•åº§ - WD19DCS æ“´å……åŸºåº§ é™„ 240W é›»æºè½‰æ¥å™¨ é©ç”¨æ–¼é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨ (æä¾› 210W é›»æºå‚³è¼¸;90W è‡³é Dell ç³»çµ±)
comment:
Great docking station. Photos of the item do not reveal the dual USB-C cables it contains to connect it to the laptop.

This docking station has a thick cable coming out of it that ends in a dual USB-C connector. I guess it needs this so that it can deliver the maximum power this laptop requires (I think max power over a single USB-C is 100W). The dual USB-C connector is unique in that the two connectors are keyed to fit together and held there with a magnet. So, if you want, you can separate the two connectors and plug just one in. This might come in handy if you have a different laptop you'd like to connect to this dock, but it has only one USB-C connector (and lower power requirements than the 7440).

This is a unique docking station, and I use it practically daily. I'm running two 4K-60Hz monitors and numerous USB-A peripherals from this docking station with no problems whatsoever.

If you need a dock for your Dell Precision laptop, consider this one - it's great!

With that you need to be careful and make sure there are no other sources of heat near them as they tend to be warm during use. For the price I would think that they would be a little more resistant to heat. Keep yours in the open and not enclosed. Donâ€™t stack with the power supply, but rather keep them separate and they will work.

comment: The dock has a couple of issues. FIrst there is an internal fan which keeps going off that gets annoying after a while. Second, and worse, is that if I use the dock with an HDMI monitor and try to screen share with Zoom, it causes the screen to flash on and off wildly until the port completely disconnects from the computer (with the usual sound). Last time I had to completely reboot my Precision laptop AND cut power to the dock to get my monitor working again. (Tried reboot first, no cigar. Had to do both.) I was trying to present on Zoom and that wasn't a good outcome. Since then I plug my HDMI monitor into the laptop port, that works, but nullifies some of the reason for shelling out big bucks for the dock. For the price, and connecting it to a NEW Precision 7760 (Late 2021) I'm not too impressed.

comment:
This uses 2 THICK USBC cables that don't lock into the laptop all that well. It's pretty easy to nudge one and have it come disconnected. You also need about 4-5 inches of space next to the laptop to fit these cables. they do not bend and if you push them it's easy to come disconnected. I had to order a second USB dock to attach to this dock to get more ports. Also had to order a USB->3.5mm headphone adapter because this doesn't have 3.5mm output or input.

Pros - this can provide a LOT of power and support 3 monitors

Cons - Dock is large. Power brick is gigantic. only has 3 usbA ports and 2 USBC ports. Portable is not a word i would use to describe this.

My old laptop had a dock that it snapped into and provided power and more ports. I wish this was setup like that and just used the 2 USBC ports to attach. This would also lift the laptop since mine seems to have pretty limited airflow under it.

Used on a Dell Precision 5570

comment:
The specs on the sticker attached to the box matched what I ordered, However, when I registered the laptop with Dell It told me that it was half the storage was 256 GB and 16 RAM memory. I verified my Amazon order just to ensure that it was not my erro. I verified I ordered and paid for 1TB SSD storage and 32 GB memory.
However after setting up that the computer and registering with Dell Dell showed the The same model with the specs as 512 GB SSD storage and 16 GB RAM which is half of the specs I ordered. I'm really not sure how this happened but I trust Dell to tell me computer be registered was not the same as I ordered and paid for it. comment: I have a Dell Inspiron 15 3583 that I bought in 2019. It was a $249 special, so it is what it is. I had the hard drive replaced 6 months ago with a more powerful, faster hard drive and it's been working great. Then about a month ago the battery stopped charging, and I was getting the error message "AC adaptor/charger not recognized." ??? I had to plug in the laptop to use it. I did some online research and this seemed to be a common issue for Dells, but I couldn't find anyone offering a winning resolution. So I purchased a universal battery for $25 and replaced it. Still didn't charge. Then I purchased a DELL AC adaptor/charger for $20. Still not charging. Then I purchased this DC power jack charging port cable for $7 and replaced it. BAM! LIKE NEW! Not sure if I needed all three, but after pricing new laptops it was well worth the $50 and all 3 items were very easy to replace. Nice tight "click" fit with the charger male into the DC adaptor port female. The battery charges quickly and lasts much longer than the original. Hope this helps.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ UltraSharp HDR 4K ç¶²è·¯æ”å½±æ©Ÿ,é™„éš±ç§ä¿è­·å¥—,HD USB é›»è…¦ç›¸æ©Ÿ,é™„ 4K Sony STARVIS CMOS / IR / æ¥è¿‘æ„Ÿæ¸¬å™¨,é»‘è‰² - é™½æ¥µæ°§åŒ–é‹ - WB7022 â€“ é©ç”¨æ–¼ Windows
comment:
Summary: Great picture quality, feel of high quality, love auto focus and face tracking.

Pros: Top tier Sony lens and CCD, the build is tight and modern looking, Windows software is much better than others have commented. Comes with additional desktop/shelf stand.

Cons: Long camera that does stick out in front of monitor a slight bit, like all add-on monitor cameras its not secured to monitor and can easily be knocked off. Some will not like that it doesn't have a mic, but I opted for an external dock with speaker and mic, so not big deal for me. Plus no webcam that sits on the monitor have speakers that are usable so you still need a speaker solution and all conference solutions have multiple noise cancelling mics in addition to speakers anyway. It also does not rotate, only up and down, but not many do. With AI face focus on this doesn't impact me as it follows my face. And lastly, of course it is pricey.

Summary: I wouldn't be surprised if Sony builds this for Dell as all the components are Sony inside. I found setup and use of the camera on Windows to be straight forward and had no issues. I see most of the negative reviews about the Dell software are Apple users. What did they expect buying from a retailer/manufacturer that is a competitor of Apple? Of course Dell isn't going to put as much effort into the Mac software/drivers. I found the AI face tracking to work perfectly. There is even settings for jump, slow or fast. Jump means it jumps without any motion. Obviously slow or fast mean it moves to your face. I use fast and find it seems most natural and least disruptive to viewers. I work in a low light environment or high light if I open the shades. The camera adjusts well to either situation. I couldn't ask for more. The camera runs only slightly warm for me, I had to touch for a little while to even notice it was above room temperature. It's possible others have gotten bad units and/or the manufacturer has resolved the issue since, or maybe I'm just lucky? Part of me thinks its just Logitech fans being hatters. LOL

This led me to search for a new webcam. I purchased this Dell webcam and a Yealink UVC30. Both had great image quality. I'm keeping the Dell, because its build quality/materials are clearly better than the Yealink. The camera does extend forward of the screen by an inch or so. Depending on the lighting, this could lead to a shadow on your screen. The one thing I don't like is the image isn't mirrored.

comment:
The camera is 4k, it's got a really nice design and mounts to my screen very nicely. It can also sit on the desk reasonably well too.

My favorite feature is the magnetic camera cover, when in use, the lens cap can be attached to the back.

My gripe is that for the price, the image quality isn't that good. I'd recommend a Logitech Brio 4k over this all day. I still kept this for my kids to use for remote school during covid.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ UltraSharp HDR 4K ç¶²è·¯æ”å½±æ©Ÿ,é™„éš±ç§ä¿è­·å¥—,HD USB é›»è…¦ç›¸æ©Ÿ,é™„ 4K Sony STARVIS CMOS / IR / æ¥è¿‘æ„Ÿæ¸¬å™¨,é»‘è‰² - é™½æ¥µæ°§åŒ–é‹ - WB7022 â€“ é©ç”¨æ–¼ Windows
comment:
I was so impressed with the manufacturing and engineering of this product as I unboxed it. It's so impressive and thought out. When I put it on my ultrawide, it looked like it belonged there. It's the perfect-looking webcam for me. I freaking love it.

I was a little worried it was dell when I purchased it. I never had good Dell experience, but the reviews are good.

Then my fears were confirmed as I started using it. Inside this very pretty exterior is trash dell software. It's supposed to be 4k, but the picture is always grainy, no matter what lighting. there doesn't seem to be a specific way to force resolution, and I tried the many setting with the required software but to no avail.

I also used it on my mac, with the same picture issue. So it's just a problem with the camera.

If anyone is interested, I ended up with Elgato, the rectangular front want. it's not as beautiful, but my picture is so good I tend to stare at myself on screen. Who is that handsome man?!

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ UltraSharp HDR 4K ç¶²è·¯æ”å½±æ©Ÿ,é™„éš±ç§ä¿è­·å¥—,HD USB é›»è…¦ç›¸æ©Ÿ,é™„ 4K Sony STARVIS CMOS / IR / æ¥è¿‘æ„Ÿæ¸¬å™¨,é»‘è‰² - é™½æ¥µæ°§åŒ–é‹ - WB7022 â€“ é©ç”¨æ–¼ Windows
comment:
First and foremost the design both spec wise and aesthetic is amazing. Easily the most beautiful webcam in some time. Camera quality is also very good. My only qualm is Dell does not from what I can tell specify what features require windows and which do not. Itâ€™s basically a dumb webcam with zero configurability or features like AI auto framing when used on Mac OS. The lack of this detail in descriptions leaves you to assume there is either Mac software or that the processing for these takes place on the hardware. It does not. All features are present and work very well on my PC but I primarily bought it for use with my Mac for work calls.

So if you intended to use the AI auto framing or dive deep into configuration and wanted to use it with Mac OS you should probably look elsewhere.

If you are intending to use it with Windows I donâ€™t think there is a better option unless you need a built in mic. The lack of one to me is a feature though as I value privacy.

If you are using a Mac and donâ€™t care about the smart features, the design and quality overall is really great but it is pretty pricy without those features in the mix.

It gets hot, very hot.
It starts dark and lightens somewhat slowly.

A couple likes:
Sharp image
AI framing works well
Nice mounting options.

Some of the options in the software is a bit scarce and we would love to have a for more picture tweaking options, but out of the box it doesn't necessarily need them. Works well in all lightning thus far.

Working in IT, I try to stay clear of Dell due to their proprietary computer crap, but for peripherals as in this case, they show they CAN be top of the line.

When I received this product (having spent over 200 for it) I noticed the seal on the box had already been breached. Looking inside I found that the plastic wrapping had been rewrapped around the product. So, I received a used product. That's problem number one.

I went ahead and tested the camera. For comparison I setup my other webcams which were all 1080p @60. The Microsoft cam was not getting a consistent 60 fps. I tried on two other computers and got the same results. Either this cam is defective or needs a firmware upgrade. For 200$ I expect flawless 60fps at 1080.

RETURNED

comment: The first one I bought was DOA, so I returned it for another. The second worked. I updated the software and the firmware, but the picture was terrible. It was grainy, washed out, and pixellated at any resolution. I couldn't get a good picture with the auto focus or by trying to focus it myself. I tried changing the settings in the Dell peripheral app, and using OBS, but I couldn't find any settings that looked good. With auto exposure on, the picture was way to bright. Turn it off and the picture becomes way too dark. It could just be the model I got, but it looks like this camera isn't ready to be sold. We have a Brio and an old C920. The 30fps 1080p on the C920 looked much better than 4k 30fps or even 1080p at 30 or 60fps on the Dell.

comment:
This product's headline feature is "AI Auto Framing". However, that feature is bogus - it does not work.

Enabling the autoframing mode simply switches the camera to the wide (90 degree) field of view and zooms all the way out. It does not give you the option to zoom in on your face, and it does not track your face.

Dell support is predictably completely useless.

My guess is that this feature is not yet actually enabled in software. They are shipping the product missing primary functionality because, hey, that's what you do in 2021.

If Dell can be bothered to reach out to me and explain how to enable this feature and make it work then I will update my review.

comment: I have previously used two Logitech cameras and decided to get this as a 4k upgrade instead of going with Logitech again. It does look like it has a good build quality, but it doesn't. At first, I had many issues using dell's software on my mac m1, and after six months, they finally upgraded the app and fixed many of the problems. Now out of nowhere, my camera cover broke while I had it on my camera. Please stay away from this camera; it has poor build quality. Go with Logitech. They never disappoint. Didn't expect this from a $200 camera.

comment:
The camera is very nice. Build quality seams great and produces a crystal clear image. With the software update the ai auto framing works a majority of the time. Every once in a while it will get lost. The exposure with a bright window behind you is terrific. A bright white computer screen background such as a web browser can wash out the imagine a little. One big hang up that I can not figure out how to fix is that it will severely reduce your bandwidth when plugged in even if you are not using the camera.
The attached pictures give a visual of this reduction in bandwidth and show a speed test with the camera unplugged vs camera plugged in but not being used.

comment:
Based on great reviews and specs, I bought this Webcam directly from Dell. It took a month to ship. When it arrived, it would only show a picture on the upper half of the screen.

I tried to get to Dell Tech Support, but couldn't get ahold of them. Finally, in frustration I sent it back (after big hassle to get return authorization). They promised to return my payment (about $200) in 15 to 30 Business Days after they received the return device. This was one of my worst customer service experiences in my life (and I am retired, so that's saying something). I have pictures that document this experience.

Ridiculous, given the price and the hype Dell is trying to generate. I would have expected this from a cheap knockoff second grade tronics manufacturer, but coming from dell this is truly disappointing.
