comment:
While using this webcam won't be nearly as good as a DSLR and HDMI capture box, this is as good as it gets when you want a simple USB-connected webcam setup. You are impressed right away with the weight and engineering of the camera. When it comes to value, this camera fully delivers at this price point.

Tips on software settings: You will want to turn off auto focus with the Dell Peripheral Manager. Otherwise it will adjust focus at times when you don't want it to. Also, change the quality setting to 4K UHD if you have software like OBS that can benefit from it. A personal preference of mine is to use the Smooth preset instead of Default because everything is "warmer" and more natural.

Most important tip: Get your lighting right. Cameras do so much better when your background is well lit as well as your face/body. I upgraded the ceiling light and got the "Unicucp 2 Packs 96 LED Dimmable 2400-6800K 97 CRI Video Light" set. If you already have a great webcam (such as the Logitech C920S HD Pro that I upgraded from), you are arguably better off investing in your lighting than buying this camera.

Happy with this purchase! When I do a before/after comparison with my old webcam and old setup, it's a massive difference.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ UltraSharp HDR 4K ç¶²è·¯æ”å½±æ©Ÿ,é™„éš±ç§ä¿è­·å¥—,HD USB é›»è…¦ç›¸æ©Ÿ,é™„ 4K Sony STARVIS CMOS / IR / æ¥è¿‘æ„Ÿæ¸¬å™¨,é»‘è‰² - é™½æ¥µæ°§åŒ–é‹ - WB7022 â€“ é©ç”¨æ–¼ Windows
comment: If you use Zoom for work, and I do essentially all of my work now on it, this is worth every penny. Can't believe I hesitated but there is a lot of cool shit you can get for the same price and it's just a camera, but this is super nice: Very wide field of view and the image is crisp, professional. I do hundreds of legal proceedings every month on Zoom and I can tell you, whatever you look like, whatever your house looks like, you will look in an entirely different class of human being than literally everyone else, if you have this camera. The build quality is actually really fabulous. I wasn't surprised, because I have an XPS13, but it really has some touches. And the software does too. You plug it in, it asks you what you want your default filter to be, it shows you as adjusts the camera and it's super slick, and that's it. It has motion features which I think will be useful, most importantly how it supposedly follows you when you're moving about. Not huge for a Zoom meet but if you are doing a real presentation and the camera does in fact pan like that while you are looking for something then it really will be worth the price of that alone, just making you look good while you're fumbling around. Great product.

comment:
It's only been two days, but so-far-so-good!

We needed an inexpensive desktop computer pre-loaded with Windows for my wife to use. Basically for email, surfing, playing simple games (solitaire) and shopping. Not demeaning my wife, it's just what she uses her computer for. This one was a good price. I've been a computer programmer for years and I know that I didn't need a brand new, top of the line, super-fast, computer for what this one's purpose would be, so I went with a refurbished one.

I did not need new monitors, which led to my only problem. My existing monitor cables were DVI style and this pc tower has ports for HDMI and VGA cables. A quick trip to Wally-World for VGA cables and I was good to go. This unit also had an extra slot and connectors for a second hard-drive, which I used to attach the hard-drive from our old computer. This made it easy to transfer pics and files from the old drive to the new one.

As stated, it's only been a couple of days, but it's working as it should.

Fingers crossed and two-thumbs up.

comment:
Iâ€™ve already reviewed the seller for attention (product was promised in 5 days, arrived in 2; and was appropriately boxed), and this is about the product:

The computer worked immediately, and with no issues. So far Iâ€™ve added a USB WiFi adapter, and have a BlueTooth dongle arriving tomorrow. The bios is from 2014 - so the computer probably wasnâ€™t built earlier than that - and along its life it picked up some dust in the â€œcup holderâ€ and the case showed the external wear expected of a 5-year-old device in institutional use. A quick look inside didnâ€™t cause me any reason to look any further.

Iâ€™ve purchased remanufactured electronic components several times - and have usually been happy. Some were touted as having no external blemishes - and they didnâ€™t. Those that were advertised as having some wear-and-tear (as in this one) did affect my purchase decision - but it eliminated surprises.

Back on the computer: I immediately hid it under a shelf (itâ€™s running my Amateur Radio station) - so the little blemishes are of zero consequence.

So, in summary - It works. It was close to what I wanted to spend. It was received in perfect shape. And it came with Windows 10 Pro.

Five Stars!

11 Month Update 6/2021:

I love this computer. It boots up and shuts down very quickly (around 30 seconds each way?). Mine came with an i5-4590 3.3 (instead of the 4570 3.2) processor. I just this week updated the 2014 BIOS to Dell's A25 5/30/2019 (per Dell's web driver scan/update) which suggests to me that the SMBIOS version 2.7 and the 2019 BIOS will give me another few years of update utility. Dell's online driver support is very satisfying.

I bought this as an el-cheapo ($290) replacement for an expensive/aged ($3,400/10 year old) Lenovo laptop (Core2 Duo - CTO T61p ThinkPad), and at less than 10% of the Lenovo's cost, this thing is much better at what little I've thrown at it thus far (except for portability). And it's quiet, runs cool, and my new 510 watt CyberPower SX950U UPS reports that it consumes about 31 watts (41 with the monitor) when it's idling -- and for short bursts of demand, around 91~95 watts (computer and monitor) - so my UPS is more than up to the task of keeping things alive until the generator spools up.

Update 7/18/21: I just updated the video driver (per Dell's very-helpful website) - just 'cuz. And I've also added a Phillips 27" 4K monitor -- and it (computer/monitor) works Great (although 27" is not "too big"). Despite the computer's birthday of 2014, it isn't showing to be long-in-the-tooth yet -- which makes me very happy.

Oh, and I sent back the CyberPower UPS (due to a weird issue - RFI sensitivity - and less-than-useful tech support) in favor of an APC BN1350M2 (810 watts) UPS -- which I rate Five Star.

The pictures included with this Dell Computer indicates it has 4 USB 2.0 connectors and 2 USB 3.0 connectors. It does not...this computer has 6 USB 2.0. connectors.

comment: I needed to replace an outdated pc, and found this one, which has great features and is an excellent value. The only problem I had with it comes from the fact it is a refurbished computer. Now, there is nothing wrong in that in itself; the problem is the company which previously owned it (before the Microsoft- authorized refurbishing company in Canada got it,) failed to remove a Chrome extension called "Advanced Analytics," which was installed by the previous owner in such a way the new user could not remove it. It took me phone calls and emails and chats to Google, (who could not figure it out,) to a phone call with the Canadian company who refurbished it (who wanted me to send it back to Amazon,) to a phone call with Amazon, who wanted me to send it back for a refund, until finally I was able to find the parent company of Advanced Analytics, who after an email and 2 phone calls, solved the problem for me, by contacting their client (the computer's previous owner,) and asked them to remove the block on the extension for that computer. Which they did writing within a couple of days! The computer is lightening fast and fun to use. I'm very happy with it now. I would suggest, if you buy one and find this file extension installs when you put Chrome on there, find "Global Analytics" online and give them a call. They're very friendly and helpful.

Update: 3/15/2023

As of now the computer is still running perfectly and there are no other issues thus far. I'm currently using it as a server for my discord Bots, and two minecraft servers I run. I intend on using it for more.

comment:
This is a tale of two PC's.
I needed a business machine for our library and wanted to it to be a reasonable cost. At first I ordered a renewed Dell 7010 from a company in Texas. The unit came with the video not working. despite numerous attempts to clear up the problem, I finally had to return the unit to Amazon.

I then ordered a Dell 9020 SFF, Abys Electronics did the renewal , and the difference was very noticeable. This unit had no blemishes on the case and it actually looked polished to a brand new luster. The new and boxed keyboard and mouse looked perfect and operated perfectly as well. Unlike the earlier unit, which I emphasize did NOT come from Abys Electronics, this unit was a delight to use. Windows 10 came up in a flash and the video was perfect. I installed my favorite office suite program. The PC did not come with WiFi installed, as expected, because it was not mentioned in the listing. I have a WiFi dongle with antenna arriving tomorrow. When it gets here, I plan on installing our HP Laser printer.
Thanks, Abys Electronics, you restored my faith!

theproduct: Dell RGB é›»ç«¶æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ Intel Quad Core I5-6500 é«˜é” 3.6GHz,GeForce GT 1030 2G,32GB DDR4,1T SSD,RGB éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,600M WiFi å’Œè—ç‰™,Win 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment: I have to confess, my expectations of a $280 refurb Win10PC were not all that high. I knew the Optiplex series were built for a business environment with better components than a consumer machine. The computer arrived in a single box cradled in foam spacers and wrapped in a recycled plastic bag. The supplied keyboard and mouse were cheap, but I already had better on hand. Note...this machine has VGA and Dual Displayport outputs, so there was a bit of digging to find a DP to DVI cable in my stocks. Initial boot from the 500GB SSD was fast and smooth, as was setup. The Windows 10PRO activation went without a hitch, something you can be burned on if you go too cheap from a reseller. There was a very minor ding in the plastic face of the DVD drive. This model has a generous layout of USB ports, with both 2.0 and 3.0 front and back. The supplied Wi-Fi dongle is VERY flimsy, I had a bad moment when it came apart on me while I was changing USB ports. However once I snapped it back together and seated it, all was well. The primary use for this machine was for my Amateur Radio operations, and it serves the purpose. The 16GB of RAM lets me have several applications running at once. This is not a game machine, and the small form factor and power supply won't fit a fancy GPU, but performance wise, the quad core i5 is up to most tasks and videos run smoothly. It was nice to find a old school serial DB9 port on the back when a lot of old ham radio gear uses that connection still. All in all, considering the cost of a new 10Pro License, this workhorse PC gives solid bang for the buck when you don't need latest/greatest. As a bonus it's nearly silent operating and has a minimal footprint while not feeling cramped when plugging in externals.

theproduct: Dell RGB é›»ç«¶æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ Intel Quad Core I5-6500 é«˜é” 3.6GHz,GeForce GT 1030 2G,32GB DDR4,1T SSD,RGB éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,600M WiFi å’Œè—ç‰™,Win 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
Although the amazon description includes wifi capability, this box didn't have wifi. It turns out that Wifi was an OPTION when buying the original unit new... tough to upgrade later if your refurb doesn't have it:

From the Dell site: "When ordering an OptiPlex 3020 / 9020 Micro system, you have the option of including the Intel Dual Band 7260 802.11AC w/Bluetooth wireless networking kit (wireless card, mounting bracket, cables and antenna) in the system....
!! Factory Wireless Kit cannot be added to system after purchase. !!
If the wireless networking option was not selected at the time of purchase, then the factory kit cannot be installed after purchase because the mounting hardware is not available for sale after system purchase to install the wireless card."

If the Optiplex 9020 you buy does not include wifi, I'm not sure how much work it is to get this going. You probably won't be able to know if you got the wifi version until you turn the box on. As I said above, the description claims Wifi is included (but it wasn't). View "Device manager/network adaptors" if there is no wifi listed there then the box does not support wifi.
Just to be sure, I added a dongle, which did not work, it was not recognized in "Devices". Evidently you will need to buy a wifi card as well and possibly upgrade the BIOS? I didn't bother with that. But if you decide to buy a card be sure you find one that will fit in this small form factor box.

comment:
I am going to try my best to report my overall experience with buying a renewed computer as this is my first time.

I design and create wood art in the form of cornhole boards, wood flags, mosaics, etc. I have been wanting a desktop computer for quite some time so I don't have to keep transporting my laptop around the house. So now I have two work stations. First of all, I did a lot of research into different computers and I could not argue with the price vs the operating power of this machine, which is amazing. I ordered this computer the first time around and it came in quickly! However, I plugged the computer in and it power cycled continuously, in other words it did not work. The keyboard and mouse that came along with it were cheap and the right click only lasted one click and then stuck (I was testing the product). I did an exchange immediately with amazon (for entire product), which they fulfilled and shipped out a new product even before I returned the old one. Excellent customer service as always!

The second computer came in within the week! Even during this pandemic! I plugged it in immediately (as I was little excited), the computer fired up properly and is lightning fast! I am impressed with the product at this time! If there are any issues I will update this review! Also, my recommendation is to buy your own keyboard and mouse. The new one I received work ok, but I had already ordered nicer products, as the ones that come with it are cheap.
Do not be scared of a renewed product! Amazon guarantees them! If you are worried about a hard drive issue, then buy an external hard drive. They are not very expensive. I had no problem with the product exchange as I do realize it is a renewed computer and there is the risk of issues.

theproduct: Dell RGB é›»ç«¶æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ Intel Quad Core I5-6500 é«˜é” 3.6GHz,GeForce GT 1030 2G,32GB DDR4,1T SSD,RGB éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,600M WiFi å’Œè—ç‰™,Win 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
Even though my 3-person family does just about everything on either a laptop or smartphone, we still have a desktop office computer for those things that you would do while sitting at a desk. We don't use it for gaming, just simple word processing/presentation creation and Internet browsing. The one we had was dying; looooong load times indicated that either the motherboard or (more likely) the hard drive was reaching the end of its life (10 year old computer). I considered a new, high speed desktop with a separate graphics card and all the bells and whistles, but I already have a laptop for that. All I needed was a basic computer, so that's what I bought.

This computer arrived on time, and it was nicely packaged to ensure it didn't get damaged in transit. I don't know how old this computer is, but the condition of the case looked brand new. I removed the cover to look at the guts, and there were no signs of any dust or previous use. Don't panic if you don't see a power cord. The cord is in the nicely packaged keyboard box, along with the keyboard (duh!) and a wireless dongle. Lots of USB ports on this baby (10!), but it also has a few legacy ports like serial, PS/2, and VGA.

Set-up was easy. If you've never had a computer with a SSD hard drive, you will be amazed at how fast it is. Remember, this isn't a gaming computer, but it still boots and loads much faster than a "traditional" computer. The refurb company didn't load any bloatware on the computer, just good ole Windows 10. The only prompt to purchase anything additional was the expected Office 365 prompts.

So far, (this is day 3) this little computer is doing exactly what I purchased it for. For that reason, it gets a 5 due to 1) cost, 2) appearance, 3) no bloatware, and 4) operates as expected.

I forgot to leave a review. First, when the product arrived there was some damage to the product I notice a huge big dent. Second, my in-house IT, notice that all the features were hidden. Then it was working one minute then it stopped. we call the number on the white label on the pc for help/assistance. He was so nice, advised him that there was no disc with the computer and we couldn't unlock the pc. He walked us through it in less than 5min. This computer works as if it was brand new, I haven't had any major problems/issues since the tech guy I called walked me through unlocking the computer to erase the last person info off the pc. The only minor issue is the black power cord keeps coming out. Everything appeared brand new except for the huge dent on one side of the computer.

Windows 10 Pro works like a charm. I work from home remotely as an independent contractor using other companies' software. I thought I was going to be very upset with this refurbished computer. Most companies require you to have an Intel Core i3 or above when working from home. This was a smart move for me to save some money. The computer works great. I have a 3yr warranty in case something major does happen. So far so good!!! If anything happens major under warranty I will post it here.

I forgot to mention that he DVD/CD player does not work...

comment: This is a great system at this price. I like when I find a good "refurbished" deal because I know that it has been thoroughly tested before being shipped. I wanted an up to date system for my 84 year old Dad so I could get them set up to pay bills and do some banking online and he is loving it. So much that now Mom wants one of her own. I CAN NOT SAY HOW GOOD THIS SYSTEM IS FOR GAMING BUT IT SURE SEEMS FAST COMPARED TO MY OLD PERSONAL GAMING RIG......so fast that I think I'm kind of jealous now..... It comes with everything except Monitor. I knew this ahead of time, got monitors stacked in the closet. Was up and running in minutes. But with every new system you have to go through windows updates etc. Then I spend an hour deleting and cleaning out the useless windows crap apps that they always put in there. When I'm done it is a nice smooth fast running computer. Very happy with this purchase again!

theproduct: Dell RGB é›»ç«¶æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ Intel Quad Core I5-6500 é«˜é” 3.6GHz,GeForce GT 1030 2G,32GB DDR4,1T SSD,RGB éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,600M WiFi å’Œè—ç‰™,Win 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment: I always buy Dell refurbished PC's. The first I bought around 2011 and it had 2GB of RAM and did the job but kind of slow. A couple of years later I replaced it with a refurbished Dell with 4GB of RAM and that one was a workhorse for 4 or 5 years until just recently, then died presumably because of the graphics card dying. I figured "why buy a replacement with 8GB of RAM. Let's just go the extra mile and get 16GB of RAM." Smart move!! When it arrived I just plugged my WIFI adapter into one of the USB 3.0 jacks in the back, along with 2 external hard drives, the mouse and keyboard. It booted up and with very little setup I was up and running in minutes. The i5 processor always runs around 3.55Ghz instead of 3.20Ghz. I can have Chrome running with 6 tabs open and 3 other programs minimized and the memory is barely even used. IE there is RAM to burn!!! It's only been a little over a week, still working flawlessly. Music/audio coming from the line out to an amplifier and big speakers sounds great! I intend to use this to record my own album on with a mixer going into this PC via USB. When I get around to that I will update this review. I have every confidence this PC can handle any DAW and whatever music I record with ease. No tech support has been needed. Any games I play are online and play perfectly. Buy this thing! You won't be disappointed..

comment:
With Core i5, 16GB RAM and 512GB SSD, it can take on regular office computing activities without a sweat. It's quite responsive, thanks to the CPU and the SSD.

In addition, it has two display ports to a legacy VGA port, and also USB 3 ports in the front and at rear. All that adds to office productivity.

While refurbished, it arrived clean inside and out, with only one short line of scratch at the bottom side of the case, which is, to me, not a problem at all. It has been running for almost 2 weeks straight and it still runs very quietly and doesn't heat up.

Overall, great buy, price wise. I do hope it will last long years before it retires. Meanwhile I did wish to get one with a 1TB SSD (even if to pay some more) if I hadn't had a deadline of having a test machine up and running.

theproduct: Dell RGB é›»ç«¶æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ Intel Quad Core I5-6500 é«˜é” 3.6GHz,GeForce GT 1030 2G,32GB DDR4,1T SSD,RGB éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,600M WiFi å’Œè—ç‰™,Win 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
We got this because both of us were suddenly working from home and realized our 5-year-old laptop had issues and the school issued Chromebooks could not handle Zoom very well. It comes with a very cheap corded keyboard and mouse and nothing else, so you will need to get your own monitor. It's small enough to put on the floor under your desk if necessary, and it's FAST! Setup was very simple and easy to navigate, but have all your various Microsoft credentials handy as you will need them multiple times.

There are several USB ports on the front and back and a CD drive which is a bonus since we occasionally have the need to view odd media like photos or a DVD of our kid's play that only come on a disk. Our son uses this PC to play Roblox, a very CPU-hungry game, with no issues. One thing I do not like is that the keyboard is very lightweight and has no rubber pads on the bottom, so it will slide around while you type unless you put something hard in front of it. We are using a wireless keyboard, wireless optical mouse, USB Snowball condenser mic, Logitech webcam, and a Google Home speaker with ours. Comes with various video outputs on the back as well. The computer does not come with WiFi or Bluetooth, but dongles for both are readily available and work well of you don't want to or can't LAN it to your router. You should also know that if you don't have a licensed copy of Microsoft 365, Windows 10, MS Office, or whatever, you will need to buy one to completely set up this PC. We are using a school-authorized copy (my husband is a teacher), but we still get the watermark to "complete Windows setup" in the lower right corner. You can also connect your phone to this PC and cast your screen and media to it just like you can with Google Chromecast or Amazon Fire TV or most other smart TVs. Cool!

theproduct: Dell RGB é›»ç«¶æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ Intel Quad Core I5-6500 é«˜é” 3.6GHz,GeForce GT 1030 2G,32GB DDR4,1T SSD,RGB éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,600M WiFi å’Œè—ç‰™,Win 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
I've purchased refurbished computers in the past, and never had issues with any of them. This unit arrived in a state that prevented me from setting it up for my personal use. I contacted the seller, and they walked me through several different processes in an attempt to allow me to log in. After a couple of days back and forth, and needing to buy a new flash drive in order to download Windows and reinstall it on the unit, I was finally able to use the computer.

After installing all of my personal files and settings, I went to use the disc drive to install software for my home business (which I'd already missed almost a week's worth of work getting the PC up and running), and found that the tray won't open. It does not respond to either the button nor the UI prompt. It doesn't even appear to be hooked up inside the tower as I hear no mechanical sound when trying to open it.

I again contacted the seller, who offered to send me a replacement drive I could install myself. Problem is, I can't install it myself and I don't feel like compromising the unit futher by tearing it apart. Buying an external drive or having a replacement installed will cost me extra, on top of what I've already spent/lost with the unit malfunctioning. The seller then offered me a partial refund of $12.

Needless to say, this was an insulting offer. I feel I was very reasonable and patient with the software obstacles, but I've been delivered a unit that was supposed to be guaranteed refurbished and it clearly was not sent through Quality Assurance to verify it would work for the person who purchased it.

Thankfully, Amazon has rectified the issue by offering me a promotional voucher for a more reasonable amount. The seller stopped responding to my messages after I expressed my displeasure with their offer.

All in all, the PC is working well--aside from the still useless disc drive--but this has been a headache since day 1 and I can't say I'd recommend this seller to anyone looking for a refurbished computer.

comment: Product came on top as promised. Packaging left something to be desired. The styrofoam around the computer was too small for the box it was in; so there was some wiggle room in the box for the computer. Thankfully, it has an SSD; so no damage upon opening. The keyboard and mouse are pretty low-end, but for the money I wouldn't expect much more than that. Powering up and activation was breeze. I should have read the description a little closer. There is NO WIFI adapter; thankfully, I had a TP-Link USB wifi adapter lying around, and it was easy enough to put that in. The other thing is that it does NOT have a HDMI output. Again, I had a spare LCD monitor lying around with VGA input; so I just used that, and it worked fine. Machine boots up in less than 30 seconds. No bloatware on it, thankfully. For the price, I'm well-pleased with it. It runs speedily enough for home productivity and streaming video; so I have no complaints. It's not compatible with Windows 11, but as fast as it runs Windows 10, I don't really care if it can run Windows 11. An excellent bargain!

comment:
Got a few of these from Skytech (provided A+ service every time I rang). Fully engaged, professional, accessible and knowledgeable. Have peace of mind now for the next year (+bought another 3 year warranty for only around $23). If/when there's a possible issue (hopefully not) this particular model seems to check every box for my needs!

Needed to return another model as it simply didn't meet expectations. Amazon def. stuck to their word and provided a care free, non tedious return process! (just make sure to do it well before that 90 days). So far, seems like a very good call on my part. While the difference for the exchange ended up slightly more, the processor and graphics card def. seem superior!

Basically no bloatware or junk. Super clean, fast set up even w/ many gigabytes of files I needed to transfer and install (~ just 40 min.) Looks & feels nearly brand new. Came w/ a standard mouse and keyboard. Appear to be sturdy enough. Added bonuses if I ever need them.

Only wish atp is I get a good 3+ years (minimum) with what I see now and how it's operating thus far!

theproduct: Dell RGB é›»ç«¶æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ Intel Quad Core I5-6500 é«˜é” 3.6GHz,GeForce GT 1030 2G,32GB DDR4,1T SSD,RGB éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,600M WiFi å’Œè—ç‰™,Win 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
I trolled around Amazon for several sessions, looking for a decent computer for me. I don't game, so that entire topic is irrelevant to me and those in the higher levels shouldn't be looking at computers in this price range, anyway.

I will start with my only complaint: The seller doesn't tell you that the WiFi is via a dongle that goes in a USB port. I was wondering what it was for when inside the box with the wired keyboard and wired mouse, the little gadget was sitting, with no indication of what it was.

When I first fired up this computer, and started to set up Windows, it only showed an Ethernet adaptor and no WiFi. After scratching my head for a couple of minutes, I remembered the dongle and plugged it into a USB port. Success!

This little desktop has a lot to offer: a 64-bit version of W10 Pro, 32GB of RAM, dual DisplayPort video ports, lots and lots of USB ports, a DVD R/W and 512GB SSD. You will need to get inexpensive HDMI adaptors if your monitors won't work with DisplayPort. That was about $15 to take care of that.

Everything came up perfectly (once I connected the WiFi dongle) and I was in business.

I mainly go on the internet, run spreadsheets, word processors, play music, watch the occasional film and use it extensively for running Amateur Radio applications. It does all of this without getting sluggish.

theproduct: Dell RGB é›»ç«¶æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ Intel Quad Core I5-6500 é«˜é” 3.6GHz,GeForce GT 1030 2G,32GB DDR4,1T SSD,RGB éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,600M WiFi å’Œè—ç‰™,Win 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
Overall, this was a very good deal (price) and the product is performing well.
However, there were a few issues I found upon opening the box and setting up the computer:
1. Case was damaged with a dent in top and the Dell Logo missing from front
2. Description stated 512GB SSD - Product has 480GB SSD. BIG DISCREPANCY!!!
I should get a partial refund. I will keep the product but this is NOT GOOD.
3. The keyboard and mouse that were provided are VERY CHEAP/LOW QUALITY products. I DO NOT EXPECT THEM TO LAST LIKE OEM PRODUCTS.

Good points:
1. Good price for the system.
2. Arrived on time and in "reasonable" condition. SEE ABOVE. Damage does not appear to be from shipping. The Dell logo from the front of the computer was not broken off in transit. It was not in the box.

Other Comments:
Please provide the TRUE country of origin fo this computer.. Is this a Chinese knock-off that you refurbished to "current standards"? I know it is an obsolete model, no longer produced by Dell. However, I would like to know if it was a US surplus, returned product, 3rd party copy, etc.

Again, I am please (SO FAR) with the performance of your product with the exception of the SSD specifications.
I only with that sellers provided 100% accurate descriptions.

comment:
We needed a desktop computer to replace our 20 year old Dell Dimension. This old thing is still working but takes over 15 minutes to boot and is definitely struggling to keep up eventually working painfully slow, we couldn't take this any more. We only use our household computer for online shopping, booking flights, simple Word documents and other simple tasks. We are in our fifties and don't do gaming. We needed a desktop PC again because we need a port for our printer to print receipts, flight tickets, boarding passes, etc.
This new PC arrived today, setup was less than 10 minutes and it boots and works lightning fast. We are so happy! I am sure this PC will last us for the next 20 years :-)

You cannot beat this company for the incredible value backed by excellent customer service.

comment: My 12 year old son loves Minecraft so he wanted a computer for his birthday. We took a chance on this tower after reading mixed reviews. It is perfect for him. theproduct: Dell RGB é›»ç«¶æ¡Œä¸Šå‹é›»è…¦ Intel Quad Core I5-6500 é«˜é” 3.6GHz,GeForce GT 1030 2G,32GB DDR4,1T SSD,RGB éµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼ ,600M WiFi å’Œè—ç‰™,Win 10 Pro(ç¿»æ–°)
comment:
For most people looking for a cheap desk top I think this is a good buy. The ram and ssd and cpu while outdated by today's standards will be enough for anyone who isn't either gaming or video editing. The real question is how long will this device last before a component brakes or it slows down. If I can get 2-3 years I will be happy enough (not I did not by the warranty) .

Here are some buyer warnings:

1. There is NO WIFI CARD! I was stupid and didn't notice this when I bought the product. I am buying a usb wifi adapter, but for now I am rocking a supper long Ethernet cable until it arrives. Please plan on buying a wifi card/adapter along with the product if you want that capability (they are fairly inexpensive).
2. The included windows 10 doesn't recognize the headphones I plug into the headphone jack. Note that this is a windows 10 issue. I have configured my pc to dual boot with linux and on linux I do not have this issue.
3. These are 2.0 usb ports. This means that data rates are slower and may be incompatible with some modern devices.

hope this helps.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ DA20 USB Type-C è½‰ HDMI/USB Type-A è½‰æ¥å™¨ ç›’è£ çµ„ä»¶é©ç”¨æ–¼:XPS 15-9500 ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ XPS 17-9700 ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ Precision 550 è¡Œå‹•å·¥ä½œç«™ Precision 5750 è¡Œå‹•å·¥ä½œç«™
comment: The adaptor was provided to me through work for use with a Precision 5550 running Windows 10. Whenever the adaptor is connected, audio plays the device connecting sound followed by the device disconnecting sound repeatedly. Muting sound can avoid the incessant noise. Lately, however, the adaptor no longer works for the mouse USB-A bluetooth dongle reliably. Plugging and unplugging the adaptor into the USB-C port will sometimes eventually work after 5 minutes or 30 minutes (watch video in the meantime.) Using the USB-A port on the docking station has always worked so the dongle is functional. My corporate IT at work was stumped by this. I have no privileges to even run USB diagnostics. I would stay away from this Dell product and especially if you are not tech savvy or like to spend time debugging a companyâ€™s products.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ DA20 USB Type-C è½‰ HDMI/USB Type-A è½‰æ¥å™¨ ç›’è£ çµ„ä»¶é©ç”¨æ–¼:XPS 15-9500 ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ XPS 17-9700 ç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦ Precision 550 è¡Œå‹•å·¥ä½œç«™ Precision 5750 è¡Œå‹•å·¥ä½œç«™
comment:
I had a need for three separate HDMI outputs from my laptop when hosting a Zoom conference, so I connect ed two of these to the two USB-C ports to get the extra two outputs. I first tested the capability by borrowing a couple of these devices from friends who had them with their computers. My laptop instantly recognized them, and I was able to go into the display settings and add two additional displays.

The two extra USB 3 ports (one on each adapter), also worked as expected and came in handy.

I like that the short cable folds into the back of the adapter for storage when not in use.

This converts a single USB-C port to an HDMI port and a USB3 port. It works as expected, for my Precision laptop, and I am happy and satisfied with the purchase.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ WD19TB Thunderbolt æ“´å……åŸºåº§,é™„ 180W AC é›»æºæ•´æµå™¨(130W é›»æºå‚³è¼¸)
comment:
I had a Dell WD15 dock I've used for several years with my 3 year old XPS13. The last 6 months I spent trying to replace the Dell with a Surfacebook 2, a couple HP Spectre X360's, and a couple Surface Pro 7's. But all went back due to my issues with docks and the multimonitor setup I need at my office. None worked with the WD15. I picked up the Surface Dock 2 for the last Surface Pro I tried, and that had its own issues. I had a Wavlink for the HP's, as well as a Belkin thunderbolt 3 dock, both had issues. So I decided to stick for now with my XPS13 and the old dock. But after all that testing, the old dock had issues with the displays being seen... So it was time to replace it.

I had hoped this would work just fine with my Dell, and for the most part, it does. The WD15 was rock solid with this, never an issue, but with this new one, I have had a few times I've had to power cycle the dock to get it to work again. Firmware is updated on it, but a few times when I plugged it in, I had no monitors, and a pop up warning on the computer saying that despite being plugged in my laptop wasn't charging because there wasn't enough power. Considering the size and output of the power supply, I found that a bit annoying.

But mostly it works, about 95% of the time.

There is a slight fan noise once in a while but it's usually lost in the ambient noise of the office space here.

One of my favorite parts on it is the USB C power delivery cable, since it's more flexible than just about any other dock I've had. So it bends around and I don't have issues lining things up easily for where my laptop is positioned on the desk. Even the WD15 dock was a much stiffer cable and had to be in a specific spot so the cable would reach correctly where it had to go.

I've got one 4k monitor off the display port, and a 27" QHD monitor off the HDMI. And other than a couple random points where they weren't seen at plugin, they seem to be fine.

It's a bit pricey compared to the alternatives, but after all the issues I've had messing with docks lately, I just wanted something that would let me use things again and not spend all my time troubleshooting like the Wavlink one I tried.

comment:
Well, I hate to bring this information to you, but the attachments to your computer are once again being changed to be very small like the one for your cell phone and there are only 4 of them and a card aperture. So if you have the old popular flat connectors they will not fit with your new $4000 Dell Computer, which is a wonderful product with wonderful support and amazing features to customize to your own taste, but if you are like me, you are inundated with the old flat, long connectors who also need a home, and because of that need you need this docking station. Additionally, the docking station has a place for the Ethernet cable and some other accoutrements, not to mention that with my lap top will completely blackout if it connected for too long to the portable charger, which means that I have to hold down the start button for a count of 25 seconds and then call for Dell service intervention to reconfigure it, one must have a docking station if you want to make sure that you have a full charge all the time, until such time as you want to move it or take it with you elsewhere, because this docking station will meter the charge and not overcharge the computer to forestall the problem in the first place. This is the only Docking Station that can be used with my: Device name DESKTOP-6RVFLFK

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ WD19TB Thunderbolt æ“´å……åŸºåº§,é™„ 180W AC é›»æºæ•´æµå™¨(130W é›»æºå‚³è¼¸)
comment:
I've always wanted a single cable solution. I purchased this dock for my brand new Dell Precision 5750 with a Xeon W-10885M CPU and 64Gb of DDR4 Registered memory and 2TB (1TB x 2 raid 0) nvme SSD and the NVidia Quadro RTX 3000 GPU. I use 3 x 3840 x 2160 monitors and thought that I could use this dock to drive the three displays and leverage my nVidia GPU. Didnt work. The HDMI Port detects the 4K monitor as a 2560 x 1440 monitor. It detects the other two monitors as 4K monitors, but only delivers 30Hz refresh rate which is crappy. I almost returned it, but then decided to take my Razer Core X with a Quadro P4000 GPU to the thunderbolt 3 port available on this dock. It worked!! I am now able to drive three displays at 3840 x 2160 @ 60Hz which is great for desktop use. Single cable. It also charges my laptop fairly well. So I decided to keep it. Other docks DO NOT charge the Precision 5750 or the XPS 17, as these laptops do require 130W from the dock to charge them. Having a Razer Core X stowed away behind my two Dell P317Q monitors and the (center) PHL BDM4350 monitor seems to work reasonably well. The P4000 is a great card for programmer use. I am disappointed with Dell for not delivering a single cable solution that can leverage the RTX 3000 through TB3, but I have a solution that works!!
This may not be the solution for everybody, but if you are wondering if you can daisy-chain a Razer Core X or another TB3 Graphics enclosure, that will work. Note that the Razer Core X has enough power to drive pretty large graphics cards. I also have a Razer Core V2 and while that worked, it resulted in some pretty strange USB behavior when I tried to use its USB ports. So your mileage with other TB3 eGPU enclosures may vary. The P4000 is a single-slot GPU which only uses about 150W of power. But My Razer Core X has worked well with other larger cards as well including an nVidia GTX 2080ti and Radeon Vega 64 (Mac use). Unfortunately, if you have a Quadro laptop, you can use an AMD GPU, but you cannot use the GTX gpu and the Quadro GPU together. For some reason, one of the GPUs have to be disabled and this results in some system instability. If you are using Quadro, stick to Quadro or AMD. If you are using GTX then stick to GTX and AMD. Back to the topic of this dock, I didn't want the hassle of returning it as it is the only dock that gives me a single-cable solution and enables me to daisy-chain an eGPU, charge my laptop and connect my other peripherals. Working for me. YMMV.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ WD19TB Thunderbolt æ“´å……åŸºåº§,é™„ 180W AC é›»æºæ•´æµå™¨(130W é›»æºå‚³è¼¸)
comment:
In short: wrong product was sent (not a unique case), the product was not new, and the existence of the fan noise (while not that loud) is not to my liking.

-----------------
1. The model I was sent was not the WD19TB, but the WD19TBS (notice the last character?)
this meant that it does not have the Audio Jacks on the front and back as advertised. (a pretty big feature if you ask me)
I now see that other people have made that same complaint in this product review section.

2. It came to me dirty somehow. Sealed in non-labelled plastic bags, the power brick still managed to be dirty when I opened it and a smudge on the actual Dock. While I wouldn't have minded this product being labelled as Refurbished (or maybe even used and/or returned) this product description has no such detail in it's listing. Now I can't help but doubt the quality of the product.

3. Never expected a fan in the item, but it's there and it's louder than I would like. Don't use in a silent environment unless you enjoy the "white noise" of a fan constantly going. I'm using this in my home office so I don't have people talking around me or the white noise generators at work. Sometimes I want it perfectly quiet instead of music playing and the fan is annoying during these times.

comment:
I have a laptop attached to a Dell docking station so I can use my monitor, Ethernet cable, external hard drive, et alia. The monitor would not turn on. So I then plugged the monitor into a small round mobile docking station I have and presto- it works again. I did one other test, opened Zoom and tried to get my webcam (attached to the big Dell docking station) to work. No dice, but it will work if I unplug from the Dell and plug into the mobile docking station. Also, the light on the docking station will not come on. So I'm pretty certain it's the Dell docking station that's at fault.

I attempted to get help through Twitter's DellCares. The person on Twitter with me said my service tag and Express service code could not be verified. I took a photo of the info on the back and sent it to him/her. They then asked for a copy of my invoice. I pasted it in. Then several hours went by... no response. Still waiting, 2 hours and 20 minutes later. Guess I'll buy another docking station... not a Dell this time.

The first thing to notice was that the inner box with the device and its accessories had had had a sticker that someone pulled partly off. The sticky was still on the box, and a part of the sticker remained. This makes me suspect that it was not brand new when I got it. The company did ship it through Prime, but it was not from Amazon. The Dell site sells it for a good bit more, and perhaps this is how they manage the low price.

I had had the older TB16 which suddenly failed out of the blue, as I was opening a Word document. Nothing would restore it. So I ordered this newer version, hoping for fewer problems, and it worked immediately, for just over a week, at which point the lightning bolt on the plug that goes into the computer would no longer light, which means it is not being recognized - the same issue I had with the TB16.

On a lark, I plugged in the TB16, and it works fine now.

IMO these docs, and the flimsy Thunderbot/USB-C plug and socket, should be a lot more reliable, hence one star.

I bought this to run my dual 1440P monitors from either my XPS 9330 or my Precision 5540. I only wanted one cable to plug into power all my USB peripherals, monitors, and external hard drives where everything "just work" on both of my machines. When I first plugged the dock into both of my machines, the monitors worked great, but the USB devices didn't recognize in Windows. The good news is I finally stumbled upon a post where I had to go into my BIOS and change a setting to remove security from Thunderbolt (I did this on both of my machines). Once doing this the dock works perfectly. Maybe this detail was mentioned in the instructions, but I'm not one to ever read manuals.

comment: The Dell WD19TB Thunderbolt Docking Station is an essential tool for anyone looking for a convenient and reliable way to connect their laptop to multiple devices. With a wide range of ports, including USB, dual display, and Thunderbolt, it makes it easy to connect all your peripherals in one place. The ability to connect two displays at once is a game-changer for multitasking and productivity, and the quality of video output is impressive. Setting up and using the docking station is a breeze, and it has become a daily necessity for me. If you're looking for a versatile and user-friendly docking station, the Dell WD19TB is an excellent choice.

comment:
This review is for the Dell Dock WD15 with 180W Adapter, USB Type-C.

I am very pleased with this dock, but I just recently purchased it and there have been a few BIOS updates to the Dell Precision 5510 and a few firmware updates for the dock, so I may have missed all of the bugs that have been fixed with the earlier software. The BIOS updates for the 5510 are easy to find, the firmware updates for the dock are not as easy. When going to the Dell support site, find the BIOS and driver updates by typing in your Service Tag and searching. Select the option to find the updates yourself and down near the bottom of the page in the "Other ways to find drivers" section and click the link to "Browse all drivers..." and the dock firmware should be in there under WD15.

Once the firmware and BIOS are updated, the dock seems to work very well. The only issues I have found with it are when I plug the USB-C cable in, the laptop starts up if it was off and my monitors display the correct screens, but my USB keyboard doesn't work until I get past the Bitlocker screen. This means I have to open the laptop, use the laptop keyboard to type my Bitlocker password, then close my laptop screen to go back to my dual monitor setup. This results in another minor issue that occurs rarely. After closing the laptop, only one of my screens is working, so I go to the display options and see it still considers the laptop screen one of my screens, so I have to open my laptop and close it again to get the laptop to recognize the screen is closed.

Other than that it works great. I have two of them, one for home and one for work. My home one uses the Mini-DP and the HDMI for video, Ethernet, USB for keyboard and mouse on the back, and USB on the front for an external hard drive. My work one uses the HDMI and VGA for video, Ethernet, a USB hub on my monitor that has keyboard, mouse, and USB headset, plus an Engineering tool on the back ports, USB on the front for an external hard drive and USB memory. So each are fully loaded and I have not had any display issues (other than the easily recoverable one I mentioned), speed issues to the external drives, or connection issues to the external Engineering tool I interface with.

The only other downside is, I just got a new personal laptop around the same time (Dell Latitude E5570) that I thought would be compatible with the dock (since it is mentioned on the Dell WD15 website), but it isn't. The E5570 I have only supports the old E-port docking station, which I still have, but now I have to use both and switch my monitors, keyboard, and mouse back and forth. Using and old KVM and a couple HDMI switches made it easier, but not flawless.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
Finally, a dock that works on Linux, USB-C, and charges my computer.

I have tried 4 separate docks, Dell's TB15 and TB16 and two from Plugable. The TB15/16 were truly awful products. Each had their own problems: disconnecting the video, dropping Ethernet speeds, garbled audio ports, USB disconnecting, overheating, weird conflicts with strong WiFi signals. Pretty much everything that could go wrong with those docks did. The Plugable docks actually worked *wonderfully* and they have great customer service, but their products are misrepresenting compatibility with the ability to charge an XPS 15 9550 through the USB cable. Their docks that claim Linux compatibility worked great, but I had to keep the power plug into the computer. I wish I would have tried this dock first.

On to the WD15. I'm running Ubuntu 17.04 with kernel 4.12. All BIOS updates have been applied, as is critical for any USB-C/thunderbolt functionality to work on these recent Dell machines. For the most part, that means installing Windows to apply the updates. While BIOS updates can be applied from DOS, dock updates MUST be done from Windows. So expect to install WIndows 10 (I recommend Rufus to install it on an external drive) to get everything working.

With all updates applied, this thing works AMAZING. I only power a single external display, but I use nearly all ports: HDMI or DisplayPort both work fine, I've got ~4 USB ports occupied, audio out the front port, and ethernet. All work, no drivers or special downloads needed for the dock itself under Linux. I've run the internal and one external display both with the nVidia (running nvidia-381 package) and Intel graphics (with drivers installed from 01.org). All the usual hoops of getting something to work on Linux aside, this dock works great. Audio has been completely consistent (a near miracle).

Even with my XPS 9550 power demands, charging through the USB-C port works. It doesn't seem to have any power charging issues as the Plugable docks did. The dock even seems to work okay with sleep and resume. Although occasionally I do have to unplug/replug after a reboot. Some times the second display does not immediately wake up, but a quick trip to the Displays control panel or cycling through the display options with F8 fix the issue for the duration of the session.

The only small issue I've had is that external USB hard disks seem to start up and spin down repeatedly when plugged into the USB ports and the computer is asleep or unplugged. This does not seem to be a Linux issue because it happens even if the computer isn't plugged in. For now I'm simply plugging it in after the computer is awake or whenever I need to do a backup.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
Update January 20th, 2017: I've upgraded my 3 star review to 4 star. With the latest firmware updates, stability is improving. Flickering is almost entirely eliminated at this point. There are still issues getting it to come back from Standby from time to time, but this is rapidly approaching "good" status.

I am using this with an XPS 13 9360 (Win 10 pro), which is Kaby Lake based.

First off, this will EVENTUALLY be a great piece of tech. The dock makes it so all you need to plug in is a single type-C cable, which is super awesome. It charges your laptop, has multiple displays and tons of ports, and it all works pretty well for a business environment.

HOWEVER... it's unstable as hell. As of 11/16/2016, there are so many problems that I can't possibly roll this out to my entire company. Here's some examples:

- If you boot the computer with the dock installed, any usb devices plugged into the dock will freeze up for about 1 second every 10 seconds. You have to unplug the dock, wait about 15 seconds, then plug it back in to fix.
- Monitors will begin randomly flickering, then stop flickering.
- Monitors sometimes don't get detected properly. You must unplug the dock, wait 15 seconds, then plug it back in to fix.
- Ethernet will just shut down for about 5 seconds every once in a while. No discernible pattern.
- Getting system to resume out of sleep mode is completely hit and miss. Sometimes you can hit keys on the keyboard to wake it up, sometimes you can hit the power button on the dock to get it to work. Sometimes you have to undock and open the laptop up.

I think that all of these issues are entirely due to how early the tech is. It may be fixed by drivers or hardware revisions. But at the current time, while this is very exciting, it's just not ready to roll out en-masse.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
I exclusively use this dock with Linux. In particular I'm using a Razer Blade Stealth previously running Ubuntu 16.04 and currently running Arch. The dock works "okay" most of the time. I realize that neither Ubuntu 16.04 nor Arch are officially supported by this device, thus I'm limiting my negative assessment to 3 stars instead of 2. That said, the hardware should be pretty universal and it being officially supported on Ubuntu 14.04 should mean that I would have no issues on newer operating systems presuming I have the appropriate drivers installed.

So let's get down to it. The charging works great. It has consistently worked with no issues so I can't fault this device here. Charging of USB devices also works fabulously.

The "Displayport over USB-C" functionality generally works well but with some quirks: displays using the VGA port can be very slow to wake up; and displays using the mini-DP port will sometimes randomly cut in and out after waking up (a quick fix normally requires locking the computer and waking it back up again). The issue persisted across both operating systems so I'm blaming the dock. I should also note that I have two of these docks (one at home, one at the office) and the issue is persistent across both of them. That said, I haven't had any issues with display recognition nor have I had driver issues.

The networking also generally works. Occasionally the system won't recognize the wired connection. This generally isn't an issue because I have pretty reliable WiFi access both at home and at work, but it's still worth noting as I can see how this could be a problem for some people.

The USB ports and headphone/microphone jack worked about 40% of the time on Ubuntu and don't work at all on Arch. This is kind of annoying because I have to keep separate USB hubs and I can't just leave a pair of headphones permanently connected to the dock. Part of the promise of this dock was to have everything working with a single cable and now I require a minimum of two. This isn't a massive issue or anything and is easily worked around, but it's still really annoying.

Anyway, I purchased these over the Thunderbolt 3 docks due to price, size, and me not requiring the extra functionality of Thunderbolt 3 over standard USB-C. Additionally the reviews for the Thunderbolt 3 version left me somewhat skittish as people were reporting problems with officially supported operating systems. I fully intend to experiment with other USB-C and Thunderbolt 3 docks in the future and I have no intention of keeping these should they continue to not meet my needs in the future.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
I picked up the USB-C dual display dock on warehouse deals new with damaged packaging for a great price. Overall, I've been very happy with this device, once the set up is out of the way. I am using this with one of the new (Kaby Lake) Inspiron 13 7000s. I'll deal with set up at the end for any one interested.

I like that the size of the dock is so small, and thus it doesn't take up much room. I also chose this option because it gives 3 different display connections (although it will only output a maximum of 2 extended displays). Also, the power delivery works great with the Inspiron, although I've read that it won't deliver power to non-Dell machines over 60 Watts, whereas Dell gets up to 130W.

I also like that there are 5 USB ports, and the lack of a dedicated USB-C doesn't really bother me. On my dock, one of the front-facing USB3 ports doesn't work, hence the subtraction of a star. It's not enough to return it, however, as competing options are twice as expensive, and the pluggable has had a number of reports of the dock frying the laptop.

So, if you're looking for a single-cable solution, I think this is the best option out there, and the price is an added bonus.

To set it up:
1. update the bios (go to the manufacturer's website and look in the drivers & downloads section for your machine)
2. install the displaylink drivers (go to the displaylink website and download the drivers for your operating system).

This second point is important, as dell, at least for my machine, hasn't posted drivers for the dock yet. But the displaylink ones work flawlessly, and from what I hear, often are newer than the ones on manufacturer's websites anyway.

comment:
I'm not sure why this has mixed reviews. It honestly made me a little hesitant on buying it. However, Amazon always has a great return policy so I figured I had nothing to lose. I'm so glad I took the chance.

I was super pleased with the set up. It was easy and very straightforward. It displays beautifully on two dell displays and I also tried it with my one acer x34 gaming display. However, I bought this for my office work. I have hooked it up to my Dell XPS 15 (9560) and MacBook 12 (2015). They both work flawlessly with the two Dell displays. They both charge and output like they should, for the most part.

The Mac displays to both, but they are mirrored. The Mac also was very finicky with the Acer x34. I think that is the Mac not being able to push that many pixels or possible resolution issues, however it does read both Dell displays and reads the x34.

The XPS 15 displays to both dell displays and the x34 perfectly. (Not all three at the same time of course). I don't know if it is the XPS or the dock, but I when I have the two Dell displays or the x34 hooked up I can open the lid and it comes right up as another monitor. Then when I flip it back down it goes back to the original setup. No hiccups what so ever.

The sleep button on the dock works great too. I've had no issues, like other reviewers, with hitting the sleep button on the dock and then coming back from lunch and hitting it again. Within a few seconds I'm at my Windows login and ready to go. It has had no issues picking up the three different keyboards and two different mice I've tried. (I like to test everything I can in that 30 days)

I would not hesitate to buy another one if I needed it. I really have tried to throw everything I can at this dock so I could justify a return. However, this thing has performed PERFECTLY! (Well minus the few things with the Mac, but it's a Mac so I half figured it would've blown up when I connected it.)

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment: So far, I'm pleased with the dock, and while I wanted to give it five stars, there were quite a few extra steps to get it working; it wasn't quite plug and play. In order to get it to work, I had to install the thunderbolt firmware, the thunderbolt power firmware, and then the ASMedia USB 3.0 extended host drivers from Dell's site; I used the XPS 9550 to page to get the USB drivers specifically. After that I plugged it into my Alienware 15 R2 and it just worked! I was definitely scared by the numerous bad reviews for the triple display dock, but so far I haven't had any of the issues described with the dual display. I figured I'd give it a chance since Amazon's return policy is so great, but will definitely update if I run into issues. Like others, I am confused by why they looped all of the reviews together for the different models as there is definitely some discrepancy between them. One thing to note is that this will not provide power if your system requires over 130 watts of power; mine asks for 180. I also wouldn't recommend this for an enterprise roll out quite yet as firmware might need to be updated on each individual device in order to make this dock work. I'm sure you could work a firmware update into the OS deployment, but this will require testing/tinkering before being confident that all thunderbolt / USB Type-C devices in an environment will work with it. Otherwise, it's great for use at home, adds some needed ports, and definitely makes cable management easier.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
Up until Mac switched to Thunderbolt 3, we exclusively used Thunderbolt Displays with our MacBook Air's and MacBook Pro's at the office. When Apple switched to Thunderbolt 3, we could not longer use our Thunderbolt Displays with new MacBooks without kludgy adapters, and we couldn't provide power to the laptop with the Thunderbolt Display at all.

This dock is a good replacement for the Thunderbolt Displays when paired with a good standard HDMI monitor. The big caveat is with the Mini DisplayPort connector. I tried using one of our old LED Cinema Displays with it, and the maximum resolution I could set was 720p in MacOS. Next, I tried a Dell UltraSharp U2715H, and while there were a lot more resolution options, it was about vertical pixels short of choosing the native resolution of the Dell. Switching to HDMI solved that problem: macOS automatically picked the correct resolution.

The side effect of this is that with macOS, because of the mDP issue, we can't run dual monitors at a decent resolution from this dock. I would assume that this is a macOS driver issue. Hopefully it will be addressed.

macOS also doesn't require any external drivers or software. We plugged it in, and it worked.

We plugged a Windows machine into the same dock with mDP, and it worked fine. My assumption is that you could drive two displays from a Windows machine with no trouble.

This dock has me considering upgrading to a 2016 MacBook Pro or 2015 MacBook. We'll see. ;)

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
Update: three things to be aware of - 1) check the Dell web site for monitor resolutions the WD15 supports. While it worked fine for my current monitor at 1920x1200, it will not support the higher resolution monitor that I plan to get in the near future. Therefore, I had to return this and get the TB16 instead; 2) the TB16 has a MUCH shorter USB-C/Thunderbolt cable attached to the dock which may be good or bad depending on your situation; 3) USB and sound output from the dock didn't work until I rebooted and received a prompt stating I needed to go through a couple steps as Administrator to allow the Thunderbolt connection to the dock. Until I got that prompt I was concerned the ports were not working for some reason.

After many years with a Dell E-Port dock as the foundation of my home office setup which lasted through many Dell laptop upgrades, I was mildly surprised to find that the Latitude 7480 did away with the legacy E-Port connector. I was then dismayed to see inconsistent if not poor reviews of the WD15 and the TB16 as well as the WLD15 wireless dock. I decided to give this WD15 a try since it was the least expensive and has the ability to be mounted behind certain Dell monitors freeing up desk space. First, Amazon Prime delivered it in less than 16 hours! Second, upon plugging in power, monitor, and laptop, everything works fine. I don't know what to make of the complaints others have posted. Power, video (I've tried both VGA and HDMI-to-DVI with an Amazon Basics cable successfully), audio, Ethernet, and USB devices (wireless keyboard and mouse, USB microphone) all "just work". To me this is better than the wireless dock since the wireless can't provide power meaning you still need to plug the laptop into its own power supply. With the WD15, the USB-C/Thunderbolt 3 connection provides power and device connectivity more or less like the old E-Port dock used to do.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
The Dell WD-15 is expensive, especially considering itâ€™s just a black box, but for my purposes it was well worth it. The most amazing thing about it is that it connects to everything, and I mean EVERYTHING, through USB type C. You can connect the included charger, up to two displays, up to FIVE usb devices (three of the USB ports supply power), speakers on the back, headphones on the front, and even Ethernet for a hardwired internet connection. And yes, ALL of that electrical information (video, audio, mouse and keyboard, external storage, internet connection, you name it, AND power to charge your battery) passes through a single USB-C cable that comes out of the side of the dock. Truly amazing.

As an engineering student who is constantly using my tiny Dell XPS 13 laptop, I find it very refreshing to plug my laptop in to charge when I get back to my dorm and simultaneously use it with my 25 inch monitor, mouse, keyboard, and external hard drive to work on things that are easier with these peripherals.

I could not recommend the Dell WD15 highly enough.

P.S. Remember to install all the drivers from the Dell website. This is not a â€œplug and playâ€ device. It takes a little setup before you plug it in for the first time.

P.P.S. Get the 180W version. When I bought mine, it was only like $15 more than the 130W version and itâ€™s worth it for faster charging and ensured support of lots of peripherals. (If you have a bigger laptop, you may need the 180W for your machine to even charge. Check the Dell website to see if itâ€™s required for your system)

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
I recently purchased the â€œDell WD15 Monitor Dock 4K with 180W Adapter, USB-Câ€ from eDealerTech (an Amazon seller). eDealerTech is very helpful, providing additional support documentation, and the seller maintains a support line if you need additional assistance.

I am very happy with the â€œDell WD15 Monitor Dock 4K with 180W Adapter, USB-Câ€. I attach the dock to a Dell XPC 13 9365 laptop using the USB Type C port, connecting to a 4K monitor (via the HDMI port), RJ-45 Ethernet port, a USB 3.0 device, and USB 2.0 device. The USB Type C port charges the XPC laptop while maintaining all the connections. Itâ€™s useful having both USB 2 and USB 3 ports because some devices (such as older wireless mouse devices and keyboards) are not compatible with both USB standards and require either USB 3 or, USB 1 or 2.

I am not experiencing any of the problems some buyers here report with the Dell WD15 Monitor Dock. I am using the dock in a small business setting with a Windows Server and 14 workstations. My HD monitors look great with no flickering, the gigabit Ethernet port runs very fast, the USB 1/2/3 ports are flawless.

I believe the problems I see people reporting with this dock can be avoided by updating their computer's BIOS and drivers. I did this and the dock is functioning perfectly.

Based upon my experience with the â€œDell WD15 Monitor Dock 4K with 180W Adapter, USB-Câ€, I can comfortably recommend this product with no reservations whatsoever.

comment:
Disclaimer: I am using this with a non-dell computer (ASUS Zenbook UX390UA). Upon receiving the item, plugged it in and it was recognized and all the USB ports worked however no video. Did some reading to find that Dell had released firmware to flash. Attempted it with my non-dell computer and no luck. Further reading revealed that it can only be flashed from a dell environment. Luckily my buddy had just purchased an XPS 15 and we tried it out with his computer. Same result at initial use no video. Flashed it and instantly video out works. His XPS 15 does not charge with this however my ASUS does. His XPS 15 requires 90watt my Asus only 65. The dock has 180watt power brick so who knows why his XPS doesn't charge but I guess that too is well known.

3 stars for the facts above summarized as follows:
-Will work with non-dell systems however REQUIRES a flash to enable video out from a Dell environment (i.e. you have to use a Dell computer to do it)
-Does not provide charging to XPS15 system (90watt requirement) which is odd as that is Dell to Dell. Does provide power to my ASUS (which is a 65watt requirement)
-Every once in a while when plugged in it doesn't pass power requiring a quick unplug replug. Not a huge deal as my laptop battery lasts more than 8hrs in daily use but just beware.

comment:
EDIT: Upped from 2 to 4 stars due to firmware and BIOS updates fixing a lot of the mess. Leaving my old review below for completeness' sake. That said, I'm now running kernel 4.7.6-ZEN with BIOS 1.4.4, everything works except audio (card is detected and PulseAudio swears it's playing through it, but the card definitely is unusable) and there's occasionally miniDisplayPort flickering (a replug of dock will usually fix this). Not sure I'm keeping the XPS or the Type-C dock; I'm partially waiting to see what docking solutions Lenovo brings on the X270 whenever it launches, or maybe bailing to a Spectre x360.

Even after a firmware update, only the power delivery and video outs work correctly in Linux (connected to an XPS 13 9350, kernel 4.6). Ethernet is untested. USB connections seem to drop after about 5 minutes of use and require a replug to work again (only briefly - the issue seems to loop). Audio isn't functional at all, but this is seemingly a kernel-level issue.

comment:
I originally loved this dock -- it was convenient, and allowed me to carry my laptop from work to home with single connection convenience. That was 7 months ago, when I first bought it. In fact, I bought 2 - one for home, and one for the office. Now - 7 months later - the video port on the dock at the office no longer works (video shows - then goes black - then shows - then goes black - repeat ad infinitum...). And in a fun twist, the video port on the dock at home is the ONLY port that works. So now I find myself plugging in a variety of cables directly into my laptop, depending on the location and the ailment of the particular dock I'm connecting to. I appear to be out of the warranty period, so I'm stuck. Dell's old "snap the bottom of the computer onto the deck" hardware was much more reliable.

UPDATE: Ok - I spent some time working with Dell tech support, and have mostly resolved the port issues. It required a number of driver updates, along with a BIOS update. I'm still seeing some odd behavior with a USB keyboard that's plugged into it, but it's mostly back to correct functionality.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
I bought this to use with a Thinkpad Chromebook 13. It worked partially, but I'll be returning it:

Features that work:
1) Power over USB-C
2) All USB ports
3) Audio
4) Ethernet
5) Any *ONE* of the video outputs

Features that did not work for me:
1) More than external monitor (deal-breaker for me)

This dock uses "DisplayPort over USB-C" alternative mode (alt-mode) for video out, driving the external monitors with your integrated graphics instead. It's supposed to support dual monitors via "extended mode", but no mater how I tried to tweak the settings in ChromeOS, it would only ever detect one monitor. This may be a limitation of ChromeOS, I don't know. I'll try again sometime in the future when USB-C and it's alternative modes are more common-place.

In the meantime, I switched to using the Dell D3100. It uses regular USB 3, so it won't charge the Chromebook. It has a DisplayLink chip built-in (essentially an external video card). So it has a little more lag, but seems pretty well supported by Chrome.

Give the dock a few mins to 'see' the device and eventually it picks everything up and you are good to go until the next time you unplug one of the devices. When this happens I just reboot my laptop, wait for a few mins and everything kicks in. comment:
I have a dell XPS 15, 9560.

I use the single usb-c cable from this product to my laptop.

The hub:
- provides power to my laptop over usb-c
- is connected to one 1080p monitor via HDMI
- is connected to my headphones
- is connected via usb to my phone
- is connected via usb to another 4 port usb hub
- is connected via usb to an external 2.5" HDD
- that 4 port hub is connected to several other minor usb peripherals

from my laptop over the usb-c connection i have no problems seeing any of the items connected to the hub, never had any problems with the monitor displaying, and my laptop is always charged.

I think the important thing is to make sure the correct drivers are installed and up to date, and that any bios related settings are correctly configured on the laptop.

comment:
read the fine print is my advice. contrary to my high hopes of a thunderbolt 3 "infinite" bandwith, this adapter cannot run a 4k at 60hz, even if the only display. I still dont understand why, if a simply thunderbolt 3 to display port can do 4k at 60hz, why not even if nothing else is running at the same time this docking station cannot do it.
also, if I check disk speeds of a SSD, I get 400mbs of two I tested indivdually, but if I run two tests at the same time for two ssds connected, I get about half the speed (245mbs in one disk, 155 in the other), so this is simply bottlenecking despite the more than abundant bandwith of the thunderbolt 3 port. so my advice, that if you can afford some cable clutter, just get a thunderbolt 3 to display port, and a usb 3 replicator. that and a hdmi cable, should give you 4k 60hz, 1080hz, and decent speeds for anything except NVME type of external disks; this dell adapter does not do much more. I dont know if any graphical/CAD professional would buy this if you lose 60hz option.
