comment:
I am using the Dell Dock WD15 with an XPS 13 9350 that I bought a couple of months ago. I connected it right out of the box and it worked, but after a minute, I lost the USB keyboard and mouse. The monitor port remained operational. After looking up a solution, I found that Dell had a forum post that instructed you to update bios and drivers to fix the issues with the USB ports.
[...]
I unfortunately decided to not return the dock since some of the post on Amazon stated that it fixed the issue. If I would have read the posts on the Dell forum, I probably would have made a different choice. I installed all of the software in order, and everything seemed to work. Even the USB ports on my connected Dell monitor were operational. After letting it sit for a few minutes, I came back and I had lost the USB ports. The computer had gone into sleep mode, so I figured that may be the cause. After restarting, the ports came back on and I turned off the sleep setting when plugged in.
This apparently did not work. I have lost my USB ports again.
Do not waste your money on this Dell Dock until they can fix these bugs. The only thing that works is the monitor connection, and you can purchase an adapter for the Type C port for just a few dollars. I have a laptop that was designed for this dock and it still does not work. For $140, this dock should work right out the box. I will continue to look for a solution and update the review if I find one.

Do not buy this dock!

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
I was excited for this product so I could connect 2 monitors to my new Lenovo Yoga 910 laptop. The laptop has USB C for power and a separate USB C for display.

Right after I received the dock, I plugged it into the USB C display port and it didn't work. The laptop didn't recognize the monitor that was plugged into the dock and the USB ports on the dock were also unavailable (I connected several USB drives and my phone and nothing was recognized). After doing some reading online, someone mentioned that I needed to update the firmware. I went to Dell's website and followed their instructions and downloaded the firmware update. I'm not sure if the update was successful since my experience during the update was not even close to Dell's documentation.

Regardless, after the update, the dock did recognize my monitor and it appeared to be working. However, the display would flicker on and off when connected to the dock. It would black out for a second or two before coming back online. This would occur several times a minute. Pretty frustrating. The USB ports on the dock still don't work, even after the firmware update.

The dock does power my laptop when it's plugged into the power USB C but then I don't have access to the extra monitor. I mainly was enticed by this device because of the power capability and the extra monitors. I can ONLY have one or the other and not both.

This product is pretty much a fail. I now have an overpriced laptop power charger and will now need to get another device for the multiple monitors. I don't recommend this to anyone.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
Since the reviews in this section are all mixed up between all the different models, I'd like to clarify that this review is for the Dell 180W USB-C 4W2HW version of the dock.

I tested this dock on the new Razer Blade Stealth, and it functioned perfectly:

1) Power works, it charges the laptop just fine, and all external ports work
2) Video outputs work just as they should - I can extend or duplicate my desktop
3) The unit is large - it has a bulky power adapter, so make sure to find space for it on your desk.

All in all, a good dock, for a relatively decent price. At under $180, you can turn your USB-C equipped laptop into a full desktop.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
This ought to be a good product, but it's far too finicky for it's high price. An auto-updated Dell laptop plugging into a special $100+ Dell Dock auto just work, and this most definitely doesn't.

I bought this for my mother in law to setup a seamless laptop to desktop transition and spent more than 5 total hours across 3 visits to her house trying to get this thing to work. I should note that I'm an IT professional that's worked in 3rd tier tech support and been informal family IT support for 20 years+, so if I'm having problems with it, anyone will. Apparently things are better in 12/16 than they were in 6/16, as I see reddit posts of people back then that found this product 100% unusable.

So after plugging this in and having it not work on a brand new XPS 13 9350, I updated the BIOS, 5 sets of drivers, the dock drivers, the thunderbolt firmware and two more sets of drivers. I originally did this through Dell auto-update with the dock plugged in but that still missed the Thunderbolt firmware. Anyway, 5 hours later, the monitor and sound work, which is good. But the USB hub still won't work for the her Logitech mouse/keyboard combo. I've left that plugged into the laptop for now and called it a day.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment: This unit is compact and works well. I miss a couple of features that I used often on previous port replicators. First, I missed a button to push for booting up the laptop (you have to open the laptop and push the button) Second, there are no suitable ports for a computer sound system or microphone. I have had to resort to using Apple headphones for Skype communication.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
This dock works fine with the 12" Macbook via USB-C (USB ports work, Mini Display port works, haven't tested HDMI / ethernet), *if* you have updated the dock to the latest Dell Firmware (as of writing, 1.0.0.8).

Updating the firmware is *hard* -- it *requires* a Dell XPS 13 laptop (you can't update the firmware from anything else, doesn't have any easily accessible diagnostic mode, etc.).

If you have a WD15 without the latest firmware -- the Mini DisplayPort may be *black* with no output to the display.

comment:
I had high hopes for this docking station. But the ethernet (RJ45-LAN) connection fizzles out after a few minutes whenever I connect to a device.

Amazon support lied to me twice in regard to support for this. I was sent on a wild goose chase over the course of weeks and it ended in calling Dell Support directly because AMazon couldn't help. Dell told me the product was 4 YEARS OLD. How is this thing being sold as New/open box?

I want to return this thing more than anything. I don't want anything to do with this hub. Not only that, but the Dell power brick it comes with is mandatory but DOES NOT CHARGE your device unless it's Dell. Tried downloading the Dell drivers in hopes it would help, but it told me to contact Dell Technical Support. Fat chance of that happening with the automated support lines I wasted another 20 minutes on hold for and navigating the VoIP menu.

comment: I've have been using this product for a few weeks now. The only issue I have with this product is that one of the two monitors that I use often ends up flickering when the laptop is awoken from sleep mode. The work around is to turn off the monitor for several minutes and turn it back on. When the monitor is turned back on, the issue usually corrects itself. I've read the other reviews and information from Dell's support site that mention installing the latest drivers. I did ensure that I was using the most current drivers for my laptop including the BIOS and graphics card. That did not correct the problem. Also, my laptop does not charge through the dock. I have to connect the charger directly to the laptop.

I've been a user of Dell docks for about 15 years (D-series and E-series). I'm a big fan of the simplicity of connecting my laptop to the dock to use full-size keyboard, mouse, monitors, etc.
Since I needed a new laptop, and the Dell E-series was replaced with USB-C method of connecting a dock, I wasn't sure what to expect. In short, I've been very happy - the WD15 does everything I expected and more. (Not having a docking station exposed on the desktop is a nice plus.)

comment:
It works, but beware, you will have to go through a LOT of updates from Dell to get it to work well.

When I installed it for my CFO's new XPS laptop, it seemed to work well (after going through standard Dell updates using their tools). Unfortunately, it started acting up as he used it. As I am off site most of the week, this was very troubling.

Good news is that Dell's tech support was able to get it running for him. Bad news is it wasted a lot of his time. It would be nice if Dell's standard tools would recognize all the appropriate updates and install them and not have needed updates hidden until you call support with issues.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
This dock will not support more than 1 monitor at a time above 1080p. I have an old fashioned Dell docking station that is over 5 years old that can power my 2 x 2k monitors but this will not and that has been confirmed by Dell. Unbelieveable that a top of the line computer from Dell in 2017 cannot be hooked up to more than one hi res monitor at a time because the only docking station that will work with it isn't up to par.

Even when hooked up to multiple lower resolution displays I got tons of flickering on and off at the beginning of each boot sequence that can't be good for the monitors. This is despite having the latest BIOS, Drivers and Firmware for all relevant hardware and having spoken with Dell Support about the issue.

Also, I get warning everytime I start computer warning that the power supply is underpowered and telling me that I need to use a 130w supply. This is despite the fact that I am using the exact 130w power supply the message is referring to. Though I was finally able to get rid of the message through the BIOS the fact is that the laptop battery is likely being forced to compensate at times for the underpowered psu.

If your needs are basic this just might work for you but I cannot recommend it.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
This thing has been a major PITA. I have it hooked to my brand new Dell XPS 15 (9550) ordered Jun 2016. The HDMI, VGA, Thunderbolt charging work great. Whenever the laptop wakes up after going to sleep, the monitor hooked to the display port connection blinks on and off until I plug and replug it. I do have this hooked up through a DisplayPort to HDMI adapter which could be a compatibility issue. All the USB ports (3.0 and 2.0) on the dock randomly work or don't work whenever the laptop wakes up -- doesn't matter if the devices connected are USB or self powered. I also have an external HD hooked to one of the USB 3.0 ports that after being plugged in for a while, will start disconnecting and reconnecting every 10 seconds or so. The audio port will randomly switch to LOUD white noise in the middle of a video or audio clip. I have none of these problems if I hook the devices directly to the laptop, not through this dock. All of this is infuriating considering the laptop and dock are brand new.

I tried buying a new dock to see if I just got a bad one but it had all the same issues so I returned it. I also have scoured the internet and installed all the drivers I could find. Nothing has helped. I think I'm going to have to buy a USB hub and resign myself to plugging in 2 things to my laptop instead of 1 whenever I'm at home.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment: Anyone hoping to buy this for your New 2016 MacBook Pro (2 or 4 Port Model), be prepared for a bad experience. I am returning mine since all I was able to get out of it was a display with a pink/purple hue. Initially thought that I was using the wrong color gamut for my display, but after much troubleshooting found that this was not the case. I also thought that I may need to force it to use RGB, but that also failed after trying a couple different scripts with SIP disabled. I tried four different HDMI cables, and five different monitors. I also tried wiggling the cables, and trying various combinations of adaptors. Much to my dismay nothing I threw at it worked. Also if you are hoping to get two displays in addition to the MacBook itself that will also not work. Now I blame Apple for this for not supporting MST, but thats a whole other rant. I did confirm everything else on the dock works fine. The charging works fine at the correct wattage. It looks like those of us that need to use two external (or more) monitors along with other legacy ports (Desktop Replacement) are forced to wait until someone else comes up with a better solution. I know of several companies doing just that later next year, but in the meantime it is dongle time. This test was done on a MBP 2016 two port non-touch bar.

Without going on a rant...this dock's NIC port is defective. The network cable will not click into place so I had to secure it with a rubber bands to keep it from falling out. Also the thunderbolt port has at best USB 1 speeds. Having owned a few Dell computers and laptops of which not a single one of them were actually fixed when warranty work was performed has been the Dell way. Dell support is marginally competent at best and usually smug and more interested in selling you more useless warranty than fixing the problem. Oh, the 1st Dell dock was non functional and Dell actually attempted to get me just to wait for a software update. Yes, I am supposed to pay hundreds of dollars for a brick that is non functional and patiently wait for a software fix. Typical Dell attitude in my experience. I have a 3 year old Dell laptop that is still waiting for a software update (that is never coming) to fix a blue tooth issue.

For this reason I don't purchase anything with the Dell brand any more. I kept the current dock because I don't use it much and it at least will power the laptop and allow a network wire with rubber bands. It is my last Dell product.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment:
I have been using dell products for many years.
Recently I purchased new XPS 13 with touch screen and this dock station to connect my 2 dell monitors.
I chose this dock station because it can power my XPS 13 thru USB C port.
Long story short, this thing is not working with XPS 13 at all.
1.constant display setting changes
2.monitor resolution is set but top part of screen won't fit to screen size
3.XPS 13 bios update was done because Dell recommend to update it to make WD15 working
4.still same or worse
5.ethernet port won't work well (connection is on and off erratically)
6.power button on WD15 sometimes no responsive
7.XPS 13 tries to reconize dock constantly and mkaing bell nosie all the time which makes me drive nuts while trying to my work

Now I am back to my old Dell docking station (D3000 model) and working fine
Only issue with D3000 was plug in power cord and dock connector to laptop.

It is possible of some compatibility issue with WD15 and XPS 13 but they are all Dell and can't believe this happens.
I do not recommend to any XPS13 owner to get this because your time is very valuable like mine
don't waste your time and money

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment: I do not normally write product reviews, but this product requires one to warn other purchasers not to waste their money. The dock serves no useful purpose and interferes with the normal functioning of a computer. I purchased this product because I wanted an easy way to disconnect my laptop from my desktop monitor when I want to use it in another part of the house. The dock, however, caused the monitor to keep going black for several seconds at a time when I was in the middle of working on something. In addition, I kept getting warning notices when I turned on my computer, stating that I had attached a device with an inadequate power supply of only 60W and I needed at least 65W. The label on the power supply for the dock says 180W, but the warning keeps coming up. I spent hours on the phone with Dell technicians to fix or find a way around these problems to no avail. Dell sent me a replacement, but it had the same problems as the original. I had no choice but to return it. Once I disconnected the dock from my computer, the problems disappeared.

When it works, it's a 5-star item. The problem is how rarely it works. In particular, the connection drops out between HDMI frequently. I've tried using different cables and hooking up my monitor to other video sources. It only has the problem when hooked up to the dell dock. Updated the latest drivers on my XPS-13 9360 with no luck. theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment: I don't normally write reviews, but for this piece of crap, I have to make an exception. I've been using the type-c version of this dock with a dell XPS 9550 and it has been nothing but a pain in the butt. Generally I can only count on the thing to charge my laptop, and if I'm lucky show on the monitors. The usb devices (2 & 3) constantly disconnect and reconnect, and I'm lucky if I can actually use them when everything is connected to the dock. The LAN connection likewise disconnects and reconnects at random times, which may or may not screw with the internet connection for a few minutes. I've gone through at least three firmware and driver updates for both the laptop and the dock over the course of 4 months of ownership. Without a doubt this will be the last dell peripheral I purchase for quite some time. I thought this would a great "one cable to rule them all" solution, and I regret ever being so naive. This is nothing more than the final irritation after a day of travel, or "mobile" laptop use. Save your time, money, and energy; find an alternative dock.

Dell products not compatible with Dell products? Wow, they need to work on that.

I'm considering returning it and trying a non-dell docking station.

theproduct: Dell æˆ´çˆ¾ USB 3.0 ä¸‰é‡è¢å¹•è¶…é«˜ç•«è³ªè¬ç”¨æ“´å……åº§ (D3100)
comment: If you have a Mac, think twice about this device. My world revolves around OS X and Windows, both with USB-C ports. About half the time one of the two of my devices does not recognize all the ports on the dock. Sometimes it is the HDMI, others it is the Ethernet, and even others it is the USB standard port. It seems like completely shutting down the computer before disconnecting it helps, but that is not consistent. You definitely want to update the Dell drivers before doing anything, but this requires a Windows device. It is my intent to hold on to this because reviews on other USB-C docks are equally squirrelly when switching between OS X and Windows. However, if the additional reboots to get it to work increases, it might go back from where it came.

comment: The docking station worked fine for a year. Ironically, I purchased in June 2018, and it died June 2019. When I contacted the company BecTech Global, they would not do anything because it was past the 90 days. While I DO understand the 90 day window, I would expect them to make some sort of exception because I expect the docking station to last longer than exactly one year. They should stand by their product more than that. I paid 146.00 to basically use it for a year, and had to purchase another one. It's not like there was wear and tear on it, since it sits on the desk. I would not do business with them again.

Never buy it crap! Absolutely not the workable and useless device! HDMI quality is extremely bad. I've compared it with my old laptop that has ordinary FullHD HDMI socket on board and also with a couple of other laptops that have HDMI on board. Second unexpected fail is extremely unstable Ethernet. It just hangs up whole dock station when I'm starting massive copy over a local network. Moreover, the Ethernet device is just disappearing at all when some other USB devices are connected, external HDD drive, for example. I have to switch off whole dock station for getting it back. I'm transferring my data from the old laptop during the unbeatable time already.

P.S. I'm using it together with this laptop  Dell XPS9350-8008SLV 13.3" 3200x1800 Laptop (Intel Core i7-6560U 2.2GHz Processor, 16 GB RAM, 512 GB SDD, Windows 10 Microsoft Signature Image) Silver  that I've bought together with this dock station.

Never buy it, don't repeat my mistake!
---------------------------------
P.S. After approx 1 year. This crap lost all video. Now it just a very expensive coaster for a cup of coffee.

comment: Initially I left a good review for the WD15 because I have one at my office for my laptop and 2 additional monitors. I purchased a separate WD15 docking station for my office at home along with 2 additional monitors so that I could replicate the set up I have at my office. It worked at first but then after a few minutes I noticed that both monitors were very grainy and then both started randomly going in and out on a consistent basis. I connected my laptop to each monitor individually with an HDMI to verify that the monitors were not defective and as expected they both worked just fine. After doing some reading it appears that a ton of people have this same problem with the WD15 and that apparently Dell can't get their act together with their docks. I would not waste your money on this and look for another dock that works as expected on a consistent basis.

comment:
TLDR; if you need a cheap wireless keyboard for a desktop, this is fine, if you need it for a laptop, buy something else.

This keyboard is clearly designed only for use with a desktop -- first there's no power switch - it's always on. This is the first wireless keyboard I've used in twenty years that doesn't have a power switch, and since this uses AAA batteries, this is not acceptable if you're not at home near replacement batteries. If you're not at home, you'll need to be able to shut this off when you're not using it to save power, and if you're on the go, you'd need to turn it off when you toss it in your laptop bag.

The second issue is that there's not a place for the USB wireless receiver. You can't store it in the keyboard or hide it in the mouse - you plug it in and leave it. This is fine for a desktop where you could put it in the back, but for a laptop you're probably going to lose it pretty quickly.

Other than those two absolute deal breakers, it's a nice office keyboard. It has the full number pad, responsive keys with a nice bounce to them, and as a nice bonus, it comes with a standard wireless Dell mouse. If you're looking for a desktop-only keyboard, this could work for you, but if you can wait and afford a $30 cost increase, I'd recommend the Dell Pro KM5221W instead which actually has a power switch, so you can use that one at home or on the go.

theproduct: Dell MS5120W ç„¡ç·šé›»è…¦æ»‘é¼  - é™„è—ç‰™é€£æ¥,é™„é•·æ•ˆé›»æ± (é»‘è‰²)
comment:
The Bluetooth mouse I use at work started to disconnect randomly. Cleaning, batteries, remove and reinstall... nothing fixed it. I looked around on Amazon and bought the Tecknet based on reviews. What a mistake! I wrote a review on that one. Terrible mouse. Avoid it. I didn't even waste my time to return it. It felt good to throw it in the trash.
I like Dell equipment. My work laptop is Dell. My gaming PC is Dell Alienware. Love them. So, I spent about 30% more on this Dell mouse and I love it. One AA battery so it is not heavy. Slightly beveled sides (wider on the top) so it's easy to pick up if needed. Very comfortable in the hand and is symmetrical so it's great for left handers too. I called it a wireless mouse because it works with an included USB dongle or with your native Bluetooth. The dongle stores inside if not used. Easy to set up - follow the instructions because there is an option to link to Bluetooth or the dongle. You can switch between the two, indicated on the bottom. The power switch is good. I only turn it off when it's in my backpack. On the desk, it sleeps and wakes seemlessly. The optical sensor on the bottom works onall surfaces and there is no red laser to blind you when you look for the switch. You can adjust the dots per inch sensitivity for your needs. This helps me for drawing sketches with the mouse. There are buttons. The usual left, middle, and right. The middle button is a wide scroll wheel, and it works as left and tight tilt, too. Two thumb buttons (for right hand use). All buttons are configurable through the provided application. I'm not using them for anything yet, but it's a nice option.
All-in-all I highly recommend this inexpensive wireless mouse for every day use. I have an expensive Alienware wired gaming mouse specificly for gaming use. But for work documentation, occasional CAD use, surfing the web, this is my new favorite. Dell MS5120W.

theproduct: Dell MS5120W ç„¡ç·šé›»è…¦æ»‘é¼  - é™„è—ç‰™é€£æ¥,é™„é•·æ•ˆé›»æ± (é»‘è‰²)
comment: I needed a mouse that could be used on the desktop, and go portable in a backpack, so it needed an on /off switch, which this has. I use my laptop with two portable monitor screens that use both of my USB 3.0 ports, and needed a mouse that could work with the laptop without using a USB port, which this mouse will connect to Bluetooth, and solves that issue. This mouse is great, it has several buttons, a wheel, Dual modes, it can work with Bluetooth, or radio frequency in USB. The software app wanted to upgrade the firmware, If you have trouble getting it to complete, try connecting with the Radio frequency USB, as Bluetooth mode didn't work for me, but it completed first try with the Radio USB connection. It takes one AA battery. The mouse Feels great, and moves accurately, quiet solid clicks. I would recommend.

theproduct: Dell MS5120W ç„¡ç·šé›»è…¦æ»‘é¼  - é™„è—ç‰™é€£æ¥,é™„é•·æ•ˆé›»æ± (é»‘è‰²)
comment:
I had high hopes for this. The battery terminals were getting corroded on my Apple bluetooth mouse, so I thought I'd branch out and try something different. Big mistake!

This mouse looks cool and feels good, but that's about it. I have to preface this by saying if you're used to using non-Apple mice you may like this mouse. The problem is... after using an Apple mouse for so many years and then switching, it's like going from a Ferrari to a Dodge.

First of all the scroll wheel is pathetic. It clunky scrolling is anything but smooth. Not only does it not give you a smooth scroll feel, but even worse scrolling a page or program with is so wildly hard to get to exactly where you want to go. With an Apple mouse you scroll effortlessly and smoothly to exactly where you're trying to go.

Secondly, moving the cursor around is also anything but smooth; at least compared to Apple's.

Like I said, if you come from a PC world this may all be natural to you. But DO NOT buy this to replace an Apple mouse. You'll be sorely disappointed.

Otherwise, this charger is really nice in that it is compact and lightweight, and has relatively high-quality cabling and casing.

comment:
My charger was sold by Derrick INC and fulfilled by Amazon, and as other reviewers mentioned, it's not the advertised model. The description clearly states there's a USB port on the charging brick, but mine doesn't have that. Frustrating because I purchased two and really needed them immediately (plus the price has gone up a bit since my purchase), but now I may end up returning them and purchasing from a different seller.

My advice: check who the seller is before you add to your cart. When I did it, it automatically chose Derrick INC (I didn't change anything.) The charger works, but if the USB port is important to you, consider selecting a different seller.

comment: When my several years old laptop finally died, I wanted a new laptop with lots of RAM, I purchased this Dell laptop with 32gb RAM with an Intel Icore 7 processor and storage of 1 tb hard drive for under $1,000.00. I use my laptop mainly for work. Being self-employed, I need a steady reliable laptop and that's what I purchased. I'm not a computer geek, but I know speed is important. I'm very happy with this product, and it's really lightweight compared to my old laptop. And, next day delivery along with updated software got me up and running with minimum time lost. I never owned a Dell product before, but I'm very happy with this laptop. My opinion, don't cheap out, buy a laptop with lots of RAM and the latest processor, you'll be happy that you did.

comment:
I had hoped that this was going to be a great laptop and would last for several years.

This laptop was needed for supporting Emergency Communication applications, which use USB Audio CODEC. I had issues with USB Audio CODEC devices on this laptop from day one and spent several days trying to resolve the issue. The laptop was sent to Dell Support with 10+ pages of documentation on the issue. They replaced the Main Logic board and reloaded Windows 11, but that did not address the issue. I have other laptops (Windows 11 & Windows 10), including an older Dell which work fine with USB Audio CODEC devices.

Since Dell could not resolve the issue, the laptop was returned as it was of no use to me.

theproduct: 2022 æœ€æ–° Dell Inspiron 3000 é ‚ç´šç­†è¨˜å‹é›»è…¦,15.6 FHD é¡¯ç¤ºå™¨,Intel Core i5-1135G7,16GB DDR4 RAM,1TB PCIe SSD,ç¶²è·¯æœƒè­°,WiFi,HDMI,Windows 11 Hã€‚ ome,é»‘è‰²
comment:
I received this laptop on June 17th. This is the first SSD laptop I have owned. (It replaced an old Sony VAIO dual core PentiumÂ© B940 laptop.) So far, it's doing very well. I wasn't having anything to do with the Windows 11 demand to create a MS account or give them my phone number, so I wiped the SSD and installed LInux on it. In less than 30 seconds from hitting the Power button, I'm booted up and logged in to the OS. It's working great! No issues running any of the apps. In just over a month, I haven't had any issues. Fast and smooth sailing.

I will add that the laptop's description advertises it to be a "Core i5-1135G7", an 11th generation i5 processor. I just noticed that I did not get the 11th generation i5 processor in my laptop that is advertised. It has the 10th generation i5 processor (Coreâ„¢ i5-1035G1) in it. I did not get what I was supposed to get, and the seller just told me "why" it is listed wrong - no apparent intention of fixing the listing. Be aware of this before you buy. You may not get what you think, either. I gave it 4 stars for that reason. The hardware is good, it's just not the hardware that I bought.

theproduct: Dell UltraSharp U3223QE 31 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment: This monitor replaced an 27" 5K iMac as my primary work monitor. I needed to move from 2 computers into 1 and ended up getting a MacBook Pro and this monitor to replace an iMac and an older MacBook Pro. I would have preferred to get the 32" Apple monitor but I didn't have $5K to spend so this had to suffice. Still a relatively expensive monitor in my opinion. The good stuff; the screen size and resolution is fine enough for viewing at an arms distance on my desk. It's not quite as revealing as my 5K was, but everything looks good, including fine text, so I don't feel like I took a significant step backward on resolution for every day use. The thing has a TON of built-in ports and they all work great! I use almost all of them to connect my peripherals and devices. You forget how many you need until you get a new computer that doesn't have many ports (Apple) and then you feel relieved that you can plug everything you own into the monitor and the Mac sees it immediately! The bad stuff; the screen is matte and reflects sunlight more than my glossy iMac did. I was surprised by how much more sensitive this screen was by comparison. Definitely something to consider if you use the screen in a room with a lot of ambient light. On cloudy days and other times when the ambient light is low, the screen looks fantastic and is easy on my eyes. I also miss having built-in: mic, camera and speakers. I use my new Mac in clamshell mode and not having these basic audio and video functions on the monitor seems like a miss to me. This is not an el-cheopo monitor. My workaround is using my iPhone as the camera and mic and I plugged a small powered speaker into the line out port which works fine for every day sound but I would have preferred if the monitor had these items built-in so I didn't have to figure out the work-arounds. All in all, I would recommend this monitor. I think the pros outweigh the cons and until a more full-featured one comes along this is probably one of the best 32" monitors in the sub $1K price range.

theproduct: Dell UltraSharp U3223QE 31 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
I used this monitor at work on a windows machine, it worked very well although my graphics card only managed 4K 30hz it was still usable. I hooked up my MacBook Pro at the same time and 4K 60hz worked very well and charged the MacBook too through usb c. The picture is colorful and bright, there are many color settings and I managed to get a close match to the MacBook Pro 14â€ screen color by adjusting the white balance.
The picture by picture mode is awesome, having a windows machine on one half and a Mac on the other half works very well. The 32â€ screen is large enough to work this way and the images autosize to fill the screen.
The Dell software is great, you can adjust the brightness, contrast and any other picture setting through both the mac and the windows pc without having to touch any buttons on the monitor.
I was concerned about 32â€ 4K and mac text sharpness, no problem here itâ€™s very good. I came from a 5k iMac and the 4K 32â€ passes my sharpness needs no problem. I donâ€™t need to change the resolution from 4K on the 32â€ it is small txt but readable. I have used 2K resolution but I preferred the 4K when the monitor is at arms length infront of me.
The brightness is good. I was concerned about this since I had a apple studio display for a month in spring and 600nits was great. However, the Dell is bright enough and I tended to use brightness between 90 and 100% during the sunny day which is ideal.
What would I change?
(1) not much to be honest
(2) I prefer glossy screens but thatâ€™s personal and the Dell is by no means unattractive
(3) add speakers and a microphone. Iâ€™m 50/50 about this as I may prefer my own choice of studio mike and monitors with good bass which only the studio display has!
(4) longer usbc cable, 3ftâ€¦.really !
(5) I find the stand bulky the footprint is large, itâ€™s very sturdy though and very effective. Iâ€™m just more in favor of the apple studio stand but thatâ€™s a smaller monitor.

In summary, a very sturdy monitor with great color accuracy and works very well with my mac and with windows pc which is exactly what I need - so I ordered one for home and canâ€™t wait to start to use it and improve my productivity.

theproduct: Dell UltraSharp U3223QE 31 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
As a visualization artist, color is very important to me. I have tried 6 different monitors recently and IPS black displays have consistently come out on top as the best bang for the buck. If you have the money to afford a 4K mini led or oled monitor then by all means but these dell monitors having amazing image quality for the price.

Having tried both the 27â€ and 32â€ version I can say the only difference was size and price. Although 4K on a 27â€ has greater ppi, the picture quality on the 32â€ was almost indistinguishable from the 27â€. The 32â€ is however $300 more, so if you donâ€™t need the extra space, go with the 27â€.

Both monitors us the LG IPS Black displays, so if you want panels with the exact same picture quality, you can buy LGâ€™s version of the monitors for significantly cheaper. $650 vs $850 for the 32â€ version. What Dell does is buy the display, improves quality control and warranty, packages it better by making it frameless on 4 sides instead of 3, adds features like a built in hub, kvm etc, so if you need all those extra features then buy Dell but if youâ€™re just looking for an IPS display with the same image quality, LG has alternatives for much cheaper.

theproduct: Dell UltraSharp U3223QE 31 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment: This monitor with the build in USB C docking station and KVM switch works great for my purposes. I have a 7 year old HP Omen workstation laptop that only has HDMI video out and standard USB along with my work laptop which is a 3 month old HP ProBook with USB C docking port. Connected both laptops through this monitor with single mouse and keyboard and can switch between devices with no problem. Just had to figure out which USB port on the monitor needed to connect to the older HP Omen for mouse and keyboard since the documentation that comes with the device is very sparce. I my work office I have a 38" wide curved monitor connected to the HP ProBook connected through a Belkin dock that is recommended by HP and the setup is very flakey (That is technical jargon for the monitor doesn't always detect the video signal) This is not the case with this Dell monitor syncs right away and always remembers it's settings. Very pleased with the functionality. I am a software programmer and primarily use Visual Studio and SSMS so my opinion on the video/graphic quality of this monitor is purely from the writing point of view. I'm not a gamer.

theproduct: Dell UltraSharp U3223QE 31 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
This was a perfect upgrade from a dell ultrasharp P2715Q lcd. Keeping the 4k resolution with a 16:9 ratio vs 5k/ultrawide monitors turned out to be the right decision. I was concerned that the pixel density was not going to be high enough on a 32" 4k but it turned out to be flawless.

Love the single cable solution for charging/connectivity for M1 MacBook Pro. Awesome. Retired my TB3 dock as a result.

Built in KVM has so far been rock solid; simple solution so I can have my work machine with one cable and my gaming desktop with only two additional. Dell really thought this through; I'm impressed.

No complaints - I love this monitor.

theproduct: Dell UltraSharp U3223QE 31 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
I have had the LG UltraFine 5K for years now, so that's my primary benchmark. I also recently tried the new Apple Studio monitor. That one wins from a pure quality point of view, but it's just too pricey for what offers. The Dell I had to fiddle with settings to get it to stop looking terrible. I'm specifically mostly concerned with text clarity because I'm a software developer, and this would be my primary monitor to stare at code all day. The Dell is OK once you set it to one notch over into scaled with "more space" in Apple's dumbed down selector. I would have expected the Dell's native to be optimal, so that was weird.

I also use this one vertically.. so one note is that 32" vertical is just about too tall. I found my neck cricking just a bit when looking up to the top (I have it centered in front of my eyes).

Anyways, even with fiddling, the quality is not there. I shouldn't expect it, either, given the difference in pixel density, but I thought I'd see if it was good enough. Not quite, in my view. But I'm finicky.

The brightness was just about good enough. A smidge less bright than the UltraFine, but in my room with lots of windows it did OK.

I wish there were more "Retina" monitors available. I started looking mainly because I've noticed some ghosting on my UltraFines, and I don't really want to buy this "old" technology again, but I also don't want to spend $1700 for basically the same thing screen-wise.

So this one is OK, but just barely good enough for my purposes. I decided not to keep it.

theproduct: Dell UltraSharp U3223QE 31 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
Before getting to my complaint, let me acknowledge that the image quality on this monitor is fantastic. Brilliantly sharp 4K resolution, great color, and plenty bright for the type of office/productivity things I do on a daily basis.

Unfortunately, the KVM functionality was problematic. This was one of the big selling points for purchasing a monitor like this. I connected two computers, one of which was a laptop using the single USB-C with 90W of power delivery. I installed the drivers from Dell's website, along with they Dell Display Manager 2.x software. It worked OK for about five minutes. But then it started registering "USB devide not recognized" errors when switching between computers. My USB devies (one of which was a keyboard) continued to work OK, but the Windows device manager showed an error saying "Unknown USB Device (Invalid Device Descriptor)". When I disconnected the two USB devices, the error would remain visible in the device manager until I removed the USB connection between the computer and screen itself.

I called Dell support and they suggested I needed to install the proper device drivers. I confirmed that I had already done that, and the problem persisted after rebooting, and even after removing the Dell Display Manager software.

For a while, everything was basically operational. The USB warnings were annoying, but they didn't keep me from working. That run came to an end and my keyboard would not function through the monitor's KVM setup. At first the laptop continued working (with the single USB-C connection). At some point, the keyboard would no longer work with it either. The issue would come and go, seemingly at random as to which device (or both) was most problematic.

Ended up returning the monitor and will try something else.

theproduct: Dell UltraSharp U3223QE 31 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment: This monitor is a total fail due to the DPBS (Dell Power Button Sync) "feature" that can't be disabled. I was very excited when I found this monitor that would allow me to remove from clutter and cables from my desk. The goal was to eliminate a docking station and KVM switch...both of which are built into this monitor. My plan was to plug my personal desktop into the Display port and my work laptop into the USB-C port with the 90w of power. On paper this monitor can do that...but in execution there is a major flaw. This monitor also has a feature called DPBS (Dell Power Button Sync) which links the monitor's power button to the Dell power button on my work laptop. With both machines plugged in I can't turn just the monitor off or else it will turn my work laptop off. I have to unplug my laptop and then I need another power source. There is not way to disable this absolutely stupid feature which is counter productive to the built in docking station and KVM. If you plan to actually use this feature look elsewhere. If you don't need this feature then look elsewhere. You can find better monitors for less. If Dell would give us the option to remove this feature it would be a totally different review.

theproduct: Dell UltraSharp U3223QE 31 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
Pros:

Price is competitive for a 32inch IPS panel with a hub built in, ethernet is a much added welcome, Factory calibration is good. And thats is where the good stops which is really what a good monitor is supposed to do. Have a good image which this one does have. (Try to find it on sale under $900)

Cons:

* Slow hub (let me explain) When you use USB C (DP Alt) you have to choose between either higher resolution + Low Data Transfers [USB 2.0] or Choose Lower Resolution + High Data Speeds [3.0]

* IPS panel coating on this monitor is does not match the price asking. I wish DELL had given us an option to have this as glossy.

* Smart HDR and IPS Black are TERRIBLE: When enabled it makes me question if this is indeed an IPS panel or a VA one.

So THIS MONITOR IS NOT FOR YOU:

* if your work requires the absolute best resolution and high data speeds. Highest supported resolution is 4K at 60HZ which is plenty but this cannot be combined which high speed data transfers of usb 3.0 nor 3.1 gen 2 which this monitor advertises.

* If you require HDR (It is there but IT IS NOT)

* If you want a monitor to make you more productive. The cons will have you looking for more things to add instead of actually getting to work.

This MONITOR IS FOR YOU:

* if you can afford it without saving too much, if you have been saving for awhile to buy a monitor please pass on this one. If buying this monitor using credit card to pay in installments, I would also recommend you pass this one.

* The monitor is also for you if you only need high resolution and not fast data transfers all at once. Just one or the other (it is a trade)

* The Monitor is also for you if you need high data transfer hub but dont care much using a resolution lower than 4k 60HZ (4k @30HZ, 2.5K @30HZ, 2K @60HZ, or 1080P @60HZ) all testings done with a 2017 maxed out MacBook Pro with Thunderbolt (USB C) to DP Alt mode.

* This monitor is also for you, if you live in reality that most people don't actually need fast speeds past USB 2.0 anyways (up to 480Mbps). Yes if you have 1Gig Internet you will see a drop when you select high resolution as speeds will be reduced which will affect your internet speeds. Yes if you are transferring large 4k files you will have to wait for forever. But if you are a casual user, transferring small documents, and occasional 2gb or 5gb video files - YOU WILL BE FINE.

I wish DELL did not rush this monitor, I wish they would have taken feedback from all past Q series both QS, QE, Q and listened to the users pain points and address those here.

SHOULD YOU BUY?

* If you can wait for next year's release, by all means wait. Save that money by the time next year comes you will have earned interests on it and you will get a much better monitor.

* If you cant wait, see how much you have made this past month and if you can afford to buy this monitor without affect next month's bills and spending, then go for it. It is a good monitor just Not GREAT and no off in terms of Price to performance. Even at 32inch note that most likely you will end up scaling both in MacOS and Windows. Which begs the question if you really even need a 32inch.

* If you CAN'T wait but DON'T have hundreds of dollars to buy this monitor then please consider Dell's own Dell S2722QC 27-inch 4K USB-C which is available on Amazon at $380. For the money, this is a much better monitor, has USB C and can charge a 15inch MacBook Pro. The display panel also looks incredible and yes comparable to the QE. To the naked eye, one may even argue that they are same panels. Also at 27inch it looks very sharp.

These are honest and humble opinions from someone who has been waiting for so long for the perfect monitor at a reasonable price. While I have decided to keep this monitor (THIS IS NOT THE PERFECT Monitor) For now it does the job, but eventually 3 years to five I will be changing this one I suspect. And I wish DELL had a program where they can buy back these if they end up fixing all the issues mentioned above by next year.

I hope this review has been helpful in giving you insights about this monitor and your purchase decision. Thank you for reading and I wish you well!

I originally submitted this review on Dell's website but was censored with no communication as to why they wouldn't publish it. Only said it violated community guidelines. I am no expert whether financial nor tech but I wanted to provide some honest reflections from someone who bought this monitor with their own money and not sponsored. If only Dell had chosen to make this monitor's ALT DP Thunderbolt then this would be an A+ monitor instead of a B- (Since thunderbolt can carry both power and high speed data but USB C is limited which is where this monitor falls short.

comment:
I purchased this monitor back in November from Dell when if first came out. The picture quality was not as good as my slightly older LG 27 Inch Monitor. It was a bit more matte than I care for and also where they show it daisy chained to another dell, you have to have a Dell PC for that. My older LG is much more similar to my Macbook Pro in screen quality. I had it mounted to a monitor arm that I keep fairly tight. I went to move the monitor up a bit and had my thumbs on the screen. I apparently applied too much pressure (it wasn't much, I know because they this didn't happen to the other side) and a giant crack spidered across the screen.
I know, my fault and I get it. However, you should know that I called Dell and was promptly informed that they do not offer screen repairs on monitors and that I would need to purchase another one.

theproduct: Dell UltraSharp U3223QE 31 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment: I was so excited to get two of these monitors as they came with high ratings. I also had two of their older monitors and was using them with a docking station. Having the docking station and kvm switch built in had me pretty excited for the reduced desk clutter and cables. Unfortunately, their monitors cannot be daisy chained (laptop USB-C to monitor 1, from DisplayPort out on monitor 1 to DisplayPort in on monitor 2). What ended up happening is my mac would only see one Dell monitor resulting in the display for both being mirrored. In order to use these I would also need to use my existing docking station and then wouldn't be able to utilize the KVM switch. Why waste all that money and not be able to utilize these monitors with their features? I may as well by two dumb monitors and use the docking station I have. I am returning these. I wish Dell would have built this capability into their docks.

theproduct: Dell UltraSharp U3223QE 31 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment: We bought this monitor to use with our new Mac M2 Airbook and were blown away by the crisp colors and true blacks. We are photographers and designers and work constantly and extensively in Photoshop, Illustrator, Lightroom, and Topaz Labs products, and this monitor delivers amazing clarity and color. We looked at SO many models before buying, trying to match Mac M2 compatibility with an excellent connectivity hub and comfortable position settings - this is it - this monitor will adjust up and down, tilt front to back, and even pivot from landscape to portrait mode, which is perfect for writing documents. This will be the monitor everyone in your house wants, but you keep locked away for YOU. It's truly a fabulous piece of hardware and would make an excellent gift. Expensive, maybe a bit more than some, but for the increase in productivity you will get in using this baby, it's worth it...and hundreds of dollars less than an Apple display. It's so much easier to work on the fine details of gigapixel photos while enlarged to 1200% on a quality large screen.

theproduct: Dell UltraSharp U3223QE 31 å‹ 4K UHD WLED LCD è¢å¹• - 16:9 - é»‘è‰²,éŠ€è‰²
comment:
Quite happy with this monitor. I bought it for the use of the USB-C hub and display. Its part of a utility desk and we can now plug in a laptop without having to bring a charger as well. The picture is quite good -- typical dell quality that I have experienced on other monitors. I have a GoogleTV connected as well for streaming. It's a good picture and it switches between them pretty seamlessly. However, I can see how people complain about the black levels. I would not suggest you buy this monitor for the HDR capabilities.

One thing that I can confirm is that you cannot have high speed USB AND 4K 60Hz refresh rate over USB-C at the same time. You have to choose and 60Hz is the clear winner. For me that was OK because the other USB ports are being used for lower bandwidth items like web cam, key/mouse, and for a sound bar.

No other real negatives that I have found. Solid construction and great picture.

theproduct: Dell æœ‰ç·šéµç›¤å’Œæ»‘é¼  - KM300C é»‘è‰²
comment:
Review Version 2 (see p.s. as to why that is): I've been ordering these keyboards for some time now for the company I work for & they've worked for us. Longevity is as what you would expect of a low-end keyboard. If highly abused, do not expect it to last more than a month. If the user takes good care of it, it may last up to 6 months of heavy use. The mouse as well has the same life expectancy. Key tension wise, the keyboard is very soft & to some may be hard to get used to if they prefer the more tactile response. The mice we've received are clicky & loud so that may be annoying to some people. I myself don't mind the click sound as it lets me know if I've selected something. Get this if you just want a basic setup similar to what comes with Dell computers. If you need a more ergonomic keyboard, look somewhere else.
p.s. Amazon wouldn't submit my previous review because it mentioned packaging. They don't want customers to know that resellers do not package goods like OM goods (see picture). I prefer the original packaging from Dell because it's easier to store these in bulk.

comment:
Preso su Amazon Warehouse con una piccola riduzione di prezzo (non Ã¨ sicuramente un prodotto economico!) in quanto privo della scatola originale, il WD19 Ã¨ una bellissima docking station, compatta ed efficiente.
Ho preso la versione 130W totalmente a caso, in quanto non Ã¨ chiaramente specificato se si sta acquistando la versione 130W o la versione 180W; per capirlo bisogna spulciare bene nelle caratteristiche, cosa che io ho fatto dopo aver scoperto di aver preso la 130W. Comunque per il mio XPS13 Ã¨ piÃ¹ che sufficiente visto che l'alimentatore di serie ha appena 45W.
La docking Ã¨ molto comoda, replica tutte le porte che possono servire per un normale utilizzo, compreso il pulsante di accensione e le prese audio (cuffie davanti e line dietro), e si collega al mio XPS con una singola USB-C.
Attenzione, se usate piÃ¹ monitor, considerate che ci sono dei limiti nella risoluzione dei vari monitor (li trovate facilmente in rete o sul sito Dell). Io ne ho uno solo in QHD quindi per me va benissimo.
E' completamente silenzioso e fino ad ora non ho mai sentito partire alcuna ventola (come ho letto in alcune recensioni). SarÃ  che non uso il computer per gaming e che ho giÃ  un supporto con ventole per il piccolo laptop, ma anche questa cosa per me comunque non Ã¨ un problema.

Per il momento non ho molto altro da aggiungere.
AggiornerÃ² magari la recensione in futuro; vorrei anche provare la docking station con un dac esterno o con una interfaccia audio.

theproduct: Dell WD19 130W æ“´å……åŸºåº§ (å¸¶ 90W é›»æºå‚³è¼¸) USB-Cã€HDMIã€é›™ DP
comment: Resulta que Dell cuando me compre el portatil INSPIRON 15 con INTEL I5 de 8 generacion y una placa RADEON de grafica me aconsejaba el D6000 como dock station. Pues resulta que esa dock era insuficiente por la potencia y me surgieron muchos problemas que al principio no relacione con la DOCK. Cuando tuve claro que el problema era la dock pude probar esta que segÃºn DELL no era compatible. Pues resulta que si es compatible. Y de hecho puedo afirmar que es compatible con cualquier portatil que tenga un USB tipo C 3.1. Si tu portÃ¡til permite la carga a travÃ©s del USB tipo C esta dock es definitiva. La potencia es 180W es suficiente. la tension en mi caso es 19,5V y el amperaje 9,23A. SegÃºn la placa de caracterÃ­sticas de mi portÃ¡til la tensiÃ³n era de 19,5 V y 3.3A con lo cual iba sobrado con 130W. Pero resulta que luego vi que la placa es errÃ³nea ya que mi portÃ¡til consume en puntas de procesador y grafica y cuando se conecta una pantalla supera esa potencia. Al final compras esta dock que con 180W y que puede darte hasta 9 A. No se calienta como si se calentaba la D6000. Espero que me dure aÃ±os y cuando cambie a otro portÃ¡til me siga sirviendo. Aconsejo al final esta dock que precio y potencia que te da, marca reconocida es de las mejores opciones del mercado.

comment:
I bought this to work with my XPS 13 laptops - a 9350 and a 9300. Plus I've also used it with a Dell Inspiron. I was lucky to have bought this with a good discount and have now had it for 18 months. I like the fact it has sockets for headphones and speakers. I also like the little lights on either side of the USB plug, which tells me it's providing power to my laptop.

On the negative side, it has a very noisy fan that seems to come on every now and again for no reason. Fortunately, it usually switches off after a couple of minutes. I've updated it with the latest drivers, but that doesn't seem to have fixed the issue.
Also, the USB C plug that plugs into my laptop came apart. I was able to superglue it back together, which seems to have fixed it.

theproduct: Dell WD19 130W æ“´å……åŸºåº§ (å¸¶ 90W é›»æºå‚³è¼¸) USB-Cã€HDMIã€é›™ DP
comment:
I have a dell latitude 5400 and wanted to drive 3 external monitors at 1920x1080. I tried to find the answer to this prior to purchase, but it was not obvious. When I had the docking station was plugged in, it was obvious i could not drive 3 monitors at 1920x1080; 2 monitors were 1920x1080 but the 3rd was at a much lower resolution.
After some reading about USB-C and its bandwidth, it seems as though it cannot handle the bandwidth for 3 HD monitors.
To overcome this, i have 2 monitors plugged in to the docking station and 1 plugged in to the HDMI port on the laptop; not ideal, but i get the outcome i require.

If you want to drive 3 HD monitors, buy the thunder bolt version of this docking station as the USB-C version does not have the bandwidth.

comment:
I was surprised to see a dusty unmarked brown box with tape decorating (but not adhering to) an edge. All the same, I was eager to try a new 'dock' after having such bad experiences with lower cost alternatives.

When I did open the box, the poorly sealed bags and thin layer of dirt (inside and out) made me second guess now "new" my new dock was.

After opening a bag, I was convinced --- that was (at best) a refurbished product.
I don't have anything against a refurbished product, but I like to know what I'm buying when I click the order button. Especially when I'm setting it up as a gift for someone.

Unfortunately, there are some stubborn oil/dirt marks on the case, and I feel like the product was not correctly advertised/labeled.
Otherwise, the dock seems to be working as expected.

03/14/2020: Update. I want to thank eDealerTech for their quick response to my email. They decided to replace the failed docking station. You guys rock and for that, I've raised the Overall Rating from 3 stars to 5 stars. Thank you for your excellent customer service.

comment:
Not purchased here but provided by employer. I think the design is flawed and is not geared towards business use. On previous docking stations, Dell has provided many monitor options but also multiple connections. DVI is not even an option now and on previous docks, these provided the best image. Dell should pick at least 1 monitor connector and have 2 of them. I haven't used just a single monitor in over 10 years. 2 of my monitors are exactly the same and i would like to use the same type of cable and connectors. The on/off works for off consistenly but randomly works for on. The USB devices are usually recognized but occasionally they are lost and when this happens, you must reboot several times and move the devices to other ports, repeatedly. Eventually the device will be known.

I do like the abundance of USB, 2 of which are USB3.

comment:
I look after twenty of these docks coupled with Latitude 7370 ultrabooks. Typical complaints run along the lines of:

1. Windows has forgotten my monitor arrangement.
2. My external monitors don't work (MST hub sometimes flakes when using DisplayPort).
3. My mouse and keyboard don't work (dock's USB ports).

We're doing nothing special with monitors: most are standard 1920x1080 flat panels with DisplayPort or HDMI inputs. I don't believe these problems arise simply from user error, and that they are intrinsic to the dock and its operation with Windows.

I give the dock two stars because Dell at least issues frequent driver updates that may resolve problems, but I'm deducting a star because Dell phone support was unfamiliar with the WD15 when I called about it in June of 2016. That might've changed by now.

theproduct: æˆ´çˆ¾ WD15 è¢å¹•åº•åº§ 4K é™„ 180W è½‰æ¥å™¨,USB-C(450-AEUO,7FJ4J,4W2HW)
comment:
Easy to hook up and start using. Does exactly what it's supposed to do. Easily connects to my Dell laptop over USB C. I bought this dock so I could run dual monitors and a keyboard and mouse without having to hook all that up every time. Like I said, it does that perfectly. I did disable the auto power on feature when the laptop is plugges into the dock. I wanted to be able to dock the laptop only to charge and not boot up.

I do wish that I could use my laptop screen as a 3rd monitor. When I open the lid, the resolution gets all weird on one of my two monitors and the other turns black.
When I install the audio drivers for the WD15, there is a popping sound at the end of every sound clip. Uninstalling the drivers and using the native MS drivers resolved that issue.
I do wish there was some indication on the dock when the laptop is sleeping. I/E a pulsing LED like on the laptop's power button. However I have to have my lid closed for the monitors to display right, so I can't see the laptop's power button.

Buy with caution, as amazon now only replace the product with the same model. You cannot return it completely. If the product is incompatible.
If your laptop only has USB 3 type c (does not have thunderbolt like in Acer Predator 300) it can only be useful as USB extender.
External displays will not be work.

P.S : - In this range you get a better model in local market, you will have option to change if there is an compatibility issue. Avoid buying from amazon if you are not 100% sure about the compatibility.

comment:
I spent $3k building a custom laptop for school and work only to have a charger come with it that broke within a week. The casing warped and tore and exposed the wires. For the last 4 years, I've had the old charger wrapped with electrical tape because a new one would cost me around $300 from the company even WITH the warranty... Insane...
This charger was a life-saver. It wasn't stupid expensive and it fit perfectly. My laptop actually holds a charge now, and it charges way faster. The block isn't gigantic like the one that came with the laptop, yet it has the exact same make as the last one. It's a little shorter than what I'm used to, but a foot shorter is way better than potentially shocking my children every time I have to use my laptop for work or school...
Better yet, the shipping was amazing. It arrived way faster than projected, which saved me missing the deadline for a paper I had to write for school.

comment:
Play Video
 I am reviewing this after about 2.5 months of using this product. It worked fine so far. Past 2 weeks I am having issue with charging. First it stopped working intermittently. But now as soon as I put it in laptop its blue light on cable stops. But when I take it out it blue charging light on cable lights up. I replaced while new battery in laptop thinking battery gone dead. But even with new battery it is same behaviour.
I bought new charger from bestbuy and used with my new as well as old battery and it works fine. That confirms it is an issue with this charger.
I want my money back for this unreliable item.

Update - 10-20-2020
After I reached out to the seller "IT Parts Now" whome I purchased this item they replied within 1hr and issue full refund in 48hours.
The item was defective but they really show great customer service. I hate to say but Amazon did not make easy for me to find and reaching out to seller. When I looked for seller by searching product it shows on the top "last purchased date" but that does not indicate if the seller is same or different. Hence you end up reaching out to wrong seller. When they can show last purchased date for the item can't they add one more details "same or different seller" ?

Anyway, not only for this but for many other electronic items I found shop around and you will find many better place. I found great deal on walmart where seller gives 2year warranty on product. I would never buy such items on amazon that I had to deal with seller myself after 30 day closing window.

comment:
One day, I was on my Dell XPS laptop and my charging cord stopped working. Frustrated at the thought that my cord needs replaced, I rushed to RadioShack as fast as I could to replace it. Buying my new $65 charging kit with multiple heads, I soon found out it didn't give off enough power to charge it. Even more frustrated now, I asked my tech friend to direct me to what kind I needed, he directed me and found the exact same cord that I had for a decent price on Amazon. Without hesitation, I bought it! The charger was sent in a fast paced delivery and was exactly the same as the one I had previously. Perfect!

The product itself is a 3 prong charger with wraps for when you are done using it and want to put it away neatly. The charger comes into two breakdown pieces that you can remove. One of the wraps is on the battery itself and wraps the port for the laptop. The other wrap is for the cord that plugs into the wall. Easy to use and put away when needed.

Altogether, if you need a computer charging cord for your Dell XPS like I did, then this is your baby. Satisfied and would recommend.
Old charger broke 01-2016 : New own bought right after : Still have and use it everyday!

comment:
Charger is pretty much exactly as described. Their shipping date was way off the estimated time of arrival and I was happy that it was early but I would've liked a more accurate estimation. The charger has it's polarity shown a strange way it while it is genuine Dell seemingly it certainly wasn't the OEM that came with my Latitude e6540.

EDIT: 3/24 I bought this charger a few months ago and I figured it would last but a portion of the charger is already broken. Fortunately my dog chewed through the opposite portion on my last charger which is why i bought this one in the first place but I had to literally salvage my old charger to make this charger continue working.

More in detail: The charger when plugged into the wall stopped actually providing power and I was really confused when my laptop almost died in the middle of some school work so I looked and it was plugged in. I figured maybe the charger had overheated or something which would still be terrible but it was cold as the tile floor so it wasn't even running. The blue light on the charger wasn't running either so it wasn't even receiving power. I tried to maybe unplug it and replug it in and it lit up for a couple seconds then the light went dead again whether it was plugged into my computer or not so it wasn't pulling a constant current. I took the old cord form the wall to the adapter from my previous charger and changed it out with the one from this charger and it started working again so I guess the cord from the wall to adapter just broke but within a couple months of use just simply breaking one day when it gets plugged in is pretty disappointed. I will follow up with an update once I contact the seller because it said these things were under a warranty when I bought it and I have screenshot of that. (side note if anyone thinks maybe my dog had chewed on this one as well I specifically checked the whole cord and it is pristine on the outside so it couldn't have been that also by the point I got the new charger she had been trained well enough not to chew on things anymore). @Adeptshop if you want to comment here feel free I will contact you within the next few days but I am super busy tomorrow!

comment: I go through these chargers almost like clockwork. Right after the 1 year mark / warranty they die on me or the cord frays at the laptop end and it becomes unreasonable to use. I contacted Dell about their warranty (on the charger) and they said they will only honor warranties when products are purchased directly through their site. Further upon inspection, the charger started to fray on the laptop end as well, again after only 2 months. Save your money and buy directly from Dell and avoid the costly mistake I made as I am now out a laptop and a charger. Not worth the initial savings or hassle it has caused. comment:
The power adapter I received was not the adapter in the picture nor was it a Dell part. The part looked, felt, and weighted completely different than the original equipment power adapter, yet the sticker had the same part number. The sticker was also missing the UL (Underwriters Laboratories) certification. What manufacture ever would ever skimp on a UL certification for a part that sells in the US? I can't say it's a 100% fake without tearing it apart but I'll let you decide.

In my pictures you can see the OEM Dell Charger on the right (Model Number: DA130PE1-00 / PN: JU012) and you can the fake unit on the left that has the same model and part marking.

Note the total cheap looking LED sticking out of the unit instead of the smooth recessed LED that is on Dell 90w adapters (DP/N: YD9W8)

In my opinion it's a knock off - A bad quality charger could nuke your computers battery so I would stay away from this suspect adapter.

comment: Dell brand in a dell bag with the correct wattage to ensure safe and proper charging while in use. Don't be tempted to buy the 135watt unit for any reason. Match that watts based on original equipment. If you have extra peripherals get a powered USB hub and plug them into that. Even with smart power ports that are part of the newer USB-C spec, powering with at more than double the intended wattage brick is not a good idea. This 65watt brick was a perfect match for the one that came with my new Dell laptop but got left in a hotel in frantic pack-out to catch an early flight home. But the hotel was kind enough to ship the missing one to my house so now I have two. Stick with factory bits for your factory laptops. Cooking a Motherboard or Power trace because you didn't isn't a good idea.

theproduct: Dell AX210 USB ç«‹é«”è²æšè²å™¨ç³»çµ± (W955K), é»‘è‰²
comment:
I purchased a few of these for our office. I wanted something attractive on the desks yet with decent sound. These did the job. They're very stylish, and the sound quality is better than what you would expect from some el cheapo desktop speakers. The bass is lacking, but that's to be expected from desktop computer speakers. These are great for playing music at your desk (albeit with not much bass), they're sufficiently loud, they look good and they don't require a big power brick as they are powered via USB port.

I do have one small complaint. Actually it's not a complaint but a "I feel so stupid" moment. For the life of me I couldn't figure out why I was getting now sound from the speakers. I mean how hard can it be to hook up speakers. I though maybe the USB port wasn't powering the speakers. So I tried on another computer, same thing. I looked for a power button, or volume knob on the speakers to no avail.

After nearly giving up and returning the speakers, I realized that there is a power, and volume knob. Look at the photo of the speaker. The top is completely flat. The volume knob is actually on top of the speakers flat/flush. The knob is not labeled and because it's so flat against the surface I never noticed it. I know I sound like and idiot but you'll see what I mean when you buy them. So once I figured out where the power and volume know was, I actually liked them more, it keeps the speakers looking sexy. No unsightly knobs poking out of the front.

theproduct: Dell AX210 USB ç«‹é«”è²æšè²å™¨ç³»çµ± (W955K), é»‘è‰²
comment:
I ordered these Dell AX210 as well as Logitech S150 speakers for Dell desktop Vostro 260S computers in our offices. We listen to news radio and/or music depending on the time of day. We also use Skype for video calls. At the price one can't go far wrong but a comparison seemed fun. Here's what I found:

- The Dell AX210 speakers are, well, tinny. They get the message across and spoken words are not lost. News radio is OK but music lacks tone. For music, there's almost no bass, midrange is muddy and treble is shrill. The good news, however, is that the volume can be set in a seemingly infinite range between 0 and, well, whatever they will handle. This may be because there is a 3.5mm green sound card connector in addition to the USB connector.

- The Logitech S150 speakers sound much better, full stop. They are more dynamic, warmer, better balanced and much more clear, pleasant and musical. But they are difficult to modulate just off silent, no matter what settings we try (speaker buttons, control panel sound controls, keyboard controls, web volume controls, etc.). So sometimes they get turned off because the lowest setting is still too much. Perhaps this is because they have a USB connection only.

They're all fine for the price! Next time out I will spend a few more dollars for better quality sound out of speakers that also can be controlled easily.

comment:
I am very pleased with this set of

I am very pleased with this set of Dell speakers. I have had a set of my own for over a year. The sound is loud and clear. No need to turn the volume up on either your computer or the speakers. I have not had any problem what so ever with this set of Dell speakers. I have used these speakers with an old Acer Laptop, a Dell Laptop and presently with a five month new HP Laptop. These speakers are made for USB 3.0 but work well on USB 2.0 ports. These speakers are well built. I have not had any type of wiring problem. I have had other speakers that had problems with internal wire connections. The set I recently puchased is for a friend. THe Description on AMazon is not accuract. The size and weight are incorrct.

theproduct: Dell AX210 USB ç«‹é«”è²æšè²å™¨ç³»çµ± (W955K), é»‘è‰²
comment: Needed a set of speakers to use with a laptop, was not looking for anything super high end but better than what was built-in. These are good quality speakers and good value for the money. They do require you plug in the audio out and also the USB to power the speakers. This is a positive in that from what I have had in the past it is easier to carry around and more functional (not tied to where you can plug speakers into the wall) than a traditional wall powered speaker. A fully USB speaker set would have been a step up from these but for the price and quality of speakers I think this was a reasonable compromise. These are not really intended to be highly portable speakers so having the extra cord is not really a major concern in my opinion.

theproduct: Dell AX210 USB ç«‹é«”è²æšè²å™¨ç³»çµ± (W955K), é»‘è‰²
comment: These work great and are a great value. It's a good sound quality for computer speakers, especially for the price. My monitors did not come with speakers built in so these are replacing the awful speaker that is built into the computer. My only complaint is that I have spread them as far apart as the cords will allow to provide separation of the left and right channel and the cords actually spring them back to the center because they are so light weight. There is no rubber on the bottom so they slip very easily on the smooth desk top and the cords are folded over each other into a Z shape instead of rolled so they get dragged back to where they are plugged into the computer until there is no spring left in the cord. I'm amazed how springy they are.

comment: These are "good" speakers but not great. They function as should and produce the necessary sound for video playback. Love the fact that they automatically wake up when the computer does. comment:
These speakers are from a trusted brand and met my needs for a usb powered speaker. My wife used these when she needed more sound while watching movies on her laptop and she was on a treadmill. It allowed her to hear and I also have used this when I take my lcd projector and need louder sound.

It is not extremely loud, but meets the needs for a medium sized room.

First time operators should know that the volume control is on top of one of the speakers and if you do not turn it on and up, you will not get sound. It is hard to see, if you are not aware of it.

comment: I noticed several reviews complaining about static interference and 'poor product'. Obviously if you are paying less than $25 then don't expect Rolls Royce speaker performance. These speakers worked very well, the sound is perfectly adequate, there is no background noise interference other than my pet Cocker Spaniel who happily joins in with the music if allowed! Volume whilst not boom box level is perfectly acceptable and manageable. Overall, worth the price paid.

I shorted out one of the speakers, my own fault, so I can only hear from one of the speakers, and guess what? I STILL have / love the stereo sound!

In addition to wishing this same quality came in a wireless form, I also wish that the speakers were more laptop-friendly in that whenever I carry my laptop, I have to juggle the two, beautifully-designed speakers in transit, which is why one of them shorted out ~ I'd inevitably drop one. If only there was a mounting attachment / clip to keep these beauties safe and still stylish ...

theproduct: Dell AX210 USB ç«‹é«”è²æšè²å™¨ç³»çµ± (W955K), é»‘è‰²
comment: It worked fine, once I found the secret control. There is a little disc on top of one of the speakers that functions as an on/off switch and volume control, but it is neatly recessed, everything (including the two tiny dots) is black and there is NOTHING obvious to lead one to find it. I spent three frustrating days wondering why my system had no sound before I finally examined these in detail and found the switch. Cool design can be nice, but there is nothing particularly cool about the design of these speakers in general -- and they will mostly sit at the back of a desk, as they do on mine -- so why not put a simple and obvious volume switch on the front of one or even underneath? These designers flunk

comment:
Good desktop pc speakers. They dont have the depth that their higher end counterparts have for music, but they are stylish, play loudly, and are acceptable for an office setting, or home setting where you aren't specifically using them for music.

The fact that they are powered by USB is great, one less power adapter to worry about, however, you do need to plug it directly into a 3.5 mm audio jack (it has a separate built in cord).

It has a large on/off volume dial on the top of the left and speaker which clicks off when rotated coubter clockwise. The dial moves smoothly and has a "quality" feel to it.

For the price, I certainly can not complain.. They definatley do the job.

I needed a speaker for my computer as well as my new Toshiba Thrive. I saw that this said it was USB connected so I didn't think it work with my Toshiba but then it came with a usb plug in as well as a 3.5 mm so it works on both my Thrive and computer. Once my wife figured out that the control is on the top the sound was great for movies, music from Spotify. It plays a nice balance for the music. The price is great at under $15.00. I tried Logitechs and the AYL speaker. The AYL wasn't much louder than my Thrive's speakers.
